"Methinks my love and I didst espy yon Waffles Cafe, and thus didst we decide to partake of their victuals. I knew full well, from perusing the reviews, that we should expect naught but paper plates and plastic cutlery. 

The fare didst take its sweet time in arriving, and we were forced to fetch our own coffee and water. I didst order the chocolate waffle, with strawberries and banana slices upon it, yet alas, 'twas but a mediocre repast. The plastic knife didst make short work of cutting my waffle, but verily, the flavor of chocolate was nowhere to be found within the batter. My love didst order a breakfast combo, consisting of a waffle with peanut butter and chocolate sauce, accompanied by eggs and bacon. Alas, the bacon didst taste as though it had been cooked in used oil from the Chinese establishment next door, a most disgusting prospect. His waffle was passable, but the eggs didst not meet with his approval. 

But lo, the most foul aspect of our meal didst come when my love didst attempt to season his food with salt and pepper. He didst pick up the shakers, and they didst stick to his fingers, covered in syrup and other unsavory substances. 

We didst discard the punch card given to us, and shall henceforth make our waffles at home, where the fare is fresher, and the utensils are cleaner."
"Flies swarmed the joint. Otherwise, not bad. Good spot, decent digs, friendly staff. But them flies, man. They ruined the whole damn experience. Hoping they sort that out next time I'm in."

"Love turned sour at Parlor last year. Recent visit proved it. Lunch with the missus, empty joint, hostess ignored us five minutes. Serverless, we waited ten. Eye contact, friendly waves, nothing. Left without a fuss. Love lost."

"Twenty-five for a shot, twenty-two for a drink. Seventy for a sandwich and pot roast. Silly wait, plenty of open tables. Fried pickles, too salty. Chipotle chicken, decent. Fries, obscenely salty. Chix quesadilla, good but small. Margarita, pricey."

"Been a TP fan since opening day. But last visit, they told me they needed a credit card up front for lunch. Don't sit right with me. Few skips out on the bill, ain't no reason to treat all customers like crooks. Other joints around here don't pull this crap. Good lookin' waitresses and grub ain't worth it. Won't be back."
"Valentine's Day special sounded good, but it was a joke.  Food was poor quality, overpriced.  Used to be good here, but not recently.  Not worth it."

"Went to Zizzi's with a mate. Two-for-one deal brought us in. Place was packed with office drones. Took a while to snag a table. Joint was clean, but had a grimy feel. Like a Mickey D's. Food was meh. Had a pizza, fresh outta the oven, but coulda been a Tesco's Finest. Friend had seafood pasta, but it was light on the seafood. Service was adequate, not too friendly or speedy. Won't be back."
"The hotel's size didn't match its quality. Big, but lacking. Service, too. Not worth more than three stars. For a real treat, hit up Mirage's buffet. Now that's a smart spend."
"Atmosphere, cool. Soup, cold and bland. Meatballs, dried out, flavorless. Another try, upstairs opens. For now, pass."

"Alas, my friends, the rice didst lack moisture,
The service, slow, and at best, a trifle.
The price, oh how it didst climb to great heights,
For sushi, far better, Albertsons doth provide,
And at a cost, a fraction of the sum,
I pray thee, let us not return anon."

"Sin City's got nothin' but frustration and a whole lotta shit. Don't waste your hard-earned cash here, pal. People got their heads up their own asses, can't even help a fella out with a simple question. Elevators take forever, packed tighter than a whore's schedule. Skinny bitches give you the side-eye, shovin' their bony asses against you like they own the place. 

But hey, the tiki bar wasn't half bad. Met a wild bunch, Americans and Brits alike, even a Castro lookalike. Most of 'em didn't know squat about Cinco de Mayo. So, in honor of the English bloke, we raised a glass to ol' Sanchez - Dirty Sanchez, that is. 

That's worth a second star, if you ask me."
"Lunch at Yuzu. Had the special. Native to the cuisine, their menu's a bunch of small plates. Not impressed. Pricey too. Mother's a better cook. Not for the authentic Japanese food crowd."

"No good. Had a decent cut here once, but that was it. Went back today, thinking they'd be open. Called at 3:45, guy said I had till 5. Got there at 4:10, he tells me they're closed. I remind him I'm the one who called, he just shrugs and points to the clock. Not worth the risk. Sketchy place in mid-city gives better cuts, better service, and cheaper too."

"We gave 'em two stars 'cause they called us later and tried to make things right. Went in to work with John Cowan, guy lied from the get-go. Two hours later, we got a better deal on what we wanted. My wife felt uncomfortable, told him so, and he blew his top, yelling at her real loud. I reckon don't work with him; he was rude, made us feel stupid, and kept telling us about his sales experience every five minutes. We don't give a damn. Anyways, the manager called later, gave us an even better deal - free oil changes for the lease period. That's why I gave 'em three stars instead of one. We're first-time buyers, maybe that's why he tried to take advantage."

"Hark! If thou hast ne'er beheld a male revue,
Thou mayst suppose this show to be quite fine.
But fear not, for I shall tell thee true,
'Tis naught but amateurish and slovenly, I do declare.

The men, though buff and brawny of physique,
Have faces that are far from fair and unique.
And as for dancing, they possess not the skill,
Their movements dull and uninspired, I do tell.

Much of the show is empty, void of delight,
One lone dancer roams the crowd, while others sit tight.
Lazy and lacking in entertainment, 'tis a shame,
For such a show, the price of admission is not worth the claim.

I have beheld the Chippendales, my friends,
And this show pales in comparison, to its end.
Not worth the twenty dollars, let alone the thirty-six,
Avoid this male revue, my advice, do take and fix."

"World Market, boo! Went in search of the Hobbit line, for my boy's New Year's taste buds. Asked the shelf-stocking gent, hopeful. He checked, friendly. But alas, not in stock, or so he said. Phoenix stores, a no-go, he claimed. But lo, online says Camelback's got it. Damn, missed out. Lame."

"Fair warning, good sir or madam, avoid the taco salad at all costs! 'Tis a dish of excess, with far too much guacamole and sour cream, making it quite vapid. Verily, a mess it doth make. The service, however, is friendly and the atmosphere of this quaint neighborhood establishment is most pleasing, yet alas, the victuals do leave much to be desired."

"Room 514. Sleep-number bed busted. Felt like a hammock by the time I finally dozed off. Liked the room's layout though - headboard against the bathroom wall, curved desk/dresser setup was different. But they didn't restock the place well after the first night. No fresh coffee supplies or clean glasses and mugs. Asked for no feather pillows at check-in, but they gave me floppy ones instead. Like, the kind you gotta wad up into a ball. And get this - no taxis. Ever. Had to call one for me. Waited 15 minutes. Not terrible, but not great either."

"Enchiladas, adobada meat. Nastiest I ever had. Waiter, friendly. Husband, me, arrived. Refill, waited. Never came. Upset, didn't enjoy. Horrible dinner. Arribas, no idea. Mexican food, not sold. Nasty."

"Alas, my friends, I pray thee heed my words,
For in this city of excess, there be those who hold
The virtue of punctuality in low esteem.
We booked a shuttle, thinking to save a few coins,
But lo, the driver didst dawdle, and we didst wait
In vain, for half an hour, our patience didst wear thin.
And when at last the coach didst arrive, 'twas full,
And we, poor travelers, didst sit and stew,
Until at last, the driver didst deign to take us,
To our lodging, The Venetian, with all due haste.
But fear not, dear reader, for this tale doth end
In wisdom gained, and a lesson well learned.
For though we saved a few pieces of silver,
'Twas at the cost of much vexation and strife.
So heed my counsel, and spare thyself the woe,
For in this town of chance and lavish display,
'Tis better to pay a little more, and be sure,
Than risk the whims of those who hold not time dear."

"Beware: Gut-busting joint. Proceed cautiously. 

Never would've tried this place without the rave reviews (and its proximity to work). Turns out, it's exactly what I expected. Lunch truck grub in a strip mall setting. 

Fry bread on the BBQ beef sandwich? Thicker, staler version of Taco Bell's chalupa tortilla. Meat tasted like pre-made grocery store BBQ. 

Inside? Strip mall chic. Disorganized kitchen, disheveled staff (but friendly). 

Dessert fry bread? Same tough, stiff texture drowned in powdered sugar. 

Wouldn't go back. Wouldn't recommend."

"Fie upon this wretched service, foul and slow! 

We came at noon, a Thursday, and found but two tables seated nigh. Our busser brought waters and iced tea with haste, yet our server didst tarry, ten minutes passed ere he took our order in hand. 

A Greek salad came forthwith, fair and fresh, but lo, the other twain didst receive their pies ere we had finished our repast. And thus we waited, twenty minutes more, forsooth, ere our server didst return with news of woe. A computer malfunction, he didst say, and our pies would come anon, within ten minutes' space. 

Alas, the pizza was good, a saving grace, yet shall I ne'er return, such service doth disgrace this place."

"I wasn't feelin' the buffet vibe at the Excalibur, so I kept walkin' till I found a coffee joint in Luxor. I wanted somethin' cooked fresh, not just warmed up. My grub came quick, but it was clear most of it had been sittin' around. Eggs were runny, corned beef hash was dry, potatoes were meh, and the toast was cold. Orange juice was decent, decaf was alright. Service was good, chairs were comfy, but not great for eatin'. Overall, not worth the extra five bucks and tip for the same quality as the buffet."

"Verily, I say unto thee, good sir, this place doth leave much to be desired. The service, in sooth, doth border on the unacceptable, and the environs, alack, doth bear a certain... shall we say, 'grittiness'? Nay, verily, I wouldst not wager a single farthing upon the tables of this establishment, lest thou desirest to part with thy hard-earned coin in haste."

"Tonight, we ordered delivery from this joint. Took 'em over 90 minutes, and the grub wasn't even hot. Rice was meh, and they forgot the egg rolls. Service? Zero stars. Food? Hard to say, really. Didn't seem like what we ordered off the online menu. Maybe they were havin' a bad night, but we won't be tryin' again anytime soon."

"Tried three times on weekends, never in top shape. Maybe puked in the parking lot once. Sorry. But on a sunny Thursday morning, got in no problem. 
Usually, the fuss is outside. Shade now, Jane L. Makes sense, summer's over. Duh. Screaming tots, go go. Tiny place. Why bring spawn here? IHOP has balloon animals. Anchor-shaped balloon matching your tattoo-inspired tee? 
Choices are slim, portions large, grease abundant. Like grease, but like it dripping from my burrito at 4 am. Feels dirty. Had oats, surprisingly grease-free. Partner had cheese omelette. Ordered home fries, rosemary's been complained about. Mine had rosemary, looked accidental. Bland, boring. Entire experience, bland and boring. Don't see the fuss. Good, yes, but breakfast...how hard can it be?"

"Sat down quick, ordered fast. Asked for #90, got #19. Waited, waited, server never came back. Dealt with it, ate my food. Sister pointed out roach next to my feet. She tried to tell someone, they hesitated, so she got up, killed it herself. Finally got the check, paid, left. Food's good, but service and atmosphere make it hard to want to return. Two stars for the cooks."
"I arrived, waited ten minutes. Grabbed a menu, asked an employee if I should seat myself. He said sure thing, then kept walking."

"Hark! The staff, though pleasant and courteous, doth strain beneath the weight of their tasks, so pray not for hasty service, lest thou wisheth to tarry long. 

And though the line to order doth move with speed, alas! The wait for thy repast doth lag, and sorely doth it vex. 

Furthermore, the victuals, though humble, doth fall short of the mark, and leave thee feeling cheated of thy hard-earned coin. Forsooth! Eight dollars for a dish of tacos doth seem a steep price to pay, when a similar sum at yonder McDonald's doth bring thee a feast most bountiful. 

And, alack! The drinks, oversweet and lacking in zest, doth fail to impress, leaving thee in a sour mood, and in disfavor of this place. 

In brief, if thou dost value local commerce, and art willing to pay a premium for mediocrity, then mayhap this establishment shall suit thy needs. But, woe betide thee, traveler, shouldst thou seek a meal of true worth and quality!"

"I've sent many a friend and colleague to this joint. Twice a week, I'd grab takeout from here myself. Sure, they might be a bit slow sometimes, but the grub's always been fresh and delicious. That is, until today. Ordered the 2 roll lunch special and a dynamite roll. Started chowing down on that dynamite roll, when suddenly - BAM! - a sharp piece of wire in one of the pieces. Cut my tongue and jabbed a hole in my gums. Not going back. One thing to have an off night with the food, but safety issues? No excuse."

"Las Vegas, where gourmet buffets reign supreme. Latest contender? The Bayside Buffet at Mandalay Bay. Problem is, it's showing its age. Food's not bad, service is decent, but the hotel's high-end vibe sets expectations the buffet can't meet. Time for a revamp, or tables will stay empty."

The restaurant's got a real friendly vibe, and I dig the unique Ome-like design. But let me tell you, the grub and joe ain't worth a damn. And if you hit up the drive-thru, you're in for a long wait. They might even tell you to pull up and chill while they bring your food out. Just not impressed with the mediocrity.

"Amusement park's got great rides, but you'll spend most of your day waitin' in line, sweatin' in the sun. We took our three kids and they got crankier by the minute. Flash passes might cut the line, but they ain't worth it. Teaches the wrong lessons to young ones."

"Brunch at this joint on Homecoming weekend? Big mistake. Service was slow, real slow. Took 'em over an hour to bring out two breakfast plates. Didn't even bother with drinks, but folks seemed to enjoy 'em. Ordered huevos rancheros with chorizo, thought it was a safe bet. But no, they still managed to screw it up. Eggs were too salty, presentation was meh. Won't be comin' back."

"We hit up The Spot for lunch, and it was just alright. Kinda like a short-order joint. 

Had the Spot sandwich - plain chicken, nothing special - and a chicken salad. Best part was the tiny apple cinnamon bread slice that came with it. Other than that, it was just a basic salad with some turkey, ham, and walnuts. 

Seating was uncomfy, and they got like two tables inside downstairs and one upstairs. Not great for summer in AZ. Ended up outside. Misters helped a bit, but still disappointing they don't have more indoor seats. 

Dessert case looked decent, but not worth coming back for. Doubt we'll be back."

"Three seventy-nine for the small blizzard? Damn! I chuckled when I grabbed it through the drive-thru. Haven't had one in a spell, I reckon. Won't be gettin' another anytime soon, that's for sure. (Probably a good thing, too.)"

"Stopped by on a whim, nearby. Underwhelmed by the grub. Joint's got a lively vibe, though - almost too much. Fish tank was a highlight, I'll give 'em that. Smallish portions, skimpy on noodles. Broccoli was plentiful, Thai BBQ chicken alright. Garlic chicken, who knows? Maybe our waiter goofed the order. Deep-fried bird with sweet chili sauce, whatever they called it. Service dragged, too. Twenty minutes for hot water and lemon? Meh, underwhelmed."

We hit up the Frank Caliendo show, it was top-notch. Got there early with the missus and another couple, hoping to snag some prime seats. But no dice, the joint wanted us to shell out sixty bucks per couple in booze or beer just to sit up front. That's a whole lotta drinkin', and it ain't exactly the most responsible thing to do. Kinda disappointed in The Improve for that one. Our seats were alright, but had a partial view, so think we'll give The Improve a pass next time.

"Tropicana Cinemas, $1.50 a pop. You get what you pay for, friend. Five screens, small lobby, old-time arcade games. Gets packed, especially before showtime. Inside, the cheap seats bring in the riffraff. Texting, squabbling with security, screaming kids in R-rated flicks, folks who can't keep their butts in their seats. I'd shell out the big bucks at other joints for comfier chairs and fewer morons."

"Hark! A tale of woe doth come from me,
Concerning conference rooms, so stuffy and humid,
In temp'ral control, a sorry state, it be.
And coffee, oh, how vile and poor the brew,
A travesty, indeed, for one to endure.
Nor can I speak of rooms, forsooth,
For none have I beheld, save those for meetings,
So dank and close, they did my spirits dampen.
Alas, a sorry lot, this conference place,
Yet still, I pray, our gatherings may find grace."

I’d been on the move all damn day, and now all I wanted was some grub from Paymon’s. So I give ‘em a ring, ready to place my order. But nope, they got some dumb rule about not takin’ carryout orders past nine o’clock. What a buncha hooey.

"Restaurant had been praised, so I took three guests for dinner. Food was mediocre - 22 oz rib eye steak, 50% fat and bones, undercooked. Scallops, just okay. Fries and veggies, barely warm. Waitress, very good. Compensated a bit for the food."

"Been here a few times. Good stuff: strong drinks, hot cheese curds, cheese soup + tomato soup = delicious. Bad: slow service, second order of cheese curds, different cheese, cold. New management, wonder what'll change."

"I tried this joint for the first time, excited to see what it had to offer. The grub was top-notch, but the service was a mess. Hostess kept seating folks at dirty tables, and the servers were clueless about which orders went to which tables. Took 'em 30 minutes to bring us our breakfast. If they got their act together, it could be a decent spot. But with so many other places in town serving up good food and friendly service, I won't be back."

"Last time we stayed here, three years back, it was great. Not this time though. Our room key didn't work, had to get it replaced twice. Housekeeping didn't close the door properly when we left for breakfast. Unacceptable. We were woken up every night by loud talkers in the hall, 2-6 a.m. The lady across the hall wasn't pleased either, so she opened her door and told them to quiet down. One night, someone tried forcing their way into our room with a card key. My husband had to yell at them to stop. Won't be coming back to this hotel."

"Puke. Chicken Korma, rubber ducky puka. Gravy, not cream or cashew based sauce. Thick, disgusting. Asked for all white meat, waitress acted like it was a problem. Chicken undercooked, tasted old. Chicken tikka masala, tomato sauce gone bad. Rice, dry. Naan, burnt. Place, Bates Motel grimy. Service, slow. Water, fishy. No one there on a Friday night, creepy. Yuck. Would not return. Too pricy for poor quality, service."
"High hopes for this park, read rave reviews on Yelp.  Ended up a letdown, trash and broken glass everywhere.  Graffiti too.  More worried about cutting my foot than a snake surprising me."

"Papa John's, usually top-notch service. Not this time. Order botched, delivery gal tossed grub at us, then split. Called 'em up, rude chick on phone. Put me on hold, came back, said she couldn't do squat. Manager same, clueless. Maybe send the driver back? Apologize? Nada. Hope they shape up. Pizza's good, vegan too. Don't wanna stop ordering."

"Yi's got some issues. Used to like the place, but now? No way. Brought in a bathing suit, brand spankin' new, for tailoring. Gift, mind you. Eight hundred bucks. Tags still on, just some loose threads. Go back today, tags are gone. Explain to the guy, woman behind the counter speaks better English, two tags, barcode and thread holder. He blames me, says I musta taken 'em off. Ridiculous. Was gonna sell it on eBay, never touched those tags. Won't be goin' back. Business elsewhere. Two stars 'cause the tailorin' was good. Losin' my tags and blamin' me? Unacceptable."

"I was eager for a tranquil facial and massage. The folks at the desk were friendly, as were the massage and facial pros. The massage and facial were unremarkable...
If asked during a massage if there's an area you'd like to focus on, don't say a specific area. I've done it before without issue, but this therapist took it as a cue to rush through the rest of the body. She gave me a quick neck and shoulder massage and then abruptly ended it. No gentle transition, just sudden completion. 
The facial was similar. The therapist was young, energetic, and chatty. She worked quickly, using short, rapid strokes instead of slower, deeper ones that would have made it more relaxing. It felt like she was trying to jolt me awake instead of promoting serenity. 
As a first-time customer, I received a discounted rate, but I wouldn't pay full price for a massage here. These people are novices. If you want to avoid these two women, message me, and I'll share their names with you."
"Good grub, damn fine rice. Shame we both got sick as dogs when we got back. Pepto B did the trick."

"Coffee here used to be top-notch. Imported and roasted their own beans, I reckon. Now it's some outfit from Ithaca, New York. Just okay, if you ask me. And don't even get me started on the price. Pecan pie, tiny as can be, cost me six bucks. Menu said it should've been cheaper. I complained, but the barista didn't give a damn."

"Salesmen here? Rude. My boyfriend and I came in, needing a car ASAP. Luke, the guy I'd been talking to, ditched us for another appointment. We got some other dude, and he was a jerk from the start. Made us feel unwelcome. Uncomfortable. Like they didn't care about our business. Lost sale. Lost customers. Work on your people skills, fellas."

"Four times have I graced this establishment with my presence, and alas, 'tis a tale of woe that doth unfold. O'erpriced fare, such as chicken wings and strong drink, doth pierce mine purse, and the rabble that doth frequent this place doth offend mine eyes and ears. Alas, I do beseech thee, good sirs, to ponder thy prices and the quality of thine atmosphere, lest thou lose a loyal patron such as myself."

"A plan most base, to please the masses, didst seem, 
The proprietor's aim, a venture of no great esteem. 
This place, a Chili's sports-bar, in truth didst be, 
But grown, alas, to encompass all, most unfortunately. 
Decor annoying, staff, and crowd, a woeful sight, 
With football games, on every TV, a blight. 
A poor excuse, to delay the poker game, they didst make, 
And wouldst not use a screen, to show the stats, forsooth! 
Whistle! Penalty! Lame, indeed!"

"Alas, I sought to be impressed, but nay, 'twas not the case. As a vegan, I do actively seek out eateries that cater to my dietary needs. And so, with time to spare, I ventured to Red Velvet Cafe, highly praised indeed. But lo, my expectations were not met. A mishmash of vegan, vegetarian, and non-vegan dishes didst greet mine eyes, a noble effort to serve all, but alas, a lackluster display. Innovation in vegan cuisine there was none, a mere swap of meat for vegan substitute, how dull! I ordered flatbread with pesto and hummus, vegan-style, but nay, the cheese, a vegan substitute, had no flavor, a shame indeed. Pesto, a sauce that should dance upon the tongue, didst taste like it came from a jar, and the hummus, oh so bland, seemed processed, not homemade. A scoop of each, placed upon the flatbread, presented not a feast for the eyes, but a sorry sight indeed. The beverage, a sparkling tea, saved the day, tasty indeed, but at $5.50 a glass, with no refills, a steep price to pay. Alas, my dear vegan restaurant in Las Vegas, thou art still my heart's desire."

"I checked in Tuesday for three nights. They upgraded me to a seventh-floor suite, but it was sweltering hot. Took forever to cool the place down. That night, some idiot started beeping a bulldozer at 4 AM. Couldn't sleep, so I hit the gym. What a joke. I asked for an upgrade and a high floor beforehand, but they ignored me. Moved my stuff to the fifteenth floor Wednesday afternoon. No more construction noise. Management, are you paying attention? This is how you treat your Premier Platinum Elite members? Disappointing."

"Hark, since Sunday have I been confined,
In this conference hall, with facilities fine.
Beds, alas, not as soft as they should be,
A maid service, poor, that doth not impress me.
Hyatt, thou dost try to save a few coins,
By leaving soap and such unfilled, I suppose.
Beds, a mess, with sheets that do not fit,
And staff, fair, but not up to my wit.
Forbes training, they must have forgot,
Or management, lacking in its thought.
Bar service, better, yet not divine,
But still, this place doth not meet mine eye.
Expensive, 'tis, and not worth the fee,
For a vacation, destination, 'tis not thee."

"Place is mediocre, at best. Used to be a favorite, but it's gone downhill. Could take it or leave it. Hubby always gets a half rack of ribs. Skimpy portion, maybe 5 fries. Portion sizes and quality have declined. Inconsistent, nothing great."

"Friends recommended Serendipity 3, so I checked it out with a buddy. Shared the Frozen Hot Chocolate. Not bad, but not great either. A bit watery, but still had that rich chocolate flavor. Honestly, I've had better at Starbucks or Coffee Bean. Friendly staff and cozy atmosphere, but that's about it. Meh, not the best, but not the worst either."
"Dead spot, through and through. One girl behind the counter, decent, attentive. Another, stuffing donuts, looked like she'd been beaten with a sprinkle stick, couldn't care less."

"Time to bring down the old castle, start fresh. Rotting from the inside out, faded plasma screens, stained carpets, questionable buffet, and strange live entertainment. Cheap, but worth every penny. Plan on spending time away from the room, that's the only way it works."

"Friendly staff, but that's where the positives end. Bland waffle, mediocre fried chicken. They lost my card, too. Cashier found it with a bunch of others in the register. Unprofessional. Roscoe's should step in and clean up this mess."

"This joint? Nah, not my scene. Themed restaurants, lame. Sure, got some lookers workin' here, but nothin' worth losin' sleep over. Next thing you know, it'll be some cheesy comic book bar. Or worse. Local celebs? They're just full of hot air."
"No-frills joint. Confusing entrance. No casino. Small deluxe suite. Tiny pool area. But close to Aria and Cosmo. Not worth another visit."

"Caesars, where I slept, ate, danced, played. Managers helped the feds search a guest's room. Unconstitutional. Shadowy lens, my experience now. http://www.nytimes.com/2014/11/01/opinion/deceptions-of-the-fbi.html"

"Hark! My hunger raged like tempest on the sea,
And thus I summoned forth three rolls to be,
To sate my craving and fill my belly full.
But lo! When I didst arrive at home,
These rolls were small, as if they were but crumbs.
Aye, 'twas a sorry sight, and one that didst vex me sore.
For thirty-five good silver pieces, I didst receive
A puny appetizer, scarce enough to fill
The void within my stomach. Never have I seen
Rolls made so small, as if they were but jests.
And so, I called upon the pizza man,
To bring a pie to my chamber door,
That I might dine upon it, and thus appease
My hunger's raging fire. For sushi, I do adore."

"Methinks I hold this eating house in some regard, for soul food doth run deep within my kin, come holiday or high day. But alas, the victuals served here leave a foul taste in mine mouth. Trowel, there be potential, yet the whole shebang doth seem unprofessional, rough as a cobblestone. 

Verily, I have partaken of their fare full oft. 

Once, at an outdoor fete, Big Mama's House of Soul did sell their grub. I stood in line nigh forty minutes, only to be told they had depleted their stores. Alack, such amateurishness! 

Furthermore, I do detest that they do not peddle single ribs. 

Thus, hit or miss, Soul Food in Pittsburgh doth remain."

"Hark! What laughter doth mine ears perceive?
'Tis Planet Hollywood, a place most queer,
Where once Aladdin's magic did reside,
But now, 'tis transformed, and in its stead,
A mishmash of East and West doth abide.

The Spice Market still doth serve its fare,
And Pink's Hot Dogs, a culinary snare,
The Miracle Mile, a shopping haven, doth gleam,
But all, alas! doth seem a bit extreme.

EXTRA, a lounge of note, doth also shine,
Yet, all this glamour doth not quite combine,
To make a place that doth truly impress,
For though it tries, it doth not quite progress.

I've heard tales of toilet trips most dire,
From those who dared to eat a Pink's hot fire,
And other eats, o'erpriced and o'erhyped,
Do make me hesitate, and my purse to grip.

But, truth be told, I do have a desire,
To see Peepshow, a spectacle of fire,
Yet, Planet Hollywood, a fan I am not,
For though 'tis gay, 'tis not my plot."

"I was stoked for this show. Took my pops, who saw Nat King Cole at the Sands in '62, and watched Dean and Sammy shoot craps in the casino. Opted for GA seats, which sucked. No tables or servers? Lame. Shoulda given everyone a table, dressed the servers in 60s gear, and immersed us in the era. As it was, it was hard to buy into the Rat Pack vibe. Dean and Frank were solid, Sammy was alright, but Joey? Not even close. Looked nothing like the real deal. Maybe folks don't remember or never knew, but it was a bum cast. The Rio's gotta take some heat for the show's mediocrity too. If we were sippin' martinis in a booth instead of crammed in with strangers, maybe we'd have enjoyed it more."

"Rude dude at the to-go counter. Asked if the party was mine, like it was a problem. Confirmed twice, still gave me attitude. Gave me my total, then asked if I had cash. Like, what's that supposed to mean? Guy had a serious chip on his shoulder. Lucky for him, the boba was good. Might not be back, though. Volcano Tea's got friendlier folk."

"Music good, crowd bad. Eleven o'clock, club dead. Free drinks and short line, shoulda been great, right? Wrong. Me and the girls hit the dancefloor first. Haters gave us dirty looks. Stupid sunglasses in a dark club. Not my scene. Pure better."

"Place was mediocre. Service, just okay. Food? Meh. Price? Ridiculous. Won't last long. Started with a Smithwicks, but they were out. Good thing, too. Didn't want to pay six bucks for a beer. Honey mustard wings were just okay. Blue cheese dressing was decent, though. Hangover burger? Nothing special. Better burgers at Denny's. All in all, a disappointment. Don't think it'll get a second chance."

"Fare decent, yet methinks for such a price,
Exceptional cuisine should be the entree of choice.
Scallops, a tasty treat, did please my palate well,
But alas, the steak, a sorry tale to tell.
Medium rare, I did request, a tender delight,
Yet what they brought, a shoe leather plight.
Dry and tough, it was a chore to chew,
Akin to dining on a piece of old shoe.
The wedge salad, a common sight,
No better than a chain restaurant's plight.
My cup, they filled to the brim with drink,
A solitary bright spot in this culinary sink.
In Vegas, there are better steakhouses, I say,
For this one, I shall not return, come what may."
"Food was edible, that's why I gave it two stars. Not great, not terrible. Customer service good, but that don't make up for the grub."

"Standard bar chow. Don't bother unless you're hankerin' for some greasy fried or grilled fare. And maybe a cold one if you're a cheesehead. Cozy joint, but nothing out of the ordinary. Just your typical suburban watering hole with smaller portions."

We hit up the karaoke joint in the lounge, just past the 21 tables and across from the bar. Sundays through Wednesdays, 8 pm sharp. Decent-sized seating area in front of the stage, but the piped-in music overhead kinda competes with the singers. Not my cup of tea, since you gotta pick your songs from a binder and write 'em down for the karaoke guy. Some folks take the binder to their table like it's their own personal playbook. And the lyric screen? Tiny, right in front of you. Place is a real smokehouse, too. Couldn't believe people were actually staying there, but one thing I liked was the speaker blasting the singers out onto the sidewalk.

"Pricey, but not worth the wait. Don't be fooled by the line outside. It's just the beginning. Once you buy your ticket, you're in for a long haul. No restrooms or snacks upstairs. You've been warned. We spent three hours on a Sunday afternoon for a 15-second ride. Feels like Six Flags all over again. And the photos they take? Not exactly flattering. They'll pressure you to buy 'em."

"Hark, a tiki culture devotee I be,
And thus, my heart did sing with glee,
When in this place I chanced to spy,
A bar that looked, to mine own eye,
Like some tiki haven of delight.

I strode forthwith, to the bar,
And asked the keep, with hope afire,
For my dear drink, the painkiller rare,
But alas, the man didst not know its name.
I requested then, a menu of drinks,
But none was forthcoming, to my blinks.

'We're but a dive bar, good sir,' quoth he,
In answer to my query, strange and free.
So here, within this tiki den,
They serve but beer, and naught else, by pen.
Odd, indeed, yet still, I do declare,
This place, a gem, in its own right, doth bear."

"We stumbled upon Cucina de Vita while shopping in Downtown Mesa. The outdoor seating caught our eye, and the staff was friendly. I ordered the Meatball Parm sub, my husband got the Sausage and Peppers sub. The food came quick. First off, the pasta salad side was room temp. Same with the marinara sauce. My husband's sub was good, he enjoyed it. Mine, on the other hand, was inedible. The sauce was too bitter, overpowering the herbs. The meatballs, though, were damn good. If they sort out their food temps and marinara, this place could be great."

"Verily, the customer service I did receive,
Was of the worst sort, a woeful sight indeed.
Dairy Queen, a place I do detest,
Now shall be my solace, my heart doth seethe.
A mood spoiler, alack, how vexing so!
Yet still, to Dairy Queen, I shall go."

"They got beer, that's one good thing. But man, they charge too much and the hours are all over the place. No phone number either, so you gotta just show up and hope they're open. And forget about any kinda customer service or beer knowledge. If you're willin' to pay a premium and know your stuff, then maybe give 'em a shot. Otherwise, stick with the hot dogs."

"A humble abode, with outdoor space vast,
They serve teriyaki chicken, lacking sauce, quite tasteless,
And chicken fried rice, devoid of zest,
The service swift, the staff, most courteous,
But alas, the site, a haven for woe,
Drunks and vagrants, a sorrowful show,
Best to take away, and not dine in,
For the fare, mediocre, at best, within.
I doubt my return, for the cuisine,
Leaves much to be desired, I do confess,
Yet, the crab puffs, a delight, I must confess."

"First-time diner here. Food? Bland. Uninspired. Drinks? Tasty, though. Server? Meh. Manager? Top-notch. Asked how everything was, listened when I said it was just okay. Even took the fish tacos off the bill. Accidental overcharge? Manager sorted it out, no fuss. Despite mediocre grub, might give 'em another shot. Thanks, boss."
"First customers of the day, my boy and me. Floors filthy, yogurt caked under tables. Cleanliness counts in a joint serving grub. Yogurt's alright, but won't be back."

"Service was decent. But they got Pepsi instead of Coke, that's a bummer. Salsa was alright, chips were stale though. Place had a nice vibe, patio was cool. Food was mediocre, overpriced. Beef taco with rice and beans cost $11, steak fajitas $17. Don't think I'll be back."

"My kid, she's a natural in the kitchen. Loves cooking, and she's damn good at it too. So, we saw this flyer, did some research, thought it'd be perfect for her. They got this'senior chefs' class for teens with experience, but it was a letdown. Too much repetition, not enough real cooking. Kids should be doing more, not just reheating pre-made stuff. Facility and staff were cool, but not for my kid. She needs something meatier."

"Went there for lunch on Friday, craving their famous honey hot wings. Service was good, but the wings were a letdown. They were tiny, half the size they usually are. Told the manager, she said they were working with the supplier. That was it. No compensation, no discount. Unacceptable."

"Urban Outfitters - a scenester's haven, filled with all the'sorta 80' attire one could desire. But let's be real, their prices are steep, like five times the value. They got a small men's section, just like all the other stores. And don't even get me started on the Scottsdale Waterfront location – it's a total waste. If you gotta choose, stick with the Mills Ave spot."

"Delux's Delux Burger, voted "Best Burger" by Phoenix Magazine, fell short of its title. The beef patty was overcooked, the baguette soggy. Organic rocket, caramelized onions, applewood-smoked bacon, and blue and gruyere cheeses failed to deliver much flavor. Caramelized onions provided the only notable taste. 

The roasted beet salad was also a disappointment. Overdressed and soggy, the beets' texture was all but lost. Blue cheese and balsamic vinaigrette overpowered any potential sweetness and earthiness. 

Despite this, Delux has a few redeeming qualities: a trendy atmosphere, an impressive drink selection, and a refreshingly cold glass of water."

Others raved of grand service, but our night told another tale. Two hours and forty-five minutes for a romantic feast, and not a moment too soon. Seated swiftly, yet the waiter vanished, leaving us to wonder if he'd forgotten us. He returned, of course, with apologies, and we settled in for a decent meal. Crab cakes arrived, mushy and lackluster, saved only by a squeeze of lemon. Calamari followed, the breading crunchy but overpowering the delicate seafood. Same went for the tartar sauce - far too much, drowning the flavors. A ribeye for sixty bucks? No contest against the likes of Capital Grille or even Durants. We left unsatisfied, the manager apologetic but unable to rectify the issues. Our bill took ten minutes to arrive, by which time the restaurant had emptied. Not a chance we'll be back.

"I stopped in here twice over two years. Coffee's good, but the vibe's off-putting. Four young bucks loiterin' behind the counter. Not a smile or hello on either visit. Too many better joints around (Hava Java, for one) to waste time and cash on snooty service."

"Methinks the women who tidied my abode didst perform their duties with some degree of proficiency and were quite agreeable in their demeanor. Alas, they failed to arrive betwixt the appointed hours of eight and eight thirty, and didst not trouble themselves to convey unto me any warning of their tardiness. My attempts to communicate with Planet Hugger by means of the telephone didst prove futile, as they didst persist in directing all calls to a voice messaging device. (Verily, I have endeavored to converse with a living soul by this method on numerous occasions, yet have ne'er succeeded.) A missive dispatched via electronic mail, inquiring as to the estimated time of their arrival, didst remain unanswered. Consequently, I was compelled to tarry and await their entrance, thereby disrupting my carefully planned schedule. Forsooth, this lack of punctuality doth render their services less than ideal for an individual such as myself, who must needs adhere to a strict routine."

"Hark! What 'tis this place? A tavern, by my troth!
And one that doth not take reservations, by the way.
Forsooth, we came in droves, and had to wait,
Until the whole group gathered, ere we could partake.

But fear not, friends! For those who did arrive,
Didst find solace in the bar, where drinks did flow, and thrive.
The bartender, a merry soul, didst serve with glee,
And made our wait, a pleasant one, for thee.

Now, mark this well! This place doth cater to the young,
And asks, if thou dost need, a high chair or booster throng.
Aye, 'tis a haven for the families, and that's no wrong,
But for us singles, a bit of a bore, I must confess.

But lo! The rolls! Oh, how divine! A carb-filled delight,
That made my taste buds sing, and my belly take flight.
Alas, they kept bringing more, and my resolve didst weaken,
And I didst eat too many, to my own chagrin.

We all didst order steak, the special of the day,
But mine was cooked too long, and the sides didst fade away.
Our server, in a jest, didst say she hated her work,
And that, my friends, didst make my evening, quite a quirk.

So, to this place, I shall not return,
Unless, perchance, I must, and then, I'll dine on cocktails and rolls, my dear.
Take thy children here, and I shall dine elsewhere,
For this tavern, doth seem, a place most fitting, for families to share."

"Love the grub, but the service? Not so much. Come here regular, but the service is hit or miss. Owners, you listening? Step it up, boys. Want to keep us coming back? Read the reviews, make a change."

"Went to Cowboy Ciao with a buddy from out of town. His wife had been raving about the chopped salad for years, so we gave it a shot. The waiter warned us it wasn't meant as a meal, but my friend insisted. The salad arrived, small and unimpressive. My friend left hungry. 

I had the $30 sliced steak special, served on a bed of corn and beans with a honey-like sauce. It tasted good, but familiar. I'd had the same meal before, at Chipotle, sans the rice. 

The food was good, the service excellent, but the price point was too high for what we got."

"Hark! A tale of woe doth unfold, my friends,
Of a parking lot, with puddles deep and wide,
And drivers who doth help with bags, so bright,
Their promptness doth make the journey light.

But lo! A sign doth appear, so bold,
Increasing rates, a tale to be told,
$6.45 per day, through holidays, so cold,
A sneaky move, their customers to hold.

And sales tax too, doth they impose,
Whilst airport lots, do none propose,
A difference great, and cause for woe,
I shall not return, so let it be known."
"Charged us to get in, they did. Me and the friend, at one am on a Saturday night. Their website said local ladies were free, but they didn't understand that part. We went elsewhere."

"Ross. Never found anything worth a damn there. Greeted by a rent-a-cop, always. Feel like a criminal, pushing a shopping cart with a pole up my ass. Racks are empty, clothes are polyester crap. Need to wash everything before I wear it. Sometimes find something decent in the home goods or toys. But mostly, it's a waste of time. Prefer Target, TJ Maxx, or H&M if I'm feeling fancy."

"Wild Wings, a joint with a name that promises much but delivers little. If you're lookin' for a place to grab a cold one and some decent wings, this might do the trick. But don't expect nothin' special. Their wings are just your run-of-the-mill size, and the selection of sauces is good but not great. The hottest one's got a nice kick, but it ain't gonna blow your mind. And let's not forget the other places in town that do the same thing better - Hazelwoods, Native New Yorker, Zipps, and Tweakwoods. They might not have the same name recognition, but they'll give you a better bang for your buck."

"Room stank. Door let in daylight. Curtains did a better job. Breakfast? Forget it. Fruit, that's all. Bed, though - soft as a cloud. Maybe I was delirious from lack of sleep, but it felt like heaven."
"Pricey. Pork's a bit dry. Specials ain't worth it. Tea's decent, though. For real BBQ, head to Hap's on Washington and 52nd. It's next to Samurai Sam's."

"My friend and I checked out Cuban Pete's, heard they had some decent grub. Menu said they got cigars, cannoli too. Sounded good, so we gave it a shot. But man, those cannoli were a disappointment. Stale shells, store-bought whipped cream, no candied orange peels nowhere. Total bust. Might give 'em another chance though, heard their Cuban sandwich is solid. But no way I'm orderin' them cigars."

"Been here a few times before, always good. Not this visit. Took damn near two hours for our table of seven. Worst experience in a while. Food was meh, used to be better. Sam, you slackin', bro? You got too many places open, forgettin' what made you great. Get back to basics, man. Greene House need a reset."

"Staff's competent, but their script-writing practices stink. They insist on brand names when generics would do. Won't even note my preference on the chart, unlike other offices. Don't give a damn about coupons or prices. Activations are a real hassle."
"Food arrived slow, tasting from a can. Decor's colorful, prices low. That's all."
"Airport grub, but still. Fries, cold as ice. Tomato slices, just tossed on top. Cheesesteak, subpar. Fast food joints do better."
"Service was poor, food a letdown. Bathrooms? Cleaner at Mickey D's. I kid you not, one sink lacked handles. Real classy joint."
"Hot dog, not my thing. Sauerkraut, sure. Husband, different story. Fried, bacon, his style. Fries, decent. Chili cheese, too. Soda, one. Thirty bucks, steep. Not worth it."

"This joint reminds me of the Black Hoof in Toronto, all about that in-your-face meat vibe. People chow down on bone marrow starters before diving into pig's head for the main event. You gotta be hungry, and ready for a cholesterol bomb. I tried to order light, but that didn't exactly work out. The "salad" was more like a soupy mess of pan-seared veal, potatoes, and watercress, topped with an egg. Not exactly what I'd call a salad. It was heavy, real heavy. Give 'em credit for creativity, but I couldn't finish it. The desserts were alright, but nothing special. If you're lookin' for a meat fest, this is your spot. If you're lookin' for somethin' light, keep lookin'."
"Adult playground. Jumbo Jenga, cornhole, beer pong, beanbags, board games. Skipped the grub. Spotless can and pleasant aroma. Lousy barkeeps, though. Rude and only catered to young ladies."

"Blandest club sandwich I've had the misfortune of eatin'. Cold cuts, shredded lettuce, and microscopic bits of bacon. Waiter looked like he hadn't showered in a week. Made me question the kitchen's hygiene. Next time, Fox Sports Grill it is."

"A cup they gave me, pour my own coffee thence,
From decanters, lever-pumped, a cheesy sight,
Not fresh, alas! And for a coffee, two fifty paid,
A price too steep, methinks, for such a paltry brew.

The 'Bold Ethiopian Night', a misnomer, indeed,
Watery, lacking depth, a disappointment, pure and simple.
A shame, forsooth, I had hoped to find delight,
In this place, but alas, 'twas not to be, by day or night."

"Patio's nice, fans are swell. That's where the positives end. Overpriced, average grub, noisy, layout's a mess. Servers and customers everywhere, getting to the john's a challenge. Forgot to charge us for an entree, then remembered after we closed out the bill. We didn't even notice, the bill was already steep. Skip this joint, plenty of better options in the area."

"Friday's, been better elsewhere. Food, same old, same old. Service? Piss poor. Five tables, three servers. Do the math. Family dinner, cousin's 21st, wanted to make it special. Asked waiter in advance, bring out birthday dessert. Three times, no dice. Brother gets brownie, no candles. Where's the birthday dessert? Server, clueless. Thought it was for him. Cigarette lighter, pretend to blow out the light. Horrible."

"Verily, I say unto thee, fair reader, that this review doth not bode well for yonder establishment. Forsooth, the victuals didst taste most wondrous, a true delight for mine own palate. Howbeit, alack! The service, 'twas a sorry sight to behold. A pox upon their house, for they didst sit us at a table foul and unclean, and didst promise to send a servant to tidy it forthwith. Five minutes passed, and nary a soul didst come to purge the filth. Another five minutes, and still naught but empty words didst fill the air. My friends' draughts didst arrive, but lo! They didst tarry ten long minutes ere they didst reach our parched lips. A plague upon their slowness, say I! Our salads didst come, and we didst devour them with haste, yet still we waited, and waited, and waited, ere anyone didst deign to notice our plight. Fifteen minutes, by the clock, didst tick away ere we couldst catch a server's eye and cry, 'Ho, good sir! What wilt thou do to end this woeful wait?' And lo, they didst offer us the salads gratis, as token of their sorrow for the poor service. Yet, alas! Two shoddy visits doth make me wary of returning to that place. Farewell, dear reader, and may thy own experience be more pleasant than mine."

"Underwhelming experience with too much repetition."
I walked into the establishment, eager to try their supposedly innovative concept. The interface appeared straightforward, but technical issues quickly marred my enthusiasm. The computer froze multiple times during photo uploads, leaving me frustrated and staff unresponsive. It seemed like they were more interested in their own conversations than assisting customers. After struggling to complete our transaction, we finally gave up and left. As I departed, I couldn't help but notice the irony of covering up Microsoft logos with stickers. It was a fitting metaphor for the disappointing experience we had just endured.

"Went for restaurant week. Brie for starters, not impressed. Dry apples, no brulee in sight. Escargot was decent, filet mignon was tiny. Disappointed. Sea bass was flavorful but small, pasta was good. Hazelnut tarte was boring. Called ahead, they said I wouldn't leave hungry. Wrong. Service was slow, had to ask for refills. Sad waste of a pick. Won't be back."

"Buffet on the Strip? No way. Not worth it. But hey, if you got free vouchers, go wild. Standard fare, mostly bad. But hey, gyros ain't half bad. Salads too. Dessert? Instant pudding, or gelato as they call it. Not terrible. Raw bar's popular. Haven't heard of no salmonella outbreak. Complementary bubbly? Bottoms up!"

"The O.D. was decent. Dr. Potter was friendly, double-checked my prescription. Rest of the appointment, typical clinic stuff: long wait, crowded, poor customer service. Waited 20 min past appt time, then had to wait again at the desk. Other guy was just trying on frames, I just needed the Rx. Had to wait another 15-20 min to check out and get my prescription. Ridiculous."

"Buncha pharmacy pals took me to this joint. Heard it was top-notch. But jeez, it was pricey. Ninety bucks a pop, my man. Food? Meh. Fancy stuff, sure. Wild boar, truffle potatoes. But taste-wise? Nah. Not impressed. Too high-end for my blood."
"Cute joint. Service, meh. Fruity drink, good. Chili cheese dog, disappointing. Hard bun. Friend's burger, mediocre. Pricey."

"We ate at this joint 'cause the family reunion planner picked it. Typical upscale American grub. Underseasoned for my taste, which leans towards Indian, Chinese, Thai, and Middle Eastern. 

Had the baby back ribs. Good quality meat, but the sauce needed some serious heat. Drowned it in Tobasco, but it only helped a bit. 

Broccoli was plain, like most American restaurants overcook their veggies. 

Wife said her BBQ salmon was mediocre, two stars tops. 

American food's all about salt, fat, and sugar, that's what I reckon."

"Raved-about green chili mac & cheese. Must-have, right? Wrong. Chewy, improperly peeled chilies. Grainy, gritty cheese. Yuck. Mac & cheese should be smooth, cheesy. Not this. Pulled pork sandwich, decent. Hot BBQ, good. Honey Bears, my first choice for BBQ. Andrew's, a last resort."

"Methinks we didst order twain bowls, one Mochiko, another Srirachi. Verily, we didst enjoy them, children finishing theirs with great haste. Alas, a quibble doth arise, forsooth, in that they didst employ frozen vegetables. A pox upon such usage! Two stars, I say, for this most grievous fault. Yet, in sooth, the victuals themselves were quite delectable."

"A Groupon didst we purchase for this place,
And thus, we didst decide to give 'twas a try.
The victuals, alack, were but of middling grace,
And thus, the name of Lagasse doth bring dismay.

A frozen patty, flat and burnt, the burger didst seem,
And thus, we didst not finish it, nor didst we deem
It fit for consumption. But, the drinks, I pray,
Were priced most reasonably, and thus, we didst say,

'We shall not return, forsooth, to this place again.'"

"We visited this joint once, and that was enough. Service was slow and unfriendly. Our waitress took her time filling our water glasses and barely checked in on us. Food was mediocre. I had the house salad and pork tenderloin, which was too salty. My buddy had the Caesar salad and fettuccine alfredo, which he enjoyed. They have a decent selection of beers and wines by the glass. The decor is nice, like a Cheesecake Factory or PF Chang's. The place is big, so you probably won't have to wait long for a table. They use Open Table for reservations, which is convenient."

"Six of us hit the joint for happy hour last night. But they got this tiny bar area, only a few tables and a small bar. Place was packed, Thursday at 5:15. Rest of the joint, empty. Asked if we could score happy hour prices on the patio. Manager said no way. We bailed and found a better spot down the street. Other couples did the same. Note to Eddies: expand the bar, allow happy hour on the patio, or lose business to the competition."

"Food's alright, but service is subpar. Called to order their Sunday special, but it was a dragged-out ordeal. Didn't dig the lack of hospitality. Pizza was just okay. Ate there once before, same crummy service. Not my cup of tea."

"Went to Town Center, used gift card. Got garlic parm chicken pizza, spinach artichoke dip, white pita bread. Bill was 27 bucks. Told me food'd be ready at 5. Got there at 5:10, parked in wrong lot. Pizza was in oven, ready. Couldn't believe it, expected bigger. Guy brought spinach dip, put both in bag, said I had to wait on bread. Waited ten minutes, bread finally came. Pizza was nothing special, just okay. Spinach dip was excellent, pita was good too. Didn't like the price, expected more for $27. Ate quick, still a little hungry."

My wife and I chowed down at the Wynn for lunch, after scoping out some glowing reviews. We're no strangers to Vegas buffets, so I was taken aback by the subpar grub. Service was top-notch, but the food? Not so much. We'll be back at the resort, but we'll steer clear of the lunch spread.

"Airports, I tell ya, they ain't all created equal. This one, in particular, it's a real stinker. Always crowded, full of hipsters nursing hangovers. Food's terrible too. Feels like purgatory, it does. Best to avoid it, if you can."

"Marry, how strange it seems that Bell Cleaners doth thrive,
Despite the recession's harsh and bitter sting.
Their pickup and drop-off service, they do proclaim,
But 'twas naught but woeful incompetence did bring.

I waited patiently, in darkness deep,
While the lone attendant searched, her mind did sleep.
She found my shirts and khakis at last, with nary a word,
And demanded payment, her hand outstretched, like a bird.

The price for khakis, two pairs, did seem quite steep,
I questioned the cost, and her response did creep.
She looked down, muttering, her words unclear,
And held out her hand, as if to say, "Fear not, dear."

Eleven shirts, a fair price, yet not so low,
That I would stay, and nowhere else would go.
If thou hast wealth, and time to spare,
Then by all means, indulge in their finery fair."

"Methinks 'tis overpriced, my dear friend. Our victuals were of fair quality, and the service, most courteous, I must confess. But, alack! The cost didst give me pause, forsooth. A princely sum, indeed, for but a few pancakes. My humble purse, now retired, doth protest at such an extravagance."

"A pox upon this burger joint, I say!
The patty, flavorless as a piece of hay,
And greasy, too, like a dirty pond.
I chose the Arizona, hoping for some spice,
But alas, the toppings were but a faint delight.
The staff, they doth not seem to enjoy their work,
And the decor, akin to a carwash, doth not quench my thirst.
For the price they charge, I'd rather take my coin
To In-n-out, where a better burger doth await,
Or Four Peaks, where a truly noble feast doth lie.
Away with this place, and its mediocrity!"

"Food's good if you like it hot and spicy. Had a shrimp appetizer, goat meat, and jerk chicken. Sides were decent too. Place could use a cleaning, though. Atmosphere's nothing special either. They got a thing about tips, bunch of signs asking for 'em. Looks kinda like a fast food joint. Got a $29 bill, saw they tacked on a $7 tip. Service was good, but didn't wanna risk askin' 'em to take it off. Plenty other places around here that are cleaner and better. Gave it a shot, but doubt we'll be back."

"Methought I'd book a breakfast for a wedding feast,
And thrice didst attempt to call this place of rest.
A manager, they said, would call me back anon,
But nary a word didst I hear from them, alack!
A fair sized group it would have been, I do confess,
And worth their while, methinks, to make some fuss.
But now, I fear, I shall not dine with them,
For poor service doth leave a bitter taste within."

"Start with the food. Good, like Chris Bianco's rep. Antipasto plate, though, was meager and plain. Not like the dozen times I had it at his joint downtown. We also got the Rosa pizza, one of his signatures, with cheese, onion, and Arizona pistachios. Damn good. Thought wine would go nice. But no liquor license yet. So, two hits and a miss. 

But the real reason for two stars: 

Ordered antipasto, asked the blonde waitress for bread. She said they didn't have any. What the hell? No bread on Saturdays, huh? I suggested they toss some dough in the oven, make some bread. She said they couldn't. Huh? Our resourceful waiter brought us some bread anyway. She just stared at it, confused, and walked off. Word to Chris: Fire her ass."

"Fair yogurt and toppings, four stars, I say,
But management, alas, a single star doth sway.
Not customer-friendly, they doth seem,
For we were charged, in sooth, a king's ransom, 'twain.
Two small cups, a fortnight past, did cost,
Six dollars, nay, a princely sum, at the most.
But lo, the scale, it doth not always reset,
And thus, we paid, in gold, a prince's debt.
The cashier, kind soul, didst say, with cheer,
'Twas but a mistake, and thus, we need not fear.
But then, the manager, with frowning brow,
Didst dispute our claim, with words of woe.
She would not listen, nor our proof accept,
And thus, we left, with naught but disrespect.
A gift card, token of their good intent,
Didst they offer, but with grief and discontent.
We've been there since, with caution, we do pay,
Lest we be cheated, come what may."

"Hype, all of it. Overpriced and lacking substance, just like most African American-owned restaurants. Fried okra, flavorful but undercooked, leaving it greasy. Fries, horrible - soggy and greasy. Fish, chewy, like jerky. Seafood Gumbo, good, but where's the seafood? Give customers what they pay for. Trying Mamas Boy Cafe next. Native Las Vegan seeking consistent southern cuisine."

"Twas my birthday, and to toast they did take me,
But alas, 'twas a woeful sight to see,
For our waiter, a grump he did make,
And spilled our ale upon my gown, so fair and bright.

I knew not what to do, in such a plight,
But up I rose, and with napkins, did clean the sight,
And dined upon them, with sorrow and despair,
For my birthday feast, was naught but woe and care.

My sweetheart's tofu, a block of sorrow,
In broth it swam, with naught but flavorless morrow,
And my burger, oh how tasteless it was,
A lentil paste, 'twixt buns, alack, what a pass!

We left, in haste, with spirits low,
For the service, poor, and food, a woeful show,
And thus, my birthday night, was ruined quite,
By this cursed place, with naught but bitter fight."

"This place, alas, doth bring forth mixed results,
Like chances taken, some do win, some lose their wits.
I, myself, didst venture there twice,
And found, the first time, a fair cut, quite nice.
The woman, cool and collected, didst tend
My locks with care, and left them neat and trim.
But, alack! The second time, oh woe is me!
The haircutter, a forgery, no doubt, didst see
My hair, and with great haste, didst split it down
The middle, ere I couldst speak a single sound.
She cut, with reckless hand, each lock the same,
Leaving me withal, a most unflattering frame.
A blunt, crude cut, that doth mock my face,
A haircut, foul and terrible, in its place.

And, lo! I have beheld, with mine own eyes,
That selfsame haircutter, with her scissors, rise
To botch a poor lad's crew cut, oh so sad!
A sight most gruesome, making me quite mad.
How couldst she, with such skill, yet lack finesse?
A stylist, nay, a butcher, in truth, doth she profess."

"Paradise Buffet at the Flamingo Casino? More like purgatory. Hard to find, hard to get to, and the grub's not worth the trouble. Limited selection, mediocre food. Shrimp cocktail and crab legs, but don't expect 'em to be cracked open like at the Aria. Sushi's dry and been sittin' out too long. Other than that, it's your standard home cookin'. Pot roast, mac and cheese, Caesar salad, boneless chicken. Feels like a fancy Old Country Buffet, but at least there, you ain't payin' twenty bucks. Check in on Foursquare, save a few bucks? Nah, just put that five bucks in the slot machine instead. Verdict: skip this joint, go see the flamingos outside."

"Grub's alright, but service is rotten at St Rose/Eastern. They don't give a damn 'bout what you want. We asked 'em to fix it, but they told us we shoulda said somethin' when we ordered. Which we did. But hell, it ain't worth the trouble. Go someplace else."

"Been here twice. First time, breakfast was top-notch. Second time, lunch was a disaster. Ordered burgers, got 'em wrong. Waiter didn't give a damn. Took forever to get it right, and even then, it was still messed up. Burgers were dry, like they'd been sitting out too long. No apology, no discount. Won't be back."
"We shoulda grabbed some cans and drank 'em on the train. That dive was packed with losers, dimly lit, and the kinda place you wanna leave pronto. But we didn't, and now I'm regrettin' it."

"Busy joint on a Sat night, prob'ly due to the ASU game. They've changed things up since I was last here four months back. Now they got these 'name cards' where you write your name and hand 'em to the cooks. Don't mind it too much, got my grub faster that way. Was lookin' forward to makin' my shrimp bowl till I saw the sign sayin' they're goin' through a shrimp shortage. Can't even sample the sauces no more. That was another thing I liked about this place. Damn shame. Felt a bit rushed too, got the bill less than ten minutes after I got my food. Not as pleased this time, but I'll give 'em another shot. Hopin' they'll have shrimp next time."

"Tonkotsu ramen, that's what I was after. Out of state, had to find it. Yelp led me here. Gonna give 'em a fair shot. Here's my take: Tonkotsu, but not quite. Broth lacked depth, too much salt. Pork, where was it? Charsui needed more time in the pot. Mushrooms, veggies, aromatics could help. Finishing sauce, a nice touch. Potential's there. Hope they step it up."

"Food overpriced, cooking sloppy. Wine unimpressive, two Pinot Noirs by glass, not worth it. Bread basket, dry. Dior sign an eyesore, ruining ambiance. Not worth the wait or the money. Waitress nice, but can't make up for poor quality. Special ordered veggie primavera, but pasta stuck together and too salty."

"Ate here last night. Food's no good. They're short-staffed. Sonoma's like the others in the group - Nola, Seviche. Goin' back for drinks though. Wine list's extensive, but the grub's poor. Get a glass of wine and eat somewhere else."
"Food, mediocre. Wait, absurd. Cilantro, everywhere. Noise, deafening. Cabo, not feeling it."
"Booooo! Nice owner sold her restaurant, a real gem. New management, higher prices, no more lunch buffet. Not worth the time or dough."

"Hark! We ventured forth to dine at yonder tavern,
Whose proximity to our humble abode did make it most convenient.
Their ale selection, quite impressive, did our hopes raise,
With bottles diverse and choice, beyond the commonplace.
I sipped a Three Philosophers, my spouse a cider, fair,
And thus began our evening, with promise in the air.

But alas! The service, slow it was, and tardy too,
Ten minutes passed ere our drink order they didst pursue.
The crowd, not overwhelming, yet our waiter, sloth-like,
Didst make us wait, and suffer many an anxious pike.
Our victuals, middling, frozen veggies, a shame,
I asked for salad, and waited, till my meal didst claim.

Thus, two stars, for now, our rating doth confer,
Yet shall we grant them further chance, to redeem and serve.
Until that day, our judgment doth stand,
Awaiting change, and betterment in hand."

"Good customer service, that's for sure. But the water? Terrible. Ruined my tea. Had to switch to cola to mask the taste. Food was just okay. Seafood, not great. Hushpuppies were good, onion rings, not so much. Salad bar, limited. Fresh, but like something out of a middle school cafeteria. Shame, really. Felt like I was back home, though."

"Pulled pork, alas, didst not impress me much,
For 'twas cold when served, and thus lacked luster.
Fried okra, on the other hand, didst delight,
Piping hot and crispy, a true gastronomic pleasure.
Vinegar sauce, a tangy treat, didst please my taste,
And Bud, the bartender, was most cordial and kind,
A friendly soul, who didst make my visit quite nice."

"Wine and cocktail list, good but pricey for the meal. I got Nordic shrimp in a tomato sauce, but they didn't say they were whole (head and tail). Real hard to eat, served hot. Quail dish was good, but small for the price. After a $80 bill with three glasses of wine, we had to go elsewhere to fill our bellies. In short, worth it for a drink, not for dinner."

"Methought this place would be most fair,
After a search on Google, I didst declare,
The best chimichanga in all of Phoenix,
But alas, 'twas not so, I do confess.

I ordered carne asada, full of hope,
But the spices, they didst not doth cope,
No cumin couldst I taste, nor any zest,
And the meat, it was bland, I do protest.

The rice, it looked fine, but the taste,
Was burnt, as if the broth didst haste,
And the beans, they were smothered in cheese,
But the flavor, it didst not please.

A couple of bright spots, there were,
The salsa, both hot and mild, didst stir,
The waiter, friendly and outgoing,
And the atmosphere, old school, it was going.

But alas, the food, it didst not impress,
So I cannot recommend, I must confess,
Tee Pee, it may be a place to drink,
But for food, I wouldst not think."
"Drive-thru line took twenty minutes, no apology. Got my son's drink mixed up too. Would've gone inside if we didn't have the baby with us."

"Alas, my friends, I must confess,
A grave mistake I made, and great was my distress.
For in a place that's not a sushi den,
I ordered sushi, and oh, what a sin!

The rolls were fair, but oh, the rice was hard,
And I, a fool, did not finish the dish, lest I be scarred.
The pot stickers too, did not delight,
For Lean Cuisine's are better, in truth and in sight.

And last, the brownie, a disappointment, alack,
A mediocre treat, that left me in dismay and discontent.
But mayhap, had I chosen another dish,
My experience might have been more pleasant, and less fishy."

"I dropped thirteen bucks on a piddly shrimp cocktail. Drinks at the lounge were pricey, bartender had a snotty attitude. Decor was straight outta the seventies, not my cup of tea. Don't get the fuss."

"Fast-casual joints that serve up healthy grub without breaking the bank? Count me in. No time to cook, no cash to burn. This spot's got it right - fish, cooked to order, with your pick of seasoning or sauce, plus a side. Soups, sandwiches, salads, tacos, too. And, kid-friendly? Check. They've got options for the little ones. 

But, let's get real. Fishy smell wafting my way? Not exactly fresh. Edible, sure, but not the best. Mango salsa saved the day, though. Orange roughy, $12, not bad. Brown rice, solid. Fish, could be better. Can't expect top-notch seafood at these prices. Go to Bartolotta or high-end Strip spots for that. 

Kid's chicken tenders, $5, seemed house-made. Good effort. But, too bland, even for my kid. 

Great concept. Questionable execution."

"Walk into Frankie's Tiki Room, and you'll feel like you're going blind. It's dimly lit, and it takes a good 10 minutes for your eyes to adjust. But that's part of the charm, right? Maybe it's so you don't freak out when you see what you're sitting in. 

The drinks come with skull ratings, from candy to sanitizer. When the bartender says, "Start with a five skull or I'll just order for you," it's a little unnerving. But Katrina M. ordered me the green gasser, and it was potent. The pour was generous, to say the least. At first, it was undrinkable, but it got better as the ice melted. 

The service is slow, though. My friends had to wait a while every time they went up, even when it was starting to clear out. It made hanging out feel like someone was always being left out."

"Methinks 'twas strange to find a dive bar serving Chinese fare,
But lo, my friend and I didst venture there,
En route to airport, we didst stop and share
A meal, the NFC championship game didst play.

Our order, chicken and veggies on brown rice,
Didst scarce receive a nod of approval, alack,
For though 'twas quick, the taste didst not entice,
Frozen, it didst seem, like microwaved dinner, quoth my mate.

Alas, our hopes were dashed, the food didst lack,
Deserving but two stars, a sorry state, indeed.
Yet still, methinks, perchance another dish may please,
And thus, a second chance, this place doth merit, ere we flee."

"Been to this Bashas' a few times. Twice we swore never to return. First time, manager talked trash 'bout an employee, right in front of us, whole time we checked out. Rude. Second time, two employees went on 'bout their sex lives while checkin' us out. Unprofessional, if ya ask me. Prices ain't competitive. Liked the Bashas' in North Phoenix, though. Worth the extra few bucks. This one? Nah. Prefer Fresh and Easy, right across the street."

"Plenty of rave reviews, time to see if they're legit. Oregon boy here, know my Asian food, especially pho. Got the 'pho-nomenal' bowl, disappointing. Asked for chili oil, they said siracha's enough. Really? Shrimp rolls were meh too. Price is on par with other pho joints, but quality's lacking. Give it three months, see if things improve. Two stars for decent customer service, that's it."

"Dark, divey joint. Torn upholstery, pool tables looked decent. Good crowd at the bar, family at a table. Not the best spot for a family lunch, but not inappropriate either. Friend had the bacon burger, I had the grilled chicken. Sweet potato waffle fries were a surprise, but crispy and tasty. Burger was forgettable, bacon was overcooked and hard. Chicken sandwich was well-cooked, but the grill flavor was overpowering. Needed some sauce. Enjoyed the Asian slaw. Left Hand Lager was decent. Prices were steep for the atmosphere, though. $36 for lunch, $6 for a Guinness. Monday's $1.50 PBRs, but it wasn't Monday and I don't like PBR. Service was friendly but inattentive. Empty glasses and slow billing. Not worth it."

I swung by this McDonald's joint for breakfast this mornin', Robyn N. taggin' along. Place was dead, but still took forever to get our grub. Menu's not exactly rocket science, but I guess that's what happens when you've got more staff than customers. Bathroom's a joke, too. No paper towels, just them silly blowers mounted way down low. Door opens inwards, so you gotta be a contortionist to get outta there with clean hands. My Sausage McMuffin tasted like it'd been sittin' around for a while, too. Not exactly the best start to the day.

"Hark, what news is this? A tale of woe and discontent,
Of bagels, once so savory, now a bitter jest.
A morning visit, with hopes of speedy service,
Didst turn to naught but sorrow and great unrest.

One soul ahead of me, a line of singular length,
Didst seem a fortuitous sign, a swift dispatch.
But lo, the gods didst play a cruel trick,
As minutes stretched to twenty, and my patience didst shrink.

The employees, with tardy steps and careless hands,
Didst take their time, as orders didst confusion demands.
A mess, a fiasco, a sorry state of affairs,
Didst leave me in a sour mood, with naught but despair."

"I was at the Encore, workin' a function. Company splits us up, sends us to different fancy restaurants. Now, I ain't no fan of seafood, Italian grub ain't my jam either. So, when I find out I'm eatin' here, I'm a bit let down. Decided to suck it up, not complain, enjoy the ride. We're in a private room, eatin' family style. Gotta say, underwhelmin' experience. Food looks like somethin' my folks would make at home, service is slow. Gotsta flag down the server a few times for a drink. Like someone told 'em not to give me booze. (Prolly my bosses, they know me too well.)"
"Biscuits? Don't see the fuss. Been here a few times, grub's alright, prices too. But underwhelmed, that's me."
"Burgers? Just OK. Shakes? Horrible. Three times we gave 'em a shot. Three times we regretted it. Cheap prices mean cheap quality."

"El Salvadoran grub ain't my cup of tea. Maybe it was the cardboard and plastic models I mistook for my meal. Either way, it was a bland mess. Even the hot sauce couldn't save it. I had the appetizer platter, chicken with rice, and a side salad that was nothing more than a pile of lettuce. Not impressed. But those pupusas, now they were something else. Crazy good. Worth going back for."
"Been here a few times, parkings a bitch, grub's alright but nothing special. Lot's of flash, not much substance. Baja sauce is good, but it'll make you sick later. Need to learn from this."

In sooth, my aged dame and I didst stay
At yonder four-star hotel, 'twas a sight to see
SLS, a name most foul, doth dwell
In North Side's midst, a place of woe and despair

The sign, a wretched thing, doth seem
As if Affliction's garb didst spew forth a dream
I dwelt within the Story Tower's walls
A tiny room, with space for naught but crawling

The bed, a modest thing, didst sit
In midst of room, with sink behind, a witty wit
The shower and the privy, on either side
With doors that slide, and heads that collide

No bag of plastic didst they provide
A closet, ha! 'Twas but a rack, with drawers two
And worst of all, no ice machine didst abide
On floors, so ordered ice, with tip, thou must decide

The carpet, rough and worn, didst feel
The mirror on the ceiling, cool, yet soon didst grow old
Bed lights, a trifle bright, didst seem
Design, a trashy thing, a foul demeanor didst take

Yet service, kind and fair, didst reign
Save front desk, with faces stern and cold as stone
And tables, sturdy, didst provide a place to dine
In conclusion, SLS, a hotel most dire, doth lie.

"Clean joint, but not authentic Mex. They make their burritos funny, and when I told 'em how I wanted it, they said no way. Didn't even want it after that. Told me Pico de Gallo's gross in a burrito. Had to let 'em know who's boss. Hard to hear 'em when orderin', too. Meat's got no real Mex spices. Done with this place."
"Underwhelming experience. Went with sis, shared veggie and shrimp tempura rolls, edamame. Didn't enjoy any of it. Good service, but that's about it."

"Hark! I came hither with two friends, 'twas six forty,
Happy Hour ended at seven, our server didst tarry.
He arrived at our table, two minutes past the hour,
And brought us naught but woe, with his tardy power.

We ordered victuals and drink, but alas!
Our waters came not till seventeen fifteen,
So we sat, parched and dry, for half an hour or more,
In this empty hall, on a Thursday, a sorry score.

A friend enquired of the Garden Burger, a vegan delight,
But lo! The waiter said, 'twas not quite right.
For Chipotle Ranch they do add, and eggs to bind,
Making it not vegan, a culinary find.

Their fare is passable, at best, I do confess,
But service, oh! It left much to be desired, alas!"

"Methinks 'tis a curious thing, this place doth hold,
A fee so small, yet the worth, I do behold.
But alas, my dear, my experience hath been woe,
For though the cost be low, the quality doth go.

We didst sign up for ballet, mother and child,
And at first, 'twas grand, a joy to behold.
But lo, the subsequent classes didst falter,
The instructors late, or cancel without a thought.

The class, designed for young ones, aged one and two,
Didst suffer from poor teaching, I do declare to thee.
The other mothers, cold and unfriendly, didst shun,
Save one, whose child didst play with mine, in fun.

In conclusion, fair reader, I say to thee,
This place, though cheap, doth not meet expectations, by and by.
Perhaps, a different class, or waiting for a change,
Mayhap, a better instructor, shall bring a brighter range."
"Food lacked zest. Well-cooked, ample portions, yet devoid of taste."
"Mall's enormous, still pretty empty since it's new. Stores are pricey, unsure what to get. Lots of eateries, tons of light. Worth a visit, but doubt I'll return."

"Moved back to the Burgh after three years in Cali. Kept track of the place, wanted to check it out. Nice changes inside. Sat at the bar, near the service area, not the best spot. Good local draft selection though. Ordered mussels and fish 'n chips. Mussels were decent, sauce was great, but should've been hotter. Fish 'n chips were a letdown. Fries were soggy, fish was undercooked, batter was bland. Only thing that saved it was the mushy peas. Might go back for those and a dark 'n stormy. Bartender was attentive, that's a plus."
"This joint's got some steep prices, friend. The grub's not too great either, especially that Malaysian chicken curry. I won't be comin' back here again."

"This joint was pretty meh. Salsa was forgettable, what a damn shame. Got a burrito that was just alright, spinach wasn't fresh, but at least it was drowned in cheese. Not worth coming back for, there's better Mexican places around."

"Methinks the other reviewers didst not taste,
As I have these past four weeks, the brew,
That doth pour forth from Oakland's cup.
Their regular coffee, lattes, iced, alas,
Are nigh undrinkable, and thus my quest,
To find the fault, doth begin. Mayhap,
The coffee sat too long, ere it was served,
And thus, the flavor doth suffer, o'er-brewed.
A Starbucks fan, I am, yet this doth pale,
In comparison, to that noble brew.
But fear not, dear friends, for all is not lost,
Their banana nut pound cake, doth make amends,
And stable Wi-Fi, doth soothe the soul.
So, not entirely hopeless, is this place,
Despite the coffee, that doth leave much to be desired."

"Alack, our second visit to this place doth bring forth naught but woe! Slow service doth plague our evening, and food most vexing doth appear. A fork, a simple request, yet five minutes pass ere it doth grace our table. Duck, a dish of mediocrity, doth pale in comparison to former feasts.
