No personal banker there, to bid me adieu,
Nor asked they why, my accounts I didst anew.
A terrible bank, subpar in every way,
I'll ne'er return, nor shall I e'er stay."

"Pros: Clean, fast service, good price ($25 for white tips with gel polish). Cons: Didn't make me wash my hands, didn't clean under my nails, placed tips incorrectly (left a gap between my nails and the tips), bubbles in my nails, thinned my nails instead of rounding them. Overall, decent service, nails look okay, left a tip out of habit. May return."

"Service stunk. Local here. Took some out-of-towners to lunch. Waiter in a funk. Slow, unrefilled drinks, no plates 'til we flagged someone down. Stacked dirty dishes in our faces. Everything slow, got ignored plenty. Only quick thing: droppin' the check. Staff never said thanks. We did, though. Food wasn't bad, but that's about it."

"Construction's underway at this spot. Might wanna choose somewhere else for now. But hey, give it a few months, see how it shakes out. Check back later, read the reviews. That'll give ya a better idea."

"I ordered a cheeseburger with bacon, not knowing the menu well. The pudgy fella behind the counter corrected me, "You mean the paradise bacon cheeseburger." He seemed miffed. I said, "Sounds good," and added a side of ranch for my fries. He took my cash like he was doing me a favor. 

The burger was decent, better than fast food, but not as great as I'd hoped from the reviews. The fries were alright, but the "ranch" wasn't ranch. I thought the register dude had mixed it up, so I grabbed another cup and explained the situation. He got defensive, insisting, "That's ranch! I made it myself this morning." 

The paradise bacon cheeseburger is better than Carl's Jr., but it's small. They don't know what ranch is, their sodas are overpriced cans since they can't afford a fountain machine, and their customer service stinks. 

Forget this joint and its land-blimp owner."

"Fast and cheap, but not exactly relaxing. My 55-minute manicure was filled with upsells. Gel nails, white tips, paraffin dip, pedicure - they pushed 'em all. Just wanted a quickie during my lunch break, but they wouldn't let up. My tech was nice, but the rest of the joint was a zoo. They claim to take credit cards, but there's a catch - it'll cost you more. If you can handle the noise and pushiness, you might score a decent manicure for $9.99. Otherwise, keep lookin'."
"Pizza came out burnt to a crisp, husband's meatball sandwich was laughable. Salads, they say, are decent. Maybe should've gone with that."
"Food took forty-five. Kids had mac, wife had salmon, I had tuna. Delay? None. Apologies, free mac. Won't return. Brutal service, too bad."

"We stumbled upon this steakhouse by accident, and it was a mistake. Zero energy, zero character, just a generic, overpriced restaurant. Our appetizer, an antipasto platter, was unimpressive - bland hummus, bland baba, and too much repetition. My wife's burger was decent, but lacked seasoning. My lobster linguini was a disappointment - overcooked lobster, chewy texture, and poorly cooked pasta. The service was apathetic, like they were going through the motions. We should have known better than to pick a place without researching it first."
"Wendy's, not bad for a national chain. Salads, a plus. Burgers, fresh. This joint though, poorly run. Salad, wilted, brown bits. Service, meh."

"Great view, but that's where the praise ends. Decor's lackluster, food's overpriced, and the bread's as plain as Wonderbread. Salad's alright, dressing's good, but canned olives and old tomatoes? No thanks. Soup's mediocre, veal piccata's bland, and chicken parmesan tastes like ketchup. Dessert's a letdown - creme brûlée's too runny, chocolate cake's cold and tastes like the fridge. Service is meh, gotta ask for refills on iced tea. View's the only thing keepin' us comin' back."

"Flamingo stay marred by new Drais club. Constant bass beats till 5 a.m. made sleep impossible. Diamond member perks include great views, but that's not worth the noise. Moving on to another property."

"In Chinatown, we chanced upon a Korean BBQ place,
A rarity, we thought, and thus, our hopes did raise.
But alas, 'twas not meant to be, forsooth,
For all our plans were foiled, and our night did lose its sheen.

The meat, we thought, the fun part of the feast,
To cook it ourselves, and thus, our hunger appease.
But nay, the server said, 'twould taste better,
If they, in the kitchen, did it, and not we, the plodder.

The Grandmother's Special, next, we did ordain,
But lo, they brought the wrong dish, and our hopes did wane.
They grilled the wrong meat, and we did wait,
Until they realized their mistake, and did abate.

And when, at last, the right food did arrive,
Our joy was short-lived, for our cooking, they did deprive.
With tongs, they took, and cooked the meat themselves,
Leaving us, in disappointment, and with no selves.

And to cap it all, a stench did fill the air,
From the kitchen, a sewer-drain overflow, so foul and fair.
We swiftly did depart, with haste, and no delight,
For such a scent, did mar our appetite, and put us to flight."

"Friends went on a date, brought me takeout. He liked his steak. She said fried pickles weren't crispy, ribs were decent, pulled pork was tender but dry, garlic mashed potatoes were alright, creamed corn was great. Said it was mediocre, wouldn't go back. \n\nI got the beef brisket sandwich with mac and cheese. Didn't look like the website pic, no au jus. Meat was tender but bland and dry. Mac and cheese was too spicy, couldn't eat more than a bite. Menu didn't say it was spicy. Disappointing. Wouldn't recommend it."

"Hark, good sir! The name doth seem to be,
Cous Cous now, and not what it did be.
New owners and chefs, I do perceive,
And oh, how the lamb burger doth grieve!
The spices, once a delight, now doth wane,
And I, in truth, do doubt my return again.
Forsooth, the last two cashiers I didst meet,
Didst leave me in disfavor, full of discreet."

"Get the Palms Club card. It's worth it. Food's nothing special, but the club prices make it worthwhile. Had a late night breakfast - bacon was decent, eggs were perfect, toast was alright, but the home fries? Forget about it. They were all grease and no potato."

"Jamba Juice on campus? Sweet. But no, it's crap. Guy behind counter's got an attitude, treats me like dirt. Other workers ain't no better, act all pissed off when I ask 'em somethin'. Place is cramped, confusing. Customers look lost, staff don't give a damn."

"VIBE 
Cool joint, Le Cartet. Castor-esque lights hang low, maps adorn the walls, poinsettias sit pretty. Buzzy spot for lunch, no doubt. But service? Zilch. No greeting, no drink offer, had to ask for specials myself. 

I ATE 
Salmon sandwich, decent stuff. But hey, thought I'd get slices of salmon, not some tuna melt mush. Pricey too, with a tiny salad for $15. 

OBLIGATORY CATCHY REMARK 
Le meh, Le Cartet. Good vibes, mediocre grub. Worth it if you're already in the area, but otherwise, it's a trek for little reward."

"Crabs, tricky devils. Limited options. Best bet, pack a toolkit - jewelry case-sized, for elegant extraction. Most folks? Confused pokes with a fork, then full-on caveperson mode - rip it apart. Legs, claws, little meat. Body, jelly-like organs. Not worth it. Twenty-five bucks. Waitstaff finds crab shells for weeks, like ninja stars. Hole In The Wall Crab Shack, I'll return. But not for this dish. Crabs, pricey. Low yield, lots of work. Garlic crabs, too salty. Shrimp, appetizing. Next time, no regrets."
"Las Vegas. Steakhouse. Expensive. Runs out of steak. No apology. Not busy. 8 pm. Epic fail. Plenty of better options."

"Good spread, decent grub. But the folk runnin' this joint? Cheapskates. Try to limit your pickins of the good stuff. Charge you extra for leftovers you didn't even like. Forget that. And they got a 'tude, expectin' big tips. Skip it. Support places that earn your business."

"Place looked promising, but it just didn't deliver. Passed by it a few times, always empty. Food's not great. Chicken's dry, sauce is bland, like something you'd buy at the store. Ribs were alright, brisket's too fatty, pork had a weird aftertaste. Sides were a letdown too - coleslaw needed more seasoning, BBQ beans were flavorless (my husband said Bush's in a can is better), and potato salad was a total waste. Even the pickles, which were breaded nicely, had a weird texture like thick paper. Dipping them in their ranch made 'em a bit better. Atmosphere's like a Five and Diner, shame since it's a cute little spot. Just not worth the trip."
"Sweet relish on a burger? Who the hell does that? And with dill pickles too? Ruins the whole damn thing. Curly fries were good though, and they got Cherry Coke. Two stars for that."

"Terrible Krispy Kreme experience. Got there round 9:45 for two boxes to take home on Black Friday night. Lady who helped us? Rude as hell. Don't care if she worked all day, she should've been friendly. Guy mopping the floor, water splashing where the donuts were just chillin' on the machine. Unbelievable. Labels didn't match the donuts on display and when we asked her to clarify, she gave us some long-winded explanation about how they distribute donuts to gas stations. Ready to walk out, but managed to pick out some decent ones under the glass door. Never coming back."

"O, 5th and Wine, thy name doth please mine ear,
But alas, the service there did leave much to fear.
'Twas slow, oh so slow, and when we sought to pay,
The waiter's attention didst evade us, come what may.
Thirty minutes passed, and still we waited,
Until at last, we paid in cash, and quickly vacated.
The art upon the walls, a pleasant sight it was,
But my grilled cheese sandwich, with dressing most foul,
Didst taste of dishwater, a most awkward affair.
I wouldst not return, for there be better places near,
To dine and drink, and merrily pass the time, my dear."
"Pad thai, usually devour anything. First dish in ten years I couldn't finish. Wife's cashew chicken, mediocre at best. Four out of ten. Keep driving to Naga for real Thai."

"Hark, good sir! Doth thou offer stamps or ice with thy Snickers bar? Nay, I thank thee not, for they do not complement each other well. How sayeth thou, Circle K? 'Tis a foul place, full of unnecessary wares and overpriced fare. The workers of the land and builders of structures do frequent it, I reckon, for convenience's sake. Yet, two stars doth it earn, for its location maketh it a rare haven in these parts. And lo, Circle K hath corrected its mistake in charging too much for 5 Hour Energy drinks, by offering a special of two for five regal pieces or six silver coins, depending on the strength desired. Verily, a fair price, methinks."

"A pair of stars doth shine upon this place,
For its fair view doth make our spirits bright.
But, alas, the food didst not impress,
And thus, our joy didst take a sorry flight.

A drinking spot, they call it, and rightly so,
For in the morn, they serve breakfas', don't you know?
A vast menu, full of choices galore,
But we, in search of brekkie, didst explore no more.

I'd return, to sip cocktails on the patio,
And watch the fountain, with a merry heart, yea, verily.
But, for the grub, my friends, I do beseech thee,
Look elsewhere, lest thou be disappointed, as was I."

"Methinks I must be in a different place than yonder two years past,
Where fun and frivolity did reign supreme, and victuals of good taste
Were served at prices fair and reasonable. Alas, tonight I found
A burger of fifteen dollars, dry and flavorless, naught but woe.
My wife, with pulled pork, didst utter "meh," and thus didst say
The fare was mediocre, lacking zest and verve. The hall was dim,
Unclean, and void of mirth, yet still the serving folk were kind,
And thus I give this place two stars, and not but one, for their plight.
If thou art bound for this establishment, turn back, my friend,
And seek instead the hospitality of Jac's, or drive afar
To Gates and Brovi, where for equal coin thou shalt find
Fare better suited to thy taste, and cheer thy spirits high."

"Five of us hit up Nanos. Four of us ordered Mofongo. But only one of us got it. The rest of us got some other dish with the same name. Our server didn't bother to clarify. They made up for it with a plain Mofongo plate. But then they screwed up our checks. Drinks on the wrong tickets, you name it. What a mess. We thought this new spot from the Sabor and Three Amigos crew would be top-notch. Nope."

"Place was jumpin' when we hit it up one night. Decor? Kitschy, yeah. We shared a pear salad, canned pears, but hey. Beef cheeks special, sauce overpowered 'em. Hubs had decent lasagna, I had more of his. Overpriced, Olive Garden does it better."

"Alas, my dear friend, I must confess,
This deli doth leave much to be desired.
The kosher corned beef, so fatty and chewy,
Some parts exposed to air, did make me feel quite queasy.

And, by the stars, the girl who made my sandwich,
Did struggle with the meat, in such a plight,
She near pushed her finger into the wheel's embrace,
A fate most dire, and cause for great alarm and fright.

Ah, how I love to see a cook fuss o'er meat,
But not at risk of losing a digit, so neat.
The potato salad, alas, did lack all zest,
Leaving me unsatisfied, and still questing for the best.

In truth, this deli doth not compare,
To those I've known in NYC, Boston, or fair Cleveland's lair.
It doth but leave me yearning for the genuine article,
And thus, my friend, I shall seek out a better location."
"Airports, I know 'em well. Eleven years of business travel, that's my story. Charlotte Douglas, though - that place needs work. Drop-off, pick-up, it's all a mess. Time to widen the roads, I'd say."

"Thursday night, I swung by to give it a shot. Lack of BBQ in the area made it worth checking out. Got a combo plate with pulled pork, brisket, and ranch beans. Sweet potato fries came with a shit ton of 'em. Beans were whatever, fries needed seasoning. Brisket had a smoke ring but tasted more like pot roast than BBQ. Pulled pork was decent, steeped in its own juices, but came with sauce already applied. Ask for it on the side. Tabasco saved the day - seemed like they designed the sauce with it, then chickened out. Empty place, but it was 8:30 on a Thursday. If you're craving good Q, hit up Bobby Q's at I-17 and Dunlap."

"O, how my heart doth ache with sorrow and woe,
For the service at Gallo Blanco didst go awry.
The server, a lazy lout, didst take his time,
To greet our table, and his face didst wear a frown.

We ordered drinks, but alas, they were out of stock,
Of Paloma margarita, dos x, and negro modelo.
We made do with an appetizer, while we didst wait,
But lo, another server didst drop our plate.

Our server, a man of little worth, didst disappear,
For twenty-five minutes, or mayhap more.
We ordered tacos, but they didst take their time,
And I didst ask the server, why the delay?

He said, with attitude, 'You should have ordered right,'
But I didst reply, 'How could we, when thou wert gone?'
The tacos came, but they were cold as ice,
And I didst tell him, 'Bring the Cajetas, and the check, make haste.'

But he didst bring the check, and not the dessert,
And I didst pay, and leave, with anger in my heart.
Oh, Gallo Blanco, how couldst thou hire such a man?
He was worse than a Wendy's order-taker, a sorry soul.
His belt was white, and it didst not match his attire,
And his eyes didst droop, as if he were on fire."

"This joint used to be solid, but it's gone down the drain. Last time we hit it up, we had to send back three dishes 'cause they were either messed up or straight-up terrible. Shame, 'cause it used to be the closest thing to Houston's in Charlotte."

"Calabria's looks swell from the outside, real pretty. Landscaping's always tidy, building's a looker. But inside, it's stuck in the 90s, feels dated. Went to a bridal shower here, nice and fancy compared to the main dining area. Party room served breakfast later, weird for a fancy spot. Good service, food's alright, but overall ambiance ain't great."
"Pizza? Forget it. Hand-tossed disaster - 25% crust, 50% bubble, 25% mush. Sauce? Ketchup. Toppings? Frozen. Thin crust Philly? Surprisingly decent. But rare."

"Bellagio, aiming for 4 or 5 stars, fell short. Service spotty, slow, and unorganized. Large party, but not packed. Waiter dropped dishes at random spots, no memory of orders. Timing issues, dishes arrived one by one. Pricy, decent food, edamame stood out. Not worth it, unless forced. Other sushi places on the Strip, worth a try."
"Eight a.m., Sunday. Appointment scheduled. Get in, get done, move on. Receptionist present, but staff trickled in between 8:10 and 8:15. Unprofessional. Medical staff should know better."

"Sushi Factory, a decent spot, but not worth more than a 2.5-star rating. Arrived, greeted by a friendly hostess, but the decor was a bit shabby. AYCE with my date, he stuck to fried stuff, rolls fell apart. Sake helped ease the disappointment. Not the best option in the valley for AYCE sushi."

"Methinks 'tis the second time I've come to this place,
And both times, chaos and disorganization did grace
Their halls, causing long waits and much vexation,
A plight most woeful, and a sorry situation.

I called and ordered, and waited patiently,
Thirty minutes passed, yet still no pizza could I see.
Another quarter hour didst tick by, ere at last,
My pie arrived, and oh, how my hunger did crave it so fast!

Alas, poor management doth mar their reputation,
For twice now, this hath been my sad experience.
The pizza, verily, was good, but at what cost?
Forsooth, I shall not come again, for such trouble doth not please."
"Overpriced grub, mediocre at best. Empty joint, yet they seated us at a crummy table. Skimpy pours of vodka. Puny portion sizes. This place won't last a year."

"Upon my second venture to Char, we doth drop two stars, alas! Forsooth, from yonder reviews, 'tis clear their cooks do roast the beef to hell and back. My burger, thrice-accursed, didst emerge o'ercooked, nay, verily, burnt to a crisp! If thou art unable, by law or inclination, to cook a burger to medium, prithee, confess! I shall then choose chicken, anon. Alack, my brisket burger, requested medium, didst arrive dry and flavorless, like a desert mummified. The onions, too, were raw, uncooked, a woeful sight. Yet, praise be, the tater tots, a worthy side, didst please mine taste. Service, once more, didst excel, and we didst sit upon the patio, blessed with gentle breezes, conducive to converse. Alas, good sirs, the service and ambiance cannot compensate for the consistent overcooking of beef. Farewell, I say, and may thy future meals be cooked aright!"

The hotel wasn't half bad for the price. Rooms were tidy, and they threw in a free breakfast. But their Wi-Fi was busted, and they charged my card four times for the same room. I tried to sort it out with the front desk, but the clerk flipped his lid, screaming at me like a madman. No help, no resolution, just a whole lot of aggravation. Now I'm stuck dealing with their corporate office and my bank. Turns out, Super 8 is a franchise, so there's not much the main office can do. I should've shelled out the extra 25 bucks for the Hilton Garden Inn and avoided all this hassle.
"Food's mediocre at best. Slapdash and hasty, not worth remembering. Thought we had a decent local spot, but this place falls short. Might give the banana pudding another shot, but that's it."

"Slipped into the joint for a bite. Small place, but the grub's good. Server's hustling, but the joint's a bit rough around the edges. Ordered a Coke, but it was flat. Went for the British Burger, though - damn tasty. Friend had the pulled pork sliders, and she raved about 'em too. Service could be snappier, but the food's worth another visit."
"Food was cooked right, ingredients fresh. But flavors were dull, portions off. Meat and eggs overwhelmed by mushrooms. Service slow, few customers. Bathrooms, a mess. Won't return soon."

"In Vegas, we tried the Stratosphere for our final night. Paid under a hundred bucks for the Oasis Suite on a Sunday. Looked forward to dining at the Top of the World restaurant for the view. Getting there was a challenge. Asked for directions a couple times. Once seated, we started with their bread basket and wine. My wife had the ribeye, which was decent but not memorable. I prefer a charred steak. Shared a huge twice-baked potato (very good) and field greens salad. I had the lobster bisque (not bad, but I've had better) and the seafood plate. The roasted vegetables and scallops were great, but the lobster and shrimp had a fishy taste. Couldn't quite place it until I had crab legs later and tasted the shoulder meat. Won't be back for the food, but might grab a drink at the bar for the view. Fantastic view, but there are better restaurants in town for the price."

"Pure Night Club can go to hell. We waited in line for over an hour, watching hoochies skip the line. When we finally got in, they hit us with a $40 cover charge, each. What a joke. Drinks were ridiculously priced too, almost $10 for a bottled water. The only highlight was seeing Dave Chappelle and Chris Rock in line."

"Groupon's a bitch. Canyon Falls, too. Massage was a joke. Nice building, big room, but that's where the positives end. Therapist shows up, sees my Groupon, and I know it's gonna be crap. Short, weak massage. Left feeling oily and unsatisfied. Won't be back."

"Verily, TAO Beach doth pale in comparison to other Vegas locales. Its diminutive size and throngs of daybeds do make it seem rather cramped, yet the cost, in truth, doth not break the bank. Alas, the murky waters do detract from the overall experience, I must confess. 

But lo, the true joy of TAO Beach doth lie not in its environs, but in the company one keepeth. In the company of dear friends, I didst find pleasure, despite the somewhat lacking ambiance. 

Once, I didst visit TAO Beach, but now, I have no cause to return."

"First time here, five stars easy. Recent visits? Not so much. Restaurant week, good grub, but old mac and cheese with bacon, better than lobster. Service first time, top-notch. Latest time, disappointing. Waitstaff, hate restaurant week? Maybe. But I know how to tip, add dishes, respect the system. Didn't feel welcome, barely spoke to us. Ordered extras, still screwed up our food. Wrong table, no to-go boxes. Unacceptable. Not coming back."

"Went to Wind Rises at the cinema last Friday. Gave it 2.5 stars, but that's not enough. It's a national chain, they charge a premium, no excuses. 2 stars it is. And I need to up my 2-star game. :P

That pic of the dirty seat? Spot on. Gross. Faux leather crumbling? Forgivable. But popcorn crumbs and stains? No way. I paid $11 for that ticket, another $11 for snacks. Not worth it. 

This place feels like a cash grab. Busy with tourists, maybe, but locals know better. My guy has an AMC Stubs card, $12 well spent, but we only come here occasionally. 

Picture and sound were good. Can't complain there. But overall, Regal's better. Rave theatre was nicer too."

"Alles ist already done. Who needs a construction site when the boss don't know where to start? Allvitalis is original, but lacks solidity, worth the price. Themed rooms are trimmed for show, but upon closer inspection, it's just a bunch of hooey. The carpenter's got a flea in his ear."

"Opened across from the brickyard, I'd been eager to try it. Twenty minutes for my order? Too damn long for lunch take-out. They ran out of boxes, so I got my pizza in a foil wrap. Cheese stuck to the foil like glue. Hard, unimpressive dough. Great spot, subpar grub. Won't be back."

"Hoped for a swell Walgreens, location and all. But no dice. Packed, overpriced joint, hard to navigate. Could've let the prices slide, location and all, but the layout? Unforgivable. Check-out area, especially. Thought they'd be more reasonable, what with the Venetian next door charging an arm and a leg. Guess not. Oh well."

"Alas, my dearest Las Vegas, how art thou fallen! 

In days of yore, a humble Vietnamese eatery didst thrive, 
A haven of flavor, packed to the rafters with delight. 
The pho, a savory brew, didst warm the cockles of mine heart, 
Fresh veg and noodles, a feast fit for a king, didst ignite. 

But lo, the curse of progress didst descend upon the place, 
And with it came a change, a shift in priorities, alas! 
The broth, once rich, didst lose its former glory, 
The prices rose, the service didst become most lax. 

Yet still, a glimmer of hope doth shine, a beacon in the night, 
For in the realm of Chinese cuisine, they doth hold sway. 
K.J. Kitchen, a haven of delight, doth reign supreme, 
A veritable palace of gastronomic joy, a gem. 

But alas, my friends, this place, once great, doth now but pale, 
A shadow of its former self, a mere reflection of its former glory. 
Saigon 8, a newcomer, doth rise, a star ascendant, 
A shining light, a beacon in the night, a haven of delight."
"Food, good. Service, bad. Call ahead, take out, eat at home. Two stars for service, four stars for food. Spent two hours, watched others eat and leave. Won't eat in restaurant again."

"Drove five hours to meet TJ at the check-in counter. Unhelpful, uninterested. Reviews were right, check-in's a pain. Haven't seen the room yet. Smells like smoke and cleaning fluid. Bathroom and linens were clean, TV's a nice flat screen, bed's comfy. Won't stay here again. Service ruined our Vegas trip. Go to Flamingo or MGM."

"Chicken and waffles, best in town. But service? Shaky. Been here a few times, always good grub. But servers? Sourpusses. Don't ask for much, just a refill or some extra menu time. But get the stink-eye instead. Maybe they're having a bad week. Every week. Who knows? Still, good eatery. Go for the classics. Just don't count on friendly service."

"A pox upon Travelocity, that wretched site,
Which with false promises doth lure folk in.
The rooms they show, so bright and new,
Are but a ruse, a trick to win thy penny.

The pool, with chairs so worn and old,
Doth make one shudder at the thought of sitting.
And Yvonne, twice-named, at front desk doth scowl,
As if her mood doth sour the very air.

The food, a disappointment, doth not please,
And bed, alas, doth hurt mine own backside.
How doth this place still stand? 'Tis mystery,
For I shall ne'er return, nor would I advise.

Two stars, I give, for staff, save front desk crew,
And mountains, fair, which surround this place anew."

"We yearned to adore this joint. Moved to the area, missed downtown Gilbert. Took the lads post-football game, a month back. Disappointment reigned. No fries at lunchtime? Odd. Greasy aroma suffocated the space. Frying something, no doubt. Server, a sweetheart. Kiddos, enamored with the popcorn machine. Alas, grub unworthy of return...for now."

"Hark, good sirs and madams, I do confess,
The Burger Bar didst leave me in some distress.
The serving maids were kind and fair,
But oh, the cookery didst lack somewhat there.

My neighbors at the table didst receive,
Two free drinks from the house, 'twas quite a tease.
But I, alas, didst find my meal not hot,
The chicken wings were scarce cooked, but fries were got.

Beware, dear friends, they take no reservations,
Cash or credit, that be their conditions.
Yet, shall I return, for every place doth merit,
A second chance, or mayhap, a new Groupon to spirit."

"Alas, my friends, I must confess,
My hopes for Indulge were quite depressed.
Their website, magazines, and drive-by views,
Did paint a picture of upscale hues.
But alack, the truth did soon reveal,
It was no different than a common steal.
Fuddruckers, thou art a poor disguise,
For mediocrity, in culinary wise.

Two burgers, built with care and thought,
And one pre-made, which we had sought.
Dill chips, an appetizer, we did try,
But none of us did utter a sigh.
Of satisfaction, that is to say,
For the food, it did not pass the play.

The tables, cramped and close together,
Did make us feel like we were in a fetter.
The noise, it did assault our ears,
And made us wish for silence, dear.
Our servers, eager to clear the space,
Did ask for dessert, before we'd grace.
The meal, it was a rush, a noise, a fray,
Not indulgent, in any way, I pray.

Oh, how my heart doth sink with woe,
For the experience, it was not a show.
Indulge, thy name doth not befitting,
For thou art but a mere pretending."

"Fie upon this place, where smoke doth fill the air,
And bartenders, rude and crude, do ply their trade.
A renovation grand, they boast, with finest fare,
But still, the stench of smoke doth linger, unabated.

I sat with mine own dear love, and friend most true,
And ordered drinks, as custom doth require.
But lo, the bartender, with words most bold,
Didst claim, to gain free drinks, a wager must be told.

Five dollars, I didst drop, in machines three,
To placate this fool, and gain our liberty.
But nay, my love, with scotch she didst desire,
And ten dollars more, the bartender didst require.

Oh, how the shame, the embarrassment, didst sting!
For such a play, so base, so vile, so mean,
I didst drop ten more, and bid the fool,
'Here, take this tip, and let us see what shall ensue.'

But lo, the fool, he lost, and laughed,
And thus, our time, was wasted, and our mirth, was dashed.
A total waste, this place, where smoke doth reign,
And rudeness, doth prevail, with naught but pain.

So, farewell, dear friends, and heed my word,
For here, no pleasure doth reside, nor joy, nor cheer.
But rather, smoke, and fools, who seek to prey,
Upon the innocent, and make their day, a dreary way."

"Hark! My belly doth protest, full of discomfort and woe. A feast we did partake, at this place, for the first time, alas! The bread, hard as a stone, did cause my innards great pain. And the fowl, oh how it did disappoint! For eighteen silver coins, a dish I did receive, of little worth, I do declare. Flattened and thin, like a book, it lay upon the plate. And the steak, oh how it did lack in substance and flavor, a sorry sight indeed. Verily, I say, this place doth not deserve our custom, no, not again."

"Went to the Pink Pony, new version. Not sure what they're going for. Old place was Old Arizona, worth holding onto. Trying to attract young Scottsdale crowd, but missed the mark. Husband and I were the youngest there. Service was terrible. Nice but clueless. Disappeared for long periods. Had to hunt for ketchup and another soda. Food was mediocre. Crispy chicken wasn't, burger was average. Bathroom was a mess. Half-used toilet paper, crap on the floor. Nothing memorable about the experience. Won't be back."
"Breakfast. Service poor. Waitress clueless. Food average. Unremarkable. Can cook better at home. Won't be back."

"In sooth, I entered in, and lo, the place was void of folk. I sat me down at bar, and waited patiently for service, but when the barkeep came, her visage did bear a scowl, as if my query of happy hour and ale did vex her sore. Methinks I shall not return anon, for though I've oft enjoyed this place, poor service doth drive away guests, ere bad victuals, in the tavern trade."

"We hit JR's last night, my old man and me. Nice joint, limo, decor, service - all top-notch. But the grub? Underwhelming, to say the least. For the price they're charging, I expected to be blown away. Didn't happen. Felt like I was taken for a ride, you know? They brought us a glass of champagne right off the bat, without even asking. $45 a pop, and they didn't bother telling us till later. My guy got stuck with a $50 surcharge for a veggie starter, and they didn't mention that either. I know some folks don't sweat the small stuff, but for us, it wasn't worth it. (They took off the surcharge when we asked, though.)"

"Salad, huh? Yeah, that's what I thought. Problem is, it's the best part of the meal at this seafood joint. Spinach and berries, real tasty. Crabcakes? No way. Sent 'em back. Clam chowder? Watery mess. Friend's shrimp dish? Meh. Disappointed we came here instead of somewhere else in Phoenix/Tempe. Been here for work before, better food then."

The air was crisp, the vibe was mellow. But the wait for grub? A good 40 minutes. And let me tell you, that chicken quesadilla? Forget about it. Dry as the Sahara, overcooked like a Thanksgiving turkey. Chewin' it was like workin' a jawbreaker. No way, Jose. And them grilled onions? Don't even get me started. Sog city, population us. Not worth the trouble.

"Summerlin's Boca Park, Rampart Boulevard. Upscale Viet joint, multimillion-dollar beauty. Artwork, waterfall, fish underfloor. Time was tight, so we skipped apps and salads. Grilled tiger prawns, famous garlic noodles. Wife's ginger steamed sea bass, fresh ginger, shitake, scallions. Underwhelming. Loved the decor, service, but food was a letdown, pricey menu."

"Went there a few times, loved it. Great menu, wine, and bourbon. Last night, took some friends from Southpark, excited to try it out. Disappointment. Out of four wine choices, and the fifth wasn't worth it. Moved up to a better bottle, but still. Roof top was closed too. Won't be back for a bit, and my Southpark friends will stick to their own turf."

"A pox upon this salon, say I! For though my locks didst look fair and bright,
Their prices, they didst play a wicked trick.
I checked their site, and called, to make sure,
That for my wedding updo, I wouldst not be poor.
But when I came, with hair most dry,
My stylist didst insist, it must be blown dry.
And though I asked him thrice, to cease and desist,
He still didst charge me, for the blow dry, he didst persist.
And curling too, they didst charge, without a care,
An extra fee, that we didst not prepare.
Oh, how they took advantage, of our special day,
And left us poorer, in a most unkind way.
So here's a warning, to all who doth seek,
A salon, in a hotel, most unique.
Be wary of their prices, and what they do say,
For they may charge thee, in a most unkind way."

"On a drizzly eve, I chanced upon this place,
My joints did ache, the humid air did seize,
We sought refuge from the wet embrace,
And found ourselves within this cozy space.

Their tea, it was a pleasant surprise,
But I, a request, did politely devise,
To brew my own, from my pot, so wise,
They would not allow, a strange surmise.

My server, a woman of ample girth,
Didst greet me with a beaming mirth,
Her smile, it lit the room, like sun on earth,
Despite her size, her spirit had great worth.

My hunger, it did grow with each passing minute,
But alas, my purse, it could not accommodate,
A muffin, small, yet satisfying, did suffice,
As I sipped tea, and waited for the rain to cease.

The hours, they passed, as we sat snug within,
Until the storm, it did finally subside,
And though my visit, was not without a flaw,
'Twas still a respite, from the rain-soaked tide."

"Our service was most vexing, I must confess,
For when they first did ask, we were not prepared.
But some twenty-five minutes later, we were quite ready,
And the appetizers, they were most delectable, I swear.

Alas, my steak, it was not cooked to my liking,
For though I asked for medium rare, 'twas overcooked, I fear.
My friend, he sent his back, but I, in my folly,
Did not, for I had hoped they'd make it right, you see.

My second beer, it was not as the first,
In taste or appearance, it was quite diverse.
If thou dost forget, I shall remind thee,
For I did order a beer of a certain quality, thou shalt see.

Methinks I may return, but if the waitress be the same,
I shall flee, for her service was most tame."

"Went here 'cause our usual spot was closed for renovations. Two visits, couple hours apart. First, happy hour drinks, but slow service from a distracted waiter. Second, sat outside, half-full, but still poor service. Hostess brought menu and water quick, but that's it. Left after 17 min, still unfed. Hostess said they were understaffed, but food was decent - catfish nuggets and artichoke dip, good bar grub. Just need to get their act together, location's prime."

"Disappointing visit. Went on a Saturday night. Waiting area disorganized. Restaurant congested, difficult to navigate. They give you a small metal bowl with instructions on how to fill it, then take it to the grill guys. Slow line, especially getting veggies. Two lines, both slow. \n\nLoud music made it hard to hear, even across the table. Service slow. My wife, wearing white pants, sat in spilled soy sauce, staining the back. Waitress offered napkins. Manager seemed unconcerned. Food good, not great. Bowl didn't fill me, didn't want to go through that again. Basically served ourselves. No need for waitresses."

"Wanted to try this joint for a while, finally made it out during Arizona Restaurant Week. Bad experience though. Waiter was AWOL, had to ask for the menu ourselves. No drink refills, no bread basket. Food took forever, other tables got their grub way before us. Ordered the pina colada cake, took over twenty minutes to arrive. Food was meh, service was shit."
"Shoe leather's been easier to chaw, pie came barely warm, sans salad. Salad finally showed, pathetic excuse. Fork? Forget about it. Toppings, plenty."

"Friday night, street was dead. Movie theater across the way, but that didn't mean much. Staff was friendly, but menu was different from online. New menu had more options, but cost more too. Asada fries were $11, forget it. Ordered tacos azules, fish and shrimp, and a basic carnitas taco. Salsa bar was basic, three options, limes. Takeout order had three azules-style tacos, carnitas had cabbage and cream sauce instead of cilantro and onions. Carnitas was dry and crispy, fish and shrimp were average. Not worth $10 for three small street tacos. Ate one and a half before throwing away. Poor value. Prices went up because of lack of customers. Maybe cut staff, four people wasn't necessary. Only customer, still got overcharged and order was wrong."

"By Jove, what marketing prowess doth this place possess! A name like Noodle ChaCha, and a maiden fair, a Pucca in appearance, doth entice me in, without a doubt! 

A solitary building, the restaurant stands, and we, a group of friends, didst arrive at lunchtime, to find 'twas mostly vacant. The servers, with haste, didst greet us, and present the luncheon specials. I, with eager anticipation, didst order Thai fried rice, and sweet and sour soup, besides, the $1 milktea special, which, alack, didst prove a mistake, most dire! Forsooth, the drink, too watery, didst taste of naught but muddy H2O. A dollar, ill-spent, I do declare! The sweet and sour soup, a mediocrity, a blandness to mine tastebuds, it didst bring. And lo, the Thai fried rice, a disappointment, akin to something I, myself, couldst prepare at home, and not so fresh, I must confess. Chinese dried shredded pork, they didst add, in strange fashion. Verily, I say, a puzzlement, indeed! 

Perhaps, another day, their noodles shall tempt me, but for now, alas, the Pucca-like maid, didst not impress, I do declare!"

"Methinks 'twas our first visit to this place,
And, by the stars, the victuals did please.
We ordered chicken puffs, egg puffs, and pastries galore,
The latter, I must confess, were quite divine,
The best, in truth, that e'er I tasted on this shore.

But, alack, there were some things that did displease,
The service, poor, and slow, did cause much vexation.
They served us not a drop of water, save we asked,
And twice, the server forgot my drink, in his haste.
The second time I went, the chicken puff was stale,
And when I told the manager, he did show no care.
Yet still, I shall return, for those pastries sweet,
Do tempt me still, and make my mouth to water."

"This joint's for the birds, kid. If you're into that sorta thing, you'll dig it. But if you're like me, you'll want to steer clear. I've been dragged in here a few times, and let me tell you, it's a real headache. But hey, it's not all bad. If you're looking for a gift for the ladies, you can't go wrong. They got all sorts of baubles and trinkets, and even some body jewelry for all you pierced folks out there."
"Hype-heavy burger joint serving soggy, overpriced grub. Quotes plastered on walls screaming greatness. Something's fishy."

"Food was good, view was great, service was bad. Server disappeared, left us hanging. We spent $70 on wine, glasses stayed empty. Would've ordered dessert, but it took too long. Forgotten, like we didn't matter. $300 for two people, expected better."

"We gave this'sushi' joint another shot under new management, but it still ain't up to par. The fish wasn't fresh, the rice was bland, and the unagi sauce was weak. The hamachi was the only decent piece, but even that wasn't impressive. The oil used for the ama ebi was rancid and the shrimp head was puny. Not worth your time if you're lookin' for real sushi."

"I've been here a few times, but last weekend was likely my last. Maybe I'm just too old for the lines and the pushin' around, or payin' $16 for a mediocre drink. Pure's lost its magic for me. The club's pretty, the roof's my favorite. If I went back, that's where I'd stick to."
"Twice now, this in-and-out's messed up my order. San Tan Mall, here I come."

"Tis not a place of honest work, my friends,
Where one may find a steady wage and end.
'Tis but a temp firm, with jobs so thin,
Outbound calls, for political surveys penned.

The day begins at two and thirty,
And ends when workload's done, night's hurry.
For pay, they offer nine gold coins,
But oft, thy time, they'll not be using.

Many a day, thou'lt call to schedule,
And they, thy name, will not be grudging.
Weeks pass, and still, no work's assigned,
A waste of time, thy quest, unending.

Avoid this place, my friends, I pray,
For management's ways, are not of play.
They treat their workers, poor and old,
As trash, and joke, their plight, so cold.

Work elsewhere, seek not this place,
For honesty and worth, doth not embrace."

"Picazzo's, once a fave, now fallen from grace. Service still good, but grub sub-par. Salad came with unlisted greens, server apologized for sub. Didn't ask if I wanted kale, which I didn't. Lettuce was brown, avocado price absurd. Not sure if I'll give it another shot. Appreciate the health nod, but meh."

"Alas, my friends, I must recount a tale of woe,
Of dining on the Strip, where service should flow.
But lo, at Diablo's Cantina, 'twas not so,
For slow and poor the service did go.

We sat at bar, awaiting menus with glee,
But nary a word from servers could we see.
At last, a finger pointed, and a mumble spoke,
"Ask bartender, not me," our hopes did break.

And when the food arrived, oh what a sight,
Bland and flavorless, without a spicy bite.
Alas, my friends, I cannot recommend this place,
For Diablo's Cantina did not show its grace."

"This joint's alright for a drink, nothing special though. Had a salad, which was meh, and overpriced at $13. Menu's got some other options, but I ain't too keen on trying 'em. Good spot for a beer and a game, that's about it."

"O, woe is me! The Rockin' Railroad class doth please,
But alas, no make-up classes may be seized.
My toddler's nap, my work, the schedules crossed,
And thus, two classes left untaught, my loss.

The owner, stern and unyielding, doth refuse
To grant an exception, or to make amends.
My babe, sickly, home I did detain,
Lest others fall ill from his contagion's stain.

Now, all they offer, a play gym doth remain,
A substitute, poor, for what I did obtain.
Disappointment doth consume my heart and brain,
For such a simple boon, they would not relent.

In other classes, instructors, kind and true,
Did gladly make up missed classes, anew.
But here, a hardened stance, they do maintain,
And thus, our Rockin' Railroad days are vain.

We shall not return, nor pay their fee,
For such poor service, we will not decree."

"Liked it at first, late night, 24 hours. Went back a few times, but it didn't grow on me. Drinks and grub, meh, overpriced. Wi-fi policy, bullshit. Buy somethin' to get the password, then again every hour and a half? Ridiculous. Furniture could use a sprucin' up, especially them leather couches."

"Buon Gusto, what's left of Picazzo's, still serves local and organic grub. Deals keep coming, but my two favorites are gone. The Chipotle Barbacoa, the best pizza I've had, with barbacoa meat, cheesy chipotle sauce, and jalapenos, was actually spicy. The Spicy Italian, pepperoni and salami with olive and carrot tapenade, was also great. But now, everything else seems mediocre. My daughter sticks to her mushroom and cheese, while my wife misses her own lost pizza. We don't go there as much anymore."

"Tacos and tequila, that's what they had. Not much else. But it was enough. The margaritas were sweet and watery, like a summer rain. No chips or salsa, but who needs them when the tacos are this good? Cheap eats, that's what they called it. And that's exactly what it was. A place to fill your belly without emptying your wallet."

"This ain't no Golden Corral. Fancy schmancy buffet with over 500 menu items. Not for the faint of heart. Need a solid game plan to tackle this beast. I'm talkin' cuisine variety, not just maxin' out your dollar. Personal faves include cured meats and cheese, kobe beef sliders, prime rib, tuna sashimi salad, and all the sweet treats. Bacchanal gets my buffet stamp of approval and 3.5 stars for quality grub and sheer grandeur."

"Makmak, decent joint. Not mind-blowing, but not bad either. They got Singha, that's a plus. Tom Yum, a little different, not amazing, but I've had worse. Spring rolls, standard. Pork dumplings, pretty good. Peanut sauce, solid. Haven't tried the Pad Thai, can't comment. Service, good. Place has character."

"Swung by to return a trailer we hauled from Seattle. Waited 15 minutes while the two employees tended to other customers. Nice guy looked up our info on the computer since we lost the paperwork in the move. 

Other employee, not so much. Commented on his coworker's hygiene in front of a few customers. But hey, I'm in it for the equipment, not the service. 

Still, no issues coming back for more rentals. Convenient spot, big lot, and they're the only game in town. Just remember, Fridays through Sundays are busy, so plan accordingly."

"Library's good. Story time's fun. But here's the thing: they give out stamps to the kiddos at the end. And this one counselor, she skips over the loud ones. My two-year-old, he loves story time, but he gets a little rambunctious. Twice now, he hasn't gotten a stamp. And let me tell you, it's a big deal to him. First time, I thought maybe she just missed him. But the second time, she looked right at him and still didn't give him a stamp. I was miffed, so we bailed. It's a great library, don't get me wrong. But inclusivity's important, especially when it comes to hand stamps. That's all I'm sayin'."

"Who knew? Not me. Thought Twin Peaks was some mountain thing. But no, it's a joint in Vegas. And now there's one in Scottsdale. Walked in, thought, 'Damn, these gals are hot.' Compared to Hooters, this place is on another level. Food? Eh, it's alright. Big portions, but nothing special. They got some cute dessert called Scenic View, free for the ladies. Nice touch. Place itself is like an REI store, but with hot chicks. Cover charge of five bucks for UFC is cool. Wouldn't come for the grub, but hey, the view's nice."

"Food's great, best I've had in Asian cuisine. But prices keep risin', gettin' too steep for what you get. Twelve bucks for chicken fried rice? High, even for good grub. Soup's just broth with some onion slices. You eat here, let me know what you think 'bout prices compared to other Asian joints. Gonna try Little Saigon in Glendale next, Vietnamese place with five stars."

"Methinks 'twas fortnight past, when first I didst set foot in this place they call Surprise, that I didst hear tell of a certain eatery known as New York Flavor. And thus, with mine own two eyes, didst I behold the sign that didst read, in bold letters, "New York Flavor". Methought, "Marry, what fortune! A taste of the Empire City, here in the desert!" And so, with haste, didst I make my way within, to partake of their culinary delights. 

The service, I must confess, was quite good. Forsooth, the maiden at the counter, when asked, didst guide me through the menu with grace and wit. And thus, I didst order the Spanish Harlem, with a side of potato salad, as suggested by the fair maiden. 

But lo, the potato salad, in a tiny cup it came, a mere morsel, a snack, a trifle! Methought, "Surely, this is some jest, some merry prank?" Forsooth, the portion was scant, and the taste, alack, was naught but common, akin to that found in the marketplace. And thus, I didst pay $1.99 for two bites of potato salad, a sorry sight indeed. 

The sandwich, however, didst please mine taste. The spread, flavorful, and the steak, cooked to perfection. The bread, alas, was naught but ordinary. And thus, for $8.99, a sum not small, didst I partake of a meal, that, though not unpleasant, didst not live up to the standards of the Big Apple, whose name it doth bear. 

In conclusion, fair friends, the service, indeed, was good, but alas, the food, a disappointment. For in New York, they do say, "You get what you pay for," and thus, I didst not find it worth the cost."

"In fair Scottsdale, where the sun doth shine bright,
A humble eatery doth stand, a wondrous sight.
'Tis Luke's of Chicago, a place of renown,
Where chili cheese dogs doth reign supreme, a crown.

Their lunchtime fare, it doth vary, I confess,
At times, a swift affair, with naught to address.
But when the crowd doth swell, a wait doth ensue,
And patience, dear friend, doth oft be tried anew.

The chili cheese dog, oh how it doth delight,
A messy, tasty treat, that doth ignite.
Crinkle-cut fries, a bonus, doth come with ease,
A perfect pairing, for those who doth please.

But alas, a tale of woe, I must impart,
A lost order, a mistake, a heavy heart.
In haste, a ticket fell, or so it seemed,
A mishap, rare, but still, a fault to be deemed.

Yet fear not, dear patron, for this place doth stand,
A gem amidst the fast food, fancy land.
So if thou seeketh a meal, free from pretence,
Luke's of Chicago, a worthy choice, make sense."
"Vegas buffets, I thought they'd be better. Nice display, but the grub? Meh, still a buffet."

"In this fair city of New York, where bustling crowds do roam,
A gentler soul doth dwell, within a place called home.
A restaurant once, now transformed, doth hold a charm,
With victuals of sport, and wings that do disarm.

The flavors of the wings, they doth abound,
A feast for taste buds, and a sight most profound.
So if thou find thyself, in this city of old,
Do seek out this place, where sports and grub do unfold."

"Water or something else? Server was subpar. Great grub, but he screwed up the basics. Salad, pizzas, apps, wine, pitcher - he thought we only wanted H2O and pizza. Screwed up our drinks, orders too. First time at Fed Pizza, not sure if I'll return due to the shoddy service."

"Hark! What spectacle doth mine eyes perceive?
Athletic maidens, scantily clad, do writhe
Upon the ground, their supple forms a-twist,
In fervent passion, with nary a stitch.
Their beefy counterparts, of eastern Europe bred,
Do sweat and pant, their muscles bulging, red.
Acrobatics and water stunts, a blur of flesh,
A two-hour ride of lust, that doth leave me breathless.
When ended, I did towel off and shower,
Then left my home, to witness 'Le Reve' at Wynn's tower."

"The joint's got a split personality, like some folks I know. One day, the barista's all smiles and chat, makin' recommendations that make me wanna come back for more. Next visit, it's like they're having a bad hair day, and I'm left hopin' for a better run next time."

"Food was decent, but the salt ruined it. Service was good though. Went back for the Super Bowl, but they wanted to charge me like they paid to stream it. Prices were outrageous, 85 cents per wing?! Ridiculous when you can get them for 50 to 6 cents elsewhere."

"Whilst I did wait for my takeout, a group of four seniors did leave,
With smiles on their faces, and joy did they bring.
One of the fair ladies did say, "Tis our fave place,
Where every dish doth please, and ne'er doth disgrace."
She gathered all the cards, and off did she go,
To spread the word, and let all know.

I pondered long o'er the menu, a feat,
For Chinese food, I knew not what to eat.
At last, I chose the ma po tofu, and lo mein,
And off did I drive, with a grin.

But alas, the takeout bag, a mess did make,
All sauced up, and nary a mistake.
The tofu, with ground chicken, light and fine,
But the noodles, oh how they did decline.
Excessive oil, a chef gone wild,
A pity, for the Peking duck, I did desire,
And still do plan, to give it a try,
And see if it doth change, my mind's eye."

In midst of renovation, fair hotel doth lie,
Amidst the bustling streets of wondrous Vegas, nigh.
I chanced upon a room, new-made and fine,
With bed so soft, a cloud, and space divine.
The view, a sight most fair and bright,
Down (or up, in Vegas' endless night) the famed Strip's delight.
Alas, the crowd, a bit uncouth, did grieve,
Yet still, the staff, with warmth and grace, did relieve.
Once finished, renovations grand and new,
This hotel shall regain its former glory anew.

Hark! My dearest girlfriend and I didst venture hither,
To partake in breakfast feast, at Dan Marino's place,
Within the Hooters Hotel, where we didst lay our head,
And rose anon, to dine upon their morning grace.

A coupon book, with offer of a 2 for 1 deal,
Didst entice us, to their breakfast buffet, so grand,
For ten gold coins, a regular price, I do confess,
But with the coupon, 'twas a steal, a true success!

Scrambled eggs, bacon, sausage, diced potatoes, too,
Dry cereal, waffles with strawberries, a treat for thee,
Bread pudding, fruit, a veritable cornucopia,
A feast most satisfying, and a bargain, beyond compare!

Coffee, milk, OJ, or soda, didst complete the meal,
A fair exchange, for what we didst receive, most real.
So if thou find thyself, in this fair city's bounds,
Do stop by Dan Marino's, and taste their breakfast rounds!

"Verily, fair reader, let it be known that The Southern doth possess a certain charm, with its neat decor and ample space. Yet, methinks, doth the menu bear a striking resemblance to those of its brethren, Holyrood 9A and Red Squirrel. Doth mine eyes deceive me? Forsooth, the burger doth reign supreme, with naught but a few variations to distinguish one establishment from the next. And, alack, what of those who crave not a burger betwixt two slices of bread? Fear not, for the fare is tasty indeed, yet diversity doth seem to be in short supply. And, pray tell, why doth the foodstuff arrive upon a wooden plank? Doth the proprietor hold crockery in such disdain? In conclusion, my burger did please mine taste buds, but how doth The Southern differentiate itself from its kin?"

"Amidst the splendor of the Vegas strip, our lodgings proved a middling sight,
With rooms of fair price, yet naught to boast of in their appointments bright.
The elevators, how they creaked and groaned, a noisy, rickety plight,
And though the soap in pyramid form did spark some curiosity,
The absence of wifi in our chambers did cause some dismay, I do confess.

The gaming floor, a grand expanse, did stretch out before our eyes,
Easy to lose one's way, yet navigable, with time, by wit and guile.
The pool, a tranquil oasis, did offer respite from heat and toil,
But alas, the costs of indulgence did our purses soon deplete.

In sooth, our stay was middling, neither best nor worst, I do avow."

"Hark! If Bistro on the Avenue didst launch anew,
In any place but Westmount, 'twouldst not endure,
For price and innovation, both doth lack,
And thus, 'twouldst not be worth a second look.

Yet, there, 'tis cherished by the local folk,
A convenient choice, when cooking doth grow tiresome.
So, though we wouldst not seek it out afar,
We wouldst not mind returning now and then,
To partake in their fare, and savor the charm."
"Ate here twice at the casino. Food was alright, better than expected. Onion straws, real good."

"Went to The Gym with some pals. Nice joint, pool tables in back, dart boards up front, and a busted buck hunting game. No biggie, didn't need any more drunk folks shootin' things up before they hit the road. Had a sweet outdoor spot for smokin', too. Friendly bartenders, decent prices. Couple rough types, but it was fun. Weirdest part was the dude holdin' down the bathroom. Loud-ass boombox, like he was the DJ or somethin'. Had candies and whatnot, but I just walked on by. Don't reckon I need to tip some dude for handin' me a towel and a breath mint. But hey, check it out. Strobe lit bathroom, Starburst on the way out. Tell your better half you went to The Gym, and she'll be none the wiser."

"Frances' sales are top-notch. Their stuff ain't cheap, but you can find some one-of-a-kind items - great for gifts. I'm a big fan of the store, I am. But, I gotta watch my wallet. Wish they had more options for us penny-pinchers."

"A year past, I didst visit this place,
Where seafood doth abound in grace.
Shrimp, crab claws, oysters baked so fine,
Didst make my taste buds dance and twine.
I didst wait a year, with eager heart,
To savor those dishes once more to part.
But alas! The menu didst change,
And my desired feast didst range.
I didst order lobster, stuffed with care,
But 'twas not what I had waited for, I swear.
The wine, too, didst have cork within,
Even when they tried again, twice to win.
My first visit, five stars didst earn,
But now, three stars, my rating doth return."

"Methinks 'tis a pleasant inn, wherein I do delight to tarry oft. Alas, they do not boast of Cirque du Soleil performances, nor doth it teem with mirth and merriment, save for the raucous fetes within the Marquee, which do stir mine ire and the inebriated folk who rule the domicile."

"Clean joint, good grub, friendly service.  What more you want?

Had lunch there, menu had some nice options.  Tempura asparagus was tasty, just wished there was more of it.  Hoagies were top-notch, especially the prime rib ones.  My missus had a veggie one, I had mine with mushrooms and onions.  Rolls were fresh, made for a messy but delicious meal.  Fries were cooked just right.

Will definitely try it again for dinner, but it's gonna be packed, mark my words."

"A fair establishment, with tasty starters, indeed. Alas, the steak, it doth leave much to be desired. Forsooth, 'twas overcooked, and lacked that certain je ne sais quoi. But fear not, dear friends, for I shall return anon, to partake of their finer cuts, forsooth. For though the steak didst disappoint, the surroundings and attendance didst please mine eyes and senses well."

"We picked this spot for a light meal, tucked inside the Paris Hotel Casino. Our hostess seated us on the edge, prime for people-watching. I went for the fish dumpling noodle bowl, my wife opted for won ton soup. We added a plate of mini pork buns when the dim sum cart passed by. Verdict? Decent, but overpriced at $46, including tip. Soup bowls were flavorful, but small for pho. Pork buns were a tad dry."

"Hark! Their sandwiches be of generous size,
The ciabatta bread, a feast for thine eyes.
And whispers say, the nine-grain doth please,
A culinary delight, beyond all measure.

But alas, my roast beef provolone,
Didst not agree with mine own belly's moan.
Perhaps, I shall return to Jimmy John's,
For my next sandwich, with haste and speed."

"Secret Garden's pricey, and they don't offer military or local discounts. It's small too, with tiny habitats that can't accommodate a sprint. The animals were sluggish, even Siegfried. But he still took a pic with my kids. Not worth the cash."

"Hark! A place of plenty, fit for any purse,
Where portion sizes be generous, of course.
Their mac salad, a dish most fair and bright,
And spam musubi, a treat most wondrous in sight.
Chicken katsu, crispy without, tender within,
A feast most satisfying, for hunger to win.
When belly be empty and craving doth strike,
This place shall provide sustenance, and naught else seek.
A fullness that lasteth, for hours upon hours,
A veritable feast, for all thy hunger's powers."

"A sojourn of three days, a culinary quest,
With kinfolk dear, at Arriba's we did feast.
The chips, crisp and warm, with salsa and dip,
Earned four stars, a promising start, methought.

The service, three stars, the server kind,
Informative and friendly, yet somewhat blind.
My uncle's hot salsa, forgotten, alas!
Until halfway through, his meal did pass.

The food, two to four stars, a mixed bag,
My tamale, green corn, lacked zest and sag.
My uncle's chile, a delight, he did say,
But naught else impressed, in truth, that day.

The decor, three stars, unremarkable,
Cleanliness, a concern, not quite regal.
A single store, mom and pop, I'd choose,
For future feasts, their charm, I do propose."

"Methinks my love and I didst wish to visit this new establishment, to partake in their barbecue offerings. 'Twas quite delectable, by Jove! My love, he didst order a dram of whiskey, which they didst have in ample supply, and I, a tankard of ale, served chilled to perfection. Their daily specials, writ large upon a chalkboard, didst catch our eye. Our server, a merry lad, didst attend to us with haste and cheer. The victuals, hot as blazes, didst require a brief respite ere we couldst indulge. We began with dill pickles, fried to a crisp, though perhaps a mite too thin? I, myself, didst opt for fowl, three pieces, with macaroni and cheese, baked beans beside. My love, a pulled pork sandwich, and fried okra, didst savor with glee. The smoke, a wondrous flavor, didst lingeringly imbue the pork."

"A speedy wash, and cheap, not bad at all, my friend! Free vacuums too, a bonus, methinks. Stay in thy carriage, and a fellow at the end doth wipe it clean. A goodly job, indeed. For a monsoon-drenched conveyance, this place doth fit the bill. Alas, no full detailing, nor interior tidying. Yet, a small towel, once given, now doth dwindle. Still, 'tis a worthy stopgap, till next thou dost require a thorough cleansing."

"Hark! What news is this? Thou art still in trade, good sir! Methinks 'twas fortune's grace that led me to thy door, for had I not possessed a device to traverse the ethereal realm, I fear thou wouldst have remained unknown to me.

"And thus, I must confess, thy victuals didst please mine taste, as did the warmth of thy hospitality. A half-turkey sandwich, with macaroni salad, didst suffice for my repast, while mine husband didst enjoy pastrami, accompanied by potato salad. Our beverages didst flow like the Nile, and thus our total sum didst amount to twenty gold coins, ere the customary gratuity.

"Verily, I say unto thee, good sir, that should thy prices bend a mite toward the affordable, we wouldst partake in thy culinary delights with greater frequency, and perchance even indulge in sweet desserts."

"Methinks 'twas but a fortnight past, my aged aunt didst take me to dine,
At Ruby Tuesday's, where we didst partake,
Of their most wondrous feast, a veritable delight,
A burger, nay, two, with salad bar in sight.

Oh, how we laughed and joked, my kin and I,
At the thriftiness of my father's kin,
But lo, my aunt, a sly one, didst produce,
A stack of coupons, and our mirth didst cease.

I, myself, do swear by burgers, 'tis my creed,
Or chicken sandwich, should I be in need,
For who doth care if grill marks doth grace,
The fowl that doth arrive upon the plate?

Ruby Tuesday's, wise guile, doth offer two,
Mini burgers, salad bar, for price so low,
And now, a new addition doth they bring,
Pimento cheese, my heart doth sing with joy.

Alas, two things I miss, from days of yore,
Bread and butter pickles, pineapple, no more,
Why, oh why, doth my voice doth raise,
In sorrow, at their absence, such a pity, alack."

"Four sprites we have, and in this shop we didst spend,
Two hundred dollars, and two hours, 'twas no sin.
'Tis wondrous, yet crowded, a tourist trap, no doubt,
But gifts for our young ones, we doth bring without a rout.

In Vegas, we doth not take the little ones,
But presents, we doth bring, upon each trip, anon.
This emporium, multi-levelled, doth contain,
M&M treasures, thy children shall surely obtain.

My daughter, she didst request, a token from this place,
When next we doth visit, in January's frosty grace.
The staff, kind and helpful, lines long, we didst find,
Prices steep, but location, convenience, doth bind.

Forsooth, without the young ones, this shop doth lose,
Its charm, its lure, its magic, doth dispose.
Navigating, a mite perplexing, 'twas no jest,
But patience, we doth muster, for our little guests."

"Been meaning to hit up this Farmers Market for a while now. Heard their produce was top-notch, but the Downtown Market's offerings were always picked over by the time I got there. Decided to take a chance today, since I had the day off. Sign said they opened at 10, but when we pulled up at 9:45, the granola crowd was already digging in. Hoped I hadn't missed out on anything good. McClendons provided most of the produce, and it looked great - bright beets, deep green leeks, fingerlings, shallots, fresh broccoli. Lot of it was organic, too, with some coming from Willcox. That meant fresher. Five registers open, but there was still a line. Housewives were snatching up veggies quick, so I had to keep my wits about me. Worth it, though. Rest of the market was mostly handmade stuff - soap, blankets, jewelry, yarn crafts, a bread stand. Not a lot, but worth a visit if you're in the area. Wouldn't go out of my way, but if I lived nearby and had the time, I'd definitely swing by for fresh veggies."

"Chipotle, my go-to joint. Why? 'Cause Chipotle's life itself, that's why. Now, I ain't gonna lie, their grub's always top-notch, deserves a full five stars, no question. But this time, it's about the service and speed. 
I gotta say, the staff was friendly, real friendly. But you could tell they were rattled, like they were in way over their heads. 
There was only three folks in line, but they looked stressed, like they were drowning in a sea of orders. 
This fella in front of me starts ordering, and the gal behind the counter just leaves his food sittin' there. She comes back, chucks it, starts fresh. 
Took a good 15 minutes to get our orders, way slower than your average Chipotle. 
But the food? Still top-shelf, like always. 
Hopefully, they'll get their act together, pick up the pace."

"Haven't been here in a while, but damn glad I came back. Service top-notch. Steak and shrimp, cooked to perfection. Salad bar, loaded and fresh. Finished with DIY strawberry shortcake, worth the trip."

"Amidst the throng, a multitude of seats doth abound,
And swift attendants, with alacrity they move around.
The interior bar, new life hath recently found,
Yet, as with most, the ambiance doth ebb and flow,
Depending on the hour and day of the week,
As slow days bring forth bartenders, friendly and meek.
Their aim, to ease thy headache, and banish thy woe."

"This joint ain't no military surplus store, but it's still worth a visit. It's a zombie-themed souvenir shop with a small armory out back. They got some neat interactive games and a bunch of T-shirts, books, and bumper stickers. The MREs are a bit pricey, but they got some decent camping gear too. I left with a Twinkie, but the staff was friendly as hell."

Hark! I didst venture forth to yonder tavern,
In hopes of finding merriment and cheer.
But lo! At five o'clock, the place was empty,
Save for a few souls, scattered here and there.

The hours passed slowly, and more folk didst arrive,
Yet still, the crowd was sparse, and methought 'twas strange.
But then, I saw the drinks, and their prices too,
Five or six coins for a sangria, wine, or brew.

And thus, I didst partake in happy hour,
With a sample platter, full of victuals galore.
Indeed, the fare was tasty, and I do advise,
To try the platter, for it doth satisfy.

"Went for pie. Apple pie's filling was good, spicy. Crust, too thick, uncooked. Didn't eat it. Portion, huge, enough for three. Key lime, good, bigger than others. Service, slow. Waitress, nice. Not the best pie. The quest continues."

"At last, my dearest friend, thou didst persuade me to dine at Texaz, a place of which thy tongue didst speak so highly. And lo, my heart was gladdened, for the victuals were not unpleasing unto mine taste. But alas, I didst discover a truth most vexing, that all our companions had partaken of the chicken fried steak, and found it to be most delectable. Fie upon my forgetful mind, that didst not recall this detail. Mayhap next time, I shall savor the delicacy myself."

"Nice joint, but the smoke got to me. Couldn't stick around for more than an hour. Everyone was smoking, too much for my taste. The DJ, a cool chick, spun some great tunes though. This spot's different from most, but they charge $10 per woman. Not my scene, but I'd hit up XS next time."

"Service was decent, but my pollo poblano was a letdown. Rice and beans were alright, but that entree? Never again. Chips and salsa were provided, but the salsa was too watery. Like they dumped in a ton of H2O. Dessert was a surprise, though. Got both an app and a dessert for free. Not bad."

"A humble shop, good for small needs,
No vast expanse of aisles, like seas.
Their fruit and veg, a sorry sight,
Picky, I, with bargains in mind, take flight.
To Giant Eagle Market District, I go,
For freshness, worth the extra show."

"O, how I adore the Venetian, with its walls and ceilings so fair and bright, and the performers on the street, they do delight. And thus, to dine within this open space did seem a wondrous plan. But alas, the wait did stretch to twenty minutes, and so we did imbibe a glass of wine at a nearby bar, to pass the time. And when we were finally seated, we did command our drinks, and I, being from Miami, didst take heed of the caipirinha's flavor, for not all know its true taste. But lo, it was most vile, and both my comrade and I didst send them back, in dismay. Then, the waiter, with a smile so bright, did recommend the pomegranate mojitos, and I, with trepidation, did accept. Alas, they too were woeful, but I would not return two cocktails, lest I seem ungrateful.

And thus, we came to the fare, and oh, how it did disappoint. A pasta dish, savory and grand, I did expect, but nay, it was but ordinary, and lackluster, at best. Alas, Postrio, thou hast all the elements, to make a feast most wondrous, but alack, thy cooking, doth leave much to be desired. Step up thy game, I pray thee."
"Eclectic joint. Friendly folk. Small plates, strong drinks. Good spot for early night meetups, but watch your wallet. They'll likely be a 4-5 star spot in no time."

"Breakfast with a friend at Whole Foods this mornin'. First time for me, but she comes here regular. I had the garden omelette and apple cinnamon toast. Tasted healthy, it did. She had the oatmeal with brulee topping and fresh berries. I tried it, pretty good. Nothin' spectacular, but good. Plenty of seats and the service was quick. I'll be back, hear the sweet potato fries are top-notch."

"A fair abode, with modern gadgets galore,
To turn on lights, open blinds, and more.
But woe betide the guest who's not versed in tech,
For they may find themselves in quite a predicament, indeed.

They seek to make things easy, but alas,
No coffee maker in the room, what a pity!
So off to the casino one must trot,
To fetch a cup of joe, or so they thought.

But we, who stayed four days, had a plan,
To buy a machine, and leave it for the maid,
A gift, a token, for their diligent care,
And now, a cup of coffee's always near."

"Tao's alright, been there a few times. First visit, loved it. Went back, not so much. They got strict rules, 50-50 ratio, guys only. My crew, four of us, they wouldn't even let us wait in line. Some other doorman, cool guy, let us in no problem. Inside, it's tight, real tight. Packed house, no room to breathe. Fire hazard? I don't know. Decor's cool, bathing girls, nice touch. Bartenders, top-notch. Doormen, bouncers, not so much. Still, worth a visit, once."

"Aye, 'tis a fair place to take the young ones, I reckon. Not so much for grown-ups, save those who dote on penguins, mayhap. 'Tis not a zoo of great renown, save for the clever staging of beastly abodes, methinks."

"Morn meal, a feast most fair and bright,
Skillets, a dish of might and light.
Outside, the patio, cool and fresh,
Breakfast there, a true delight, by my troth."

"Aye, 'tis a place I've oft frequented,
And now, my thoughts on it, I shall present.
The victuals, middling fare they do provide,
Better than gruel, yet no feast for kings, they ride.

Breakfast dishes, waffles, toast, omelets made,
Meats and potatoes, all in their shade.
Lunch and dinner, similar in their array,
Fried seafood, pizza, Chinese, come what may.
Crab legs and steaks, at a higher cost, they bear.

Waitstaff, pleasant and attentive, they do show,
Price, a bargain, with player's card, it doth flow.
Six, nine, twelve, the prices, they do range,
A decent meal, under ten, a rare change.

In conclusion, 'tis a place of moderate worth,
Basic, yet cheap, a value, of great earth."

"Fair Basha, thy victuals be of quality,
With meat most genuine, not the tainted sort,
Thy salads too, fresh as the morning dew,
A feast for eyes and taste, no need to fault.

But, alas, thy female servants, fair,
From Middle East, their ways not ours,
Do shun the men, and scant their duty bear,
In this, the land of liberty and power.

For here, in West, men and women meet,
In shops and markets, all do greet,
No shame in't, nor impoliteness found,
For such is custom, and tradition bound.

So, Basha, heed my words of wisdom,
Train thy females, in our ways of pleasantry,
Lest they, in scorn, do shun the male clientele,
And thus, poor service, doth bring thee naught but woe.

For I, myself, have witnessed, twice,
Their scant regard, and sullen, troubled vice,
At Ste Catherine, Peel, a dame most dire,
And at Place Mont Royal, a woman, coy and shy,
Whose husband, bald, and friendly, didst seem,
Yet she, with scorn, didst give me change, most queer.

If she, in truth, doth loathe the male folk,
Then let her hide, in kitchen's darkest nook,
Where she, from men, may safely be apart,
And thus, no more, our custom, doth impart."

"I stepped into the joint, blinded by the garish floral seat covers. They were a real eyesore. But the rest of the place wasn't so bad - round tables, red lanterns, and some old-time Christmas tunes playing in the background. I was feeling pretty cheerful, waiting for my grub.

I went for the soup dumplings and fried string beans. Twenty bucks for two dishes, not too shabby.

The verdict? The dumplings were just okay, a bit overcooked. The green beans were tasty, but man, they were swimming in grease.

I might give this place another shot. Didn't exactly love what I had, but it wasn't all bad."

"Monica, the waitress, was a peach. Friendly and attentive, she made sure I had everything I needed. The burger was decent, nothing special, but it hit the spot. She took my coupon without a fuss and even pointed out when I missed the discount. Nice touch. The place was clean, but the country music was a bit much. Still, I'd go back for Monica's service alone."

"Hark, fair friends! I've visited this place twice now, and verily, 'tis a hit or miss affair. Despite the renovations of yore, the cafeteria feel doth linger still. The selection, middling at best, doth depend on the day. Alas, my previous visits hath left me unimpressed, but lo, I did return last week, for George Michael did play at the MGM, and thus, I gave the buffet another chance. By fortune, the steak station was open, and the savory scent of grilled meat did stir my appetite. The crab legs, too, were delectable and sweet. Yet, alack, a special event price of ten dollars more per person did make our visit costly. Forsooth, had we planned better, we might have gone to the Wynn instead."

"Moved from Chi-town, needed good sushi in Madison. Found it in a strip mall, next to a buck store. Surprised me, exceeded expectations. Been going for a year and a half, still worth recommending. Lunch special's a steal, two rolls and miso soup for cheap."

"A plentitude of confections, they do boast,
But, alas, their prices do border on the coast.
The servitors, not overly cordial, I fear,
Yet, verily, the gelato doth taste most dear."

"Upon mine visit to Goodtimes, I didst ponder giving it two stars, yet, being a stranger in this fair city, I knew not if 'twere consistent in its quality. 

Upon a Thursday eve, we didst venture forth to partake in their Goth night, "Carpe Noctem". Verily, the youthful spirits in the parking lot, and a hearse, didst indicate we had found the proper place. 

The dance floor, full of merry makers, didst leave us no choice but to seek the bar, where we didst find a courteous and swift tender of drinks. 

As my cup didst runneth over, I didst venture forth to dance, yet, alack, the floor, made of strange metal plates, didst not allow for a carefree frolic. 

A single visit doth not a judgment make, for the goth scene, a lifestyle 'tis, and not a fleeting fancy. Thus, I shall not be hasty in mine assessment, for the goth scene, like a slowly withering flower, doth struggle to survive in this fair city."

"Tried Elmer's with the kid last night. He got the Asada burrito, said it was good. I got the green beef hot burrito, tasty but messy. Had to use a fork and knife. Decent menu, cheap prices. Better than Guedo's, they take debit cards and have chips and salsa. Not the cleanest, definite hole in the wall. Smooshed food on the floor bugged me."

Hark, a friendly gathering at Drew's we did make,
My comrade and I, our hunger to partake.
The service, quite good, our needs they did fulfill,
A place of such ilk, Eat n Park or Denny's, their skill.

I, the farmer's omelette, didst order with glee,
My friend, the Corned Beef Hash, didst he choose to see.
A hearty dish, made from scratch, not from a can,
My comrade, in delight, didst give his nod and pan.

But alas, my omelette, a bit lacking, I fear,
For though 'twas filled with potatoes, no hash browns did appear.
A small slice of toast, a meager offering, indeed,
A platter, bare, save for the omelette, a lonely deed.

A pity, for a place of such renown,
To skimp on the fruit, a frown didst wear.
Yet still, a decent meal, we didst share,
And thus, our bellies, full and content, didst bear.

"Methinks the oxtail chili cheese fries didst taste but like a common chili cheese fries, save for the egg that sat upon it. Naught else didst make it stand apart. Yet, the fries themselves were quite good, in sooth.

Alack, I didst order the Kiki's burger, and my husband, the Miyagi Wagyu. But then, I didst change my mind, and we didst switch. I didst find the Miyagi burger to be more to mine liking, reminding me of the Manly burger at Umami. My husband, however, didst prefer the Kiki's. Thus, all didst work out well.

Three stars do I give this place, for its food is indeed most tasty. Alas, 'tis also quite costly. Moreover, 'tis the first place in Vegas where I didst find boba of decent quality. Long and hard didst I search for a place that could match what I had in California, and this place didst come near. The only drawback, alack, is the price, and the small portions. Nonetheless, I wouldst still dine here again."

"Hark, good sir! I didst say, ere now,  
That I wouldst revisit this place anon,  
And, verily, I do recommen-d it now,  
For, in sooth, the victuals were most sweet.  
But, alack! 'Tis not a meal for the thrifty,  
Forsooth, 'tis somewhat costly, I do confess."
