"A place of plenty, yet of little worth,
With service that doth vary in its birth.
A wall of stone, from Berlin's great fall,
Doth stand within the bathroom's narrow hall.

The food, a mix of good and not so fine,
Yet priced so low, it doth seem divine.
The prime rib, fair, but brisket, oh how vexing,
Cut wrong, it doth become a chewy, tasteless mess.

The bar, with brew of foam and golden hue,
Doth serve it up, for just a buck or two.
But watch, my friend, the service thou dost receive,
For 'tis a gamble, whether good or leave.

The space, with ceiling high and grand,
Doth bring to mind the skies of Columbia's land.
Yet, cleanliness and ambiance, do vary,
As service, hit or miss, doth often tarry.

My rating, based on three parts, doth stand,
At three, the average of my thoughts, so grand.
A place of value, for a group of friends,
But watch the service, lest thy meal doth end."

"Solid coffee joint in a decent neighborhood. Friendly gals workin' here, coffee's good, not the best I've had, but I prefer it over Starbucks. Love the Kona brew, always get stoked when I see it on the menu. My only gripe is they don't serve breakfast sandwiches. They got some local pastries and bagels, but I'm hankerin' for a bacon, egg, and cheese with my joe. And Sundays can get hectic, church crowd pours in, makin' it a tight squeeze in there. Just a heads up."

Hark, I've been a patron of this place for four years and more,
Where laughter doth flow like a river in springtime's prime.
In every nook and cranny, we've made merry and bright,
But one thing doth puzzle me, and that is the plight.

Of the bathrooms, I speak, which doth leave much to be desired,
With doors off their hinges and soap and towels uninspired.
And yet, despite this, there's still much to delight,
For games and music and the outdoor space doth ignite.

The staff, they doth shine with kindness and grace,
A true asset to this place, in this humble face.

"William Street's got some great spots, but The Melville ain't one of 'em. Place felt old, like it was stuck in the past. Three dudes smokin' outside, stinkin' up the joint. Drinks were overpriced, not as cool as Teuchters across the street. Food looked decent, though. Might come back for that."

"Lake Las Vegas, where I first met my fiancee. Never ate in the village before. Chose this joint for our one-year anniversary, patio right by the marina, great view of the lake. Patio was dirty, seats covered in bird shit. Food was damn good, steak cooked just right, still juicy. Service was decent, but our waitress disappeared most of the time. Cocktails? Horrible. Food was the only plus. Had to hunt down the waitress to pay the check."

"Prince-Arthur's got a bunch of overpriced joints, but Les Deux Gamins ain't one of 'em. Reasonable prices, no BYOW nonsense. Standard French grub - tartare, frite, lamb shank. Nothing fancy, but sometimes that's just what I need. Kitchen messed up our apps, but they made up for it with a free bottle of house wine. Not the best French spot in Montreal, but you could do a helluva lot worse."

"Hark, fair friends, I come from sunny Cali's shore,
Where sushi doth abound, and freshness doth implore.
But now, in Arizona's desert clime,
I seek a spot where sushi doth shine.

At Hiro's, I didst venture, hopes not high,
For in the landlocked West, fish doth not fly.
The ambiance, pleasant, doth my senses greet,
And sushi, though not Cali-fresh, doth meet.

But alas, the prices, they do climb,
As rent and fish costs, they do combine.
Bento boxes, too dear, doth make me frown,
For tempura, chicken, locally found.

The chicken, dry, doth leave me unsatisfied,
And organic, free-range, doth my mind divide.
A shame, for Hiro's, doth have potential grand,
But for now, I must seek elsewhere, in this land."

"Methinks these men of trade be personable indeed,
Their promptness in attending to my need, doth speak their creed.
A simple task, of electric sort, didst require my aid,
And lo, they found a space, within their busy schedule, to abide.
Alas, they could not solve the problem, but with grace,
Didst admit their limitations, and sent me to an electrician in haste.
He, in five short minutes, didst repair the fault,
And now, I find myself, with naught but praise, to utter.
A second task, of greater worth, didst require their skill,
But alas, their calendar, didst not allow, for two weeks to fulfill.
The sum they asked, for service rendered, was but a fraction,
Of what other craftsmen, didst demand, with no relation.
So here I'll stay, and wait, for their return,
For these men, of hand and heart, have earned my trust, and my concern."

"Food's alright, not great. Chicken's got flavor, but it's dry. BBQ's similar. Ribs are good, though. Sides are where it's at - all four we tried were tasty. But service? Not so much. They messed up our order and made us wait while others who ordered after us got theirs first. Guy at the register apologized and gave us a freebie. Might give 'em another shot, see if it was just a bad day."

"Went for dinner, sat outside. Noise from the road, but better than stuffy inside. Flat bread and garlic balls, good. Linguini and clams, small portion. Chicken marsala, flavorful. Shared food. Service slow. Not sure about returning."

"Alas, poor sushi! Ra, a place of wonder, where first I did partake of sushi's delight. But alack, how limited was my knowledge then! For since, in other halls of Hiro, I have found far greater joy. 

Yet still, if thou must go, take heed of this advice: the Las Vegas roll, a curious mix, and calamari, fried and wrapped in cream cheese, rice, and eel's sweet embrace, do taste divine. The rest, alas, doth pale in comparison. 

But fear not, for happy hour brings forth good cheer, and rolls, though small, do satisfy."
Urban Outfitters, same as all the others. Good clothes, some funny shit up front. Mandalay Place, shared parking with Mandalay Bay. That's it.

"A decent Chinese feast, akin to Panda's fare,  
In a food court, 'twas served with nary a care.  
The prices, alack, did seem a mite steep,  
For a bottle of brew, the cost did make me sleep.  
At the casino, 'tis better to buy thy ale,  
And play a game, while thou dost doth regale.  
A good place, indeed, for a quick repast,  
I shall return, but without the beer, at last."

"Haven't been to a dollar store in a bit. Forgot about the killer deals they got. Times are tough for everyone, so if you ain't lookin' in the right spot, you might miss out on somethin' good. This place got all sorts of stuff - plates, dishes, canned grub. You'll always find somethin', even if you ain't searchin'. Next time you're around, take a gander and see what you come across."

"Food's not bad, but there's always somethin' missin'. Order the pear salad, it's never right. Waitress ain't listenin', or I ask for blue cheese, get ranch instead. Little things like that, it's frustratin'. Want what I pay for, don't wanna get home and find my wings are wrong or my salad's messed up. But they're always real nice about it, fix their mistake and give me somethin' extra. Just wish it didn't happen so often."

"A secret gem, this eatery, tucked away in a corner strip mall, beside a high school, didst we find. Small, yet cozy, with booths, tables, and a sushi bar, 'twas run by an elderly couple, kind and true. Their bento box specials, we didst order for lunch, a feast fit for a king, with soup, egg roll, tempura vegetables, half a California roll, and white rice, all for a mere $6.95. My brother, he chose General Tao Chicken, while I, Mongolian Beef, both dishes, a delight. We shall return, to savor their bento boxes, and try their sushi and sashimi, of the finest sort. Spread the word, good people, that they may prosper, and their business flourish."

"A tidy shop, with naught but cleanliness within,
Deceives the eye, for greater space doth lie.
I ordered chicken noodles, served in bread,
A vessel cold, which needed heat to stir.
The broth did taste most wondrous, rich and deep,
Yet bread, alas, did lack in flavor, swift to soak.
A simple roll, with hole, did serve its purpose ill,
As bread bowl, it did not fulfill its duty well.
I noted too, a man, with hands unclean,
Did scratch his backside, then returned to cook.
Fair machines, with drinks of varied hue,
Did please my sight, yet could not make me stay.
My meal, though not most wretched, left me unsatisfied,
And thus, I shall seek sustenance elsewhere, ere long."
"Fare still as tasty as of yore, yet salads now diminished in size. The newfangled fashion doth mar the cozy ambiance."

"Beanscene, trusty joint. Year after year, same spot for me. Big mug of Americano, Metro in hand, leather booth for some quiet time. Staff's friendly, tunes are chill, not some corporate vibe. Never came for the grub, but a solid cup o' joe and a place to sit, Beanscene's my go-to."

941, a gay bar in the city, ranks middle-of-the-pack. Nothing terrible, nothing amazing. You wouldn't even know it's a gay bar unless you've done your research.

I visited 941 last weekend in the afternoon. Few people, comfortable atmosphere. Got a Mai Tai ($4.75, larger glass). Bartender was pleasant. Great experience!

A few months back, I came here with my boyfriend on a Friday night. Weird crowd, an unusual mix of people. Prices were steep for beer. Ordered a cranberry vodka, came in a small glass. 1/4 the liquid of my drink this weekend. Touch and go, so be prepared.

"Been wantin' to hit this joint for a while now. Building's got a certain somethin' that pulls me in. Finally made it out there during my last trip. 
Wait was a bitch for a table, couple hours plus, so we grabbed some grub in the food court and came back for some frozen hot chocolate at their outside window. 
Line was still long as hell, but we found out why when we finally got up there - one guy, doin' his best to keep up with the demand, but strugglin' nonetheless. 
Had a group of seven, so we shared a couple large frozen hot chocolates, which were good, but not worth the eight bucks."

"Methinks the tacos didst taste most wondrous fair,
In yonder tavern with an overly cute air.
Three of the meat sort didst I sample with glee,
Yet found the rice and beans to be somewhat lacking in zest, alack.

I shall return, but when my heart doth yearn
For Mexican fare, I know there be better choices to learn."

"A fair breakfast spot, yet overpriced, I fear. Better value doth Cora provide, and Cafe Orange, better fare. Yet, if thou art in the vicinity and hunger doth beset thee, 'tis not a terrible option, I do confess."

"Hark! I do frequent Outback, forsooth,
For there, my friends, doth lie a truth most fair and bright.
The victuals, they be good, the place, clean as a whistle,
And service, average or better, doth make my spirit light.
This very location, meeteth all requirements, by my troth.
Two of us didst dine at five o'clock, avoiding crowds most foul."

"Terrible Herbst, no more. Food's improved, service quicker. Ten-dollar deals, still a steal. Always preferred Cafe over Buffet, even when the latter was free. One issue remains: old waitresses, slow and forgetful. Need reminders, sometimes thrice, for condiments or extra settings."

"A fair theatre, with naught but pleasant memories doth lie,
Save for the throngs that gather, causing woe and strife.
And, alack, the cost, a princely sum indeed,
Yet, lo, the matinee, a paltry five dollars doth yield."
"Walmart's lines, they stretch on forever. Take an age to get in, out. Open more registers, we need."

"Chocolate shop didn't deliver. Expected more, got less. Atmosphere like Sephora, but no black gloves. Interesting flavors, but none worth buying in bulk. Sampled five, but still underwhelmed. Got some freebies, tortilla chips with Cayenne pepper. Different, but not delicious."

"High hopes for this joint, but it didn't quite deliver. Carne asada tacos, bomb. Shrimp tacos, meh. Service slow, 15 min for beer. Order mix-ups galore. Guy bringing food looked perturbed. Paying customers deserve correct orders. Give it another shot, maybe. Frozen margaritas, weak and overpriced. Not recommended."
"You work at Bally's? You look the part. This joint's not bad for a relaxing afternoon, and the drinks won't break the bank. But let's be real, the pool's nothing to write home about."
"Food's good. Drinks too. Fish on Fri's a bitch though. F&C's top-notch, fried or broiled. Mushrooms, fried, are aces."

"A humble Mexican eatery, hidden away,
I chanced upon, while seeking another place to dine.
The menu, brief and concise, held ten items dear,
And one bearded man, not quite Mexican, did shine.
He took the orders, cooked the food with care,
As I sat, wondering at this quaint place rare.
Hot sauces and seasonings, on each table laid,
Added zest to the meal, and made my taste buds swayed.
The decor, a mix of tiki hut and Mexican flair,
With Frida Kahlo art, and paper lanterns fair.
Mexican sweets and drinks, they also did provide,
A delightful surprise, my curiosity to abide.
Enchiladas with mole, I ordered, and they were grand,
The sauce, rich and flavorful, a true Mexican brand.
The kitchen, small and cozy, reheats, I do suppose,
But the food, delicious, left me in a state of repose.
A charming little spot, I shall return anon,
For more of their fare, and to savor each bite, ere long."

"Methinks 'twas two days and two trips to yonder spinning meat sticks of joy. Hark! I must confess, fair readers, that I had already summoned the dolmas when mine eyes didst peruse the reviews. Alas! Valerie's words didst paint a picture not so different from the truth. Dolmas, like pakora within Indian halls, are found in most establishments, yet their quality doth vary. Methinks the ones I received didst look the part, but alas! The scent of citrus was all that could be savored. Eight of them there were, and five and a half remained. Fearful was I of what might come next, but fate didst smile upon me. The gyro salad, fresh and plentiful, didst delight mine taste buds. Decent pita bread and sauces didst accompany it. My comrade, who didst order the gyro pita basket, didst also enjoy her repast. Verily, I shall return, forsooth, based on the entrees alone, and without the dolmas, 'twould have been a four."

"A plethora of plays have I witnessed, my friends,
But this one, alas, did fall beneath the mark.
Coordination lacking, errors did abound,
And rude, discourteous staff did further mar the ground.

A performer spoke at the start of the show,
"Flash photography, good people, is not allowed, you know."
The crowd, obedient, did turn off their flash,
Only to be met by an elderly woman, quite brash.
She snatched their cameras, with a scowl on her face,
"No photography, I say! Leave now, and save grace!"

Oh, how the gamble of watching did leave me in woe,
For mediocrity did reign, and poor staff did flow.
I pray, good people, save your coin, and flee,
For this show, alas, doth not merit your attention, 'tis a farce, indeed."

"This joint's got a great vibe, especially the bar. Food's alright, but that fried bologna sandwich is top-notch. Didn't give it five stars though, 'cause I went in there last Saturday, sat at the bar, and asked for a glass of white wine with my lunch. They didn't have any - not a drop. What kind of bar doesn't have white wine on a holiday weekend? They need to get their act together. No wonder the place was dead."

"Fried chicken salad, good choice. But why no grilled option? Fried chicken strips on a salad, counterproductive. Bartender/waitress, attentive. Sun, blinding like gamma rays. Asked her to shut the blind, sun reflecting off windshield, boring a hole in my face. She shut all blinds but one, supernova still shining through."
"Sports bar with a twist. Patio's big, on the greenbelt. Sandwiches come with a salad option, swap bread for lettuce. Specials galore, birthday perks too. Big place, lots of TVs."
"Food's good, but service could've been tighter. Get the dumplings, they're tops. Margaritas pack a punch, so pace yourself."

"O'er-rated, say I, this place doth be,
Pabellon, a wondrous sight to see,
Rice, dry as dust, doth leave me unsatisfied,
Prices, too steep, for such scant fare provided.
Expectations high, alas, not met,
Meh, a feeling of disappointment doth beget."

In sooth, a wondrous sight didst greet mine eyes,
A multitude of folk, in haste and throng,
Didst pace the floors of yonder Casino's halls,
Their faces bright with hope, their spirits strong.

The staff, kind-hearted souls, didst tend to our needs,
With smiles and courtesy, they didst dispense their deeds.
But alas, dear friend, the drinks they didst sell,
Were not the cheapest, nor the easiest to tell.

"Hark! 'Tis Walgreens, a place most plain,
Three stars, for naught but sameness doth remain.
Alack! I wish I could bestow four stars,
If they but sold wine and beer, perchance then 'twould be a cause for cheer."
"Methinks 'tis fair, though not the best, yet far from base. Have not been let down, and thus do dine here once a week. The Thai basil doth please my taste, as doth the steak salad."

"Place ain't bad, but service needs work. Sat fourth at lunch, took forty minutes for two half-and-half orders. Forty minutes! Wildflower or Paradise Bakery, you gotta be kiddin' me. Service good though, kept drinks full, apologized for wait. Food's alright, my salad had too many onions, girlfriend's was good. Paninis, nothing special. Go back with friends for wine, maybe. Won't go back for quick lunch."

"A Vegas dining spot, traditional in its ways,
With naught o'er the top, yet pleasant still,
The renovated space, once a cafe, now doth sway,
In tropical hues, with beachy vibes that chill.

Indoor or out, thy seat thou mayst choose,
And view the pool's waterfall, a sight to muse,
The staff, friendly, and the fare, most fine,
A bit pricier, true, yet worth each coin divine.

The dishes, tasty, with generous portions too,
So, pretty, pretty, this eatery anew."

"Dillard's, just okay. Bought a few dresses, tops. Sales associates? Pushy or MIA. Accessories department, better. Helpful. Return policy, strict. Manager, cool. Store credit, nice. Selection's good. Back again, sure. Waiting for that wow service, still."

"Falafel, like sand between your teeth. Crispy outside, reminiscent of beach days when sand found its way into every crevice. Falafel plate, rice, salad, pita, but no hummus, no respite from the dryness. Tahini, a measly ramekin, not enough to quench the thirst. Stick with the sandwich, my friend, or another value meal. No need for parched mouth at a Greek pita joint. Overpriced too, near $12 for a plate with soda, $16-17 with hummus, for one person."

"Food, top-notch. Service, subpar. Sat at the bar, still waited. Bartender, a heavyset fella, stuck to his corner like glue. Walked to the sports bar, grabbed a cold one. Six-thirty on a Saturday, and this guy still hadn't noticed us. Pathetic."

"Hark! A Milwaukeean through and through, I stayed at Wynn, and thus didst venture to the in-house Bartolotta's, unaware of its origin in my fair city. Alas, I didst not partake in the full experience, forsooth, for I do not consume seafood, which doth arrive fresh daily from the Mediterranean. Aye, 'tis a bit absurd, yet understandable, given the arid environs.

Thus, I didst opt for pasta dishes and pancetta. Verily, the pancetta was tough and fatty, but I didst expect such. The sheep's milk ravioli, however, didst delight mine taste buds. The spaghetti with ragu? Not so much, alack.

In conclusion, methinks the price didst outweigh the quality, but mayhap 'twas the ambiance that didst lack. Forsooth, they should transport Bartolotta's Lake Park Bistro from Milwaukee and plant it within the Wynn, anon. In my humble opinion, 'twould be an improvement, by the stars!"
"June, I wrote a review, unsatisfactory. Company damaged our gazebo, fallen palm tree branches. Agreement reached, they compensated, won't happen again. Good customer service, issue resolved."

In fair Edinburgh, where we didst honeymoon,
Our first full day began with breakfast sought,
To give us strength for all the sightseeing we'd do.
Down to the Grassmarket, from our hotel, anon,
We walked, and searched for a place to dine,
Wherefore we chose Cafe Jacques, most thronged, no doubt.
A sign of quality, the crowd doth make it out.

We squeezed inside, the space was small, indeed,
And found a seat, my love and I, in need.
I had the English breakfast, he the American,
The coffee, hot, my jetlagged soul to redeem.
Alas, I burned my mouth, in haste, I did confess,
For two days more, my tongue did suffer, alack.

The waiter, strange, our request to fulfill,
Two tall glasses of milk, for my love, did bring.
Is this an American custom, pray tell?
I rated three stars, for this place, 'twas just fine,
And started well our day in fair Edinburgh, divine.

"This joint serves up some top-notch corned beef hash, but my last visit was marred by some poor service. I arrived at 2:15 pm, and while the neon open sign was still lit up, I was informed that they closed at 2 pm. A server named Cindy said she checked with the kitchen and her boss, and they could still accommodate us. She was friendly throughout our meal, but another server, Carol, made a big stink about us being seated late. She complained loudly and made us feel unwelcome. The grub was great, but Carol's attitude left a bad taste. If the boss says it's okay, then it's okay. And if it's such a big deal, maybe turn off the open sign at 2 pm. That's all I'm sayin'."

"We swung by this joint on a Friday arvo, en route to Vegas. No line, sweet. Sat by the windows, checkin' out the strip. Food was a ways off, but we needed the exercise anyways. 

Started with the salad bar, worked our way through the buffet. Variety was top-notch, lots of action stations. Flavors were meh, tho. Beet salad was bangin', everything else was just okay. Unlimited beer and wine was cool, root beer on tap was tasty too. Service was alright, but our dirty plates sat around a bit too long. 

Wouldn't mind tryin' other spots before comin' back here. $16 for lunch was a decent deal, variety-wise."

Yester-morn, I had occasion to meet a client from the north,
And visit other customers in Deer Valley, by the south.
There be few eateries in the area, open early,
Save for this place, where I didst decide to have my fill.

The owner, a gruff man, yet friendly, doth run the show,
And though his prices be higher, the food doth flow.
A Max burrito, with egg, potato, cheese, and meat,
Didst satisfy my hunger, and left me feeling neat.

The place, though small, doth have a steady stream of guests,
And though the parking lot doth fill, 'tis but a test.
For I shall return, to partake of their fare,
For it doth please mine taste buds, and the service doth share.

"Hark! All ye who seek knowledge of China Stars,
In town there be three, and confusion doth reign.
But fear not, fair reader, for I shall make clear,
The difference between them, and end all doubt and fear.

Two China Stars there be, on Murray Ave,
One at 4219, in Greenfield, the other, 1900,
In Squirrel Hill, at Pacific Ring's old site.
The first, no kin to North Hills' China Star,
Doth serve standard American-Chinese fare,
While the second, affiliated, doth offer traditional Chinese cuisine,
A guide to China Stars, for all to share.

Now, I, myself, have ordered from the first,
And found their fried, greasy Chinese food to be the best.
For cheap takeout, China Star doth reign supreme,
So, next time thou hast a craving, give them a call, and thou shalt see."

"Fair cooked victuals they serve, yet ingredients of low degree. A pleasant sight doth the decor provide, but service, alas! doth leave much to be desired. Fried bananas, a dish most wondrous, my heart doth sing with joy at its mere mention!"
"Fish 'n' chips, Irish grub. Live music, good bands. Happy hour, hangouts. Friendly staff. U2 tribute act, Joshua Tree. That's the place."

"Verily, this place doth please mine eyes, yet doth it pale in comparison to that most noble room, the Foundation Room, which sitteth atop yon hotel.  The melodies here were but passable, and the ambiance, though somewhat neat, doth not compare to the Foundation Room's grand club within Mandalay Bay."

"Monte Carlo's seen better days. Once a swanky joint, now it's showing its age. -5 Bar ain't the best. Renovations underway, maybe it'll shape up. Central location, but I'd rather splurge on a newer spot."

"Rugged Wearhouse, I love it. This one's organized, too. Three stars, though. Bought some boots for twenty-five bucks. Not bad. But the tag, still on 'em, said twenty. Department store, selling 'em for more than they're worth. Annoying."

"Beckett's Table, nice joint. Liked the vibe, the setup, the glasses, the tables. Food? Not so much. Bacon cheddar biscuits, good. Apple honey butter, too hard, couldn't spread it. Green chile pork stew, osso buco, nothing special. Chocolate dipped bacon s'mores, now that was good. Homemade peanut butter, excellent. A pleasant surprise."

"Feelin' poorly after chowin' down on some grub at this joint. Service was lackin', but they had a decent selection of veggie options, as per usual. Pricey, though. And let me tell you, they were fresh out of them tasty spring rolls when I swung by. Not exactly fillin', neither."

"Fresh fare and prime locale, yet portions small they be.

LYFE Kitchen, near Whole Foods, our steps didst lead,
For a pre-shopping snack, we didst decide and feed.
I, vegan thai curry, and hibiscus tea didst choose,
My love, grass-fed burger, and cafe mocha, didst voice.

Drinks, to die for, his mocha, energizing,
My tea, hibiscus, flavorful, refreshing, didst find.
Meals, decent flavor, small portions, a sight,
My curry, spicy, wheatberries and tofu, lacking in might.
His burger, good, hickory flavor, a delight,
But still, hungry, we didst feel, and wished for more bite.

Questions, two, I didst ponder, tofu organic?
Beef, grass-fed, or conventional, a thought didst engender.
If not, then why, to a health-conscious place,
Eat meat and soy, grown with haste, without grace?

Return, we may, to try other dishes, anon,
But next time, hunger, we shall not be upon."

"Fair sir, I must confess, the victuals here have ne'er impressed me much. Overpriced, they be, for the meagre dishes they proffer. But, verily, 'tis a pleasant place to partake of potables and light repast - upon the patio, by the fountain's gentle flow. Their small dishes are passable, and reasonably priced, and the atmosphere, most agreeable. I do enjoy bringing visitors hither, when they come to call upon me. And, should they still have hunger pangs, we shall repair to Los Sombreros for a hearty feast!"

"Tis like Samurai Sam's, but not so grand,
The prices fair, the portions of a decent land,
But alas, the steak, too thin it doth seem,
And though the sauce be passable, 'tis not my cream.
I do prefer a more soy-salty taste,
Yet still, they give a small container to haste."

"Fare thee well, dear gourmand! Hark, what news I bring, of culinary delights most wondrous! In this fair city, there be a place, where food doth reign supreme, a veritable feast for thine eyes and taste buds. Alas, 'tis true, the cost doth rise, yet fear not, for 'tis worth each penny spent, I do aver. Their cable cars, a sweet delight, doth make thy mouth to water, and leave thee in a state of blissful satisfaction. And should thou seek a meal most fortifying, to start thy day aright, then to the Bellagio thou shouldst repair, where breakfast doth await, a spread most generous and fair. Farewell, and may thy hunger be appeased!"

"Thin Crust? More like Thin Trash. Awful. Should be taken off the menu. Ordered Sausage and Bacon, heard it was better than Rosati's and Oregano's. Lie. Couldn't even bite through the cardboard crust. Disgusting. Stick with the Butter Crust Deep Dish. That's good. Leave the Thin Crust in the dumpster where it belongs."

"Thus, with three stars, my review doth begin. A first-time visitor, I, to Panera's den, For sandwiches, a change from subs, I didst choose. 'Tis newly opened, near my humble abode, And so, I thought, why not give it a go?\n\nThe service, swift and kind, at the counter, didst shine, But waiting, long, for takeout, didst seem like a crime. Yet, understanding, came, when I didst see, Folk, eating in, with orders, placed before me. Homeward, I brought the sandwiches, with glee, And found them, quite good, indeed, they were. My wife, her Cuban chicken panini, didst enjoy, And I, the Steak and white cheddar, didst employ. A fair kick, from the horseradish, didst bring cheer. Chips, in small bags, for each, we didst receive, And the order, neatly packaged, in cardboard boxes, didst conceal. A quibble, I didst find, with no way to discern, Which sandwich, which, without undressing the bread. A suggestion, to HQ, I didst send, And they, didst reply, with thanks, and a vow to amend. Again, I shall return, and next time, I shall dine, In the pleasant room, or outdoors, when cooler, the climate doth become."
"No dessert. Had brunch instead. POTATO PANCAKES WERE WEAK. Go back? Try dessert. Or sit at bar. Late in day."

"Alas, the tequila selection doth leave much to be desired,
And errors on the menu do abound.
Fare was passable, but service did prove a trial,
And 'twas not a bustling crowd that doth impede.

In sooth, the spirits of old Mexico do seem to fade,
And in their stead, a mediocrity doth reign.
Alack, for those who sought a festive mood,
Their hopes were dashed upon the rocks of disdain.

Yet still, the kitchen doth produce some worthy dishes,
Though served with little grace or finesse.
And he who doth attend thee, doth perform his duties,
With a countenance that doth belie his distress.

So if thou art in search of cheer and jollity,
Best seek it elsewhere, for here 'tis scant.
But should thy hunger pangs o'ertake thee,
Then peradventure, a meal mayhap shall suffice."

"Spent a night here this week. Dusty furniture, even the couch. Dirty coffee maker, filthy hair dryer. Couldn't get a detailed room service receipt or a receipt for my stay emailed to me. Feels like they opened the hotel before they were ready. Location is the only thing going for it. For work trips, try the HGV on the strip. Well-maintained and great customer service."

"Rehab burger, a dive bar of sorts, yet with an air of coolness doth it possess. A place where one may find solace in drinks of great value, and burgers of renown. Alas, my experience didst leave much to be desired. The Hangover burger, with sweet potato tots, didst fail to impress. A mistake in cooking, no doubt, for I requested it medium rare, and received it well done. Methinks 'twill not be worth mine while to return and give it another chance, for Scottsdale doth boast of better burger joints in plenty."

"Methinks 'tis a bit pricey, yet still a merry spot,
Where young ones may express their artful thought.
The staff, in general, doth seem kind and apt,
Though at times, the younger maidens did converse,
In their own world, leaving work to be desired.
But fear not, for their turnaround is quite fast,
A mere few days, and thy piece shall be ready at last."

"Food's good, location's great, rooftop patio's sweet. But the drink prices? Outrageous. Like, strip club or upscale bar prices. Not cool. I've worked in bars, I know how it works. These prices ain't gonna fly. People are already talking, saying they'll stick to soda or tea. Come on, guys. Don't try to recoup your investment in one month. Price 'em reasonable and you'll do just fine."

"Taqueria Express, that's what the sign says. It's a small taco stand, carved out of a fruit market west of Woodlands on Albemarle. Order at the window, kitchen's hot and cramped. Simple food, quick and good. Surprisingly big menu, tacos, quesadillas, burritos, no Salvadorean or Ecuadorian dishes though. Might be a language barrier if you don't speak Spanish.

I'm a sucker for tortas, so that's what I got. It was good, a bit pricey ($6.50 for eggs and cheese) but one of the best I've had in Charlotte. Soft, sweet bread, Monterey Jack cheese, shredded lettuce, some jalapenos. Messy to eat, but who cares? Not the best torta, but still worth a visit."

"A humble donut shoppe, neat and clean,
Open round the clock, with Subway seen.
Fresh pastries filled the shelves, devils food cake,
Moist, chocolatey, a delight to partake.
Glazed donuts, too, with flavors so bright,
Better than Dunkin' or Krispy Kreme's blight.
Winchell's, a cut above, a decent sight,
Selection fair, a satisfying bite."

"Outback's always been my jam. For a chain joint, they do a damn good job. I usually park myself at the bar, and the bartenders are always friendly and on point. Last week, I decided to grab some grub to go. Ordered salmon, broccoli, and a sweet potato. The salmon and broccoli were on point - cooked just right and seasoned like a pro. But that sweet potato? Overcooked to hell. Like they stuck it in the oven for months. Just kidding, but that spud was done for."

"We hit up City Center for a late dinner before clubbing. Chose Julian Serrano 'cause they had veggie options. Was a bit let down, truth be told. Ordered mushroom soup, Tortilla Espanola, Shrimp Ceviche, chicken skewers, eggplant/peppers, mixed Paella (lobster, chorizo, chicken). Paella was alright, but for $40, I expected more. Other dishes were just okay. Decor was cool, service was top-notch, menu and wine list looked great...but let's be real, I've had way better tapas at my go-to spot in SF, for a fraction of the price. Not exactly eager to come back."

"Hark! A gathering of friends and colleagues didst doth grace this establishment on the eve of mine own birthday. And verily, the ambiance didst please mine eyes and heart, for it was filled with mirth and gaiety. Thus, I didst return anon, with friends in tow, to partake in the happy hour revelry. 

Ah, but alas! The cost, it didst border on the exorbitant, yet the service, it was most excellent, courtesy of our server, a maiden fair and kind, with robotic decorations upon her skin. Her name, I didst not catch, but her demeanor, it was most pleasant and accommodating. 

Now, as for the victuals, they were, in sooth, quite satisfactory. The Polynesian chicken sandwich, it didst delight mine taste buds, accompanied by the sweet potato fries, which were cooked to perfection. But lo! The drinks, they were the true stars of the evening's entertainment! Most especially, the Scorpion bowl, which I didst find most intriguing and worth another visit, perchance with a larger group of merrymakers."

"Methought the establishment's arrangement was pleasing,
The beverages did flow, and servants were cheerful.
But, alack! The manager, bald and with a moon boot on,
Didst possess an air of haughtiness, most rude.
Even our waitress didst concur, 'twas plain to see,
That he was naught but a knave, with manners none too fine.
Save for him, I wouldst return, and gladly pay,
For prices fair, and victuals that didst pass muster.
I only sampled hors d'oeuvres, and found them just so-so,
Yet still, I wouldst give the place another chance, anon."
"Diner grub, not bad. Expectations, meet 'em and you'll be swell. Spanish omelet, damn tasty. Service, slow, but who's counting?"

"Methinks 'tis a fair place indeed, where one may watch a game with glee.  The staff doth seem to hold a care for those who enter in.  Aye, the menu doth please mine eyes, and food, it doth taste of sweetness.  But, alas! The last few times I chanced to visit, 'twas cold, so very cold, that which they brought to mine table.  Oh, how I do detest a meal that doth lack warmth!"

"A hearty meal didst First Timer devour,
With prices fair, the victuals didst please.
The tavern's charm didst lie in its decor,
And emptiness didst make our visit ease.

Alas, the youthful servers, cold and grey,
Didst lack the warmth of a kindly way.
A smile or greeting, sincere and bright,
Might make this place a true delight."
"Fried food, flavorful but not spicy. Decent spot for lunch, I'd return."

I showed up 15 minutes 'fore closing, waited 10 for my bird. Place is tiny, pictures ain't lying. Chicken was good, but best when it's hot. A bit too salty, like some folks said. Liked the hot sauce, though. Lady was real nice, gave us a free 2-liter and some extra chicken 'cause they were closin' up shop. Didn't have no red velvet pancakes, but that's okay, got another Groupon to use. Heard about Flavor Flav's joint in Clinton, Iowa, didn't last a year. Hope this one does better. It's all right, but without Flavor Flav, dunno if it'd make it. Two stars, plus one 'cause it's Flavor Flav.

"Hark, a strange occurrence doth befall me,
In a restaurant, with a companion, did I see,
Yelp, the app of reviews, didst reveal,
Two stars, a rating most foul and unseemly.

The service, odd it was, and hard to explain,
The host, his words, didst we not comprehend,
And later, my friend, his soup didst receive,
Before mine, a full ten minutes, didst he relieve.

His soup, it seemed, didst please him well,
But mine, a duck meat soup, didst not swell,
The noodles, undercooked, they were, alas,
And green, salty stuff, didst float within the broth,
A questionable sight, indeed, it was.

And pricey, too, the place didst prove,
Caesar's Palace, a name of note, didst groove,
So out we went, to seek another spot,
For lunch, a better choice, didst seem to be not."

Russ proposed My Florist for lunch, being nearby. I countered, "I frequent My Florist at night and spotted a quaint lunch spot across the street, eager to give it a try. Let's go there." It sufficed for a speedy lunch and served as a respite from fast food. I opted for the chicken feta pita, which was unremarkable. The venue's aesthetic appealed to me more than the cuisine. A plus for effective marketing and design; now, if only they'd diversify their offerings.

"Rainy Sunday brunch. Nice interior. Excellent service. Coffee, meh. Fresh ingredients, good technique, but flavors lacking. Crepe, cooked well, but cold inside. Waitress comped our coffee. Didn't finish my breakfast. Maybe try again for better flavors."

"Pink's had me under its spell, no doubt. \n\nWe rolled in, famished, on the heels of glowing reviews. Bravery got the better of me, so I went for the Chili Cheese hot dog burrito - two dogs, chili, cheese, all wrapped up nice and tight. It did the job, alright. But, damn, the aftermath. My gut was in shambles. Maybe next time, I'll stick to the plain Jane dog."

"Hark! We didst move from Chicago's chill embrace
To Scottsdale's sun-kissed, arid space.
And here, within these walls of rice and sea,
Didst seek succor from the summer's heat.

Alas, my hopes were high, too high, methinks,
For though the Sapporo didst quench my thirst,
The sushi, fine though it may be, didst lack
That je ne sais quoi, that certain zest.

A roll with fried fish skin, a curious treat,
Didst please my taste, but couldst not lift
This place to heights of culinary bliss,
Nay, 'twas but decent, nothing more, alas.

So shall I return? Aye, verily,
But not with fervor, nor with haste,
For though 'twas good, 'twas not divine,
And other sushi joints may yet entice."

"I spent four days in Vegas, Thursday to Sunday. Can't gripe about the price, got it through an agency, half off what I saw online. Nice spot, five-star hotel smack dab in the middle of the strip. Casino, same rating. Pro dealers, plenty of games. Food? Two stars. No Starbucks, no 24/7 grub. Had to trek to Bally's for a slice or Subway at 3 am. Room? Two and a half stars. Bed, springy and cheap. Not comfy. TV, away from the bed, not convenient. Clean though, felt luxurious. Good value for a strip hotel. Been to Vegas many times, but for a first-timer, this place would be great."

"Hark, good sir! I do protest, thy venue doth lack,
In charm and grace, it doth not hold a candle,
To other eateries, where one doth pay,
A similar sum, for finer fare, I pray.

The lobster, twain, we didst order, 'tis true,
And found it tasty, I must needs avow,
But, alas! The surroundings, they didst grieve,
A shopping mall, most unbecoming, doth leave.

The decor, akin to a peddler's stall,
Didst little justice to thy culinary skill,
And for the price, I say, 'twas far too steep,
For such a humble abode, so plain and cheap.

My garb, it didst bespeak a night of fun,
Yet, here, amidst the cartoonish walls, I've none,
Fit for a king, my attire, I do confess,
Yet, here, 'twas naught but mockery and mess.

Peanut shells, they didst not lie upon the ground,
Yet, still, the ambiance, it didst lack, profound,
A finer establishment, I wouldst advise,
For such a sum, a better choice, I do devise."

"Hiking, rafting, running - that's my jam. But Victory Lanes? Not my cup of tea. Karts, speed, and circles - underwhelming experience. Might give it another shot with friends, though. Location's easy to find, but use GPS to be sure. Bought a members pass, staff's friendly, and bathrooms are decent, but not great for changing. Suites look sharp, add to the excitement."

"Hark, good sir! Thou seekest sustenance and drink? 
Fear not, for Mandalay Bay doth provide, 
Ale, beer, and pub fare, to thy heart's desire. 
Thy ex, a man of taste, doth swear by shepherd's pie, 
So, try it thou must, ere thou doth say goodbye."

"Methinks my mem'ry doth fail me, fair friends,
For when I first didst step within these walls,
I know not if I had a merry time or no.
Yet, verily, I did return anon,
And found the place not half so bad, I swear.
In sooth, the barkeepers didst move with speed,
But the music, by the gods, didst make my heart sing.
Aye, 'tis a decent spot, if thou canst gain entry free.
Alas, not my first choice in this city of sin.
But, an it please thee, take my humble word,
If thou canst enter cheaply, 'tis a place to be."

"My comrade and I, in pursuit of the finest steak in the land, doth venture to diverse establishments of repute. Our latest sojourn, to Fleming's, didst fall short of my expectations. 

Tales of their happy hour, with deals most fair, didst reach mine ears, and indeed, the choices were plentiful and the service, good. A fine selection of wines, at prices reasonable, didst also catch mine eye. 

But alas, the steak, mine heart's desire, didst fail to impress. Overcooked, it was, and not properly trimmed, a filet, it didst seem. The sides, forgettable, they were."

"A fine establishment for a swift and affordable repast. For those unfamiliar with Filipino cuisine, mayhap begin with the barbecue and pancit, a pair of delectable dishes that shall surely please thy taste. Should thou wish to venture further, sample the dinuguan, a savory broth made with blood, or the balut, an egg most curiously fertilized. Verily, my own dam makes a finer dinuguan and pancit, but this place doth serve its purpose well, and at a fair price, too. Alas, I do suggest taking thy meal away, lest the woeful dramas they play upon their televisions doth dampen thy appetite with their incessant sobbing."

"Service? Forget it. Waitstaff don't know how to smile. But who cares? Food's too good. Get the shredded pork pan fried noodles, 'Hong Kong Style,' for lunch. Salt and pepper shrimp, heads on, are a close second. Rich, man. And the salt fish and chicken fried rice? Salty, but damn good. Don't bother with the usual Americanized crap. These are the real deals."

In sooth, the fishery department didst impress,
With helpful folk, and little time to guess.
But one, named Tyler, doth require some schooling,
In art of serving customers with cooling.

"Hark, the service here, 'tis fair,
Depending on the time of day, thou shalt declare.
In mornings, first, a draught we did receive,
To cure our hangovers, a merry conceit.

On Saturdays and Sundays, I didst order forth,
Chicken Fried Steak, a dish of noble worth.
'Twas good, and anywhere I roam,
If chicken fried steak be on the menu, I'll make it known.

This place did not disappoint, my friends,
For all at my table, save one, didst partake.
And after tasting, they didst agree,
'Twas a wise choice, indeed, a verity.

But alas, the coffee shake, a woeful tale,
Didst not taste of coffee, a sorry fail.
Jack in the Box, a better shake doth make,
A truth, a truth, a kingdom for a shake!

Yet still, I shall return, forsooth,
To this place, or Pink Taco, both of which are good.
A different tale, another time,
Pink Taco, a worthy feast, sublime."

"Methinks I long to cherish thee, dear Daily Dose,
In thy prime location, convenient for my needs.
Yet, alack! My heart doth falter, for each time I doth step within thy halls,
I find myself lost in thought, unable to choose from thy vast array of delectable dishes.
My spirit doth wane, and I settle for a humble omelette or toast,
A choice most plain, and lacking in zest.
I shall continue my quest, yet fear my hopes doth dwindle with each passing day."

"Hark! I've been to this place afore,
And found the drinks to be but poor.
The service, though, was quite divine,
But alas! The cocktails lacked that certain shine.
I tried a few, but they did not impress,
And so I had to order more, to excess.
Forsooth! The drinks did taste well,
But oh! The alcohol content, it did dwindle and fell."
"Tiny airport, GSP layover. Planes too small, seats cramped. Uncomfortable for a tall man like me. Sticking to bigger airports next time."

"I was twelve when my sister got her first apartment. She took me to Pier 1 and I was in awe. It was like a dream world, full of Director chairs, lava lamps, and bamboo vases with baby's breath. I wished I could replace my Charlie's Angels bedroom theme with all this cool stuff. But we were there for my sister, and twenty-five years later, Pier 1 still has that same charm. Sure, they've expanded and the prices have gone up, but the quality doesn't quite match the cost. I mean, a balsa wood nightstand? Not exactly sturdy. But those cute little plates with palm trees? Nice touch. Just be careful not to drink too many pre-shopping cocktails or you might end up breaking something. Like a lamp. Or something."

"Went there last night, around 9:30. Place was hoppin'. Decor was swell, utilized the space well. Had the sliders, they were good. Sat at the bar, bartender came up, asked my husband if he wanted a drink, ignored me. Husband got a beer he didn't ask for. Two other bartenders were friendly, knew their stuff. First bartender continued to ignore us, didn't refill our drinks, took 20 minutes to check on us after hitting the cash out button. Fourth bartender was good at clearing plates and glasses, didn't ask if we needed anything else. Might give 'em another shot, they're new."

"This Whole Foods, the smallest of the three, don't lack in selection or variety. Not my go-to, but I dig the vibe, cozy in its smaller space. Produce is looking good, nopales and all, well-stocked and tidy. Meat counter's a bit small, but deli, salad bar, prepared foods, they're on par with the others. All things considered, not bad."

"Mini golf with a twist. Drunk people. That's the ticket. After a boozy brunch at DW, we stumbled upon this place. Anthony M., the generous host, treated us to a round of mini golf. And what a round it was! The name Putt Park suits it well, as it's more of a putting course than a mini golf. But hey, who needs obstacles when you've got a good buzz going? We tried to play a serious game, but let's face it, we were all feeling pretty silly. It took all of us working together to get the ball in sometimes. And that, my friends, is the definition of bonding. For $8.50, it's not a bad deal. Just don't expect any lost balls down a hole. And if you're looking for a good time, come here after a few drinks. Trust me, it'll be a blast."

"Upon this night, my fair companion and I did partake
In culinary delights, at yonder tavern's bar,
Wherein the bartender, with mirth and glee, did play
The host, and served us with most excellent fare.
A pizza, fresh from oven's heat, we did share,
And dumplings, savory, with duck meat within,
Did please our taste buds, and we did exclaim,
'Tis a fine establishment, this place doth win.
Akin to Cheesecake Factory, in splendor doth it shine."

"Alack, the spread they lay before us now,
So bountiful, yet with a tainted hue.
For though the feast be grand, 'tis true,
They've cut the choices, and we must wait anew.

Once, we had a choice of crustaceans fine,
But now, alas, they've pared it down to one line.
And wait we must, for up to fifteen minutes more,
Just to receive our platter, and then we're sore.

A pox upon their house, for trying to save a coin,
By making us wait, and suffer thus, in vain.
This service, once great, now doth leave us cold,
And two stars, I fear, is all they'll hold."

"Lobster pot pie, fabulous. Service, lacking. Waiter vanished for half an hour. Missed opportunity for drink sales. Pot pie's a signature dish, but they should set better expectations on delivery time. Maybe if we were young women instead of middle-aged men, we'd have gotten more attention."

"Hark, what news is this? A meal most fair,
At yonder eatery, didst I partake.
A roast beef sandwich, of tender care,
Didst please mine taste, with juices rare.
The others, at my table, didst delight,
In Thai salad, of flavors so bright.
'Twas vast, a feast for sore eyes,
And left them all, in sweet surprise.
Another, of our merry band,
Didst choose the Mahi, so fresh and grand.
The servers, with smiles so wide,
Didst tend to us, with gentle pride.
I say, good sirs, give it a try,
For though 'twas not of little cost,
'Twas worth each penny, I do boast."

"Verily, I must confess, this place doth leave me in a state of utter disappointment. Forsooth, I had hoped to find a culinary haven, a place where I might satiate my hunger for a most excellent burger. Alas, 'twas not meant to be. The service, indeed, was most pleasant, the maidens friendly and helpful. But, alack, the victuals, they did not meet my expectations. I ordered the Pestorica, a burger with relish, pesto, and mozzarella, and a side of onion rings with dips. The burger, when it arrived, was a feast for mine eyes, but, alas, 'twas too thin, lacking in substance and seasoning. The onion rings, too, did not please mine taste, for they were crumbly and greasy, not battered as I had hoped. In sooth, the oreo milk shake was the sole redeeming feature of my visit. Methinks this place hath potential, but, for now, they do fail to meet mine expectations."

Saturday morning, I hit the brunch spot at 11am. Line wasn't too bad. Noticed they got them self-pay kiosks now. Good call when the line's long.

Omelette station's where it's at. Got two eggs over easy. Way better than them powdered eggs for scrambled. Other breakfast joint had potatoes and Portuguese sausage.

Found the salmon lox, capers, onion, and made a killer croissant sandwich. No bagels though. Finished off with some fresh fruit and Greek yogurt.

A lot of stuff looks good, but my buddies said otherwise. No high-end items like prime rib, crab legs, or lamb. Solid 2.5 or 3 stars, but watch what you eat and you'll enjoy your meal without feeling like a slug afterwards.

"Methinks I fail to comprehend this establishment. I perceive their aim, yet the victuals do not quite measure up to the lofty standards of other esteemed steakhouses in this fair city. The cost, my good sir, doth border on the exorbitant. Methinks 'tis naught but a ruse to puff up the egos of those who partake in games of chance, deceiving them into believing they receive a meal worth three hundred golden coins. Alas, the fare doth not compare to that of Cut, Delmonicos, or Del Frisco. If thou seekest an atmosphere reminiscent of days of yore, mayhap a visit to Hugos, nestled within the Four Queens, shall satiate thy craving. There, the cuisine doth please, possessing a similar aura, yet at a fraction of the cost."
"Paradise, loudest joint I've been to. Meetings? Forget it. But service? Top-notch."

"Tuesday night, we picked this spot 'cause it was close to the Luxor, where we had tickets for a show.  Hostess gave us some serious attitude, like we were inconveniencing her or something.  No wait, but we sat at the bar 'cause we wanted quick service.  Blonde chick with long hair comes over, tells us we're at a dining table, and makes us wait again.  Ten minutes later, she takes us back to the same damn table.  What a joke.  Menu gets tossed on the table like we're an afterthought.  Server saves the day, though.  Good guy, hustles hard.  Busser's on it too.  Food's decent, not amazing.  Steak quesadilla and steak tacos with bacon hit the spot."

"Hark, good sir or madam, if thou seek'st a place
To sate thy hunger and behold a wondrous sight,
Then stop thou must at The Mad Greek, 'tis a sight most fair,
With two locations, one near Death Valley's gate,
And one near Las Vegas', where the sun doth shine bright.

'Tis a popular spot, so expect a crowd,
But fear not, for the fare is worth the wait,
The falafel balls, they doth taste most sweet,
And the creamy Tahini sauce, doth complement the treat.

The exterior, adorned with Roman statues grand,
Doth make it hard to miss, as thou dost pass by the land,
And within, a Greek cafeteria doth await,
With much seating space, and people, in abundance doth create.

In Baker, a decent bathroom doth abide,
And to the left of The Mad Greek, a pole doth reside,
A thermometer, the largest in all the land,
Doth show the temperature, though a few degrees off, 'tis grand.

So if thou art in search of food and sight,
Then stop thou must, at The Mad Greek, 'tis a wondrous delight."

"A fair Italian eatery, with victuals that pleased. Our server, in haste, did leave ere we had finished speech. The cost, a mite steep, yet not beyond belief. A pleasant ambiance, with flavors consistent, I'd return, in sooth, to dine again, anon."

"Place looked promising, being local and all. But, it didn't take long to realize the grub and service weren't up to par. Table was sticky, server was in a rush, and the food? Just mediocre. Bruschetta, for one, was a letdown. Flatbread was stale and cold, toppings were alright, but nothing special. Husband's orecchiette with sausage? Oversalted, sausage was meh. My porcini ravioli with tomato cream sauce? Sauce was too salty. Ambiance was decent, TVs in the bar were a bit much though. Not worth the cash, won't be back."

"Good spot, but get there early. I showed up late one weeknight in June and they didn't have a decent room left. They stuck me in a room for hearing-impaired smokers. Had to wait till the next afternoon to get an upgrade. Nice room, but I was pissed I had to rush back to switch rooms. Other than that, the hotel was alright. Pool's nothing special either."

"Small mall. Not like Vegas. Few stores. Pricey."

"Nice interior. Nice decorations. But expensive."

"Good for a short walk. That's it."

"A fair chain, indeed, with service most kind. My visits here have been pleasant, I do find. Grilled cheese with hash browns, my usual fare, Evenings, too, and the bread, crispy and rare. Once, alas, the cheese was not melted quite right, But the lady, kind, did correct the plight. In the microwave, the plate did she place, But too long, alack, and the cheese did turn to rubbery grace. The bread, too, lost its flavor, I did perceive. Cheese sticks, also, I do enjoy with glee, When melted well within, a tasty spree. Ranch and marinara, my dipping sauces of choice, do make. Good service, good food, a place to meet or be alone, A pleasant spot, indeed, to call my own."

"Methought I spied the Blue Man Group last week,
With expectations high, I must confess.
'Tis one of Vegas' longest running shows,
And soon to move to Monte Carlo, I suppose.

My excitement grew, as I took my seat,
But alack! The show itself did lack coherence, methought.
The three blue men, they beat their drums with glee,
Then climbed the chairs, for no apparent reason, I could see.

A marshmallow trick, most impressive, did they perform,
But 'twas quite random, and left me in a storm.
I've seen such feats on Vegas Boulevard,
And wondered how they fitted, in this show so odd.

Their humor, though, didst redeem them somewhat,
Their comedic timing, was quite worth the sum.
They had some laugh-out-loud moments, I must say,
And audience participation, made each show unique, in its way.

Alas, I enjoyed it, but 'twas not worth the cost,
For the hype, it did not live up to, I fear the most."
"Cool and welcoming inside. Great massage, full body, 90 minutes. Only forty bucks, including tip. Will be back, and I'll bring my crew."
"Good, not great. Quick service, too much slaw. Pastrami's a bit chewy, fries undercooked. Asked for double meat, got the same. Not worth the trip."

"Hark, what shenanigans did ensue at Camelback Inn Spa! 'Twas a day of pampering, with facials and massages galore. And then, we wished to partake in some FaceTime merriment, forsooth! But lo, the constabulary of quiet didst descend upon us, and our mirth didst turn to woe. We didst flee, my friends, to the outdoors, where water sprites didst not roam. And there, we found icy towels to cool our brows. Ah, but the facial given by fair Andrea, how can I praise it? She didst spend much time with me, answering queries of skincare and such. If thou dost cherish silence, and wish to read or relax, this place shall be thy haven. They do offer lemon water and tea, and when thou dost depart, thou canst create thine own sachet, a most excellent gesture! My sachet, it doth contain lavender, and it doth guide me to slumberland with ease. Well done, good sirs! The victuals and potables were quite satisfying, and the attendants, they didst hover near, ready to assist or hush all noise. Hush, my friends, when thou art there, that all may revel in tranquility!"
"Three stars from me. Coffee was mediocre at best. Should try it twice before judging. Hours are poor for a coffee joint, closing at 7. Better options out there."

"Hark! This eatery doth lie near my place of work,
And my fellow workers do frequent it, by the Lord above.
Their lunchbox specials, verily, are quite good,
Chiefly the Short Rib, a dish most tender and sweet.
I have also partaken of their special sushi rolls,
The AZ Diamondback, a feast fit for a king, no doubt.

But alas, the service, at times, doth leave much to be desired,
Oft they are o'erwhelmed by guests, and their hospitality doth suffer.
Yet, notwithstanding, the victuals are of fair quality,
And for a midday meal, this place doth serve its purpose well.
Mayhap one day, I shall essay their Korean dinner,
And savor each bite, with relish and delight."

"Met a friend at The Good Egg for breakfast. Service was top-notch, but I'm biased since she's a server here. Patio seating was nice, especially since it wasn't too crowded. However, the chairs were uncomfortable and not ideal for lingering over coffee. Decaf coffee was decent, but the scrambled eggs were only lukewarm. Sausage was cooked well, though. Thin pancakes were a pleasant surprise - not too crispy or doughy. The Good Egg is consistent, but not my go-to spot for breakfast."

"Lunch at Todai with the boyfriend, craving shrimp tempura. Plates piled high with seafood, $20 per person. Variety abounds - sushi rolls, nigiri, salads, udon, desserts. No crab, sadly. Udon station, my highlight. Ring the bell, they'll bring the goods. Fish cake, tofu, green onions, and more. Broth's a bit salty, be warned. With better options in Vegas, unlikely to return."

"My buddy raved about this joint for breakfast. It's decent, no doubt, but the service is spotty. Sometimes you'll get prompt refills, other times you'll sit there with an empty cup. I still go there regularly, but my main gripe is the price. Six bucks for two eggs and bacon? No way. There are some good deals on the menu, but also some duds. It depends on what you're in the mood for, I reckon. And don't even get me started on the military discount. You gotta be in uniform to get it? What's the point of that? If you're gonna go on the weekends, get there early. The late-night crowd shows up around 10, and the wait'll be a real doozy."
"They make it on flash, big helpings, and a famous name. But in this town, there's better places to get your morning grub."

"In days of yore, when first this place did open,
I came here oft, with naught to do but wander.
But for two years, my foot didst not step within,
Till a friend didst wish to try their buffet, and thus I didst enter in.

The service, decent as it doth always seem,
And atmosphere, most pleasant, doth abide.
But lo, the food, a disappointment doth bring,
For salt doth reign supreme, and flavors doth falter.

In days past, the fare didst please mine taste,
But now, alas, 'tis naught but woe and waste.
Yet still, the desserts, a sweet delight,
Do lift my spirits, and make all right."

"Methinks my offspring doth hold this shop in high esteem,
For 'tis a place where they may purchase finery and gear,
Inspired by popular cable shows and musical ensembles,
A haven for the young and fashion-conscious, I do declare.

The salesfolk, verily, are of a similar ilk,
Youthful and vibrant, with enthusiasm they do seek,
To guide patrons in their choices, with prices most fair,
For licensed goods of quality, beyond compare.

In conclusion, this store doth meet my approval,
For its wares and staff do both possess a certain je ne sais quoi,
A place where one may find a gift or treat,
For the young at heart, who seek to look their best, no doubt."

"Colombian joint, not Mexican. Different menu, bigger portions. Pricey, but worth it. Been here 10+ times, always get the #25. Shrimp in coconut sauce over tostones, fantastic. Juices are great too. Try the fried yuca, like French fries. Service is decent, friendly staff, fast service. Only been here on slow nights, can't speak for busy nights."

"Indian grub, we devour it frequently, both at home and out. Persi's, renowned spot, didn't disappoint. Lunch buffet, decent spread. Not vast, but quality dishes. Chicken tikka masala, rice, my fave. Biryani, spicy, intense flavors, but too hot. Desserts, meh. Gulab jumun, fruit, underwhelming. Good, yet craving more."

"Vegas, third time this year, first at Mandalay Bay. Previous trips, The Hotel. 

Room and bathroom, too cluttered. Dirty, hairs in tub and shower, spots on counter. 

The Hotel, better. Suites, bathrobes, slippers, clean bathrooms."

"Methought this place didst seem most wondrous fair,
By personal recommendations and Yelp reviews so rare.
The dinner, they say, doth rival the gods,
And thus, 'twas fitting for friends from afar to share.

But lo, we didst decide to visit ere the night,
For brunch, a meal most curious and quite right.
Now, mark thou well, fair Charlotte, thy brunch scene doth lack,
Compared to other cities, where breakfast doth reign supreme.

Our waitress, friendly and kind, didst attend to our needs,
But oh, how slow her steps, and how long she didst tarry!
The food, alack, didst lack the warmth of the sun,
My burrito, cold and hard, like a winter's day begun.

Yet, my friend, he didst enjoy his shrimp omelette,
Though lukewarm, it didst please him, and his spirit didst settle.
So, here's the tale, good sirs, of this place so fair,
For brunch, 'tis good, not great, but hope doth still abide there."

"Hark! A novel notion, circuit training doth seem,
A constant flurry of activity, no time to dream.
For those in poor shape, a true eye-opener 'twill be,
A test of endurance, a challenge to thee.

Six sets of four reps, each lasting three or four minutes,
Did we complete, in one hour, our bodies in tune.
Heart rate monitors, a helpful guide, didst display,
Our progress, and a friendly trainer didst convey.

Yet, comparison to others, a distraction doth make,
And the "zone" confusion, a minor drawback doth take.
But naught a major qualm, for still it doth delight,
This fitness regime, diverse and engaging in sight.

A free class, at dawn's break, didst I partake,
With fifteen folk, a bustling scene didst make.
The gym, though small, a cozy feel didst possess,
In orange hue, a vibrant, welcoming dress.

Ware for sale, a few items didst they have,
Alas, a bit pricey, yet still, a worthy cave.
The program, costly, yet for some, a boon,
Who crave variety in their exercise, soon.

Farewell, and fortune to all who doth pursue,
This circuit path, a fitness journey anew."
"Food, five stars. Service, shaky. Lunch rush, bad. Can't hire another server, not sure why. Almost left, bad service. Keep coming back, matzoh ball soup."
"Coupons, chicken fingers, fast service, friendly. Good eatin', but watch the heat. More to try, verdict pending."

"Place wasn't great. Service was meh from the jump. Decor was cool, especially if you snagged a spot by the lake. Vegan grub was tasty, but nothing special. Show on the lake? Corny. All in all, it was just alright."

"A devotee of this establishment, through various guises and proprietors, I have been. One of the scarce venues in town, wherein a cigar, a mug of ale, and merriment may be savored within its walls. 

The attendants, a congenial lot, tend to a respectable array of cigars, and a modest, yet choice assortment of brews. Patrons may take a seat at the bar, sink into a cozy chair, or gather 'round a table, and gaze upon the telly. 

My sole quibble, the ambiance, a tad too smoky for mine own taste. A cigar, I do enjoy, on occasion, but the pungent cloud that lingers within those walls, did leave my garments reeking of smoke, and my nostrils, in dismay. Not for the faint of heart, this place, I do declare."

"My friend, a Vegas native, didst lead us to this place,
In search of prime rib, late night, a wondrous feast.
The price, a mere $15, didst make our eyes light up,
And though the atmosphere didst reek of steeds,
We didst not let it deter us, for the deal was fair.

The meal didst come with soup or salad, and a choice
Of potatoes, which didst please our taste buds quite well.
We all didst order it medium rare, but lo,
It came to us more rare, and that didst surprise.
But when we sent it back, they didst correct the flaw,
And gave us a new cut, cooked just right, we didst allow.

The customer service, it didst impress us so,
And though the meat was chewy, the flavor didst flow.
A rating of three and a half stars, I do declare,
And yes, I would return, for the food didst pair."

"Hark! Our bellies full from pizza and ale,  
We chanced upon this place, our thirst to quench.  
Il Bosco Pizza, where we did dine,  
Didst not open till four, so we didst stroll and search.  
This tavern, clean and welcoming, didst greet us with cheer,  
And happy hour, daily, from eleven to seven, didst appear.  
Methinks, fair sirs, 'twas a fine place to rest,  
With TVs abounding, for sportsmen to behold and boast.  
We didst not partake in victuals, but their menu vast,  
Didst tempt our taste buds, with flavors so lavish."

"A Groupon alert, yet again doth pique my interest. A local establishment, with offers most enticing, doth tempt me to partake. 

The fare, alas, doth leave much to be desired. Spicy chicken bowl, with sweetness o'erwhelming, doth fail to impress. Rice, too, doth lack the savory taste I crave. Shrimp tempura, a middling delight, doth please, yet not astound. Orange chicken, with texture most appealing, doth win my favor, somewhat. Chicken teriyaki, a pleasant surprise, doth round out the meal, with satisfaction. 

In conclusion, a decent, swift repast doth this eatery provide. Worth a visit, should another coupon come my way, but naught more, methinks."

"Ay, cool for younglings, mayhap not so much for elders. Hark! I came expressly for yon mummy display, and, alack! 'Twas but a mediocre sight. Aye, the tiny computer stations, they didst speak of Egypt and the mummy proper, and those, I didst find most intriguing. Alas, the rest, a mere shadow of greatness. Nay, I wouldst not advise thee to pay more for this spectacle."

"Thin crust pizza, oh how fine!
Wise guy, a gem, doth shine.
Price, a steal, doth make me smile.
Service, friendly, doth attend,
Yet, alack, consistency doth wane."

"Food's great. No doubt about it. But the service? Disorganized, rude, and poorly managed. Long waits for no good reason. Still, the grub's so good I'm willing to give it another shot. Just don't have any plans afterward, 'cause they won't care if you're late. They'll still charge you and give you the cold shoulder. Boo!"

"A humble abode of culinary delight,  
This burg'ry joint doth serve a meager fare,  
Yet, hath a few dishes of note, I do declare,  
Which, alas, I have not had the chance to share.  
For coin, I'd choose Smashburger, anon,  
If only 'twere nearer to my dwelling place,  
But since 'tis not, I shall return, ere long,  
To partake of their delectable, savory grace."

"Friends and I scored a deal here. Expected the worst, but got lucky. Adjoining suite, kitchen stocked for Vegas essentials. Heated pool, perfect for a return visit. Old digs, but worth it for the fam and tourist trap experience."

"Forty bucks for two, including two mimosas. Not bad. My husband and I feasted like kings. We arrived at eleven and ate till we couldn't no more. Lunchtime, so we had a bit of everything: crepe with all the fixin's, gnocchi, salad, grilled veggies, dolmas, hummus, pita, and plenty of sweets and breads. Damn, we were in a food coma. I dozed off in the elevator, woke up four hours later to get hitched."

"Methinks three of us did dine together,
And, as newcomers, the serving maid did proffer
Samples of their fare, with nary a frown.
The victuals came swiftly, and at a fair price,
Thou hast not broke the bank, nor didst thou pay too much.
My meal, with egg foo young and red chicken,
Was but a mediocre feast, I must confess.
I've had far better Chinese, in truth be told.
My comrades had red chicken, rice, and pork,
And deemed them passable, though not of the best.
Shall I return? Mayhap, after a year hath passed."

"Drinks, decent price. Not the diviest joint, but it's cool. DJ spinning, small dance floor. No fuss, no muss. Barkeep, tall and handsome, caught my eye. Danced, shook my tail feathers - $4 cover, meh! \n\nSome youngins', looked 15, weird, but hey, I'm on vacation. $6.50 CAD for Jameson, Jack, most beers. Hipster haven, if that's your scene. Great spot, just a tad too youthful for me."

"We hit this joint every couple months. Clean enough, friendly folks, and the grub's not bad. We always go for the maple hot wings—best flavor in town. Sure, they're small, but who needs a whole bird when you can have a taste explosion? Nice spot to catch a game, too. Not too rowdy, just a chill crowd."
"Pricey, but options galore. Sushi, chicken, shrimp noodles. Good, but not quite genuine, like Pan-Asian spots often are."

"Hark! What news is this? A comic store most fair,
Whose shelves do hold a treasure beyond compare.
For oft, when other shops are bare and dry,
This place doth still possess the book I would buy.
Their stock doth rival that of any store,
With figures many and tomes galore.
Deforest, thou art blessed to have found such a place,
And may thy visits there be filled with grace."

"Wanted to try this joint for a while, finally made it. Cornbread, decent. Smoked salmon hash, meh. Fiance's salmon burger, good, huge portion. Host stand, four people, too busy chatting. Server, nice. Shoulda gotten a burger, next time. Will be back."

"Last week, I dined with a friend at Kikeri's. 'Twas a so-so affair. The chicken, which lay in the belly, did not sit well, and during consumption, I did not perceive that high-quality meat was of great concern. Three stars for the fair price and the tasty, very spicy rice noodle soup."

"A fair pizza and salad doth please mine eyes,
And in the eve, a place most meet for guise,
To hang about, and laugh, and merry make,
Before the flick'ring show, that doth our senses take."

"Saw 'Oklahoma!' here a few years back. Enjoyed the show, but the dinner buffet was just okay. The desserts were the only thing worth trying. If it weren't such a haul from Chandler, I'd have been back by now. But, it's a 28-mile drive from Scottsdale, so I think I'll pass on those 80% off gift certificates."

"Methinks I've visited Gilbert Pizza oft,
Their victuals, most delectable and soft.
But lo, the maiden fair behind the counter,
Her manners, rude and unbecoming, did beset her.
She gazed upon me with a scowl, and not a word,
Didst she speak, as she wiped down the counter with a curled lip.
And when I placed an order o'er the phone,
She snapped at me, with a tone most dire and woe.
'Twas five more minutes, she didst declare,
With nary a smile, nor a hint of cheer.
I shall take my coin and spend it elsewhere,
For such behavior doth not befit a servant fair.
She was rude to all who came after me,
A pox upon her, and her surly mood, sayeth thee!"

"Alack, fair friends, I must confess my fault,
That I, with words, didst Sports Authority besmirch.
For, in my haste, I didst seek out their aid,
And found, in David, a most excellent guide.
He didst attend to me with diligence and care,
And showed me shoes that wouldst suit my needs fair.
He didst dissuade me from a costly pair,
And showed me Asics, at a price most rare.
The checkout, alas, didst cause some woe,
But David's kindness didst make amends, I do declare.
So here, my friends, I do recant my former tale,
And say, in truth, that Sports Authority doth prevail."

"Beware, fair maidens, of the EBAY MAFIA's wicked grasp,
Their schemes and plots to keep the best deals from thee at last.
In league with staff, they swoop in, like vultures to the prey,
And snatch away the finest garb, ere break of day.

Their mission, to deprive thee, dear consumer, of thy due,
To leave thee with naught but scraps, and nary a clue.
They hawk their wares on Ebay, with haste and great delight,
And laugh, no doubt, at thy misfortune, and their own spite.

But fear not, dear shopper, for there is hope yet,
To find the deals thou seek'st, and not be foiled by their threat.
Search Ebay, and behold, the truth shall be revealed,
For in the listings, thou shalt find the markings, plain and sealed.

So, brave maiden, take heed, and do not let them win,
For Last Chance shall be thine, if thou dost but begin.
And when thou find'st thy prize, and hold'st it tight,
Know that thou hast bested them, and emerged in the light."

"Oh, how I adore the Nola cuisine!
The genuine and delectable taste of this kitchen doth shine.
In Las Vegas, I didst savor the shrimp and grits,
So delightful, it doth make my senses tingle and twirl.
The bread pudding, oh how grand,
A culinary carnival, a symphony of flavors at hand.
But alas, the service doth leave much to be desired,
The waitress doth roam, and oft doth seem tired.
I have visited thrice, and each time, the soft shell crab,
Doth satisfy my craving, crispy and flavorful, a true delight.
The jambalaya and gumbo, layered with flavor so deep,
I shall return, for the food, my heart doth leap.
For though the service may lack, the cuisine doth make up,
I shall return, my love for Nola food, never to forsake."

"Korean and Japanese grub, like sushi, decent in Pittsburgh. Galbi, bulgogi, kimchi, the usual suspects. Galbi bento, my go-to, but pricey, so I don't indulge often. Bento boxes come with chap chae, kimchi, salad, pickles, pot stickers, and your choice of entree. Simple, yet satisfying. Bowls, just rice and meat, yum. Small space, fits four."

"Methought 'twas a grand opening indeed,
At Primebar, where we didst take heed.
A free open bar, with drinks galore,
Didst flow like a river, ne'er before.
The victuals too, were plentiful and fine,
But naught exceptional, save the service divine.
For servers came to us, with speed and grace,
And brought our drinks, without a moment's space.
But alack, the design didst leave me cold,
So bland and boring, corporate told.
With wood-like walls, and lights so dim,
It lacked the sleekness, of a true whim.
The music too, didst not impress,
A mix of alt and rock, didst not repress.
I hadst thought, it wouldst be a place,
Of sophistication, and of grace.
But nay, 'twas more like Yard House,
A place for sports, and not for louse.
So there you have it, my dear friend,
Primebar, a place to watch the game, but not to wend."
"Work event at Cosmo's. Food was decent, not remarkable. Loud, typical Vegas joint. Good for groups, but there are better options."

"Methinks my love and I didst not enjoy this place,
'Tis loud and small within its walls, we found.
I ordered mushroom, cheese, and omelette,
With bacon and a biscuit, to make it neat.
My love, a Spanish omelet didst choose,
With salsa and home fries, to make it grand.
But lo, my omelet lacked seasoning,
And flavor, it didst not have, I fear.
The bacon and biscuit, they were quite good,
But coffee, oh, how it didst taste like mud!
We both agreed, in this we were as one,
That coffee, it didst leave much to be desired, ere done."

"The Wicked Spoon, a place we hold dear. Great grub, always something new. But this trip, service went sour. Our server, a grump, forgot our orders often. Drinks came slow, plates piled high. Empty tables got attention first. A shame, Wicked Spoon. You can do better."

"The Garage used to be my go-to joint, but now it feels like just another dive. Sure, the grub's still good and the service is top-notch, but it's not exactly setting the world on fire. I've never had to wait for a table, which is nice, but it makes me wonder why more folks don't come here. They used to have lamb as a starter, that'd bring me back in a heartbeat."

Hark, good sir! I do beseech thee, let this humble patronage of thine establishment be met with a modicum of enthusiasm. Forsooth, 'tis a truth universally acknowledged, that a customer in possession of a local loyalty must be in want of a pleasant experience.

Alas, upon entering thy domain, mine eyes didst behold a sight most curious. A mere handful of patrons, and yet, the service didst seem so lacking in zeal. The barista, apathetic and unmoved, didst attend to mine order with all the fervor of a sloth.

Pray tell, good sir, doth thy staff possess a certain... disdain for the art of hospitality? Methinks, a smile, a kindly word, or perchance, a gentle nod of acknowledgement, might prove a balm most soothing to the souls of those who grace thy premises.

Forgive me, kind sir, if mine observations doth seem unduly harsh. 'Tis merely that, as a patron, I do crave a sense of welcoming, a feeling that my presence doth bring a measure of joy, however small, unto those who serve me.

In conclusion, prithee, dear Next, let this humble plea touch thy heart. In the future, mayhap thou couldst instruct thy minions to embrace the virtues of courtesy, and thus, ensure that each and every customer doth depart, feeling grateful and content.

"Hark! A gathering of folk at McKoys didst take place,  
For lunch, a meal most wondrous and of great grace.  
I, myself, didst partake in a sandwich of pork,  
Pulled, it was, and verily, 'twas a delectable work.  
A side of mac and cheese didst accompany my feast,  
And filled me up, it didst, to the utmost degree.  
Two things, fair friends, beware of, ere ye dine,  
The first, a wait for all, until your party's whole,  
The second, noise of traffic, loud and most vile,  
Outdoors, a seat, doth make conversation quite dire.  
A solution, pray, they find, to this woeful plight,  
And install bushes, or such, to block the din of night."

"Lived in SoCal and Vegas, where Asian food reigns supreme. This spot, three stars at best. Portions generous, flavors unique, but spice lovers beware, Sriracha needed. Not quite the real deal, but sufficient until my next adventure."

"Beatles Lounge, huh? Didn't hear any Beatles music the night I was there. Didn't matter though. Decent tunes, but nobody was dancing. Except the go-go girl on the pole, of course.
