Got a 'free' drink voucher, but the bartender only gave us the cheap stuff. Read the fine print, my friend. People-watching was great, though. Two old ladies, chain-smoking and hitting on young dudes. Hilarious. Don't come here to dance or hear the Beatles."

In sooth, the hostess was discourteous, nay, churlish, when I didst approach, albeit I didst not anticipate excellent service at this aerodrome tavern. I didst pose a query regarding the seating arrangement, and she, with a shrug of her shoulder, didst remain mute. Her name, as I recall, didst begin with the letter D, mayhap Della. Upon sittin g down, my experience didst improve, for a comely lass named Jack didst tender me a salutation and didst take my order. She didst bring me the wrong brew, but didst proffer to rectify her mistake straightway. Now, I am not one to suffer drinks to go to waste, and thus, I didst not press her to correct it.

"This joint's got good grub and top-notch service. But let me tell you what really gets my goat - they let kids sit at the bar. Now, I ain't one to discriminate against the youngins, but it just don't feel right, ya know? There's a restaurant part too, plenty of seats, but that's beside the point. It's like they're tryin' to ruin the whole damn atmosphere."

"Huzzah! A feast most frugal doth await!
A corn dog, oh so tasty, doth inflame my soul!
Intoxicated, mayhap, yet the price and place,
At one and thirty morn, doth make it a most wondrous find.
Seize thee a corn dog, and into the casino thou shalt stride,
And thus, thy hunger sated, shalt continue on thy way."
"View from here? Bellagio, water show? Amazing. Food? Decent. Paying for view, Eiffel Tower-esque experience. Worth it. Bar up there? Don't know. Drinks, not eat."

"Hark! A loyal patron of Aloft I be,
And rooms and lobby, familiar to me.
But alas, this hotel doth sit near a busy road,
My chamber faced it, and the noise did annoy.
All night, the hum of cars did pierce mine ears,
And from the In & Out, a speaker's voice did reach.
Despite this flaw, I would still recommend to thee,
To ask for rooms away from the highway's din,
Or pack earplugs, lest thou suffer as I did.
A convenient place, for business trips 'twain,
And nigh to Ikea and airport, a quick jaunt."

"Methinks these cupcakes be fair and bright,
As pretty as a maiden in her prime,
Their frosting doth delight, in moderation applied,
A feast for mine eyes, a treat for my taste.

Their toppings, diverse and full of whimsy,
Do bring to mind a merry carnival,
The clerks, so friendly and full of mirth,
Doth make my visit most enjoyable and worth.

But alas, the cake itself doth lack,
A certain je ne sais quoi, a certain flair,
It doth resemble a muffin in disguise,
A culinary conundrum, a curious affair.

Yet still, I would return, forsooth,
To savor more of their sweet delights,
For though they may not be perfect,
They doth possess a certain charm and might."
"Stay north, friend. One mile up the road, there's a place with nicer rooms and indoor corridors. It might cost a bit more, but it's worth it."

"Verily, this place didst please mine eyes and taste. Yet, there be many other places that doth excel. 

In sooth, I didst partake of dinner here, and we didst order two dishes as appetizers - the Jumbo Shrimp Cocktail and the Shrimp Spring Rolls. The shrimp cocktail was as expected, cold shrimp with cocktail sauce, but the spring rolls, they were quite good, and if I were to return, I would begin my meal with them. 

But alas, the main course, the Crown Cut Bone In Filet Mignon, 12 oz., didst not impress me. At such a price, I couldst have a better steak elsewhere. 

Therefore, next time I find myself in the Forum Shops, seeking a steak, I shall venture next door to Joe's."

"A hearty welcome doth await thee at Al's, my friend,
Where atmosphere doth please and prices doth descend.
The waitresses, fair and kind, doth serve with grace,
And patrons, merry and bright, doth fill the space.

Ale, thy name is beer, doth flow with excellence,
And food, though not my choice, doth make presence.
Outside, the benches doth invite to sit and stay,
And chill, thou shalt, on nights of fair weather's sway.

This place, it doth delight, and I shall come again,
To partake in mirth and cheer, with friends, and not in vain.
So here's to thee, Al's, and all the joy thou bringest,
May fortune smile upon thee, and thy patrons, ever blessed."

In sooth, fair maidens, Northlake Mall doth boast
A multitude of shops, wherein thou mayst find
Apparel galore, to please thy feminine taste.
But woe betide the men, whose options are but few,
For most of these shops cater to women's whims.
Alas, the bookstore, once a haven for wit,
Hath closed its doors, leaving naught but empty space.
Yet still, the mall doth gleam with cleanliness bright,
And in the food court, sustenance doth abound.
So, if thou seeketh garb, this place doth merit thy sight,
But for electronics, Best Buy, across the way, doth beckon thee.

"San Remo, we gave it another go. Solid breakfast, inexpensive. JK, decent chopped steak, good blue cheese dressing. Waitress, competent, friendly, attentive. Flat screens, too many, but volume down, a plus. San Remo, still a dive, but that's okay. Improvements, hopefully, we'll see."

"Tis a gamble, my friends, to dine at this place,
For the tacos, they may be fresh and full of grace,
But the salsa, alas, doth resemble a hot sauce,
And the chimichangas, well, they are not worth the cost.

A jug of horchata, large and awkward to hold,
I do procure, with a laugh and a wink, so bold.
But mark my words, dear friends, do not expect
A feast fit for kings, for 'tis but a humble abode.

And when the line doth grow long, and the wait doth seem endless,
Park thy carriage and order from the window, lest thou tempt fate.
For in the throes of hunger, tempers may fray,
And thou mayst find thyself in a bit of a pickle, by my troth."

"Hark, what news is this? A feast most fair and bright,
With flavors bold and savory in sight.
And, lo, they serve it all through the day,
A boon for those who crave it in their way.

But, alas, a drawback doth there lie,
In waiting long to be seated nigh.
The server, too, didst leave much to desire,
And cold, the food arrived, like winter's fire.

Yet still, a gem within the rough,
This eatery holds, for those who dare enough."

"Hark, fair readers, listen well to my tale,
Of Brew Lab, a place of coffee and bustle,
Where students rich and eager do congregate,
And seek their daily dose of caffeine and chatter.

Amidst the throng, I found a seat at last,
And sipped a peppermint tea, freshly brewed,
The staff were kind, the decor was neat,
But alas, the crowd did make me feel beat.

So though I'd give the tea four stars,
The busy atmosphere doth leave me scarred,
For in a place of peace, I'd rather be,
Than amidst the hubbub of humanity.

Yet still, the popularity of Brew Lab doth shine,
A testament to its appeal, divine,
So if thou art a fan of coffee and its kin,
Then hie thee hence, and give 't a spin."

"Methought, my dearest wife, this eve of ours,  
In comfy couches, low lighting, sweet delight,  
Would bring us joy, as we did celebrate,  
Our fortieth year of wedlock, full of love and fate.  
The music, methought, did strike a merry chord,  
But when we called for drinks, our server did ignore,  
Our pleas, as if she had a grudge to bear,  
And left us hanging, without a bill to share.  
I had read reviews, of this place, so bright,  
And thought we'd try their brews, on this special night.  
Alas, my dear, it seemed they did not care,  
For us, or our desire, to show them fair.  
So, we did leave, in search of better cheer,  
And hoped that others may find more welcome here."

"Aye, 'tis true, my friends, that TB doth serve  
A guilty pleasure, fit for vegetarians,  
Their menu doth offer many a choice,  
Fit for those in haste, with naught to lose.  
This place, like others, doth seem the same,  
With food that's decent, though not quite tame.  
The staff, young and cheerful, doth greet,  
And serve with speed, though not too fleet.  
So if thou art in need of TB's fare,  
This location shall not leave thee bare."

"I concur with some of you Yelpers who hail from Cali...since I too am a former So. Cal gal. You're shelling out double for a sandwich that doesn't hold a candle to Lee's Sandwich in L.A., but I'm familiarizing myself with Vegas and this joint is the only spot I know for a decent Vietnamese sandwich. Everything on the menu is pricey. Curiosity got the better of me, so I brought my husband back to sample the rest of the grub. I opted for the Banh Cuon, while he went for the Rice dish with BBQ Cornish Hen and Pho Dac Biet. Verdict? Their dishes are flavorful, thanks to an abundance of MSG. So much so that it gave me a headache and left me parched for the entire day."
"Chai tea latte. Didn't like it. Watered down. Threw it out."

In sooth, a humble place, fit for the folk of the land,
Yet, Orleans, not far, doth boast a finer hand.
A lively alley, full of cheer and glee,
And a theatre, where one may see a play, or three.
Gold Coast, too, doth cater to the oriental crowd,
With PingPangPong, a game of skill and chance allowed.
The Noodle Exchange, a place of sustenance and delight,
And Baccarat, a game of cards, for those who dare to fight.

"The joint's got some balls, charging like they're the only game in town. Food's too rich for my blood, $49 for a kid and two adults? My old man had a $5 Guinness, I had a $4 Pour of Pinot Grigio, not bad. Then comes the grub. Served my salad in a styrofoam box with plastic utensils, the tiny dressing container was a red flag - they wanted top dollar for a second helping. It was a good salad, chicken on top had some gristle, bacon was decent. Hubby got Stromboli, nothing special but good. He got real silverware and a pizza sheet. Kid got a cheese pizza. Took 15-20 minutes for drinks, another 15-20 for food. Wish they had real dishes and wasn't so damn pricey. The bar's a nice touch, though."

"Taco Bell, a greasy joint, but my friend craved it, so we went. Haven't been there in five years. Split a sourdough breakfast sandwich with my sister. Not bad. Curly fries were good too. Fast service, but my sister didn't like the potato wedges. Still, McDonald's fries are better."

"A worthy feast, yet not so grand,
For ten silver pence, a dish they hand.
A hearty portion, to be sure,
But scant the veggies, and scarce the cure.
If hunger pangs thy belly wring,
This place will ease thy suffering.
Yet, seek thou better Asian fare,
And to another door thou must repair."

"I got Take-Out. Masaman Curry with Tofu and Vegetables. It was alright. Not impressive, but not bad either. Would've been better for lunch, cheaper and more stuff. Might go back for lunch or take-out, give 'em another shot."

"Verily, 'tis worth a visit, at the least, my friend,
A single time, to behold the merriment that doth never end.
A place of much activity, with music, dance, and cheer,
A sight to behold, and worth the journey, I do declare.


Alas, the zip lines be expensive, yet a delight,
For those who seek such thrills, and wish to take flight.


We dined at two places, a gourmet hot dog, they say,
And a middle eastern eatery, with a curious array.
But alas, both were lacking, and left us unfulfilled,
No desire to return, our taste buds unreconciled."

"Dave's Dog House serves up tasty dogs, real good. Bun's like thick toast, east coast style. Dogs are top-notch, flavorful. Price is right too. Fries? Meh, not worth writing home about. \n\nNow they're on campus, off Gammage Parkway. A bit harder to reach from Mill during school, but still worth it. Better than most dogs on Mill."

"LAX, not my fave club in Vegas. But they all blend together after a while. Went on a Wednesday night, decent crowd. Our cocktail waitress in VIP was top-notch, made sure our group was taken care of. Mezzanine area for VIP booths was a nice touch, but they cram two parties in each booth. That caused some issues for us. Security tried to fix it by putting up a couch as a divider. DJ was alright. Might go back if I have to."

"Hark! What light through yonder window breaks? Average fare, methinks, doth grace these halls. Two lunch boxes didst I procure, filled with meat, and rice, and naught but meat. Cheap and convenient, yet satisfaction doth evade mine eyes. Alas, the chicken with broccoli, a dish most vile, doth mar the feast. Forsooth, the fowl doth taste not of its kin, but of a lesser breed, most base and poor. Yet still, I shall return, for thrift and sloth doth rule my days."

Alas, my heart did yearn for love of Port of Subs,
For many a location doth it boast in this fair town.
But alack, my hopes were dashed, for though the service was good,
The sandwiches themselves didst leave me feeling down.

The meats and cheese, freshly sliced, didst taste most fine,
But the bread, oh how it failed to impress me!
'Twas not as sturdy, nor as tasty, as I had hoped,
And thus, my appetite didst remain unsopped.

The prices, fair and reasonable, didst seem,
Yet still, I couldst not help but feel a sense of loss,
For just a bit more, across the way, doth lie,
A better value, and a tastier prize.
"Food, top-notch. Service, could've been better. Bathrooms? Gross. Free soup, salad, fruit? Nice touch. Potential for 4 to 5 stars."

"Shopped at a new spot today, not my usual haunt, but close enough to swing by. Place was dead, only a few folks millin' about. Lots of staff restockin', though. Didn't find what I needed - probably a seasonal thing, school supplies or somethin' - but took a gander at the regular stuff I get: cat chow, music CDs. Prices were fair, selection was good, and the checkout lines were short."

"Sold some old stuff here. Didn't see much worth selling. But they got some nice clothes. Not like Goodwill crap. Unique and clean. Wanted it all. But too damn pricey. Shirts, $15? Dresses, $25? No way, kid."

"It was a swell joint, modern and hip. Maybe a bit too much like the Roxybury, ya know? But still, it was fun. Big bar and lounge, perfect for a night out with pals. Room was a bit snug, though. Grub was terrible. Wi-Fi was a bust, had to hit up the lobby to get some work done. Didn't feel like botherin' with the customer service number, so I stuck with the ethernet. But that didn't work either. What's the deal with wired internet, anyway? Shouldn't be so darn complicated."

"Hark, what news is this? A tale of woe and shame,
Of aging folk who still do cling to youthful games.
My Chemical Romance, a band of teenage delight,
Yet here I stand, a man of thirty winters' might.

In Anaheim, a place of wonder and of dreams,
The venue fair, with levels twain, it seems.
But here, in Mandalay, a different sight doth greet,
One level only, with three bars, a dance floor neat.

Oh, memories of yore, of drunken nights and cheer,
With friends, and shots, and dancing without fear.
A couple, aged, who sought to join our fun,
But we, in haste, didst flee, our dignity to save, ere done.

And thus, my friends, this tale doth end,
With age, and wisdom, perchance, to amend."

"Hark, fair traveler, thou seeketh sustenance? 
Away from the Strip, a hidden gem doth lie, 
In Vegas, a place of wonder and delight, 
Where Korean cuisine doth reign supreme in might. 
The bul-go-gi, a feast fit for a king, 
With marinated pork, a taste that doth sing, 
And jap chae, a dish of grace and poise, 
Shall satiate thy hunger, and leave thee in joys. 
But heed this warning, good sir, ere thou dost dine, 
Lest thou waste food, a penalty thou shalt divine, 
Five dollars or more, a price to pay, 
For each morsel left, a sum thou shalt dismay. 
So eat thy fill, and leave naught behind, 
Lest thy wallet suffer, and thy belly unwind. 
But fear not, for payment comes at the end, 
Thy meal, a bargain, at a price most reasonable, my friend."

"Vegas, baby! First timer here for a work conference. Conference room was a hike from my digs, but no worries 'bout that. Brought my own gym shoes, thank you very much. Food was top-notch, but man, those portions could knock you out. Sleepy time during the afternoon sessions, but hey, that's what coffee's for, right? Rio casino was chill, not too crowded on a weekday. Variety of games, but I didn't spend much time there. Strip's where it's at for gamblin'. Free shuttle to other casinos was sweet. Room was comfy, but outdated tech, ya know? Old CRT TV and no wifi. Ethernet cable did the trick, though. Conference area had wireless, so that was cool. All in all, not a bad trip, especially since it wasn't outta my pocket. Just the gambling, though. That's where the real fun's at."
"Solid customer service. Tailored my suit like a pro. Parking's a breeze. In and out quick. No funky smells. But who reads reviews for Mens Wearhouse? You know what you're getting."

"Hark! I do confess, my dearest friend,  
That here, within these walls, doth lie a treat,  
A feast most wondrous, fit for any king,  
Their nachos, oh, how they do sing!  

Three cheeses blend, a spicy delight,  
The salsa fresh, a taste so bright,  
Burritos, standard, yet still a joy,  
Consistent, never any alloy.  

But lo, a quibble doth arise,  
For veggies' sake, the price doth rise,  
Fajitas, rice, a surcharge, 'tis true,  
Yet still, a bargain, I do pursue.  

Cleanliness, a virtue, doth abound,  
Not crowded, peaceful, service profound,  
So here, my heart, doth stay and dine,  
In Qdoba's embrace, I do entwine."

"Food wasn't half bad, but the view and ambiance made up for it. Peanut butter bread, not too shabby. Shrimp cocktail, interesting twist. Beef tenderloin and cod, decent. MiX candy bar, a sweet treat. Service, a tad snooty, but acceptable."

"Hark! Does anyone truly patronize this place?

My spouse and I, lodged next door at Aria, chanced upon this mall, curious about its wares. Alas, 'twas a haven for the wealthy, with naught but high-end goods on display. I dared not hope for such pedestrian shops as Office Max or Lane Bryant, nor a fast food court with KFC and Taco Bell. Yet, I wished to find a place where I might feel at ease, perusing the merchandise. 

In vain! The stores were all too rich for my blood, and few folk tarried within, save for the occasional browser. The rest wandered, awestruck by the grand architecture and artful installations. The News Stand, a humble abode, lay hidden beneath the escalator, a rare haven for those without an American Express Black Card. 

I'd return but for The News Stand's bottled water, a coffee at Starbucks, or to bask in the A/C and admire the art en route to The Strip."

"Grub's good here. Chicken and steak tacos, damn near authentic Mexican street food. Soup's top-notch too. Been coming here regular, but last time, service was off. Order got screwed up in the drive-thru, employee didn't know how to split it right. And the guac sauce I asked for? Never made it into my bag. No time to complain, on a tight lunch break."

"Don't see the appeal. Finding where to order and get grub's a pain. Drinks in a separate line? More confusion. Same prices as a sit-down joint, but no service. Food's meh. Avocado pizza's just okay, nothing special. Super greasy crust and weird cheese, not mozzarella. Sourdough dough, not my thing. Won't be back unless I'm desperate."

In sooth, fair friends, I came to this place,
For a 21st birthday of a dear acquaintance,
And found it to be a bit of a mixed case,
Depending on my mood, as it were.

Pros, thou ask? Well, 'tis a fine spot,
For people-watching, with a curious lot,
Of interesting folk, and fair ones too,
The prices, reasonable, and no cover, I do.
The atmosphere, merry and bright,
A good place to amuse young friends, in sight.

But alas, cons there be, my friends,
For 'tis a bit douchey, at times, it tends,
The patrons, they do scrutinize,
And the music, loud, but dance space, scarce, it lies.
The drinks, they take an age to come,
Awaiting, a test of patience, 'twill become.

In conclusion, this bar, just average,
Not my favorite, but not my worst,
For a 21st birthday, a fitting place,
But not one, I would frequent, with haste.

"Place had potential, but it fell short. Service was top-notch, but the server botched my wine order. Asked for house wine, got charged $13.50 a glass. Food was good, not great. Osso buco was decent, insalata bianca was mediocre. Sea bass special was nicely grilled, but came with bland spaghetti squash. Price wasn't bad, but the wine upsell hurt. Overall, it's a solid three stars."

"Expectations lowered for large groups. Menu limited. Onion soup with Gruyere, good. Main course: prime rib, herb chicken, or salmon. Wanted salmon, but rare. Chicken, just okay. String fries? For formal dinner? Service good. Drinks overpriced. Food, just okay."

Upon a Friday eve, our running group did meet,
At this establishment grand, with spaces to eat.
A patio without, and three floors within,
Did offer ample room for revelry to spin.
Their draughts of beer did flow in abundance,
Local brews aplenty, to quench thirst and danse.
Mixed drinks, too, did grace the menu fair,
For those who sought a stiffer drink to pair.
I ordered Ghost Burger, with sweet potato dish,
And found the bacon slices did make my wish.
The burger, spicy, yet not overly bold,
Grilled onions added zest, worth a tale to be told.
Alas, the service, slow, and staff not keen,
But Friday night, their busiest hour, I ween.
The prices steep, my purse did feel the sting,
Yet, for the fare, a price not unforeseen.
Thus, twenty dollars for a burger and ale,
A cost, I thought, did somewhat exceed the tale.

"We stuffed ourselves at the Wynn buffet for lunch, so dinner had to be simple and quick. Mom's go-to pho spot in town was this place. It was alright. Summer rolls could've used more mint, but they skimped on the herbs. Veggie sides? Bean sprouts, limp basil, and a few slices of jalapeno. Not exactly a feast. But hey, we were in the desert, not SoCal or Hawaii. Broth was decent, I guess. Overall, just okay."

"Honestly, I wouldn't have come here if it weren't for my husband's coworkers. College bars ain't my thing, living in Boston'll do that to ya. But it was summer, we were a group of 50, so I figured why not? We took over the back, which was nice. Drinks were well-made, assume they were cheap. Two pool tables in the back, a bit awkward near the bar. Music was generic, classic drunk girl anthems to Top 40 hits. Hubby liked the bathroom attendant, said he must be related to Lil Jon, yelling stuff like "Get yo piss on!" No pictures policy, which was pretty lame. Can't take a pic of you and your friend having fun without permission? Never experienced that before, and I frequent nicer places. Wouldn't go back when classes start in the fall? Hell no."
"Exterior's a mess. But inside, it's not half bad. Cheap, too. Good for a quick escape. Visited a pal, that's all."

"Forty of us, a merry band, did dine at La Porte Grecque, a place most meet for groups of such size. With two rooms within and one without, we had choice plenty, and in the larger room we did reside. 

The service, fair and prompt, did please, despite our number great. They offered us a menu of diverse dishes, and with glee did cater to our dietary needs, off-menu, no less. 

Alas, the victuals, save the starters, did not impress. Feta, olives, tzatziki, all were small, yet tasty still. The main courses, large as they were, did lack in flavor, and the dessert, a cake, did not surpass. 

And so, dear friends, this writer doth say, La Porte Grecque, a decent place, but not the best, forsooth."

"O, woe is me, fair friends, for service here doth lack,
A sorry state, indeed, and cause for discontent.
My negi-toro roll and philly roll, a mere half hour wait,
Yet those who came later, served before mine eyes, didst take.

The sushi, fresh and decent, yet not so finely rolled,
A shame, for one would hope for more, in such a place.
Prices, reasonable, yet lunch specials, poor and weak,
No sushi option, save four pieces of a cali roll's embrace.

Alas, my heart doth yearn for Sushi Fever's fare,
Better prices, fish, and rolls, beyond compare.
But alas, my work doth keep me near this place,
And so, I must endure, with patience, its disgrace."

"Hark! I didst partake of the com bi cha suon nuong,
A meal most wondrous, with flavors so strong.
The pork chop, verily, didst please mine taste,
Not oversalted, a delight to devour in haste.
The bi, a dish of wonder, didst also impress,
Though the meatloaf, alas, didst not win my favor,
For 'twas too firm, as if from the oven it didst emerge,
A mite too long, I fear, didst it dwell therein.
Yet, despite this, didst I enjoy my repast,
A goodly lunch, with naught to make me fast."

"Hark, fair maiden, I do confess,
A year hath passed, and still I find,
My tresses, though well-coiffed, alas,
Do lack that certain je ne sais quoi,
That élan, that certain charm, that doth,
Make me feel fair and lovely, as 'twere.

Oh, Julia, dearest stylist of mine,
Thou art as friendly as a summer's day,
And in thy skill, I do place great trust,
For thou dost remind me of my dear friend,
Whose spirit doth dance with joy and grace.

But lo, my latest visit, full of woe,
Didst leave my locks in disarray, I fear,
For Megan, though kind and pleasant, didst,
Leave my mane unkempt, and lacking flair.
The price, too, didst rise, as I didst see,
Fifty percent, a sum most dear, indeed.

And so, fair friends, I shall seek elsewhere,
A salon that doth make me feel most fair,
For though the cut was good, the style, alack,
Didst leave me feeling plain, and not quite chic.
I shall continue my search, till I find,
A salon that doth make my heart sing, and mind."

"Methinks I didst want to love this place with all mine heart,
For its conceit and service didst please me well.
The space, intimate, and food, of good report,
Didst make mine mouth to water and mine spirits to swell.

But alas, the price, it didst not align aright,
With market rates, it didst not keep pace.
The food, not bad, but o'erpriced, I do declare,
And portioned small, likewise, didst leave me in disgrace.

The cheese and charcuterie, a paltry sum,
For eighteen silver pieces, scarce a crumb.
And lo, the lamb bolognese and cassoulet,
Good, but not worth the silver they didst beset.

The Russian honey cake, a sweet delight,
But chilled from th' fridge, and lacking in its might.
Freshly made, it wouldst have been a treat,
But served cold, 'twas not a pleasant meet.

A loyal customer base, they shouldst seek,
With prices fair, and food most meek.
For though 'tis small, and new to boot,
'Tis not the prices that doth make the root.

Cheap furnishings and utensils, a sight to see,
Incongruent, with prices so high, methinks 'tis not the key.
A time to cut costs, and a time to invest,
The trick, to find the formula, that doth make the best."

"A novel notion, this build-thy-own sushi roll,
Where one may choose the fillings of their heart's desire,
But, alas, the price doth seem a bit steep,
For ingredients of questionable quality doth one acquire.

The rolls, they be of ample size, no doubt,
Yet, 'tis mostly rice that doth make up the bulk,
And though the machines do speed the process,
'Tis hard to ignore the lack of finesse.

In a college town, this establishment doth reside,
And thus, their target audience doth it abide,
But for those who seek a culinary delight,
Mayhap elsewhere shall they have to stray and roam."

"This joint's not my cup of tea, but maybe it's your thing. I ordered the enchilada omelet, and let me tell you, it was a disappointment. They slathered some disgusting processed cheese all over it. I mean, who does that? It's like they're trying to ruin a perfectly good dish. And don't even get me started on the menu - they claim it's got jack cheese, but let's be real, it's just some fake, processed crap. But hey, the service wasn't half bad, and the coffee cake was decent."

"Underwhelming experience with too much repetition."
Service was sufficient but lacked authenticity, and the food, while passable, wasn't impressive.

In fair Phoenix, where sports fans do gather,
I sought a new haunt, to watch the game,
Tired of the Half Moon, its atmosphere,
I yearned for change, and a different name.

Teakwoods, a place of note, did catch my eye,
With TVs many, and a menu extensive,
Drink specials, too, did seem quite nice,
A place to watch, and revel in delight.

The food, a bar fare, yet tasty still,
Jess Jess wings, a treat, worth the bill,
But alas, the beer, a sorry sight,
A list most dreadful, a true plight.

Yet, the crowd, a diverse throng,
Eclectic, and full of life, a song,
Frat boys, five, in merriment,
Gangstas, four, with attitude bent,
Hipsters, three, with shades so bright,
Goth chicks, two, on a date so right,
A daughter, one, with her mum so fair,
Arguing, laughing, in the air.

Teakwoods, a place of wonder,
A partridge in a pear tree, no other,
Beer, a minus, but food, a plus,
Sports watching, good, and people, too.

So if thou seekest, a place to cheer,
Teakwoods, a spot, most dear, my dear.

"Alack, the Whole Foods I visit, doth lack
In size and selection, compared to others of its kind.
Their gluten-free offerings, fair and plentiful they be,
Yet finding what I seek, doth prove a challenge to me.

In this small space, I wander, searching high and low,
But oft, my quest doth end in disappointment, I do confess.
The prices, dear, they doth climb steeply up the scale,
Overpriced, methinks, and doth leave me in dismay."

"Went to a Lakers preseason game against the Kings. Had decent seats. Got there early, told the attendant we had tix, and she sent us to the long line to buy more. Waited 10 minutes, asked again, and she said we could skip the line. What a waste. Food and drink lines were long too."

"Went to this joint with the missus and grandma on Mother's Day. Made a reservation, glad we did, place was packed. Decor was alright, but the crowd made it feel cramped. Ordered the biscuits, not bad, but not worth raving about either. Hubs had pancakes, decent. Grandma had the hash, she enjoyed it. Would go back, try something else next time."

"Hark, what's this? A fast food feast, fit for a king!
A lobster dish, that doth my senses sing!
But nay, my mind doth play the skeptic's part,
For how can such rich fare be found in a cart?

And yet, upon my taste buds doth it make its mark,
With flavors bold and aromas that embark.
The bloody mary lobster shot, a curious delight,
Doth dance upon my tongue with grace and might.

And those lobster lollipops, oh how they shine,
A sweet and savory treat, most divine.
The price, a steal, for such a culinary find,
Doth make my purse strings sing with joy unwind.

So heed my words, dear friends, and give it a go,
For this fast food lobster doth surprise, I do avow.
A taste of luxury, in a humble guise,
That doth elevate the common to the skies."

"Fair priced, good victuals, and service most kind,
A place to dine, if thy purse be not too thin.
Thirty dollars, all thou canst eat, a feast most fine,
Choose thou thine own sides, a pleasant design.
Bulgogi, their best meat, and short ribs, a delight,
Their service, excellent, with hearts most bright.
But, alas, a trifle marred my joy, a woe,
The cashier, with words most bold, didst say,
'Twas mandatory, a tip, I must bestow,
A command, most vexing, didst make me go.
I wouldst have left it, but their words, so rude,
Didst make me reconsider, in a mood.
So, three stars, I give, for their fare, most fair,
But, service, with a smile, they must repair."

In fair Verona, where we lay our scene,
A humble eatery doth stand, Trevi by name.
No wondrous feast, yet tasty, doth it bring,
And o'erpriced by just a few coins, doth cling.

The cheese ravioli, a dish most fine,
Did please my taste, yet seemed not worth the dine.
But in fair Las Vegas, where all is grand,
Trevi doth offer prices most bland.

Amidst the fare, one dish doth shine,
Polenta Fries, a treat most divine.
Cutely served, in marinara's embrace,
A culinary delight, without a trace.
"Mexican joint, old-school style. Good grub, no brew. AC, meh. Not for the faint of heart. Traditional, through and through. I'll be back when the sun ain't blazing."
"Reservation or not, the joint was hoppin'. Filet was a letdown, as were all the other dishes. Maybe I should've gone with seafood."

"Hark! When to BRGR I didst venture forth,
The Button Buster didst catch mine eye.
A hearty burger, full of juicy girth,
Didst make mine mouth to water nigh.

But lo! The braised short ribs, so fatty,
Didst dampen mine spirits, I must confess.
I plucked them off, and to the rest,
Didst give mine teeth a thorough quest.

Alas! No side doth come with this feast,
A sorrow, truly, and a woeful waste.
Yet still, if to BRGR I do return,
A different burger shall be mine to learn."

"Solid grub from Christian. Sometimes, I crave some good ol' fashioned WT chow. Their nosh is greasy and delish. People often compare joints to high-end steakhouses. Not me. I rate 'em based on what they are. This spot serves up tasty, hearty victuals. Enjoyed every bite."

"Fare thee well, good sir! Verily, the victuals here be of highest quality, a true delight for mine own taste buds. Alas, the attendance doth leave much to be desired, a bitter flavor indeed. I fear 'tis not a place for younglings, nay, not at all."

"Fair juice indeed, but mark my words, good sir,
The machine must be clean ere thou dost sip,
Lest it doth taste of previous draughts, and thus,
Thy drink be marred by flavors most uncouth.

And, prithee, manageress, hold thy tongue,
For yelling and ill speech doth make a scene most foul.
In front of customers, thy words doth sting,
And rudely doth thy authority unfold."

"Methinks Bouchon doth merit three stars, fair sir,
Based on my first visit, with pleasure I do aver.
A pretty dining room, with atmosphere most fine,
My love and I didst dine there on a Saturday of late.

We ordered chicken and waffles, steak frites, oysters too,
And cocktails to boot, as any couple might do.
The bread and butter, soft and fresh, a delight,
The oysters, fresh indeed, yet specify thou must,
For types of oysters, ask thy waitress, lest confusion reign,
Chicken and waffles, naught out of the ordinary, I do swear,
Steak frites, good and tasty, no complaints could I make.

Yet this, my friends, a minor quibble, I do confess,
That one person serve us, to make things more neat,
For timeliness and consistency, 'twere my humble request,
For though the staff were kind, our dishes came not all at once,
A gap betwixt the bread and oysters, and main courses too,
And when I asked the waitress, if my drink would come anon,
She seemed surprised, in truth, it had not yet been done.
Perhaps 'tis the bartender, who doth deliver the drink,
I know not, yet this, my friends, a small thing to think.

So, Bouchon, three stars, upon my first visit, I do say,
And willing, I am, to give it another try, ere long,
For pretty dining room, and atmosphere most fair,
It doth deserve a second chance, without a single care."

"Hark, what news is this? A chicken parm so fine,
It doth astound and make my taste buds twine.
And though some say, with Puritan disdain,
That Chinese folk didst cook this Italian gain,
I say, "Pshaw!" For flavor knows no bounds,
Nor heedeth it the hands that doth prepare the grounds.

But alas, dear friends, two stars doth fade,
For prices steep and menus poorly made.
A score of twenty dollars, forsooth,
Doth seem a bit too much, and quite uncouth.
And naught but chicken, breasts so fair and bright,
Doth leave me wanting more, with appetite unsatisfied in the night.

Yet fear not, gentle patrons, for there is a way,
To dine on chicken, and pay a smaller fee, per day.
A kiddie meal, with spaghetti, doth suffice,
And at a sixth of the cost, doth seem quite nice.

Now mark this well, for 'tis a curious sight,
A sign that doth proclaim, with words so bright,
"Health Inspected," as if to calm our fears,
And show us that the food doth meet the standards, year by year."
"Good spot for people-watchin' or sippin' a drink while you wait for a table at Le Provençal. Gelato's decent, but the grub's more on the junk food side. Service is a bit slow."

"Vietnamese grub, my standards run high. Lived in SoCal, twenty minutes from Little Saigon. Service here, good. Restaurant, clean, modern. Food? Just okay. Grilled pork, too fatty, too salty. Even for me, a salt-lover."

"A hearty meal, the chicken shwarma doth make,
In a soft pita, with chicken of fair quality,
No grease, a pleasant surprise, doth it bring.
The owner, a sweet soul, doth serve with glee.
Seating, alas, doth leave much to be desired,
Yet still, a worthy feast, at a fair price, it doth provide.
I shall, ere long, the gyros dish assay,
And see if 'tis as good, as they say."

"My dearest husband, I didst implore thee to visit this place ere we returned our rented steed, forsooth, the reviews didst speak highly of their confections. Verily, the maple donut, a celestial delight! Crisp without, soft within, a true marvel of the baker's art. Of cinnamon crumb, a worthy second, a sweet and savory treat. Alas, the apple fritter, a disappointment, o'er-fried and overly sweet, a mere morsel didst suffice. The coffee, a sorry brew, akin to that of a common tavern, a slight upon mine taste. Yet, for the maple and cinnamon crumb, I wouldst return, mayhap to sample the old-fashioned glaze, but the coffee and apple fritter, ne'er again."
"Wings were dry, nachos were decent. Better than back home, where Buffalo Wild Wings ruined it for me. Crowded on Sundays, perfect for football."

"Good hotel. Amenities galore. Pools are top-notch. But steer clear of rooms near the Vista Lounge. Live music blasts for hours daily, and it ain't exactly melodic. Internet costs extra, which stinks. Room service is decent but pricey, like most resorts. That's the way it goes."

I came for a dinner, informational and networking. Cheese curds, first time in Wisconsin, had to try 'em. Waitress surprised us, don't know what we got, but they were alright. Someone said best she'd ever had, but I couldn't tell ya. No standard, y'see?\n\nScandinavian chicken dinner, half bird rubbed with cinnamon, cardamom, juniper. Mashed potatoes, stuffing on the side. Decent, but nothing special. Lovely decorations, though.

"Tight, Cali-style clothes for dudes and chicks. Tanks, boards shorts, tees, jeans, and kicks for the fellas. Dresses, shorts, tops, shirts, swimwear, jeans, and shoes for the ladies. Brands like Brandy Melville, Volcom, Billabong, Quicksilver, Vans, and some Nike SBs. They got some rad accessories, too. Big store, decent quality. Good spot for teens or those who are slender (lol). I dig some stuff, but a bit pricey if you ask me."

"Hark, good sir! Thou art in search of a hearty meal? Pray tell, what say thee of this establishment? Aye, 'tis true, the decor doth please mine eyes, and the serving dishes, they doth delight. But alack, the price of the triple B burger, verily, 'twas a steep sum of twenty dollars! Methinks 'twas not worth the cost, forsooth. Our hostess, she didst ignore us, leaving us to wait, ere she didst seat us. And our waitress, her service was poor, indeed. Yet, our runner, he was most kind and attentive, a true gem amidst the rest. \n\nIf thou dost seek a fine burger, prithee, try Bachi burger, where thou shalt find a grass-fed burger, eight dollars cheaper! In conclusion, methinks 'twas a trial worth attempting, yet the high prices and lacking staff doth make me doubt our return."

"Amidst the throng of modern hotels that now do stand,
The Flamingo doth hold its own, a veteran of the land.
With amenities complete and rooms that be clean,
It doth succeed, yet also doth it fail, I do glean.

The service, alas, doth leave much to be desired,
And the casino floor, dingy, doth not inspire.
The rooms, though nice, do not compare to those nearby,
And dining, nightlife options, do leave much to be desired, I say.

Margaritaville, a valiant effort, doth come across as dated,
Cheesy, even, to those who do behold its fate.
But central location, rooms pleasant, value high,
Flamingo, not a bad choice, doth catch the eye.

Imperial Dungeon, a place to avoid, I do declare,
Flamingo, much better, doth show it fair and square."

"Food's good for the price, but the place needs a scrubbin'. Givin' 'em three stars 'cause they ain't doin' their job right. Don't matter how good the grub is or how friendly the service is, if it's dirty as hell, that's all that matters."

"Hark! A place most wondrous, fair and bright,
Where one may dine and drink with great delight.
A score of visits have I made, 'tis true,
For there, my purse doth stretch and grow anew.

The champagne brunch, a feast most fine,
Doth please my taste and quench my thirst divine.
The servers, swift and kind, do pour,
Mimosas, abundant as the morning dew.

The buffet, full of dishes, doth abound,
Yet none, I say, doth stand out from the ground.
Still, value for thy coin, doth it provide,
And thus, my friends, I shall return, and bide.

More than once, shall I partake,
For there, my heart doth find its sweetest cake."

"Methinks this place was passable, in sooth,
A hour we waited, ere we were seated,
Then didst wait yet another hour, ere our victuals were presented.
I ordered waffles, of a goodly size,
And deemed it wise, not to share, lest it be too small a portion.
My spouse, however, chose a dish most bountiful,
A feast fit for two, and verily, 'twas a sight to behold.
In conclusion, fair readers, give this place a try,
At least once, ere thou dost depart this mortal coil."

"Amidst the gaudy hotels that line the famed Strip,
One lodging stands apart, with charm that's quite hip.
The Flamingo, though not decked in glittering array,
Offers a humble stay, at a price that's quite play.

The buffet, too, is modest, yet still a steal,
With victuals that may not impress, but will certainly reveal
A taste of the exotic, a hint of the grand,
In this avian-themed haven, where flamingos take command.

So come, dear friends, and join in the fun,
At the Flamingo, where laughter and luncheon are won.
For though it may lack the pomp of its peers,
This bird of a hotel will bring you cheer and ease."

In fair Southern Highlands, we didst seek  
A place with Wi-Fi, our hearts didst speak.  
And lo, we found a spot, named Perk Up,  
Wherein we might find sustenance and cup.  

With haste, we entered, eager to partake  
In their offerings, and our bellies to slake.  
The menu, we didst peruse, with much delight,  
And saw coffees, teas, and pastries in sight.  

A chalkboard, standing tall, didst proclaim  
Breakfast and lunch dishes, in its name.  
I ordered tea, and then, didst decide  
To partake in lunch, my hunger to abide.  

I asked the maiden, fair and bright,  
About sandwiches, and her words didst ignite.  
She spoke of pumpkin muffins, fresh from the oven,  
And quiche, a dish, that didst make me proven.  

I chose the quiche, with fruit, beside,  
But alas, the fruit, didst not abide.  
'Twas old and wilted, a sight to behold,  
But the quiche, didst satisfy, though not of old.  

The maiden, seeing our dismay,  
Didst bring fresh fruit, in a play.  
Nice and clean, the place didst seem,  
With service, friendly, and of good esteem.  

Though not a place, I'd crave to dine,  
For coffee or tea, 'twill be divine.

"Hark! We came for lunch and a view most fair,
Of the strip, where Bellagio and Caesars do stand.
A table with a view, we did easily find,
And for our meal, we didst not have to wait in line.

I had a burger, cooked to perfection,
For sixteen dollars, a fair price, no objection.
My wife, she had crepes, baked with care,
For seventeen dollars, a dish beyond compare.

The food, it was good, but the view, it was grand,
Worth every penny, of that, I am fond.
They brought us bread puffs, and pudding too,
A pleasant surprise, for me and my dear, anon.

But alas, the Eiffel Tower, so tall and proud,
We thought we'd reach the top, but 'twas not allowed.
This place, it stands but five floors high,
A modest elevation, yet still, the view doth lie."

"Alack, my friends, I bring tidings of woe,
For though improvements have been made, 'tis still a bleak scene that doth greet mine eyes.
The train station, once a place of hope and cheer, now doth resemble a dank and dismal cave,
Where chill winds howl and frost doth bite, despite the indoor waiting area's sheltering embrace.

Alas, I had wished to raise my rating to three stars, but alack, 'twas not meant to be,
For though the efforts have been made, the result doth leave much to be desired, I do declare.
This station, so well-used and bustling, doth cry out for greater care and attention,
Lest the weary traveler, lost in thought, doth shiver with each step and sigh with discontent."

"Tucked away at one end of the wondrous Miracle Mile Shops,
This eatery doth boast a bounty of benches and chairs,
With friendly faces aplenty, eager to serve and assist.
And through the windows, thou mayst gaze upon the pool,
A shimmering oasis, a haven from the desert's heat."
"Burger and rings, decent. Good, not great. If you're at the Mirage, sure. Otherwise, look elsewhere."

"Twas a fair events center, but naught special, I say,
For trade shows, at least, it didst not sway.
Perhaps, had I been there for music or fray,
I might have found it more to my liking, who knows?

But alack, the wi-fi, it didst cost a pretty penny,
Five hundred gold coins, per day, they didst demand, oh me!
A typo, a bug, a mistake, I didst think,
But nay, 'twas no error, just a cruel trick.

And thus, I didst decline, to pay such a price,
For free wi-fi, the Las Vegas Convention Center doth provide, in nice.

And then, a cab, I didst seek, to flee the place,
But lo, there were none, and a long wait, I didst face.
Ten persons deep, I stood, and twenty minutes passed,
Ere a carriage, finally, didst arrive at last.

Oh, cursed fate, that doth beset this place,
With poor service, and no cabs, to grace its space.
But still, go thou, for the event, 'tis worth the while,
Though the center itself, doth leave a bit of a smile."
"Floyd Mayweather's spot, cute and touristy, but pricey. Not plus-size friendly. I dig good service, might've bought something if they were friendlier. Small business supporter, #girlpower."

"Applebee's, a place for the hipsters. Decent service, but slow on the grub. New table-side computers, distracting and pushy. Food's alright, Sysco stuff with too much salt. Chicken tortilla soup and honey pepper chicken tenders, not bad. Music's meh, but sometimes aggravating. Wonder why we keep going back."

"Hark, what's this? A sign doth say,
In this place, thou mayst sit but twenty minutes, ere thou must away.
So, prithee, come with hunger great, lest thou be forced to flee."

"A fair location, with view of the lake so blue,
Flexible they were, with last-minute reservations anew.
Not fit for small children, alas, did they say,
But we, a party of seven, didst come what may.

The server, a laggard, didst flag us down,
 Multiple times, for water and order, and payment profound.
The victuals, not bad, but o'erpriced, I do declare,
And the wine and dessert lists, most extensive, beyond compare.

But here's why I shall not return, mark my words,
Two antipasta plates, brought forth by the server, unheard.
We did not ask, nor request, this offering so free,
Yet charged we were, seventy-two gold coins, oh woe is me!

The server, unhelpful, didst not remove the plate,
Nor separate the bill, four checks, such an irate.
With Lake Las Vegas' Village, in struggles so deep,
You'd think the businesses, their patrons would appease, and creep.

Alas, a bad taste, doth linger in my mouth,
This restaurant, I shall not recommend, no doubt.
Long story short, a poor experience, indeed,
Shall keep me away, and advise others, take heed."
"This joint’s for gringos. Drink specials are top-notch, but Taco Bell’s got better chow."

"IHOP ain't always great, but this one's not half bad. Busy spot too, especially during spring training. Made the mistake of goin' there during peak hour, had to wait a bit to sit down. But once we did, service was good and so was the grub. Open 24/7, just in case you need some pancakes in the dead of night."

"Walk out feeling healthy. Thinly sliced beef and veggies in broth or sauce, not too many carbs. Small noodle portion, mostly protein and veggie. Good value. Sukiyaki can be too salty, especially when it boils down. Shabu shabu's my preference."

"This joint's alright, I reckon. If I had a million hours to kill, I'd stroll over and grab me some sweet 'n' sour chicken, maybe a cup of green tea too. Shame they don't deliver, though. Last time I was there, the fella was so busy he put the phone down and forgot about it. I found it funny, but I'm sure the customer on the other end didn't. \nNow, if they ain't gonna deliver, they should at least keep the place tidy. I've peeked into the kitchen a few times and it's a mess - too many cooks in the kitchen, if you know what I mean. \nStill, the grub's good, but I only come here a couple times a semester. It's just too dang crowded for my taste."

"Afore the truth doth come to pass,
Excitement doth abound in this place,
Chocolat Bistro, where crepes doth please,
But alas, the tourist TV doth disgrace.

In fair Las Vegas, where all is bright,
The buffet doth shine with four stars light,
So giddy up, my friends, and doth partake,
For here, excess doth make the heart to break."

"In fair Montreal, where we didst roam,
A dish called Poutine didst grace our list,
Cafe Poutine, a place of some renown,
Didst draw us in with its name and site.

The eatery was small, the tables close,
We struggled through, with elbows bent,
The menu boasted many a Poutine choice,
And sandwiches too, with fries to augment.

My love, she had the smoked meat kind,
Whilst I, a chicken, apple, brie find,
No fries for me, I thought to share,
But lo, a mountain of spuds didst glare.

The portions were generous, to say the least,
My baguette, toasted just right, a feast,
The brie and apples, a perfect pair,
Together on a plate, without a care.

The service, alas, was swift and cold,
They missed my request, no cheese to hold,
And two waters, poutine, chicken, all told,
Cost us 35 CA, a sum not small.

If in the area, a stop, perchance,
But for a true Poutine experience, advance."

"A woeful plight, my friends, doth lie within the land of electronics. Forsooth, service doth vary, and oft doth leave much to be desired. A sprinkling of kind salesfolk doth grace the halls, yet all too many doth prove inept or overly zealous in their endeavors. 'Tis wise, then, to enter with purpose and foreknowledge of thine desires, lest thou be led astray by confusion and frustration."

"Flight oversold. How's that happen? Flying back from an Iron Maiden show in Phoenix, paid and checked in early. But my flight's oversold. Pissed, I was. Review started at one star. Raised it to three 'cause they found me a comfy seat on the same flight. Flight attendants, nice and courteous. So, I'm happy."

"Cracker Barrel. Haven't been there in eight years or more. Ordered takeout last week. Manager fixed a problem with the order, so husband said to give 'em four stars. But that chicken fried steak? Minus one star, easy."

"In fairest Phoenix, where the sun doth shine bright,
A restaurant didst beckon me with its delight.
'Twas my first venture into such an eating place,
And, truth be told, my nerves were in disarray.
Afore an interview, I didst partake
Of luncheon here, and though my mind was astray,
I found the fare to be most excellent,
Sushi, a feast for eyes and taste buds, didst prevail.
The service, too, was of the highest sort,
Efficient and kind, a true delight, no doubt.
So, if thou art a fan of sushi, do give this place
A try, and should thy schedule be quite tight,
'Twill serve thee well, a meal to eat at thy desk,
With nary a fuss, nor any great inconvenience."

"Family eats fish, I don't. Husband and daughter rave about fried catfish. I stick to steak, it's a disappointment. Menu's all fried, nothing healthy. Salad's drenched in cheese and bacon. If you care about your health, you'll feel guilty leaving."

Hark! What ho! I have not reviewed this place ere now,
And yet, a hundred times, I've graced its bow.
No serious, 'tis the best eatery in the east,
But friends at Corbin's could spice up the feast.
Their grub, though good, doth grow stale with time,
Oversauced pasta, buttered wings, a crime.
Pizzas, too, they make, and quite well, I say,
But why, oh why, doth the owner frown away?
He ne'er hath said a word, nor thanked me for my patronage,
A pox upon his house, for such discourtesy!
Yet still, betwixt five and eight, the crowd doth swarm,
For in the east, this place doth stand apart.
A fine selection of ale, they do possess,
But methinks, their hospitality doth need address.

"Food was good, not gonna lie. Barbacoa burrito, meat was tender, sweet. Beans and sauce made it hard to pick up, needed a knife and fork. Pricey, not the cheapest. First time there, they asked tricky questions. Wanted to know if I wanted it enchilada style. I said no, they did it anyway and charged me extra. Not worth it. Good food, but pricey and tricky."

"Methinks 'twas but a fortnight past, my aunt and I didst dine at yonder eatery, whereupon she didst revel in the fried soft shell crab, a dish most delectable, I must confess. Yet, in sooth, I must demur, for though 'twas not unpalatable, I have had far better at other Japanese taverns of like quality. Verily, we didst order two great vessels, overflowing with sundry sushi rolls, of spicy tuna, California, eel, soft shell crab, and skewers of chicken teriyaki, besides sashimi. Alack, the victuals were naught but middling, and I wouldst not choose to partake of them again."
"Vegetarians need not apply. Meat-eaters, rejoice. Good grub, stiff drinks, and swift service at the bar. Lawyers love it post-work."

"A treasure hidden'mongst the glitz and glam,
In Planet Hollywood, a secret gem,
Food priced fair, and served with haste,
Though timing matters, pace thine taste.

In midst of Strip's bustling throng,
This haven beckons, all day long,
Sandwiches, middling, naught to boast,
Yet serves its purpose, no need to roast.

And lo! 'Tis open round the clock,
For those who crave a midnight snack,
After a night of revelry and fun,
This refuge shall thy hunger shun."

"Staff was real friendly, rooms were good size. But experience wasn't all that great. Room wasn't ready 'til after check-in time, so we had to drop our bags and hit the strip. Came back to the resort, hung out in my buddy's suite. Didn't get to my room 'til 4:15 am. Bedding was dirty, but the staff was cool, replaced everything with fresh sheets and pillows. Some other small issues, but the staff was always pleasant. Not sure if I'd stay there again."

"Great joint, fun and hip. Balcony's a nice spot for the pirate show. Prices are steep, though. Shrimp stir-fry was too salty, had to send it back. Kobe sliders were also too salty, but the onion rings were good. Lychee beignets were like doughnuts, too sweet, but the yellowtail sashimi was decent. Edamame was warm and salty, sushi was good, and hubby liked the steak yakitori."

"Went for lunch on 10/26/11. Girl at the counter gave us the stink-eye for comin' in off-peak. Asked about coffee, she tells me there's two joints next door. Real friendly, that one. Almost made me wanna skip the sandwich and go next door for my caffeine fix. Bread was decent, though - warm and toasty. Caprese salad's usually chilly, but on a sandwich, it felt off. Like it was warm and crumbly on the outside, cold on the inside. Not bad, but not worth another visit anytime soon."

"Methinks I didst oft order from yon place,
Their pizza, it didst please mine taste,
But alas! their ravioli, o'ercooked it was,
I do prefer it, Al dente, in truth.
Their lasagne, a mediocre dish, at best,
And oh! the bread knots, how they didst burn,
Despite my pleas, they didst arrive, alack,
In tardiness, thrice, their delivery didst lack.
This was not during peak hours, I do declare,
Alack! I fear, I shall not return there."

"Mimi's, huh? Heard good things. Went with a buddy, GF like me. Told 'em we were comin', so they knew to save some gluten-free goods. Scones were decent, but crumbled like sand. Ate 'em with jam and cream, though. Cupcake? Forgettable. Not worth the trip to The Shore. Better GF cakes elsewhere."

"In Arizona, where the sun doth shine bright,
There lies a place that doth serve a feast,
Of Ethiopian cuisine, full of delight,
Though not the most authentic, 'tis a treat.

Their sour injera, a spongy bread, doth please,
With alicha sega wat, a beef stew, if thou dost seize,
A taste so rich, it doth astound,
And in the combos, three stews are found.

A way to sample, and find thy desire,
And in this place, thy taste buds shall fire."

"Our server, a most excellent fellow, didst attend to our needs with great haste and diligence. Our glasses, never empty, didst remain full to the brim, and our orders, in a timely fashion, didst arrive. I, myself, didst partake in the chili cheese fries and twelve wings, honey BBQ style. Alas, the sauce, a tad too potent, didst overpower the taste, and the wings, they didst not remain warm for long, growing cold within five brief minutes. The fries, too, didst suffer the same fate. 

Now, being a man of experience, having once tended bar, I do confess, I am quite particular about the preparation of drinks. My Shirley Temple, alas, was made with the grenadine at the bottom, making it difficult to mix, and, mayhap, a bit too sweet. 

We sat without, in the open air, which was most pleasant, and the televisions, they were ideal for viewing the contest between Carolina and Duke. Methinks, the victual, mayhap, doth not hold the highest place in their regard, yet wouldst I return, anon, to partake in the sporting events."

"Tao, my first Vegas clubbing experience. Loved the decor, theme, Buddha, girls in bathtubs, unique restrooms. But, it got too crowded, the crowd was meh. Won't be back. Try Encore or Wynn clubs instead."

"Happy hour's decent here. Good crowd, atmosphere's top-notch for Chandler. Staff's friendly too. But the tables are cramped, like a fat kid's pants after a Golden Corral binge. Parking's a pain, you'll probaby have to park elsewhere and walk. Food's just okay. Not the best. If you're lookin' for a happy hour spot, this'll do. But for a meal, keep lookin'."

In fair Phoenix, where culture doth abound,
A humble pit stop, with treasures profound.
A gallery, with walls of brick and floor of stone,
Doth house a bookstore and bakery, all alone.
The art, though pricey, doth not disappoint,
A pleasant stop, for mind and taste, 'tis apt.

"Barbecue ain't all the same. Grew up on Chicago's south side, eatin' proper ribs, not that pulled pork nonsense. Rib tips, ya hear me? Saturated in sauce, meat falls off the bone. Smell the char a couple blocks away. That's barbecue, friend. Don't get me wrong, other styles are fine too. Had a pulled pork sandwich, decent. But when it's great, I don't share. Those ribs were just alright. Service was top-notch though. Hostess and waitstaff, real friendly, attentive. Shame more places ain't run like Bobby Q."

"Groupon, sometimes. Like this time, they weren't ready for the crowd. Service was slow, real slow. Stuff came wrong, but we were too hungry to give a damn. Our local sushi spot got overwhelmed, but we'll be back."

"Went to a Rutland Bar with pals for drinks one eve. Prices too steep for my taste, but damn fine atmosphere and friendly staff. Classy joint, this one. If you're lookin' for a spot to chat and sip drinks while takin' in the sights of Princes Street, it's not a bad choice. Just remember, it's a bit on the pricey side."

"Rudy's, decent joint for BBQ. Pros: sauces galore, creamed corn's top-notch, spacious digs, convenient location. Cons: service can be unprofessional, no fries, general store's lackluster. Verdict: give it a shot, especially for that damn good creamed corn."

"Met at BW3 for a work meetin'. Host and waitress, real friendly. Good grub, decent service. Ordered the Bleu & Black burger, tasty. Fries, a bit soggy from that big ol' pickle, but I ain't complainin', 'cause I was starvin'. Not bad, not great. Wouldn't go outta my way, but I ain't opposed neither. Okay spot."
"Food was two-star quality, at best. But we were hungry, and it was late. So, I give it three stars. It was your typical breakfast diner grub. Didn't blow my mind, but it filled my belly."
"Skillet, more veggie than meat. Sausage, barely a bite. Pancake, fluffy and fine. Decent grub, but nothing to rave about."

"Four times here, and the grub's top-notch. Had my fair share of Italian fare, but this joint takes the cake. Server, though, left a bit to be desired. Hoping for a bit more attentive service and a friendly smile next time around."

"A fair tavern, fit for a pint ere a match,  
But beware, 'tis oft crowded, and space doth lack.  
No victuals served here, thou must seek sustenance  
In yonder hall, and bear it back with patience.  
The expansive courtyard, a wondrous sight,  
With ample room for revelry and delight."

"Hark! What do mine eyes perceive? A sight most fair and bright,
A sushi bar, with artistry in every detail, doth delight.
My purpose here, to rest and refresh, 'twixt duties great,
Fujo's hospitality, did timely and well-appointed greet.

In Carolina's clime, with fiery craving, I did choose,
The Cajun Roll, with crayfish, shrimp, and crab, in noble voice.
Though not a feast for gods, nor did it leave me cold,
Acceptance, I have learned, in sushi, doth my soul enfold.

But alas! The hot-and-sour soup, did not my taste buds cheer,
With ingredients, not fresh, and broth, but bordering on fear.
Yet still, this place doth hold a certain charm, and grace,
Though perhaps not Charlotte's finest, in culinary embrace."
"Food was passable. Don't expect much from India Palace or Taj Mahal. Private party with rowdy kids. Should've closed to public or asked for respect. Service was fine. Food, meh."

"Hark! What beer doth flow within these hallowed walls?
A church, yet now a tavern, doth enthrall.
The ale, it doth delight, with flavors so bright,
And yet, methinks 'tis strange to quaff here through the night.

Three or four brews we didst sample, all most fine,
One Belgian style, oh how it didst shine!
But alas, the service, it didst leave much to be sought,
For servers who doth pout, their tips are naught.

Church Brew Works, thy name doth say it all,
Yet, minus one star, for service doth fall.
Perhaps, we shouldst have sat at yonder bar,
To savor beer, in this most curious place, so rare."

"Last weekend, we chanced upon a novel sushi spot, near our abode, to dine and sample their wares. The rain did pour, and we did crave a feast most fine. Upon entering, we found the place to be quite snug, yet clean and well-appointed. We ordered four rolls of sushi, and Goyza and edamame to start, which did please our palates greatly. The diamondback roll, oh how grand, with its light and crispy tempura bits, a true delight! The fried cali roll, a close second, and the dragon roll, not bad at all. My dear wife, she did enjoy the spicy shrimp roll, but alas, 'twas not to mine own liking. \n\nIn sooth, we would return anon, during happy hour, to save a few coins, and in truth, the only drawbacks to the place, were the decor and space, a bit lacking, I do confess. But fear not, fair maiden or noble sir, for the sushi, verily, doth rock, and a quiet night for two, most pleasant and fine."

"Mailing's cheap here, cheaper than UPS or FedEx. That's a fact. Post office's alright too. Big, plenty of space to wait. Not like those cramped old spots that make you feel like cattle. Lines are long, but that's expected. Always give yourself extra time. They got rid of the stamp machine, so that's a bummer. But there's a self-service machine for small packages. That's handy. Parking lot's huge too. Overall, not bad."

In this humble inn, where fancy trappings be not found,  
I oft reside, and merriment doth abound.  
The Toby Keith bar, a place of mirth and glee,  
Doth bring me joy, with friends and drinks aplenty.  
A Chinese eatery, with flavors so fine,  
Doth satisfy my hunger, and doth combine  
With the casino's charm, a place of chance and skill,  
Where fortune smiles upon me, and my will doth fulfill.  
The staff, though average, doth their duty well,  
And ne'er have I encountered trouble or hell.  
The location, too, doth suit my needs,  
Convenient and central, as my heart doth plead.  
So join the club, and claim thy share of deals,  
For Harrah's doth provide, with generosity that doth reveal.

"Methinks my sister and I didst venture forth into Chinatown upon a Friday eve, with sushi being our heart's desire. Yet, with a wait of ninety minutes, I didst pose the query, hath thou, my dear sibling, partaken of Korean BBQ? She, with haste, didst reply, "Aye!" And thus, our destination was chosen.

Forsooth, I, a man of little faith in culinary novelties, didst seek guidance from my kin. Once gone, I didst embrace the experience, and, with zeal, didst introduce others to this wondrous feast.

Upon entry, we didst behold rows of cozy booths, each adorned with a round grill, central to the table. 'Twas BBQ-ing within walls, a veritable carnivore's haven! Beef of diverse sorts, fresh shrimp, and pork, in abundance, didst grace the menu.

Few vegetable options there were, in the form of a salad bar, accompanied by prepared Asian dishes, sweet and sour pork, sushi, tempura vegetables, and varied other salads, akin to macaroni, yet, Asian, their names, I knew not.

Our glasses, ever full, didst remain, and the grill, when messy, didst they diligently cleanse.

In sooth, a unique experience, and one worth attempting, methinks!"

"By chance, we found ourselves within these walls,
Where elders gather, Sun City's finest souls.
Their dinner bell doth ring at three o'clock,
And we, the youthful pair, do take our place,
At yonder bar, where libations flow and snacks abound.
Their mixers, skillfully crafted, bring us joy,
And tasty bites, a pleasure to employ.
The barkeepers, with cheer and grace, do serve,
And welcome us, the young, with open arms.
Though better seafood may be found,
In need, Red Lobster doth suffice, profound."

"Never been a fan...too much shabby chic and new country junk...real antiques are rare and overpriced. Staff can be standoffish, or I feel like I'm being watched. But sometimes you'll find a steal, and some new dealers have created cozy spaces. Worth another look."

"Hark! A feast most wondrous did we partake,  
My wife and I, at Papa Kelsey's fair.  
A pizza special, hot and freshly baked,  
Did I devour, with toppings of my choice.  
Whilst she, a calzone with extras did choose,  
Tomato, pepper, olive, and onion, a tasty mix.  
Two salads, Italian, with blue cheese and dressing,  
We ordered, and a root beer, oh so refreshing.  
The food, alright, our hunger did abate,  
But, alas! A booth seat, torn and worn,  
A sight most unseemly, a shame, a blight.  
Yet still, we must support local eats,  
For they do bring us joy, and fill our bellies with delight."

"Hark! If thou seeketh a stiff drink to flee the heat of this wretched strip,
Then hie thee hence to this establishment, where strong margaritas doth flow like a river.
We sampled them, both on the rocks and frozen, and found them to be quite divine.
I must confess, I was taken aback, for they do churn them out in vast quantities,
Like a never-ending stream of liquid gold, poured forth from the gods above.
The victuals, alas, were naught to write home about, but neither were they a disappointment.
For in this city of excess, 'tis the ambiance that doth command thy attention.
Aye, 'tis a trifle garish, but that's the charm of this place, and why we flock thither.
I would return, though not with bated breath, for there's naught truly remarkable to speak of."

"Went to the real deal in DC Ranch. Stopped by with some pals for a late-night bite and drinks. First timer, so one of the fellas got us a couple Tootsie Rolls (three, counting me, since my guy don't like sushi) and a Berry White martini - it's blue, baby. Don't recall what was in those rolls, but they were good. Love sushi, so I wolf it down. This joint's got a smooth, slick vibe."

"Methinks I do adore this place, with its pool tables grand and screens so vast, 
The tunes they play, the ambiance fine, the servers swift and kind at last. 
Their grilled cheese, oh how supreme! A dish most wondrous, doth make my friend beam, 
A vegetarian patty, alas! Not to my liking, yet still, I find this joint quite keen."
"Target, like all others. Nothing stands out, 'cept hybrid car chargers in the lot."
Busy spot. Good deal on Big Mac’s. Quick, easy grub for the kiddos on the move.

"Three visits to this place, always good. Breakfast, that's what I'm talking about. Acapulco express omelette, hell yeah. Chorizo, avocado, green chilies, onions, melted cheese, sour cream, fresh salsa. French toast, scratch-made, prickly pear butter, Arizona style. Now it's covered in berries and kiwi, still good. Service, top-notch, 25% tip, every time. Fruit bowls, not just crap melons and grapes. Coffee, decent, carafe always full. Solid joint, breakfast, that's my take."

"Disappointment hung heavy in the air like a bad omen. The restaurant, with its elegant layout and friendly staff, had promised so much, but failed to deliver. My expectations, sky-high, came crashing down like a bird shot from the sky. The food, mediocre at best, left a bad taste in my mouth. Forgettable, like a lover's quarrel. I wouldn't return, not with so many other options in this city. But, I must admit, their bread was decent, a small consolation prize for a disappointing meal."

"A jolly tavern, full of brew and cheer,
With victuals that did please mine eye and ear.
Our server, though a mite slow to begin,
Didst hasten forth with speedy grace therein.
I shall return, but mayhap not for meat,
For this place doth satisfy mine every need, save one,
That is, the craving for a frothy treat.
So here's to thee, good pub, may thy fame increase!"
"Sag paneer, nasty burnt garlic. Naan, good. Mango lassi, great. Confusing sign on door, thought it meant no cocktails. Actually means bring your own beer and wine only. Decor, nice."

In fair Las Vegas, we didst see four shows,
Mystere, Le Reve, O, and Criss Angel-Believe,
Their beauty was theatrical, with moments grand,
But alas, o'erhyped, they didst not stand.

Way too costly, for the price we didst pay,
Boredom didst creep in, and drove us away.
Mystere, the best, with laughter and delight,
Didst steal the show, and made our night.

"Went to Shoku Ramen three weeks back. Ordered tonkotsu ramen and potstickers. Potstickers, good. Slightly burnt, just how I like 'em. Crunchier when you bite in. Ramen, though? Needs work. Broth, too salty. Noodles, overcooked. Mushy when you bite in. Felt like the broth was too seasoned. Couldn't taste anything but salt. Wouldn't go back unless real hungry and real close. Wouldn't drive outta my way to eat there again."

"A pox upon this pharmacy of ill repute,
Whose service doth crawl at snail's pace, doth it not?
And lo, the checkers' queues, they doth stretch far and wide,
As if the patrons' time, it were of little worth.

In this, the city of excess, where doth shine
The glittering lights of vice and sin,
This pharmacy doth stand, a beacon of despair,
A place where patience doth go to die.

And yet, across the way, a Walgreens doth thrive,
A haven of efficiency, where doth time fly.
But nay, not here, where doth the staff, so slow,
Their ExtraCare discount card, didst none bestow."

"A most delightful spa pedicure, verily,  
That doth make my day, nay, my week, so merry!  
Clean and friendly, they do be, in truth,  
But alack, their massage chairs, a sorry sight,  
Do crave renewal, else I fear, their plight.  
Yet will I return, again and again,  
For their gentle touch and skilled hands, anon."

"Methinks 'tis strange, the praise that ATS doth receive,
A niche vegan group, perchance, doth give it leave?
I find the place, in truth, to be but so-so,
Despite the name, best carne asada, given by the local press, doth flow.

The menu, limited, doth leave much to be desired,
The prices, high, doth make my purse to feel quite tired.
And though the food, in fairness, doth have its own style,
I find it, in the end, to be but mediocre, at best, awhile.

So when out-of-towners ask, where they might find
The best Mexican fare, I doth steer them away,
For other places, better, doth my mind incline."

"Fast food, perchance to dream of fries most wondrous,
And burgers, juicy, savory, a feast for the taste.
Five Guys, a place where hunger doth meet its match,
A veritable cornucopia of culinary delight.

The fries, they do overflow, a bounty most fair,
Greasy, mayhap, yet a delicacy beyond compare.
And burgers, a bargain, a meal most true,
Not gourmet, no, but a treat for the soul anew.

The pop machines, a marvel of modern device,
Dispensing drinks of choice, a wondrous surprise.
The staff, a merry band of friendly folk,
A smile and a welcome, a pleasure to behold.

So, to Five Guys, we shall return again,
For fast food, a kingdom, a treasure to gain."

"Noodles serves up good grub, no question. Portions are generous, selection's top-notch. But the service? Not so much. Last time I was in, the joint was dead, save for a few occupied tables. And let me tell you, those tables were a mess - dishes and food scattered all over, just begging to be bussed. Had to ask 'em to clear a table for us before we could even sit down. If they'd been slammed, maybe it'd be excusable. But they weren't. Just poor form, if you ask me."

I walked into the joint around 8:40 on a Monday night. Place was already hopping with three parties deep. I hit the head before settling in, and let me tell you, there was a cockroach the size of a small dog staring back at me while I was taking care of business. Not exactly what I had in mind.

My buddy and I went for the AYCE dinner, $22.95 a pop. Appetizer was some questionable stuff called "THE SHIT!" - didn't do much for me, but my friend seemed to enjoy it. We also scored the 2-for-1 Sapporo deal, which was a damn good thing. Two huge bottles, enough to fill four cups. Not bad.

Sashimi salad was decent, loaded with sashimi. Just how I like it. Don't need no rice filling me up at an AYCE joint. I also went for salmon, yellowtail, and albacore sashimi. Fresh, but not the best fish I've ever had. Thin slices, too. Sashimi roll was solid, packed with raw fish and wrapped in cucumber. No rice in sight.

My friend ordered a spicy crab roll, monster roll, baked lobster roll, and baked scallop roll. All good eats.

Place could've used a little less Clorox in the air, but it wasn't too bad.

"Three stars for the grub, good stuff. BB wings, spicy but tasty. Flavored soju, top-notch. Rest of the joint, eh. Nice environment, crummy service. Did karaoke with pals, no issues. Went back, sang in a room. Owner barges in, gives a tour, asks if it's cool. Rude, real rude. Haven't been back since. Crappy service, dude."

"Can't complain too much 'bout this joint, got comped for being a Platinum Player. It's an older hotel, not as swanky, but it did the trick for a quick nap. Housekeeping was a bit creepy, though. Chick didn't even knock, just tried to barge in while we were trying to sleep off a hangover. I was like, "No, no, please leave." She was a total creeper, man. 

If you're on the strip side with a view, watch out. They got this crappy band playing from 11 am to 2 am. It's horrible. Last day, I wanted to sleep, but I couldn't. Almost went to the grocery store to buy eggs to toss at 'em. Not exactly classy, but damn, they were annoying. 

Overall, not a terrible experience. Just be aware of their chapel hours. My buddy tried to marry some random chick, but the chapel on the third floor was already closed. Not sure who got lucky on that one. Anyway, enjoy your stay, folks."

"Aye, 'tis a curious conceit, this notion of swift succor,
In which one doth order food with minimal fuss or bother.
This establishment, it seemeth, hath the system down pat,
Wherein one merely chooseth a bag, selecteth toppings, and payeth.
'Tis done! They maketh thy sandwich, and thou art on thy way.

I chanced upon their turkey, with cole slaw and dressing,
And found it middling fair, though not without its flaws.
The bread, alack, didst lack freshness, being overly crusty,
And the turkey, verily, didst taste o'er-salted, I do declare.

Yet, were I invited thither by a friend, I might consent
To sample another of their offerings, with hopeful intent."

"Fattening grub, that's what it is. Wish they'd ditch the tortilla and just give me the greens. Drink station's always running dry too. Staff's got the hustle though, moving folks through the line quick. But still, 20 minutes for a plate of slop? No thanks."

"Hof Kelsten, new blood in Mile End's bakery scene, quickly made a name for itself across the city. Jeffrey Finkelstein, baker and owner, earned a rep supplying top restaurants before opening to the public. Central European influence dominates the menu - think caraway rye, rugelach, babka - but they also bake some killer French loaves, like my current fave Montreal baguette. They do meals too, but I stick to the baked goods. Pastries are solid, a breath of fresh air in a city full of same-old bakery fare. Just watch out for the occasional undercooked item."

"Alas, my dear friend, I must confess,
This burger joint didst not impress.
The bacon, oh how sweet it was,
But alas, the rest, a letdown it was.

A Monday, it was, when first I tried,
But lo, they were closed, my heart did die.
I waited patiently, until the morrow,
To taste their wares, and see what they could borrow.

A regular burger, I didst order,
With bacon, eggs, and all the fixin's, in disorder.
The presentation, fair and bright,
But alas, the flavor, lacking in might.

The seating, comfortable, I must say,
The decor, quite pleasant, in a modern way.
The service, good, with nary a frown,
But alas, the food, a letdown, a disappointment profound.

I would return, for an out-of-towner's delight,
But for myself, I fear, not in sight.
The fries, two versions, we didst try,
Truffle, and cilantro, a sorry pie.

Creative, they didst strive, I must confess,
But for my taste, a failure, alas, a mess."

"You get what you pay for. Check-out time was 11 am. Called at 11, asked for a late check-out at 1 pm. Arrived late, tired. Never had a problem with late check-outs. Asked for two extra hours, not five. Lady said no, only till noon. Pissed me off. Stayed at over 100 hotels, never been turned down for such a small request. Especially in Vegas, you don't want to have a bad experience. Room was decent, modern, but the service was lacking."

"A no-frills joint where you can grab a drink, shoot some stick, and jaw with pals. Not much else, but not bad either. They play the gay tunes all night long and draw a mixed bunch - chubby gays, young bucks, silver foxes, and their gal pals. Inclusive, you know? Daily drink deals too, good spot to start before hitting the club next door. Only downside, it's a smoky mess and you'll reek like a cigarette. Old Vegas charm, I reckon. Limited options for our kind in this town, so can't grumble too much."

"Hark! A tale of Planet Hollywood, I shall recount,
Where meats and seafood, in abundance, they do mount.
A Groupon, it was, that did entice us to dine,
For $79, all-you-can-eat, a feast most divine.

Sirloin, lamb, and shrimp, oh my!
In a separate plate, the surf, did they bring nigh.
