Mussels, salmon, and tilapia, a delicious sight,
But alas, some meats, were dry, not quite right.

The salad bar, a decent spread,
Vegetables, hot dishes, all well-prepared, 'twas said.
And drinks, they did include, in this deal,
A chinahuia, with pineapple, lime, and tequila, did steal.

The hunny, a rum runner, did pour,
Much heavier, than mine, it did devour.
Overall, an okay restaurant, I must confess,
But Texas de Brasil, better meat, does possess.

Marcile, our server, did run,
With a split section, his work, was done.
Bad reviews, I had seen, before this night,
But not as bad, as anticipated, the sight."

"Methinks each visit to this place, on weeknights doth bring
A pungent scent of vomit, left o'er from yestereven's revelry.
The hostess, underdressed, doth seat me with a wink,
And our waiter, in a bandana jean attire, doth take my order with a blink.

We started with the Gouda fondue, a gooey delight,
But over-salted, perchance. Then, my companion didst partake
In the salmon, which he found most delectable, I must confess.
Whilst I, a French Dip devotee, didst find disappointment in the mess.

A mayonnaise-based dressing, applied with liberal hand,
Didst give the roast beef a creamy, yet unpleasant, taste and feel.
The au jus, a strong French onion brew, didst not agree with the sandwich,
Leaving me to ponder if this place doth try too hard to be trendy and fashionable.

The food, a four, the ambiance, a two, I didst aver,
And thus, a three, the overall score, didst seem most fair and proper, good sir."

"Hark! A dilemma doth beset mine mind,
Whether to like this place, or leave it behind.
Their happy hour and brunch specials, oh so fine,
But the food, alas, doth puzzle me, in truth.

I've visited thrice, and tried their fare,
But cannot say, with certainty, if 'tis fair.
The initial bites, oh how they doth delight,
But soon, the flavors doth become too bright.

The service, too, doth leave much to be desired,
For though not woeful, 'twas not inspired.
A waiter, once, forgot my iced tea,
And left me parched, to pine for thee.

Yet, there was a time, when happy hour did grace,
Our presence, and a mistake did occur,
They charged my friend but three pence,
For two drinks, a veritable bonanza!

In conclusion, 'tis a place, just passable,
Not one I'd choose, but neither would I flee.
If thou wouldst go, I wouldst not object,
But for myself, I'd seek a different venue."

"In-N-Out Burger, a West Coast sensation. We had to try it, East Coasters that we are. Verdict? Decent burger, but nothing to lose your mind over. Fries, same story. Average joint, quick and dirty. Note to drive-thru guy: when someone declines ketchup, don't give 'em the stink-eye. They might not be from your planet, but they still deserve respect. Worth a visit, but don't go out of your way. A burger's still a burger."

"Upon mine eyes, a place most fair didst Yelp present,
Which I didst visit for my evening's repast.
Chow mein and Thai tea, my order didst comprise,
The latter, a brew most excellent, didst surprise.
Indeed, the best Thai tea that e'er I didst taste,
But, alas! the former dish, didst not so well find grace.
A variant of the noodles, thin and flat, it was,
Not like the full-bodied lo mein, that doth please.
The victuals, save the saltiness, didst delight,
And though the service was not poor, 'twas not quite right.
I shall return, to sample Pad Thai, anon,
And Thai tea, in quantity, shall be mine own."

"A fair establishment, indeed, for those who have ne'er savored Thai delights. Though, by my troth, 'tis hard to fathom how any soul couldst resist such culinary allurements! The staff doth seem to push their buffet with great fervor, as if their very existence did depend on it. And, verily, the bill did reflect such zeal, a whopping \u00a321 per head! The spread was satisfactory, but, by the stars, I didst not devour \u00a321 worth of victuals!"

"Mediocre fare, yet not so dire,
At standard rates, doth Egg Works aspire.
The taste, not wondrous, nor so vile,
Yet suits my needs, with eggs awhile.

I shall return, for health's design,
Doth prompt me, from sloth's sweet shrine.
Though three stars, Yelp! doth confer,
'A-OK', a label, I do aver."

Dear Breadfruit,

You'd rate four stars if your prices weren't so steep. But I'll still take a slice of that sweet potato pie, and coffee too, if you insist.

Sincerely,
Rachel

"A feast most fair, yet middling in its fare,
Didst grace the table at the noontide hour.
A varied choice, with dishes manifold,
Yet somewhat lacking in its savour, I did find.

The spread didst boast of meats and sweets,
And soups and salads, all in neat arrays.
But when I didst partake of the repast,
I found the flavours somewhat wanting, alas!

The sauces lacked a certain zest,
The meats were cooked, but not to perfection's crest.
The sides, though plentiful, didst lack a certain flair,
Leaving me to pine for more, and wish for less despair.

Yet still, the spread didst have its charm,
With offerings that didst please, though not disarm.
For those who sought a simple, hearty meal,
This buffet may have been their ideal.

But for mine own self, I didst expect
A greater feast, with finer, richer effect.
Alas, 'twas not to be, this day and age,
Yet still, I shall not judge, nor utterly disparage."

"This joint's got character, like an ol' cowboy. Service can be a mite quirky, but it's not bad, just unique. Breakfast's the real draw - standard fare, but done right. Interior's straight outta the Wild West, like John Wayne or Gene Autry might've hung out here. Fun spot for a hearty breakfast."

Thus, late at night, I did arrive at Wynn,
Tired and hungry, seeking sustenance to fill.
The Cafe, a place of wonder, did present itself,
With sandwiches, salads, and sweets, a feast to behold.

A Chicken Portabella sandwich, I did ordain,
But lo, it was not fresh, but refrigerated and reheated.
For eleven dollars, a bit steep, I did declare,
Yet, with garlic aioli, it was quite delicious, I dare say.

A bottle of Coke, four dollars, a price to pay,
Yet, with my meal, I did feel satisfied, come what may.
The Cafe, in mornings, doth get busy, I do say,
So, rise early, and to Starbucks, take thy way.

"Server busy, food dry. Steak Gorgonzola, pasta dry. Pappardelle Pesctore, fishy smell. Northern Tour of Italy, OK. Salad, lacking dressing. Calamari, bland. Asked for lemon, didn't get it. New Italian style buffalo wings, dry. Three stars, loyal customers."
"Cheap eatery. Fill up or get sloshed on their offerings. Free donuts and coffee for early risers. Old joint, but give it a shot."

"Fair victuals, but slow as the night's darkest hour!
Our reservation, twenty minutes didst pass,
And in the waiting area, we didst find no space,
But stood in pathways, where folk didst come and go.

Our waitress, friendly, and with menu didst explain,
But she, the hostess too, didst bear the weight,
Of duties many, and with slowness didst detain,
Our meal, two hours didst consume, alack!

Mussels, we didst order, first, small and sweet,
In white wine sauce, they didst our taste greet.
Bread, we didst request, but fries didst come instead,
Soggy, they were, our server's words didst belie.

Bouillabaisse, my entrée, hot and steaming,
With seafood plentiful, and saffron sauce gleaming.
A feast, it was, and worth the wait, methought,
But oh, how slow, the service, to behold!

My spouse, his chicken, brie-stuffed didst taste,
And found it fair, but not worth the cost, he didst say.

The food, impressive, but the delay, a bane,
If back I come, 'twill be on a weekday, and alone.
More staff, they need, to speed the meal,
For delicate fare, doth merit greater zeal."

"Wonton soup's my go-to here. No noodles, just the goods. Broth's got a nice sweetness to it, dumplings are on point. Haven't tried anything else, but I keep comin' back for more. Upstairs, Crown Bakery's worth a visit too."
"Dined well, but grub was just fair. Killer cocktails from three to six, though. Should've gone earlier."

"First time at this joint. Sat in the bar, happy hour just ending. They got free snacks, but I passed. Had a few drinks, ordered some fish. Salmon was good, yellowtail sashimi was too thick. Place smelled like piss and cheap cologne. Made me sick."

"Golden Phoenix, a joint for a decent, cheap lunch. Not too busy during the week, especially if you roll in around 11 am. The staff ain't the friendliest, but they don't bother you none. Food's alright, not too shabby, but nothin' special either. Spicy? Nah, more like a gentle tickle on the tongue. Still, for sixteen bucks, including drinks, it's a damn good deal. And it's close to my work, so I'll be back."

"Went to this joint for the first time. Wings were decent, service was alright. Catfish? Not so much. But hey, it's a wing place, right? Had the ATL seasoned wings, pretty good, a bit too salty though. Cashier seemed a bit sour, but she kept track of all the orders. Would go back for the wings and fries."

"If thou seekest a taste of the south, amidst the sinful city's gleam,
Come hither, to this venue, a Treasure Island gem.
Late at night, it opens wide, when other doors are shut tight,
A haven for revelers, who still burn with delight.

Country tunes fill the air, and two-step dances abound,
A mechanical bull, for the brave, doth astound.
But beware, fair maiden, of the golden-haired cowgirl's might,
She doth ride the beast with grace, and leaves all else in flight.

The dance floor's ample space, and the hall's kept clean and bright,
Bartenders, merry and kind, serve drinks with hasty might.
Alas, I did not partake of their culinary fare,
For by the time I arrived, the kitchen's bounty did declare.

An elder crowd, they gathered, in their thirties and forties prime,
Yet, our youthful band, of country fans, did find joy in rhyme.
So, if thou art in search of a western oasis, in this town,
Come to Treasure Island, and let its spirit astound."

"Methinks my friends do hold this place in high esteem,
And thus, I come to partake in their delight.
The victuals, though not cheap, do please my taste,
Save for the pies, which are a worthy prize.
The ale, too, doth quench my thirst, and at a fair price,
But wines and other potions, alas, do burn a hole in my purse.
I must confess, their brew doth not agree with me,
For 'tis too heavy and sweet, and doth not suit my fancy.
Yet, if thou seek'st a place to gather and make merry,
This tavern, clean and well-appointed, shall not disappoint thee."

"With my young brood in tow, I sought a sweet treat,
A place untried, their eager minds to greet.
Their laughter echoed loud, as we did enter,
The lasses there, with beaus, did converse at leisure.
Their mirth did grate, but frozen yogurt sweet,
Did please my children, and myself, did meet.
We shall return, this place of icy delight,
Despite the rudeness of the maidens bright."

"Methinks 'twas not the best of Mexican feasts,
But neither was it the worst, by my troth.
The service, attentive though somewhat astray,
Did bring us water, albeit in disarray.
Three times I asked, and three times they brought,
One glass of water, which we didst share, no doubt.
Their promptness with chips and salsa did make up,
And frequent checks upon us did they keep.
The victuals, decent, yet a mite too hot,
For my taste buds, which do prefer a milder plot.
Yet others seemed not to mind the fiery bite,
So take my words with a pinch of salt, good sir.
The margaritas, strong and potent, did flow,
A pitcher sufficed for four, as you do know."

"No fuss, no muss. No special tools or missing parts. Just a simple meal, like a well-crafted sentence. But, like a Hemingway story, it lacked depth, substance. A disappointment, considering the venue. 

This ain't no food stand, folks. It's the fancy upstairs cafe. Wider selection, sure. Wraps, salads, soups, hot tray line. Sweetish classics, maybe. 

Wife had a veggie wrap. Close to a chicken wrap, but not quite. Shelves and labels, disarray. Acceptable, though. Four bucks, yeah? 

Smoked fish plate, seven bucks. Not bad. Creamy horseradish sauce, mixed greens, few beans. Well-smoked fish, y'know? 

Vegan sweet potato soup. Nice touch. Flash your IKEA family card, get some freebies. A meal, yeah? Not pricey, fourteen bucks for two. Self-service furniture store, though. 

Mild food, kid-friendly, great views of furniture. Your spot, maybe?"

"The joint's alright, ain't perfect though. Service was good, but they didn't seem to get that we wanted grub after studying the menu while our tea was being made. Decor's nice, got some comfy chairs to relax in. Big windows let in plenty of light, nice view of Frederick Street. Food and drinks? Nothing too exciting, but they do it well. Haven't checked the cans or the nosh yet, so I'll give 'em three stars for now. But I reckon they'll easily hit four stars next time I stop by."

"Went to Cafe Grande today, feeling meh. Clients picked it, and I thought of all the groovier spots nearby. Menu was basic, burgers and paninis, but the fishcake was decent, chips and salad not bad. Cheese plate was good, Scottish cheeses, various desserts looked alright, banoffee pie got a thumbs up. Other options were lackluster, soup and sandwich dull, bean burger sad on a plain bun. Not bad for a local spot, but wouldn't go out of my way."

In my pursuit of gluten-free fare, I chanced upon Nello's abode,
Wherein I savored a pizza of ham and pineapple, a treat for my taste buds,
The crust, devoid of gluten, was quite satisfactory, I must confess,
A rarity, indeed, in this realm of culinary excess.

Their menu, a list of ingredients and toppings, didst reveal,
A limitation of options, a challenge to conceal,
Yet, the service, friendly and prompt, didst make up for the lack,
And left me content, with naught to attack.

So, if thou seekest a gluten-free meal, without much fuss or fanfare,
Nello's shall serve thee well, beyond compare,
For though it may not be the best, 'tis a suitable choice,
To satiate thy hunger, with a cheerful voice.

"Eyebrow threading went from eight bucks to ten. Still, she does a swell job, doesn't overdo it, and keeps your brows looking natural. Facials? Good, but watch out for those coupons. They'll give you a raw deal. My ma got a coupon for half off, but they cut the time in half too. Not worth it."

"Hark, fair sir! My visit to this establishment was but a middling affair. The service, indeed, was quite good, and the beer, a frosty delight. But alas, my taste doth runneth towards a hearty IPA, which they didst not possess. 

The victuals, too, were naught but mediocre. Wings of chicken, standard fare, and a sandwich with bread a tad stale, fries lacking crunch. Alack! 

Yet, within, the decor was pleasant, and many a television doth grace the walls, making it a fine spot for a pint and a game. The scent of wood smoke, wafting from the pizza oven, doth stir mine appetite, and thus, a pizza shall be mine choice, come next I dine."

Alas, my dear friend, I didst fall prey  
To the snare of chips and salsa's allure,  
A plight most vexing, I must confess,  
For my belly, now full, doth protest.  
But, save this mishap, the fare was fair,  
As one would expect from a Mexican lair,  
With portions grand and ingredients fresh,  
Though naught extraordinary, the price was neat.  
And so, anon, I shall return, God willing,  
When hunger pangs for Mexican dishes still.

"My mother and I didst venture forth to this establishment, forsooth, upon her sweet tooth's insatiable craving. She didst inquire of the maiden behind the counter, if the coffee-flavored gelato didst contain caffeine. The maiden, with a shrug, didst reply, 'I know not, for I do not make it.'

And thus, we didst laugh at the absurdity of it all, yet, my mother, still curious, didst ask the maiden if there were any dairy-free options available. The maiden, once again, didst reply, 'I know not, for I do not make it.'

In utter disbelief, we didst proceed to order our gelato, and my mother, determined to extract some semblance of usefulness from the girl, didst ask her to recommend a flavor to accompany chocolate. The maiden, with a sheepish grin, didst respond, 'I know not, for I do not eat it.'

Verily, I couldst scarce believe mine ears! Forsooth, the girl mayhap was in high school, and 'twas true, she didst not make nor eat the gelato, but, by the stars, customer service, thou art a dying breed! 

But, lo and behold, the gelato, it didst taste wondrous, and the prices, quite reasonable. Banana Yum, indeed!"
"Food was fair, prices too high. Friend and I played video poker all night, but they only comped us one drink. Disappointed, thought it'd be a decent dive with some gambling fun."

"Hark, what praise doth fill the air?
A buffet, they say, beyond compare!
But lo, my friends, let us not be fooled,
For here, the truth, I shall unfold.

A fourth of all they offer, bread,
A waste, a folly, a misdeed!
And for this, they demand a fee,
Forty dollars, a price too steep!

The California roll, a gem, I confess,
With real crab meat, a rarity, no less.
But all else, a disappointment, a shame,
No special treats, no unique name.

Prime rib, cold shrimp, and crab, they say,
Are reasons why this buffet's the way.
But nay, my friends, those items find,
At every buffet, of a lower kind.

So heed my words, and do not pay,
The price they ask, for it's not worth the fray.
Rio Carnival, Rio Seafood, Wynn,
Buffets superior, for less you'll win."

"By the holy spirits, do people dine here?  Verily, I have visited this establishment on multiple occasions, and each time, my level of inebriation hath ranged from a gentle buzz to a full-fledged blackout.  'Tis true, neither I nor my comrades have made it a habit to partake in the culinary delights offered here, for our primary focus hath been on quaffing ale and enjoying the merriment of the evening.  But, alas, the happy hour menu doth boast an impressive array of appetizers, including the common california roll, gyoza, seafood dynamite, and coconut shrimp skewers.  Yet, 'tis the specialty drinks that truly maketh RA shine.  When hunger doth strike, concurrent with inebriation, the quality of the victuals doth not matter overmuch, for 'tis like beholding a maiden fair through the haze of ale-tinted spectacles.  I cannot, in good conscience, bestow upon this place a rating of utter rubbish, for the fond memories of yore, though hazy and fragmented, do still linger in my mind."

"Came here with friends after exploring Luxor. Menu had plenty of options, but we struggled to choose. Food was top-notch, solid 5 stars. Service, however, was subpar. Asked about virgin margaritas, waiter was snarky, like he didn't want to be there. Attitude was terrible. If it were just my husband and me, we would've left. Not a great experience for the restaurant."

"Decent spread, not amazing. Shrimp and sweets stole the show. Prime rib? Meh. Watermelon infused with tequila made up for it, though. Rice Krispy treats and candy apples too. Could've used more salad options, but breakfast selection was solid, even at 2 pm. Might return, but Aria and Paris trump Wynn's offerings."

"Excalibur, good spot. Remodeled tower, room 2. Door wouldn't close, called, moved next door. New room, nice, flat screen, comfy beds. Next day, same issue, door won't shut. Guy comes up, fixes it. Pool area nice, windy as hell. Thin walls, heard neighbors. Checkout at 11am, too early after a wild night. Called down, extended to 12pm. Stay here for cheap, decent rooms in a good spot."

"A feast fit for a king, this spread doth lay,
With all the fixings of a humble day.
The salad bar, a garden fresh and fair,
Doth tempt the taste, with crunchy greens to share.

The carving station, a sight to behold,
Doth offer meats, both roasted and cold.
Pizza, pasta, corn, and mashed potatoes too,
Doth round out the menu, with naught to do.

Green beans, fish dishes, sushi, and bread,
Doth complete the feast, that doth feed
The belly and the soul, with naught to dread.
Though not the fanciest, 'tis a meal well-spread.

The price, not cheap, yet still a bargain true,
Doth make it worth, the trip anew.
So if thou art hungry, and in search of fare,
That doth fill thy belly, without breaking the air,
Come, join the crowd, and partake in this feast,
For a meal most satisfying, and truly a treat."
"Food was fair. Soggy rice on the sushi. Service was lacking. Felt rushed, poor timing, and staff didn't know their menu like they should. Hype didn't match reality."
"Waitress, friendly. Service, top-notch. Steak boxty, tasty and satisfying. Pint of Harp, perfect complement."

"Abuelos, a chain of Mexican eateries, doth please my taste buds well. Their service, too, is friendly and their fare, passable. In days of yore, a lengthy queue did form outside, a wait of an hour, perchance, did ensue. Yet, on my most recent visit, entry was swift, our party of six, straightway admitted. For guests from afar, I shall return, but, whenever possible, local haunts, I do prefer."

Hark! I have not partaken of their victuals yet,
But on a night of revelry, I did step within their gates.
A fraternity so wild, they let young lads and lasses in,
And those of age, with wristbands, did their mirth begin.
But lo! The youth did drink, despite the wristbands' might,
Yet still, the atmosphere was merry and bright.
They have a game of beer pong, and potions fine,
My spouse and I, we danced and laughed, and drank with glee divine.

"Hark! Good for a hangover, they say,  
This place doth cure the night's excess,  
But loud it be, in truth, I pray,  
That thou mayst find some peace, and rest.  

The fries, alas, are thin and weak,  
A disappointment, I do confess,  
Yet still, the food doth please, meek,  
In its simplicity, 'tis blessed.  

The drinks, they be strong and bold,  
A plus, indeed, for those who crave,  
A respite from the night's cold,  
And a cure for the morning's wave."

"I stopped by for a trim 'cause I was in the neighborhood and needed a tidy up. Got the usual scissor cut, nothing fancy. Walked right in, no wait. Stylist did a good job, seemed to care about her work. Haircut was better than average, but pricey, 25% more than other joints around here. Still, not a bad deal for a decent haircut."

"Food's good. Bruschetta's top-notch. Service? Shit. Went on a Friday, place was dead, three bartenders yappin' away. Couldn't get a damn thing. Had to grab our own silverware and plates. Took forever to get a drink. But the grub's what keeps us comin' back. Happy hour's decent too, five bucks for a glass of wine. Might give the other spot a shot next time, see if they can do better."

"Hark, my thoughts on this establishment align with the masses. Good tidings, there be:

Food, when it doth arrive, doth please the palate. Lobster and corn, oh how grand! A gin drink, fit for royalty, doth impress. The menu, diverse and full of wondrous choices, doth entice. Drinks, aplenty and creative, doth delight. Weekly specials, a treasure trove of savings, doth abound.

Alas, poor service doth mar the experience. Many a black-shirted server doth stand idly by, while two hostesses doth attend to their duties. A bartender, hardworking and diligent, doth pour forth libations with haste. Alack, management doth need to address this disparity, lest it doth become a grievance most foul.

In conclusion, tasty victuals, potent potables, and questionable service doth sum up this place. Mayhap, a visit shall reveal the truth of these words."

Daily drink specials:

Margarita Monday: $3 off specialty margaritas from 7pm-close.
Guys Night Out Tuesday: 1/2 off whiskey, bourbon, and scotch from 7pm-close.
Paper Bag Beer Special Wednesday: random beer in a bag for $1 from 7pm-close.
Ladies Night Thursday: $3 off glasses of wine and $3 360 vodka drinks from 7pm-close.
Fireball Friday: $2 shots of Fireball from 7pm-close.
$10 Mimosa Carafes Saturday: Get a mimosa carafe for $10 from 11am-3pm.
$10 Bloody Mary Carafes Sunday: Get a bloody mary carafe for $10 from 11am-3pm.

"A haven of delight, this eatery doth serve  
The finest of Italy's culinary fare.  
Its ambiance, warm and inviting, doth imbue  
A sense of comfort, fitting for a king.  
The portions, generous and bountiful, doth fill  
The belly with joy, and prices, fair and square,  
Doth make it a steal, a true rarity.  
In this place, thou shalt find solace and cheer,  
A haven of delight, indeed, my dear."

"Hark! A stay most pleasant and affordable too,
With rooms that beckon warmth and welcome anew.
Though dated, they provide a comfortable abode,
And for the price, a veritable haven to reside.
The adjacent chambers, a boon for families blessed,
When traveling with young ones, a true godsend, no less."

"A burger, not of highest quality, I fear,
Passable, mayhap, yet the setting doth leave much to desire.
By th' drinking machine, a woeful sight doth lie,
A space so cramped, nigh impossible to navigate by.
Throngs of people, swarming like bees in springtime bloom,
Do make it hard to pass, with naught but grief to assume."

"A friendly staff doth serve this place,
Where young folk gather, full of grace.
All seem to seek love's sweet embrace,
But alas, the underground space doth lack,
In ambiance, it doth not abound,
No dance floor there, nor lights around.
No mirror ball, no laser beams,
To stir the soul and lift the dreams.
If thou wouldst have folks dance and play,
Spend a few coins and make the day.
Create some ambiance, that doth please,
And all shall revel in joy and ease."

"Champaign's got some solid eats, but Middle Eastern's in short supply. That's why I'm glad Holy Land Grill's around. It ain't the best I've had, but it's good. Had the falafel and Greek salad yesterday, both were on point. Service was top-notch, friendly and attentive. They brought us water, compliments of the house, weird but appreciated. They also got Mexican Coke, nice change of pace. Baklava for dessert, real good, but the simple syrup didn't add much. Plain or honey would've been better. No music at all, usually I'm griping about loud tunes, but some soft Middle Eastern jams would've been a nice touch. Enjoyed my meal, planning on going back soon."

"Carson Street Cafe, near the elevators, offered a buy-one-get-one deal for Golden Nugget guests. Not bad. Decent grub, too. Stick to the basics - my BLT was alright, and the chicken in the Caesar salad was good. Service was slow, though."

"A haven of refreshment, where one may quench their thirst and sate their hunger. 'Tis a place of solace, where one may find respite from the heat and the bustle of the city. Yet, beware, good sir or madam, for the service there is not of the most hospitable sort. 'Twere best to pay with cash, lest thou desirest to avoid the awkwardness of a prolonged encounter with the keepers of the establishment. So, if thou art in search of a cool draught and a quick bite, this place may serve thee well, but tarry not, lest thou be vexed by the gruff demeanor of the staff."

"Twice a week, for two months straight, we hit up Big View. Service and grub were top-notch, till the holidays rolled around. Then, they served us stale, old cookies from their bakery. Haven't been back since. \n\nUsed to be, we'd go there once a week. Tried a lot on the menu, and it was all good. Breakfast plates, french toast, pancakes. Shrimp & grits, chicken souvlaki, spinach pastry, greek salad, crab cake. Bakery was great too. Service was friendly, except when we sat at the bar and watched the kitchen get wild. Still, it was a solid spot. Recommend it, but avoid the bar."

"Across from campus theater, we did stray,
Convenient spot, indeed, 'twas our aim.
In we walked, and swiftly seated were we,
Drink orders taken, with haste, did they bring.

But then, a delay, there came to pass,
After drink orders, some fifteen minutes' wait,
Our orders taken, by hostess fair,
Due to waitress's o'erwhelmed plight, we did surmise.

Food came, some fifteen minutes later,
We ate with haste, lest we be late,
Turkey dinner, with small pieces, did come,
Not long cut strips, as menu did proclaim.

Pancakes, with white chocolate raspberry,
His choice, a good pick, did prove to be,
Egg Nog pancakes, a good option, did seem,
But alas, not chosen, by me.

Ticket paid, I did, with speedy hand,
So we could leave, and not be late, in this land.

Overall, a B-, service was good,
Food, just okay, an A-OK visit, as understood."

"A pox upon this tavern, and its rude servitors too!
Two stars I subtract, for poor service I didst receive.
On a Tuesday eve, my friend and I didst sit at the bar,
But the bartenders, they didst pay us no mind, nor care.
Their friends were there, and they didst attend to them alone,
Leaving us to wait, for a menu, forsooth, for long.
And when I asked for ale, the bartender didst throw
The list at me, with scorn and disdain, I do avow.
She came not back, for full fifteen minutes more,
A plague upon her, and her surly demeanor!
Take Midol, woman, and improve thy mood,
For ill-tempered service, doth make a tavern, no good."

"Sunday morning, we hit the buffet. Closest spot for breakfast grub. Decent spread, too. Prime rib, nice cuts of meat. Not bad for an elevator ride down. Lobster and crab? Nope. But hey, you're in Vegas. Why not splurge? Twenty-five bucks ain't cheap, especially if you're not gambling. But hey, you're on vacation. Might as well treat yourself. I'd go back, if I could eat more or had a ton of comps. If you're feeling flush, give it a shot. Just don't forget to bring your appetite."
"Yard House, good spot for a quick drink. Beer selection top-notch, plenty to choose from. Food specials during happy hour, solid. Entrees just okay, though. Neighborhood's got better options."

"Fare good, but dearly priced, I say,
The wait, long during peak hours, doth come what may.
In Vegas, 'tis the norm, I do suppose,
But, alack, the cost, doth make me choose.

If half the price, the buffet were,
Then four stars, I would confer.
But, alas, the food, doth not make worth,
The price, that doth thy purse unworth.

In brief, thy coin, elsewhere, best spend,
For equal fare, at lower rate, thou shalt find.
And, perchance, fortune shall thy way attend,
At slots, where jackpots may be thine to amend."

"I hit up this joint near my crib for their killer veggie or supreme pizza, and I always grab a pitcher of cold brew and some wings. They've got a bunch of TVs blastin' sports, so it's a sweet spot to catch a game. Prices have crept up a bit, but the grub's still solid. Plus, the service is top-notch and they've got a rad takeout game too. They've got a ton of pizza options, that's the main draw. Other menu items are just there for variety's sake."
"Grand Lux, love it. Corned beef hash, top-notch. Hair in the fries, a minor hiccup. Waiter and manager, proper apologies. Desserts, fantastic."

"Upon a pair of reviews, I chanced this place,
Expecting wondrous fare, and such it was,
Four stars for victuals, that did please my face,
But two for service, that did leave me sore.

What went awry? A score of minutes passed,
For pita sandwiches, and we were alone,
And when they came, alas! The order was amiss,
My comrade had to take his meal to go.

The food, indeed, doth please my taste,
And I might visit again, but, prithee,
Get orders right, and hasten service pace,
Lest patrons flee, and leave thee in disgrace."

"Methinks I've visited this establishment a fair few times,
And each occasion hath been filled with mirth and prime.
A VIP table, we didst possess, which didst grant us ease
Of entry and enjoyment, as we didst please.

The DJ's tunes, they were quite fitting for the dance,
But alas, the space, it was a bit too concise.
A pole, a platform, didst rise above the fray,
Where women, bold and beautiful, didst sway.

Last time, the private room, a grand sight to behold,
Was closed, perchance for renovations, who doth know?
For in that space, apart from the main throng,
Didst lie private tables, dance areas, and a DJ strong.

Not bad, this place, for groups of friends to gather,
But for a pair of lads, perhaps not the best haven."

"Bought the onion and mushroom poutine, Montreal smoke meat sandwich too. Sandwich was real good, meat was warm, juicy. Poutine was alright, coulda used some bacon or somethin' meaty, ya know? But I liked the onion and mushroom, just thinkin' 'bout other options. \nWaiter asked if there was somethin' wrong with the service, but there wasn't nothin' wrong, just nothin' special either. Went early on a Saturday, place just opened. Told him nothin' was wrong, he says in Montreal, tippin's 15%. Asked me for $1.50 more. Felt kinda embarrassed, wasn't payin' attention, just wanted to give him a flat $30 after eatin' $26 somethin'. Maybe I'm cheap. Before goin' in, my brother and I wanted to check the poutine price, they were yellin' at us it ain't open yet. Food was good, service was...iffy. Gave 'em another chance after bein' shooed away."
"Room with a view, not too shabby. Right on Miracle Mile, convenient for shopping."

"This joint's got plenty of space, and the seating's versatile. Good for meetups, real close to the highway. Business types come here, study groups too. Tutor meets me here. Coffee and tea, always solid. Wi-fi's free, just ask for the password. Shame about the dirt though, tables are messy, trash on the floor."
"Drinks flowed like a river, each one a unique gem. Patrons sparse, like solitary birds perched on branches. Food, untouched, a mystery waiting to be solved."

"3.5 stars. Better than US airline lounges in terms of grub and drinks. Cookies, cheese, veggie platter, cous cous, spring rolls, mini quiche. Full bar with wine, liquor, and soda. Soup too. Sitting area gets packed, but it's better than the hallway. Closed from 10:30 am to 2:30 pm."

"Hark, what wonders doth this eatery bring!
The calamari, a dish most fine and fair,
Didst please mine taste, and with delight
I didst devour it, without a single care.

The tacos, alas, didst not compare,
For though they were good, others beare
A greater charm, and so I say,
Seek elsewhere for a better way.

Our server, full of mirth and glee,
Didst make our time most pleasant to be,
His jokes and wit, didst lighten the mood,
And made our evening, most good.

So, to this place, I say, go thou,
For laughter, food, and drink, doth flow,
In abundance, and with joy, thou shalt find,
A night most merry, and most divine."

"Race was a blast, real fun. Like Amazing Race, ya? But I expected more brain-teasers, y'know? Not just Google-it-on-your-phone stuff. You gotta be fit, ready to run if you wanna win. Forgot about the winners' hundred bucks, but they said they'd mail it. That's good."

"Four of us hit up breakfast. Two of us went for the $5.99 steak and eggs, which came with some killer house fries and toast. The other two had the veggie omelette, loaded with fresh veggies and smothered in cheese. Coffee and tip, we're talking less than $35. Hell of a deal. Service was top-notch, servers were friendly and kept our cups full. Next day, we're back for dinner. Two of us went for the penne al forno, real creamy and delicious. The other two had burgers, no complaints. But the real highlight? $2.25 20 oz. beers, brewed in-house. Hefe and Light, both smooth as silk. Total bill for five beers and four entrees? $45. A damn steal, especially since it's within walking distance of the strip."

"Bought a Groupon for a cut and color. Stylist did a good job, listened to what I wanted, and nailed the look. Three stars 'cause of a couple things: \nShe mixed the color in a bowl and said if she ran out, I'd have to pay another $15. Felt like I was getting hustled. Should've been told upfront. \nAlso, my shirt got ruined from the color bleeding through the robe. Manager said it'd come out in the wash, but I ain't so sure."

"A humble tavern, this place doth be,
With atmospheric charm, so plain to see.
TVs abound, a wondrous sight,
And service, friendly, withal a delight.

Their beer, cold as winter's snow,
And menu, limited, yet fit to go.
Sandwiches, salads, and more, we did try,
Fair portions, prices, did not make us sigh.

Yet, flaws there be, that doth detract,
No happy hour, a sorrowful fact.
Limited menu, a lack, indeed,
No specials, nor deals, to plant a seed.

Not open all day, a shame,
Drinks, pricey, a burning flame.
UFC, ten dollars, a steep cost,
Wine menu, scant, a sorry loss.

No pitchers, no bottles, to buy,
A drawback, verily, 'tis no lie.
But still, a visit, worth thy while,
For atmosphere, and service, with a smile."

"A decent cup of joe, a pleasant place indeed,
Where scholars gather, books and homework at hand,
In the "back space", a haven for study and thought,
Though crowded, 'tis a scene of quiet contemplation.

Bring gold, my friend, for credit cards they do not take,
But fear not, for within, an ATM doth make,
Withdrawal of funds, though with a small fee,
A price to pay for convenience, as thou seest.

And mark this well, fair maiden, the barista,
A vision of beauty, a heart-stealer, no less,
His form, a work of art, his face, a shining sun,
A sight to behold, worth more than any gem or fun."

"Hark! Seeketh thou old-fashioned soul food? Verily, this place doth fit the bill. Fried chicken and cornbread, most delectable fare! A plethora of sides to choose from, thy taste buds shall be sated. Service, good and prompt, maketh this an excellent spot for midday repast, shouldst thou find thyself in town."

"The chambers be dimly lit, my dear,
Alack, they lack sufficient light, 'tis true.
No fridge nor microwave, alas, doth grace
These halls, but, verily, I do confess,
The latter's absence doth not vex me so.
A Philips LCD, of thirty-two inches, doth
Adorn the wall, a modest sight, methinks.
But, lo, the water, hot, doth not abide,
When one doth bathe or doth take council with
The shower's spray. A grievous fault, indeed.
And, prithee, mark this well, a fee doth lie,
A resort tax, hidden, of twenty dollars,
They should include it in the total sum,
And not seek to conceal it, like a trickster.

"I didst watch the pirate show, before the inn,
'Twas passable, yet, my room, the eighth floor,
Didst offer solace, distant from the din.
A blessing, indeed, that noise didst not pour
Into mine ears, a pleasant respite, forsooth.

"Now, listen well, fair sir, the Treasure Isle,
Doth stand within the heart of Las Vegas' smile,
'Twixt Wynn and Paris, Bellagio, nay,
Planet Hollywood, doth form the central way,
All else, beyond, doth pale, and doth not claim
One's attention, save Fremont Street, of old."

Panchos, a buffet of mediocre Mexican food. Enter the colorful building, cafeteria-style. Choose from chili rellenos, enchiladas, tamales, chimichangas, flautas, taquitos, rice, beans, tacos, tostadas. Reasonable price for the amount of food. Non-authentic, greasy, trans fat-filled Mexican food. Flag system for more items. Good service, clean restaurant. Fresh hot sopapillas. Hubby loves the cheese sponges. Reluctantly agree to go.

"Newest Starbucks on the strip, but not really. Just a fake one cashing in on the name. They take the gift cards, but also Total Rewards cards. Prices are jacked up too. Ordered a passionfruit iced tea with a splash of strawberry. Normally costs me $2.85. Here, it's almost six bucks. Didn't question it, just paid with my Starbucks card and moved on. Place is big, lots of outlets, plenty of other items like mugs and sandwiches. Giving it three stars for the ridiculous price hike. It's a business, but doubling the price for a drink that usually costs less than three bucks is crazy."

"A winding corridor doth lead to this place of pie,
A secret hideaway, for those who do aspire
To taste the flavors of Italy, in disguise.

Within, a scant few seats, for weary travelers to rest,
And wait, some twenty minutes, ere their feast be blessed.

Alas, the pizza, middling fare, at best,
For Slices, in Dublin, doth my heart possess.
But still, a novel experience, in this town of vice,
Yet, should I find myself in Las Vegas once more,
I fear, I shall not darken this door again,
For other culinary delights, my soul doth yearn."

"Verily, the victuals didst please mine taste,
Afirst, I didst think it but a common feast,
But lo, the flavors didst dance upon mine tongue,
And made me reconsider mine erstwhile boon.

I do confess, I didst feel a mite confused,
Whenas I didst behold the menu, unprosed,
For in mine haste, I didst not see it ere,
And thus, I didst feel a mite discomposed.

Moreover, they didst give me but a box,
To hold mine aliment, and naught but that,
No bag to bear it, nor a straw to sip,
Which didst vex mine spirit, and didst make me rip.

Yet still, the food didst satisfy mine hunger,
And thus, I shall return, to partake of their plunger."

"Hark, a solid three, I say, yet doubts remain,
For thick-cut pepperoni doth not please mine eyes.
I crave the thin, delicate slice, a la Villa or Verrazano's guise.
Alas, the crust, a tad too dark, doth not delight,
A golden brown, my heart doth sing, with joy and mirth.

Their renovations, quite extensive, I must confess,
Transforming the old Atlanta Bread Co., with finesse.
Yet, fair New York, my mind doth wander,
With visions of pizza, so fine and grand.

Shall I return? Aye, mayhap, forsooth,
But shall it be a regular haunt? Only time shall prove, my friend."

"Chicken ain't what it used to be. No more big chunks of white meat, now it's stewed in some broth all day. Not even sure it's all white meat no more. And don't get me started on the burrito lady. She's using her gloved hands to fill that thing up. Fine for rolling, but when she's sticking her hand in all them bins of lettuce, corn, tomatoes, cilantro, it just don't seem right. They should be using spoons on thongs for that job."

"O fond memories, how thou dost play upon my mind! 
In days of yore, at Pitt, where funds were scarce, 
Two eateries vied for our meager purse, 
Lu-Lu's Noodles, Yum Wok, both names entice. 
Their prices low, their proximity a boon, 
But alas, delivery they did not proffer, 
On cold days, through brown slush we had to go, 
With laughter and wet pants, our spirits did glow. 
For us, 'twas worth the perilous journey, 
Up Cardiac Hill, to dorms in haste, 
With food in hand, our bellies full and merry, 
Those memories, forever shall they last."
"Bank's nothing special, but it's there. Drive thru or walk up, whichever suits you. Just keep an eye out, y'know? Smith and Nail place nearby, other businesses too. Convenient spot."

"American Apparel ain't my usual haunt. Vintage is more my speed, and tight clothes don't do much for me. But, I had a mermaid costume to put together, and I needed something to cover up without showing too much skin. So, I ended up at American Apparel. They had all sorts of shiny, tight tops, just what I needed. Course, I felt like I paid too much, but at least I got what I came for."

"Hark! What news is this? A puzzlement doth fill my mind,
Concerning video shops and their purpose, I find.
For in HMV, new DVDs doth drop in price so fast,
A fortnight passes, and \u00a35 doth last but a moment, alas!
And thus, the question doth arise, why rent,
When purchase doth cost nigh the same, pray tell?
But fear not, dear friends, for all is not lost,
Their bargain bins doth hold a treasure trove, no doubt.
A recent film, or one of great renown,
Doth wait for thee, at a most reasonable crown.
And video games, they doth offer at a fair price,
So all is not lost, nor doth it seem quite so nice."

"Methought I would give this fair fest five stars, indeed I did,
For last year, my love and I didst attend, and joy didst we find.
The victuals were of finest sort, the music didst delight,
But then, alack, the jousting match didst take a bitter turn.

The host, a knave of foulest sort, didst play the villain's part,
Humiliating a poor maid, and offering her a wretched sum.
He didst espouse his politics, a woeful sight to see,
And thus, didst tarnish the fest's good name, in shame and infamy.

Fests of yore, shouldst be of mirth and glee,
A place where families gather, free from worry and fear.
All cast members, shouldst stay in character, throughout the day,
Lest they sully the fest's good name, and drive the crowd away.

I wouldst love to return, come October's golden light,
But if that knave doth still remain, I shall not partake in the fight."

"Aye, we sought the morning meal, a spread of victuals vast,
For twenty silver pieces, a fair price to pay.
A line of folk did form outside, in wait,
But once within, we found ample space to sit and stay.
The servant, diligent, did keep our cups full,
With juice of oranges, freshly squeezed, no doubt.
Alas, the surroundings, lacking grace, did dampen mood,
Yet still, we found delight in certain dishes, as we could.

The omelette station, bustling, with crab and shrimp,
Did please our taste buds, with flavors quite primp.
Salads, pizza, soft serve, fruit, all did abound,
And waffles, oh so crispy, with sweet syrup profound.
Danish pastries, flaky, and almond croissants too,
Turkey sausage, savory, our hunger did subdue.
Pancakes, alas, did suffer from delay,
Cold and stale, they failed to win the day.
Muffins, dry and uninspired, a disappointment, indeed,
But overall, the fare, was not so ill-conceived.
Worth a visit, verily, this breakfast buffet may be,
So gather thy coin, and give it a try, thou'll see."

"A burger. That's what I was after. A big, juicy one from a place that knows their stuff. Fuddruckers, they call it. First time there, so I had hopes. Eh, it was alright. Just a burger, nothing special. In n Out does it better, and cheaper too. If someone asks, I'll go back. But if you want a real burger, there's better joints out there."

"Rehab, a place of revelry and delight,
I visited today, with expectations high and bright.
The line, I thought, would be long and winding,
But lo, it moved swiftly, and my wait was finding.

The cost, a mere $60, a sum quite fair,
And the security, not overbearing, I declare.
A car key, credit card, and ID, all they sought,
And in three seconds, my entry was bought.

Inside, a throng of people, fair and bright,
But not so packed, as videos and photos might.
At four o'clock, still room to move and sway,
Not a madhouse, as I had thought, by day.

Few dancers, just two lovebirds, locked in embrace,
Rehab, it seems, is not the wild, crazy place.
Drinks, oh so pricey, $28, a single serving,
But Heineken Light, in buckets, a bargain, worth savoring.

Alas, I would not return, for though it was fun,
Rehab, to me, was not the wild, crazy run."

"Verily, I have visited this venue for birthday revels,
And though 'tis a popular choice, I do not concur.
The scent within doth leave much to be desired,
And those who toil here, their mood doth oft impair.
I gave it three stars, forsooth, for its merriment doth please the young ones."

"Methinks 'twas naught but ale that I didst partake,
Yet found I joy in this fair brewhouse's make.
The tavern itself, a square of finest design,
Didst boast a central bar, where bartenders didst shine.
A tiny aquarium, full of fish so fine,
Didst add a touch of whimsy to the scene divine.
The crowd, though small, didst revel in the night,
And nearby, tables twain didst offer respite.
If thou dost find thyself in Middleton's embrace,
And seek a pint, without the need to pace,
Then hath this place, a worthy stop, indeed,
To quench thy thirst, and banish sorrow's creed."

"Alack, my friends, I must confess,  
My breakfast at Perk did not impress.  
The victuals were fair, I must avow,  
But service, alas, did lack somehow.  

My dam and I, we both did dine  
On burritos, mine with bacon, fine.  
And though they were small, as I do reckon,  
The flavor was good, with cilantro sauce anon.  

But, oh, the waitress, how unkind!  
No word, no smile, nor any sign.  
She left us be, like strangers, alone,  
And when we needed her, she was nowhere known.  

The hostess, fair, didst attend to us,  
With water fresh and our bill, what a fuss.  
But when the waitress came, in such haste,  
She slapped the bill down, without a taste.  

No thank you, nor farewell, she did say,  
And so, my friends, I shall not stay.  
For I can make my own burrito,  
And save myself from such disdain and pity."

"Methinks, fair maiden, thou and thine beau didst decide to partake in libations at yon establishment, a place of ill repute, yet affordable. Thy swain, in days of yore, didst frequent this tavern, and thus, thy expectations, fair maid, were low. The atmosphere, coarse and unrefined, didst not perturb thee, nor didst the facilities, rude and basic. Thou didst command a potion, Tokyo tea, they call it, and didst request the device, a gadget, if thou wilt, to engage in the quiz, projected upon the wall. And, lo, the fiery wings, anointed with honey, didst taste most sweet! Upon thy departure, thou didst espy the chamber of karaoke, where merriment and mirth didst reign. A humble abode, fit for those who seek naught but drink and victuals, without pomp or fanfare."
"Beerarita, hell yeah! Quesadilla, full of bird, but needed more zest. Chips and salsa, tasty. Salsa, just what quesadilla needed."

"This joint was just alright. Pricey for what you get. A la carte menu, not my scene. Had the Caesar salad, decent but couldn't finish it all. Hubby got the burger, nothing special, overpriced. Might come back if other spots are packed."
"Coffee and tea, both good. Noise from radio and blenders, but who cares? WiFi works well, and now that I know the way, I'll be back."

"Good service, but hard to find due to its location in a strip mall off the beaten path. Generous portions, but the taste was only so-so. I had the everything omelet, while my husband opted for the Scottish eggs Benedict. The Benedict sauce was decent, but the bread was a bit chewy. The omelet was unremarkable, accompanied by home fries and an English muffin."

"Came here with two girls after a mall run. Place is alright, standard BBQ joint. Got some decent jalapeño bread to start. Ordered a turkey sandwich with stuffing and cranberry sauce - Thanksgiving on a roll, basically. It was good, but a bit dry. My friend wanted a PBR, but they don't carry it. Waitress was friendly, though, and when one of our burgers wasn't cooked right, she took it back quick. It's an average spot, but the decor's nice and the service is good. After a long day, their grub hits the spot."

"Tried the 'Juan Turkey Wrap' and was left feeling underwhelmed. Normally, I steer clear of healthy grub, but thought I'd give this joint a shot. The wrap was a flavorless mess, like mush in my mouth. Couldn't make out any distinct flavors, just a bland nothingness. Ended up drowning it in hot sauce. Might give them another chance, maybe order something from the 'happy' side of the menu next time."
"Sipped coffee, ate eggs. Not bad, not great. Prices okay, but not gourmet. Plastic utensils, good. One napkin, lame. Service, meh. Nice spot, though. One bathroom, annoying. Won't be back soon."
"Location-wise, it ain't half bad. Food-wise, it's a mixed bag. Somewhere between Panda and the real deal, but leanin' towards the latter."

"Juicy Pho, off the strip. Not bad for Vegas. Ordered pork chop rice, small portion, not great. Friend's Korean BBQ ribs, decent. Their Pho, just okay. But the egg roll wrapped in lettuce? Damn good. A bit of a haul from the strip, 10-15 minutes by car."
"Burgers, cheap but not worth the price. Like those rubbery ones from grade school. Won't be going back, that's for sure."

This place, methinks, was but a middling sight,
A place where food of China did abide,
But, alas, of quality rather base,
And service, though fair, could not suffice,
To make it worth a second visit, think,
For there was naught that did my senses quick.

In sooth, the victuals they did serve,
Were of a sort that did my taste deceive,
And though the staff did strive to please,
Their efforts were but feeble, as it seems,
For in this place, no joy did I perceive,
Nor aught that did my spirits relieve.

So, to this place, I shall not soon return,
For there are better sights, and more to learn,
In other haunts, where food and drink do flow,
And merriment doth reign, as all men know.

"Hark! I come to this place to play cards and perchance watch a film. But lo! The scent of smoke doth fill mine nostrils, a stench most foul and pungent. 'Tis worse than that of Korean BBQ, where Kalbi doth leave its mark upon mine garb. Nay, I must needs wash mine attire straightaway, lest I doth reek like an ashtray. 

The poker chamber, full of tables and activity, doth teem with elders. I, a mere stripling in mine thirties, doth oft find myself the youngest at the table. 

Fare for the belly, passable though not palace-worthy, doth include Fuddruckers, Subway, and an oyster bar of middling quality, yet not as fine as Palace Station's own."

In fair Madison, where the Capitol doth stand,
A new-ish coffee shop doth please the land.
Colectivo, by name, doth boast a charm,
With rustic, hipster feel, and no alarm.

The tunes, they play, are cool and fine,
The decor, a sight to see and divine.
Seats abound, both within and without,
E'en on the porch, where one may pout.

A variety of brews, both hot and cold,
Teas, too, for those who dare be bold.
And should thou hunger, fear not, dear guest,
For food and ale, they have at their behest.

But, alack! No wi-fi on the weekends,
Lest ye be forced to converse, or read a book that ends.

"Stayed at the Westin, heard noise up in my room. Thought nothing of it, dropped my gear and headed to work. Toilet wouldn't stop running, went downstairs to report it. Came back, still running. Went to grab grub, came back, still not fixed. Reminded 'em again, finally got fixed. But then, found a pool of water behind the toilet. Called 'em up, they fixed it quick. One good thing, check-ins usually around 3 pm. Switched from Hilton Garden to this place early one morning, they let me check in at 8 am."

"Hark, my dear friend! 'Tis my first visit to this place,
And, verily, the victuals didst leave me in a daze.
Fresh, they were, but choices few, alack!
For luncheon, I didst find their spread to be quite lacking.
But lo, their breakfast spread and salad bar didst please,
A feast for mine eyes, and a treat for my taste buds, 'twas.
Alas, no fish, save fried and feathered fowl, didst they proffer,
A bitter disappointment, indeed, and cause for dismay.
Nor didst their sweet treats delight, alack and alas!
I shall not spend six-and-fifty pieces of silver there,
Forsooth, their customer service didst shine, full fair."

"2.5 stars. Small, clean, and bright. Unpleasant smell upon entry, like Asian markets. Limited olive bar, but decent meat selection. Fresh cheese, too. Bacon selection lacking. Only one loaf of whole grain bread. Bulk section looked sparse. Emergency stop, sure, but not my first choice."

"Meh. Not bad, but not great either. Older room, though. Staff? Not exactly friendly. Checked in, girl barely said a word. Told me the wrong floor too. Lugging my bags all over, couldn't find my room. Finally called the front desk, different floor altogether. Construction going on, bunch of workers and trucks. Sat in my car for 12 minutes while some guy tried to back a trailer in. Nope, I'm a paying guest. They should work around me. Wouldn't stay here again. But the actual hotel? Nice. Staff? Fantastic."

Hark! I have not had the pleasure to behold
The place where cronuts first did make their bold
Appearance, for fear of lines that doth extend
Far past my patience, and my heart doth wend
In search of sweets that doth not make me wait
I chanced upon La Cornetteria's gate
And there, my friends, I didst find delight
In cronuts, fresh and hot, with flavors bright
A taste of fame, without the lengthy fray
I thank thee, La Cornetteria, for this day.

"Thus, after that woeful burger I didst receive  
From Carl's Jr., a redemption didst I seek,  
By ordering two cheeseburgers at BK,  
A simple feat, or so it didst seem.  
But lo, I waited, and waited, and waited,  
While others didst receive their chicken nuggets,  
Their Whopper Jr's, and Extra Long BBQ Cheeseburgers,  
And all the while, my order didst remain,  
In red letters, a full five minutes didst pass,  
While others didst finish in but a minute,  
For two plain cheeseburgers, a trifle, indeed!  
But finally, my cheeseburgers didst arrive,  
And they didst make amends for that foul meal,  
I didst enjoy them, with great relish and cheer,  
And thus, my hunger didst depart, with great zeal."

"Hark, I called ahead for a table, they said nay,
Just come in, no need for a fuss, they did say.
But lo, a half hour wait didst greet mine eyes,
And I didst think, 'tis folly, they should devise
A way to take reservations, 'tis Vegas,
On a Saturday eve, and the crowd doth swarm,
Like bees to honey, they do flock,
To this place, where food doth overflow.

The menu, small it may be,
Yet the flavors, they doth burst with glee.
Truffle fries, oh how divine,
Other dishes, good, but not quite fine.
Company, good, didst make the meal,
A pleasant time, we didst reveal.
'Tis a fair place, I wouldst return,
Under the right stars, my heart wouldst yearn."

"A fair brunch, with atmosphere most pleasant,
But flaws, alas, did mar our joyful feast.
We asked for none onions, yet they came,
In dish prepared, as if by fate's decree.
The cook, they said, did try his best,
But onions remained, like a festering pest.
And when we spoke, the waiter showed
Little care, as if our plight were naught.
Their efforts, though well-meaning, did not hide
The breakdowns in service, staff ill-trained.
So, sadly, we shall not return again,
For flaws, though small, did tarnish our delight."

"Hadn't had Asian Buffet in two days, so I stopped by E-Z Buffet for lunch. Place has different names depending on the sign or print - EZ Buffet, EZ Chinese Buffet, Easy Buffet. Whatever, here's the deal: 75 main dishes, including Clam Chowder, beef roast, Stuffed Bell Peppers, Calzone, pizza, and pink marshmallows. Yeah, pink marshmallows. Also got your standard Chinese fare - Sushi, Kim Chee, Egg Foo Young, fried chicken, boneless spare ribs, stuffed mushrooms, fish, shrimp. And real ice cream for dessert. Solid 3 stars for this joint. Lunch buffet is $6.75/$6.08 Sr. Monday through Saturday, $8.75/$7.88 Sunday. They got a regular menu too."

"Chase Field, where the Arizona Diamondbacks play, is a swell place. Nice and big, with plenty of seats and levels. Sun or rain, the retractable roof's got it covered. Been there a few times, always a good experience. Not too crowded, easy to find seats together. Family-friendly, but don't expect a gourmet meal. Prices are steep and the grub's not great. Better to eat outside, save room for a cold one inside. If you're local or just passing through, check it out."

"This sushi place doth boast most wondrous fare,
And atmosphere quite fitting for a date.
But alas, poor service doth mar their score,
For though the servers were friendly, they did ignore.

A group of six, we sat and waited long,
Our orders taken by several servers strong.
But as the night wore on, we were forgot,
And our requests for sushi went unnoticed, alack.

We waited nigh on 45 minutes, I swear,
Before we could get someone to take our fear.
And when they did, they added a gratuity,
Of 20%, which did our bill multiply.

And thus, we had to split the cost between,
Three ways, they said, or else we would be seen.
So there you have it, friends, a tale of woe,
That doth make me less likely to go, you know."

"Hark! If ne'er I had set foot within wicked spoon's halls,  
I would have deemed this feast most fantastical.  
The victuals were of fair quality, 'twain true and good,  
But alas! The crowd did swarm, like bees in springtime's mood.  
And dear it was, for what thou got'st, save thou didst plan  
To gorge thyself with quantity, like some great gannet or cormorant.  
Nay, 'twas a bit too much, like Disneyland's buffet,  
Where all the world doth gather, and doth eat, and doth forget."

"Verily, we've visited this establishment oft,
And found the service to be either sublime or wroth,
But still, the victuals here be of fair quality,
Thus, three stars doth be its rightful quantity.

Yet, should the fare decline in taste and worth,
Then shall we bid this place adieu, forsooth,
For mediocrity doth not suffice our needs,
And thus, we shall seek elsewhere for our deeds."

"Methinks 'tis strange, this place doth call itself a park,
Yet doth it close its gates at nine o'clock?
A family-friendly spot, it doth proclaim,
But families with young ones, it doth not accommodate.

We went this day, my daughter and three adults,
And found a fort where she did play and make merry.
We walked to Fremont Street, and there did dine,
But when my daughter asked to see the burning mantis,
They would not let her pass, though she didst plead.
My husband went to fetch her, but they didst say,
"You cannot enter, lest ye be of age."

At nine o'clock, they didst announce the park's demise,
And we, who had just bought our meal, didst feel quite vexed.
For we didst have to rush, and leave behind,
Our dinner, which we had just begun to find.

If families be their aim, then they should change,
Their hours, to suit the needs of parents and their brood.
But if they be not, then they should make it known,
That families need not come, for they are not shown.

I didst not appreciate, the haste we had to make,
To leave the park, and leave our meal to waste.
So here I write, to warn others of this fate,
And hope that they will heed, and change their policy, ere too late."
"Been here thrice. Once for dinner, twice for brunch. Three stars, tops. Food's not great, even when I'm famished. Presentation's on point, though."

"Labor Day weekend, came here with my Groupon. Nice time, but rooms need update - tile, shower curtain, and a fridge-less cabinet. TVs worked sometimes. Staff was fine at check-in and out. Many activities: pools, movies, smores, music, mini golf, playground. Rent paddleboards and kayaks for Lake Las Vegas. Dog-friendly, too. Price I paid was fair, but full price would've been a ripoff."

"In fair Charlotte, my kin didst arrive,
During restaurant week, their hunger to relieve.
Mez, the eatery, with menus diverse and wide,
Didst entice us in, with atmosphere upbeat and bright.
Cocktails at the bar, we didst imbibe with glee,
Their creative mix, a true delight for thee.
Our table, swiftly gained, with service so fine,
A sweet and spunky server, our needs didst define.
The restaurant week menu, a wondrous sight,
Crab cakes, the best, in all of Charlotte's light.
Steaks, cooked to perfection, a tender delight,
Leaving naught but wishing, for a sweeter bite.
Dessert, a tasty treat, yet not quite divine,
Still, Mez, a place, where I wouldst happily dine."

"Hark! Red Ridge Park, so near my humble abode,
A mere ten minutes' walk, and I am there,
A place of recreation, exercise, and joy,
Where I do run, and gauge my distance, by and by.

Two sides of hills, and two of level ground,
A pleasant course, for feet to tread around,
Well-lit at night, and safe, I do declare,
For solitary runs, without a single care.

A haven for young ones, with waters bright,
And play areas, for the little ones to delight,
Basketball courts, and diamond, for the bold,
A place of merriment, for young and old.

But now, they build, across from this fair park,
Dunhill homes, with prices, quite a mark,
A growing neighborhood, indeed, it seems,
With views of green, and joyous dreams.

Alas, one thing, I wish they had,
An enclosed dog park, for furry lads,
Like some other parks, I have chanced to see,
A place for pups, to frolic, wild and free."

"Methinks the reviews didst speak of wondrous feasts,
But alas, mine own dish didst not meet expectations.
Chicken pasta, with linguini, basil, and cream sauce,
Didst weigh heavy on my stomach, like a leaden anchor.
The service, though, didst shine like the brightest star,
Five stars, I say, for their courteousness and care.
And gladly, they didst serve my favorite brew,
Dos Equis amber, a drink most fair and true."

I've hit up Osteria twice now. First, for a sandwich on the go, then for a pie to go. Hoped it'd be good since I'm right across the street. Been a mixed bag so far. The sandwich was a solid Italian deli job. Pizza? Meh. It did bring back memories of those free slices I used to score in grad school, but that ain't exactly a glowing review. Not terrible, but could use some work. 

Osteria's got potential. Hope they make it. Maybe throw in a weekend brunch? And step up their pizza game - less basic takeout, more fancy (and tasty).
"River-floating, beer-guzzling, hat-sporting good times. Dirty? Who cares? We had a blast."

"Tis well, my friend, 'tis well indeed,
No need to fret or make a fuss,
For all is fine, and doth proceed
As it should, with naught amiss.

Verily, I speak the truth, my word
Is bond, and thus it shall be heard,
No sarcasm doth my voice convey,
But rather, all is well, come what may.

And so, my dear, let us partake
In this most noble of breakfasts, fair and bright,
For here, within this hallowed hall,
Doth lie a feast most wondrous and grand, fit for a king's delight."

"Thou knowest full well, ere thou dost step within,  
That fare provided may not be of the finest kin.  
Yet, hope doth spring eternal, that staff shall befriend,  
And make thy sojourn pleasant, with service of a kind.  
Alas! 'Tis a gamble, for this OG doth play  
A game of chance, where fortunes may sway.  
I've known both joy and woe, at hands of those  
Who tend the tables, and pour the flowing doses."

"Fair food, good sir! 'Tis a fine place to break thy fast, indeed. Thou savory crepes, how they doth please mine taste! And coffee drinks, oh how they doth delight!

Yet, there be some things that doth trouble mine eyes:
A hostess, fair maiden, to guide me through the door,
For here, within this hall, no clear path doth lay.
Counter service or table, who doth know? Alas,
I hadst to seek an employee, to learn the way.

And service, spotty 'tis, with two fair maidens serving,
Each table full, our order, didst take some time arriving.
Wait times, long they be, for crepes, twenty-five minutes,
A lengthy span, indeed, for one who hath a plan.

But still, I say, two out of three, not bad, my friend,
For crepes and coffee, they doth make amends.
So, here I shall return, when time doth allow,
To partake in feast, and drink, and merriment, anon!"

"Solid deal in Vegas. $109 per night on weekends, compare that to $400 for a small, cramped room on the Strip. Throw in free brekkie and drinks in the eve, you're lookin' at a sweet score. 

Hotel's been renovated, rooms are decent. Lobby's a bit old-school, fake plants could use a dustin'. 

Some service hiccups. Ordered grub to go, they said 20 min, took 40. Check-in took forevs, front desk dudes had to stop and answer phones, annoyin'. One dude called me "cute", not sure if I should be flattered or creeped out. 

Shuttle to the Strip was a wild card. Told us they'd take us anywhere, but then said they only do Pick-ups and Dropoffs at Planet Hollywood. Ended up takin' cabs, $10 a pop. 

All things considered, I gotta give it to the other Embassy Suites on Paradise, liked 'em a smidge better. But they wanted $50 more a night when I booked, so we settled here."

"The Gyle Industrial Estate's shopping center, a haven for lunchtime escapes from the office. Others may view it as worn down, but to me, it's a treasure trove of clothing stores, food options, and Starbucks. A respite from the daily grind, where I can indulge in some retail therapy and caffeine. 

Opened long ago, perhaps, but the selection remains impressive - Marks & Spencer, Morrisons, Boots, New Look, Dorothy Perkins, and my beloved Starbucks. Let's not forget Millie's Cookies, a weakness of mine, according to Kelly F. Yes, cookie cake, please! 

Dark, yes, and limited healthy options in the food court, but still a worthy destination for a lunch break or emergency beauty runs to Boots. Or when I simply must have that dress from Dorothy Perkins, featured in my Gossip mag. It's alright, this place, despite its age, still offers a fair amount."

I've wanted to check this place out for years, but always ended up sticking to the Strip. Finally made it out here on my last trip. It's an outdoor party, and the screens are pretty impressive. This is old Vegas, where everything is dirt cheap - drinks, food, you name it. But, let me tell you, it's pretty damn ghetto here, especially at night. Saw a lot of street people, and some suspicious-looking bags. But hey, that's part of the charm, right? You can just walk around with an open container, no worries. Had to keep an eye on my wallet, though. Maybe the earlier shows aren't as seedy. Came for the last show of the night, so maybe I was asking for it.

"After Zumanity, we hit this joint, looking for a spot to grab a drink and watch the crowd. It was Halloween night, and people were out in force, dressed to the nines. We scored some free drink coupons, so we didn't have to break the bank. Prices were reasonable, anyway - six or seven bucks for a great selection of craft and microbrews. I went for a Sin City Amber, while the missus opted for a Sam Adams Cherry Wheat. They had a solid selection, with names like Sierra Nevada, Alaska, Abita, Rogue, and Stone. Better than most bars in Vegas, that's for sure. \n\nIt was a Friday night, and NYNY was jumping, but this place wasn't too packed. The bartenders were hustling, though. My only gripe was the service - with free drinks, I expected a bit more attention. I still tipped well, hoping for a better experience next time. Definitely coming back, especially since it's a great spot to meet up with friends staying on the Strip."

"In fair Oakland, where dining options abound,
Lucca stands as one of the finer Italian grounds.
Their fare, well-prepared, doth please the palate,
And staff, with smiles, do make the guest feel great.
The atmosphere, not too formal, doth create
A comfortable setting, suitable for a date.
But alas, the cost, a bit too steep, doth say
This meal, more fit for cities grand, like SF or NY."
"View's the thing. Day to night, Vegas spread out below. Food? Decor? Average. But who needs 'em when you got a view like this?"

"Viva Elvis. Saw it a few times. Opening night to a few months back. Improved, sure. But not by much. Not bad, just doesn't fit with Cirque's other shows. Liked the music, scenes, costumes. Jail House Rock, Return to Sender - my favorites. Didn't like the choreography. Minimal. Not enough 'wow.' Women singing Elvis songs? No thanks. They're not bad, just shouldn't be singing Elvis. Awkward transitions between scenes. Enjoyed it though. Recommend it. It'll be gone soon."
"New ownership's taken over. Quality's gone downhill. My brows, uneven and thin. Gotta grow 'em out longer now. Won't be back."

"Methinks 'tis my second visit to this wondrous place,
Where culinary delights doth fill the space.
The atmosphere, it doth delight,
With the Yard, a merry sight.

Hark! The happy hour, a warning give,
For drinks, a bar, high-tops, or outdoors doth live.
We didst not partake in such revelry,
But couldst have been, a tale to tell, ye see.

A hip bar menu, we didst enjoy,
With friends, a work hangout, didst employ.
Good fare, it was, I do declare,
And fun, a place to gather, without a care.

An adult playground, full of mirth,
A place to laugh, and let go of dearth.
So come, my friends, and join the fray,
At this culinary dropout, night or day!"

"Tuna carpaccio, ninja roll, and elephant roll, oh my!
How delectable they did taste, upon my word!
Trendy, indeed, the vibe doth seem, yet somewhat cramped,
I do confess, the low rise sushi bar, doth not appeal.
AYCE dinner, priced not too steep, a bargain, one might say,
Parking, plentiful, a convenience, beyond a doubt.
Music, pleasant, and ventilation, most fair,
Food, satisfactory, and experience, generally, quite pleasant."

"Bang's the spot for you if you're into Billy Joel, Elton John, and some good ol' fashioned people watchin'. Don't mind standin' 'cause tables are scarce, and you might just find yourself beltin' out Journey tunes with the rowdy crowd. But if you're lookin' for a more low-key night, this ain't the place for you. There's a cover at the door, and it's a fun spot, but livin' here? Nah, that's a hard pass."

"Thou Squirrel Hill, thy charm doth impress me sore,
More than Bangkok Balcony, I do declare.
My friend and I, upon a vegan's guide,
Didst find this place, and late it didst abide.

With ease, we found parking on the street,
And marveled at the mix of old and new,
In clothing stores, alas, most were shut tight,
But still, the wares within didst catch our sight.

The layout of BB, modern and sleek,
Didst please mine eyes, and all was neat.
The flatware, too, didst win our praise,
A detail oft ignored, in verse I raise.

Tofu dishes, plenty, and spice, they didst ask,
On a scale of one to ten, my taste to task.
Fair prices, too, for such a busy place,
With decorations fine, and packed with grace.

Thai food, my heart doth sing, my love so true,
This place, three stars, my rating, anon, I do.
For though it pleased, our bellies, later, didst ache,
A minor quibble, in this culinary tale, I make."

"Table by the window, view of the strip. Not too shabby. Eiffel Tower in the distance, adds a touch of romance. Drinks, top-notch. Live music, on the other side of the bar. Choose wisely, my friend. Crowd, mature, date-night types. We had one drink, laughed, and left. Worth a visit."

"A frozen hot chocolate, I didst procure,  
To sate my thirst and warm my soul.  
The wait, it was a lengthy one, I must confess,  
Yet, the drink itself, didst make amends.  
'Twas rich and creamy, with a flavor so divine,  
That I wouldst have it once again, in a heartbeat, 'twine.  
For though the price, didst seem a bit steep,  
I found it worth it, in the end, to sleep.  
And thus, I shall return, to try their fare,  
And see if their dishes, be as fair and rare."

"A hearty breakfast, fit for a king,
Eggs, spuds, bacon, and coffee, we bring.
A steep price, twenty-two dollars, we pay,
For a meal that's quite decent, in a way.

An entree of ten dollars, a cup of joe,
Three bucks, and orange juice, you know.
A side of hash browns, plate-sized, no less,
Six dollars, a price that's quite excessive, I guess.

Now, compare this to Waffle House, my friend,
Twice the food, for half the price, it does end.
Better coffee, in fact, they do serve,
A better value, you'll surely deserve.

In conclusion, good but not great,
Overpriced by twenty-five percent, that's quite a feat."

"Fare thee well, good sir! The victuals here be passable, 'Tis the sole establishment near that doth provide sustenance swift and fair. At Mandala Bay, my lodging lay, And thither didst I stroll to partake of their fare."

"Korean BBQ joint took over old McDonald's spot. Prices a bit steep for fast food, but worth it. Bulgogi, veggies, and kimchi - all good. Sweetness, garlic, and spice blend well. Want to try Mandu and tempura, but concerned about heat lamps. Health inspection issues, but mostly resolved. Newly added Boba tea - exciting! Hope prices drop as they get busier. One of few Korean places on east side of Phoenix."

"Not my scene, Old Town Scottsdale nightlife. Went to The Mint with 12 girlfriends for Happy Hour on a Friday. Had a good time. Food's great! Drinks are good, especially at half price. Interior's cool. Bathroom's weird, didn't like it. Staff's friendly, but seemed new. Server had trouble with our big group. Told us one group bill would be easier, then it wasn't. Waited 30 minutes for my bill. Would come back for Happy Hour again, but insist on separate checks."

"Cool joint. Artwork, big screens in the main bar. Pool tables, arcade games upstairs. Outdoor patio, smokers love it. Popular spot for Sunday football. No grub, but they had a free chicken wing buffet one Sunday. Local brews, nice. Street and back lot parking."

"Methinks 'twas not as wondrous as some folk did claim,
With four and five stars, they did loudly exclaim.
Good, indeed, yet not the finest burger e'er,
And for six tens, I didst feel somewhat queer.
Aye, verily, my lovely lass doth concur,
Our expectations, alas, were not quite sure.
Three stars, I say, a fair and honest rating,
For though 'twas good, 'twas not entirely satisfying."

"Alack, how different from its fame,
This Canyon Ranch doth bear a name,
In books and reviews, a place of bliss,
But in truth, a disappointment doth miss.

Over-priced, and small, compared to The Venetian's spa,
And naught but an expensive energy massage, they do offer,
Without touch, a strange and puzzling thing,
Leaves me to ponder, and my heart doth sing.

Not my first choice, I must confess,
For better value, elsewhere I shall address."

"Went to HH with the husband. Ordered a couple of things off the menu, including the Gladiator burger and daily dose burger. Decent prices, but the food was lacking. Flavor was scarce and the mushroom brie was nothing special. Place was dead, but our server, Hope, was in a rush. She was training some new girl and talked down to her like she was dirt. 'Don't ask her questions, she's new and won't know,' she said. Jesus, I've been a waitress before and I'd have been pissed if someone talked to me like that during my training. And as a customer? It looked bad. Real bad."

"Apple stores, big and bright. Products on display, easy to find. Friendly staff, happy to help. But let's get real, folks. Prices are steep. You can do better with your cash. Donating? Sure thing. Eat, drink, and be merry, my friends."

In sooth, the victuals were of fair quality,
With choice enough to sate thy appetite.
But, alack, the ambiance didst lack,
That je ne sais quoi, that doth make night bright.
'Twas not a lively place, I do confess,
Especially for Vegas, where mirth doth reign supreme.
Yet, praise the gods, a Groupon didst aid,
And made the cost, a goodly sum indeed.
For otherwise, o'er-priced, 'twould have been deemed.

"Airpark, a detailing service of fair renown,
Didst perform their duties with skill and care,
For a price most reasonable, a sum of $150,
Their work, though not outstanding, was beyond compare.

Danny's, a rival detailer of ill repute,
Could never hope to match the quality found,
In Airpark's work, a true bargain, no doubt,
Their prices, too steep, a whopping $250, alas!

In this fair town, I have seen detailers,
Whose work surpassed Airpark's, in truth,
But their prices, oh so high, near $250,
A king's ransom, for a service, scarce worth the fee.

So, if thou seeketh a detailing, fair and bright,
With a price that doth not break the bank,
Airpark, a choice most wise, doth shine so bright,
In this realm of detailers, a true gem, a paragon of might."

"I come here often when in Vegas, but let's get something straight - if you're white, they'll dumb down the food without asking. Case in point: I ordered the house special pho, and it arrived sans tendon or tripe. No extra meat to make up for it either."
"Galaxy Luxury theater, great place, but not always convenient. Brenden, comfortable, reliable, employees polite, prices normal."

"Alas, my dear friend, how fares Mamma Mia's reach? A mere 0.7 miles, a distance too great, alack! Their online system doth declare, 'Tis not enough, thou art too far away, East of 20th or West of 64th, North of Washington or South of Lincoln, nay, 'tis a journey too long, a drive most foul. Yet fear not, fair sir, for their pizza, though distant, doth remain most delectable, a treat worth the toil, a slice most divine."
"Mexican joint. Decent. Salsa bar, top-notch. Generous servings. Four stars, minus one for the outdated dcor."

"Hark, a teriyaki bowl place doth catch mine eye,
