A stones throw from Midwestern, 'tis nigh.  
A fan of Flamebroiler, I do confess,  
And seek a place that doth serve a similar mess.  
Rice bowls, a meal most quick, cheap, and fine,  
For Asian and Indian folk, a wondrous find.  
I tried their Cayman, a combo of two dishes,  
Fiji and Singapore curry, both quite delish.  
The Fiji, slow-cooked chuck roast in teriyaki sauce,  
Good, but a bit tough, alack, in truth.  
Singapore curry, with chicken and carrots,  
In a Japanese curry, a hint of sour notes.  
The chicken, stringy, slow-cooked, I did not prefer,  
But overall, my meal was good, and served in a generous portion.  
The price, a mere five bucks, a steal, indeed,  
Less, even, if thou dost order but a single dish.  
Their menu, unique, and different from the rest,  
Away from the usual teriyaki beef or chicken crest.  
A 10% discount for Midwestern students, a boon,  
I shall return, and try their crab puffs and egg rolls anon."

"Hark! A tale of feast and revelry, my friends,
At Trader Vic's, where we did partake,
Of lobster, shrimp, and duck, oh so fine,
In a banquet room, with hula dancers divine.

Eve, Trader Vic's granddaughter, did grace,
Our presence, and showed us the unfinished place,
With executive chef Rick Giffen, of renown,
Whose culinary skills, did our taste astound.

Alas, the decor, a single star didst claim,
But fear not, for VR helmets, may yet proclaim,
The virtues of this Trader Vic's Lounge, so bright,
Akin to those in Beverly Hills, a wondrous sight.

And though the Polynesio, in Havanna, a tale,
Of its own, this Trader Vic's, did our spirits sail."

"A fine hotel chamber, yet pricy, alack!
I visited thither on Memorial Day eve,
With friends, and found the room quite fair,
Yet, for each small luxury, they did charge.

For a bed, a mere $20 per night, they'd say,
And the fridge, a fee, lest ye wish to play.
But, 'twas in a prime location, near the Strip,
Where Rehab, a concert, doth take its grip.

Drake and Wayne, they did perform, I heard,
But, alas, the line, long, and tickets scarce,
Doubled in price, and sold out fast,
A two-hour wait, at least, to pass the test.

The casino, restaurants, and nightclub, too,
Did offer diversions, for me and you.
Yet, on my next visit, I may choose to stray,
To other hotels, or a less busy day."

"Went with the Waffle Fry Nachos to start. Good stuff. Cheddar and sloppy joe on waffle fries, topped with salsa and jalapenos. Solid. Maybe skip the sloppy joe next time though. Not a big fan of the meat. 

Had the Crispy Four Cheese Burger after that. Cheese was fried nice and crispy onto the patty. Good combo. Brioche bun was a bit much though. Made the burger a bit dry. Onion roll would've been better. 

Husband went with the BYOB. Beef patty, pepper jack cheese, jalapenos, and caramelized onions on an onion roll. Well done. Flavorful and juicy. 

Service was a bit slow, but they'd only been open a week. Cut 'em some slack. Hopefully, they'll get it together soon."

Steve's Greenhouse Grill? A-OK, I reckon. Like Cracker Barrel, but without the corporate backing and with a dash of sporty flair. Loud colors, loud TVs, and booze ads plastered everywhere. Menu's a mixed bag - something for everyone, but nothing too fancy. Drinks? Overpriced, but what do you expect? Servers? Friendly, but a bit too eager to please. Had the chicken fried steak with fries, Kristen had the fish and chips with clam chowder. Food was decent, but not perfect. Some dishes were too salty, others just right, a few too bland. If Cracker Barrel trimmed the fat and tried to cater to every type of customer in Phoenix, they'd end up with Steve's Greenhouse Grill.

"We watched Central Bistro take shape, curious about what it'd become. Inside, it's lively, almost too loud. Windows open, Phoenix's mild weather made it perfect. Wonder how it'll be when they close 'em. 

Food? Delicious. Service? Good. But, two visits, we saw bartenders prepping garnishes with bare hands. Juice running down their arms, slicing oranges for drinks. Another time, a bartender reached into the olive jar, grabbed a handful, and put 'em in the garnish tray. I promptly removed the olives from my martini. 

Central Bistro, get your act together before Maricopa County pays a visit."

"I wanted all my meals at the bar of old homes in downtown Phoenix. Found Coronado Cafe. Went for lunch, didn't order much, just the roasted chicken sandwich and potato salad. Small place, tiny bar. Sat at the bar, had a wait for a table. Nice spirits and wine selection. Chicken was juicy, potato salad was great. Simple, good lunch. Want to go back when it's not busy. Hard to get server's attention, outside seating too hot in August."

"Pierre and Donald, both right. Two menu items stand out: lettuce wedge, willy burger. Steaks? Awful. Overseasoned, can't eat 'em. Cook needs to learn med rare from well done. Rib-eye came out like a hockey puck. Bread's good when hot. Wrap up burgers fine, lettuce wedge great. Skip the steaks."

"Fair priced victuals, they do serve herein,
We chanced upon this place mid-week, forsooth,
Upon the morn, our hunger to assuage,
And sampled dishes, of which we had heard tell.

A fortunate hour, we came, forsooth,
No waiting, we didst endure, nor tarry,
The server, kind and swift, didst attend,
Our needs, with grace and gentle demeanor.

A varied menu, there didst abound,
Our choice, didst cause some puzzlement, profound,
Jamm's French Toast, my selection, didst make,
My spouse, an omelette, didst partake.

The fare, middling, I must confess,
Perhaps, our choices, not the best, alas,
Yet would I return? Nay, I do fear,
For other morn, in Las Vegas, we shall hear."

"Hark, what changes have been made, my dear!
The entrance, once a grueling climb, doth now
Conveniently deposit thee on a random floor,
Where thou must navigate through a concert's din,
And up a flight of stairs, to reach the dance floor's shore.

But lo, the dance floor itself, so small and cramped,
Doth leave me wanting more, and the crowds, they do
Block out the view, so one cannot even see
The floor, where all the revelry doth come to be.

And thus, I say, this place doth lack the flair
Of TAO, where one could dance and breathe with ease,
For here, the design doth seem to be so bare,
And comfort, it doth not provide, alas, my friend,
So back to XS, I shall return, for there, at least,
I can enjoy the night, without such discomfort and unrest."

"Upon a Sunday eve, with friends I didst stroll,
Into a place of victuals, where we didst dine.
A smallish room, yet cozy, with heat outdoors,
A menu vast, with choices manifold.
Each of us chose a dish, but lo, the portions great,
Didst fill our table, making meal-time quite a feat.
Beware, dear friends, lest ye be overcome,
By sauces rich, and servings most generous.
Tea, in a metal dish, didst come to us,
And though the fare was heavy, I didst find it tasty.
Alas, the service, left a bit to be desired,
Yet still, a night of joy, with friends, I didst acquire."

"Pizza most excellent, service most vile.
The maiden at the till, with skin as dark as night,
Didst ignore my presence, and with rudeness didst reply,
When I didst ask if I should sit, she didst roll her eyes in scorn.

A youth, with fiery locks, didst greet me with a smile,
And he who crafted pies, didst say 'thank ye' in style.
But lo, the pair didst engage in bitter strife,
As she didst shout at him, and he didst take his life.

This place, so foul and dirty, with tables all awry,
I couldst not find a seat, save one that didst make me sigh.
My pizza, from a pie that lay upon a stool,
Was tossed within the oven, with haste most cruel.

Good pizza, yes, but service, oh so poor,
I pray they mend their ways, and customer service adore."

"Hark! My dearest wife doth crave red velvet cupcakes,
And so we stopped here for a sweet treat.
But lo! The selection was quite limited, alas,
On this fair Sunday afternoon, so neat.

Each cupcake doth cost three golden coins,
A price not too steep for gourmet sweets, I reckon.
But verily, the frosting did o'erflow,
And the caramel upon mine own did not meet my expectations, I do confess.
The red velvet ones, alas, did lack cream cheese frosting,
A fact that did dampen my spirits, I must admit.

Yet still, a pleasant dessert it did provide,
For those with a sweet tooth, it doth abide."

"Airport eatery worth a stop. Friendly service, pleasant surroundings, and a satisfying meal. Opted for the grilled chicken stuffed pita, accompanied by fresh lettuce, juicy tomato, creamy hummus, and a tangy vinaigrette. Outlets available too. A fine choice indeed."

"Blossom, the joint serving up the best Peking duck in town, according to our server, takes two days to prep. Seventy-nine bucks a pop, so my expectations were high. I've had the real deal in Beijing, and this place didn't quite measure up. Duck came wrapped in skin and meat, sauce and all. Shoulda been just skin, if you ask me. Sauce was alright, but the skin wasn't crispy enough. They chopped the duck up after that, meat was juicy, but had a weird duck smell. Better than other SoCal spots like Duck House, but not worth the price tag."
"Pasta dish, no thanks. Pizzookie, raw. Waiter, useless. Rating, down. Maybe next time."

Thou hast arrived upon a Thursday eve,
And found, to thy delight, no wait didst grieve.
Their feast didst include dishes of finest fare,
Fish, fowl, and beasts, all cooked with care.
But thou, my friend, didst choose a lighter course,
A summer menu, with sandwiches, pasta, and force.
Thy appetizer, chicken wings, didst please,
Prepared in manner strange, yet tasty, if thou dost seize.
Italian cuisine, a favorite of thine,
Didst cause great strife, betwixt pasta and pizza divine.
Thou didst select, alas, the wrong dish,
A bolognese, with penne, lacking in finesse.
The taste, unremarkable, the presentation, poor,
Leaving thee unsatisfied, and craving more.
Yet, service was good, and pizzas, a sight to see,
Perhaps, another time, thou shalt try, mayhap, thee shall agree.

"This joint's become the go-to spot for the local hipster crowd. Tea's the new cool, I reckon. And the key to their success? Bright colors, youthful vibes, and a healthy dose of YAY! No stuffy, damp tea rooms here. First time I visited, I had some questions, and a youngin' behind the counter told me to check their website. Thanks, I guess? Second time around, the staff were eager to give me the full DavidsTea experience. You can buy tea for home or to-go, and they've got different labels for each. Pricy, but I figured I needed a pick-me-up. So, hot or iced? Latté, black, or with milk? Honey or agave? I went with a chocolate-orange blend, whisked soy milk, and agave...for 4,50$! Everything's optional, but watch out, 'cause the tea-maker'll toss whatever doesn't fit your cup down the drain! Was it good? Hell yeah, it was epic! But also pretty damn pricey, if you ask me. This place is more for a quick caffeine fix, and it gets cramped fast. Might wanna skip buying a glass kettle here."

"Hark! A tale of woe doth come from mine own lips,
Of a hotel stay that did my patience test.
'Twas earlier this year, on business I did stray,
And found myself within these walls, a guest.

The check-in, oh how slow it did proceed,
As if the procedure were of ancient creed.
And when a delivery I didst require,
It came not swiftly, but with much delay and blunder.

I didst not partake in the restaurants' fare,
But chose instead a cafe, with pastries so fair and rare.
Yet, after a pair of days, the Frenchness didst wear,
And I didst find myself in search of something more to share.

The room, it was a bit above the rest,
But still, the hotel left me feeling quite depressed.
I would not choose to stay here again,
For pleasure's sake, my friends, I do declare."
"Antenna balls? Out. New ones coming, but no word on when. Picture didn't help much. Grabbed a Jumbo Jack instead. Tasted good, but not worth the trip from Canada."

"Twas not my fancy, this eating house,
In Scottsdale Quarter, a place of trend.
Fox-like, it seemed, in menu and in taste,
With dishes plain, and portion sizes scant.

A roasted chicken, I did order, fair,
But lo, a meager thigh and drumstick there.
Sodden spinach, too, and runny polenta,
Did make my meal a disappointment, verily.

Creative, indeed, the dishes did appear,
But flavor, alas, did lack, I do declare.
Confusion reigned among the serving folk,
Mistakes abounded, as if in some jest.

This place, I shall not seek again,
For better fare, my heart doth yearn and pain."

"Fair Chinese victuals, fit for a king,
Their Lo Mein, a dish most wondrous, doth sing.
Shrimp and beef, both cooked to perfection,
A feast for the taste, a joyous obsession.
But alas, their shrimp and lobster sauce,
Doth leave much to be desired, in truth, a cause.
Ribs, a gamble, fatty or lean,
A chance taken, a risk, a culinary scene.
Won ton, egg drop soup, a disappointment,
A letdown, a shame, a culinary accident.
Fried rice, a staple, a delight,
A dish most fair, a pleasure, a true sight."

"Went back to Chang's, service was good this time. Friendly and efficient. Had the prawns and shrimp fried rice, both were great. Always liked their food, not the best but solid. Service was the issue, but seems they've improved. Told the waiter about the blank fortune cookie last time, he apologized and said they got a bad batch. This time I got a fortune, wasn't great but still, a saying on a piece of paper, that's all I wanted."

"Methinks the ornamentation of this establishment doth seal the deal forsooth. 'Tis a temple of Mid Century modernity, and the fare provided within its hallowed walls doth please mine eyes and taste buds alike. In sooth, the privy booths wherein we sit do make our converse seem most intimate and exclusive. The chopped salad, verily, doth reign supreme amongst mine order, forsooth, for I do adore it passing well. And, by the gods, the green goddess dressing doth complement it most divinely. Moreover, the rolls and butter served forth do seem a genuine relic of yore, soft, warm, and most delectable. Mayhap, perchance, I do confess a certain fondness for iced tea, and, lo, how pleased I am by its presentation here! A mighty goblet, fresh mint, a sideline of simple syrup for sweetening, and an iced tea spoon, all these doth combine to elevate mine enjoyment. Alas, I know not if 'tis still available, yet the cake and shake for dessert, aye, 'twas a diminutive chocolate shake accompanied by a tiny chocolate cake, a most exquisite and satisfying sweetmeat, in sooth."

"Good grub, but not quite on par with the other high-end joints in Scottsdale. Prices are the same, so I expect the same quality. Not bad, but not worth the same price tag as the others. Popover bread's a nice touch, and some main dishes are different. Steaks are decent, but not outstanding. Everything's about the same level. Might come back for a change of pace, but not in my top three for steakhouses in Scottsdale."

In this place, thou shalt find treasures both fair and foul,
A haven for thy purse, yet beware of the toll.
I purchased a trinket for my mother, a token of love,
A keychain of worth, for the price of twelve dollars above.
But alas, 'twas a curse, for it broke in her hand,
And twice it did fail, like a fleeting dream in the land.
I returned it with haste, and didst receive a card in exchange,
For cash was the payment, and no receipt could I arrange.
This shop, a gamble it be, with goods of varying worth,
Yet park thy steed with ease, within Tivoli's girth.

"Thai Rama, a small joint near the light rail, easy to miss. Big fan of Thai food, a little picky, wasn't sure what to expect. Menu was extensive, lots of options. Ordered F.B.I., friend bananas and coconut ice cream, didn't know what to expect. Food came quick, ice cream first, then shrimp pineapple curry. Ice cream was a bit too frozen, but still good. Curry was spot on, flavorful, but pineapple was canned, lacked freshness. Staff was friendly, wouldn't go out of my way to return, but if in the area, might stop by."

"'Tis the crew, my dear, that doth make this shop thrive!
Their diligence and care, they do not leave untried.
Above and beyond, they strive with each task they take,
Their service, a rarity, doth make my heart sing and shake."

"In days of yore, thou couldst stroll into Uncle Sal's on a Friday eve, sans reservation, and be seated straightaway. Alas, those halcyon days are now but a distant memory, forsooth! \n

Verily, I didst coordinate dinner, yet failed miserably in mine endeavor. Hark! The Blind Pig, a nearby establishment, didst save the day, and we four famished patrons were quickly seated and served. \n

We shared dishes, and sampled each other's fare. The steak salad, a triumph! Short ribs, cooked to perfection, and all else, merely adequate. Alas, my trio of tacos, unremarkable, save for their freshness and execution. \n

Anon, if fate doth lead me to the Blind Pig, I shan't protest. Yet, I fear not, for in my present domain, other eateries hold greater allure."

"We rolled in past midnight, the place still lit up, serving up grub. Service was slow, but hell, it was late. I don't recall what I had, maybe a steak, but that watermelon juice was damn good. Friendly service, prices a bit high, but that's Aria for you. We found better deals elsewhere."

"A plate of breakfast potatoes, au gratin, doth please,
With vegetable chow mein, a wondrous sight.
Cover all with melted butter, a most excellent treat,
And thou shalt see why terrorists do hate this land so bright.

The place was neat, the service fair,
The food, a plenty, as expected there.
But that great vat of melted butter, oh how grand,
'Tis the perfect topping for each dish in this land."

"Hark! This tavern beckons thee, my friend,
After a night of revelry and ale.
The victuals served within are plain,
Yet satisfying, as the hunger doth wane.

Aye, 'twas the drive-thru that didst impress,
Quick and efficient, with nary a mess.
But lo, the portion size of my fries,
Didst leave me in a state of dismay and surprise.

Forsooth, the Carne Asada, once a hearty dish,
Was now but a mere morsel, a paltry wish.
I pray, dear tavern, that thou mayst reconsider,
And grant thy patrons a more generous portion, ere they surrender.

Yet still, I shall return, in hopes anew,
To find a better fate, and a heartier brew."

"Aye, naught too wondrous didst I find,
In this place they call a 'fast food joint'.
Burgers, fair and juicy, yet not divine,
Onion rings, crispy and tasty, didst shine.
Price, alack, didst sting like a bee,
For what it was, in Vegas' glee."
"Food and service? No gripes. But, hell, there's better burgers for cheaper in this town."

"I stop by here often, 'twixt my place and the folks'. Orders can be a crap shoot, me and the kids, ya know? Staff's always changin', but I reckon it's worth it for the convenience. Lines can get long, mornings especially, but they hustle folks through quick enough. Had to send drinks back once or twice, they were real sorry 'bout it, fixed it up pronto."

"Upon a Friday eve, I chanced to stray
Into this place, where people doth play
Their revelry, with mirth and glee
Amidst the din, a merry spree

The drinks, they did flow freely
And bartender, he did ply me
With concoctions of his art
Yet, alas, one drink did depart
From expectation, a trifle strange
The three wise men, he did not arrange

But fear not, for the music did play
A lively tune, to banish dismay
The DJ, he did spin his wheel
With skill and grace, did he reveal
His craft, a wondrous delight
To stir the crowd, in joyful sight

Yet, tacos, I did not partake
For those, my taste did not awake
But still, this place, I shall not shun
For drinks and music, it hath won"

"Been back a few times since new ownership. Things improving, so giving 'em another star. Service better, old chefs back. Worth a visit. New owner still hovers near sushi bar, though. Like he's counting fish."

"Hark, good sir! I pray thee, tell me what thou didst order from yonder menu, that I may partake in this feast with thee."

"Marry, kind sir, I didst request two eggs, scrambled, if thou must know, and a dish of potatoes, all for a mere $3.85, a veritable steal! And, prithee, didst they not come with a slice of toast, and a side of home fries, to boot?"

"Indeed, they didst, my good fellow. The eggs, though scrambled, were quite plain, and the toast, a trifle burnt, I must confess. But, alack! The home fries, devoid of flavor, didst leave much to be desired. A sprinkle of salt and pepper, I didst add, yet still, they didst lack zest. A few bites, I didst take, then, with a sigh, didst push them aside."

"Twas early morn, when first I didst enter this establishment, and lo, 'twas empty, save for a scattering of regulars. Low key, indeed, the atmosphere didst seem. Aye, I couldst envision, how, after a night of revelry, one might seek refuge here, within these walls, open, as they are, throughout the night."

"Verily, I say unto thee, good sir, that, save for such nocturnal adventures, I wouldst not make it a point to visit Ritters, for, alas! They do accept naught but cash, and that, a pitfall, methinks, forsooth."

"Sunset Grille? Nah, not my cup of tea. Sure, it's got a swell atmosphere and the service is top-notch, but the grub's just alright. Had a salt-cured Canadian bacon that'll make your taste buds quiver, and the eggs benedict's ain't half bad either. But let's be real, there's better places to chow down in this town."

"Tortillas, handmade in front of you. Corn, delicious. Sweet pork, too sweet. Shredded beef, okay. Rice and pinto beans, best part. If I had to choose, this place over Chipotle. But without a gun to my head, forgettable."

"Methinks I do adore Thai victuals,
Their flavors doth delight mine taste,
But lo, the cost doth trouble me,
For portion's worth, the price doth chase.

I prayed the cook to make it not too hot,
He heeded not my words, alas,
No seasonings did he add thereto,
My meal, a blandness did pass through.

Mayhap I shall return anon,
But on my coin, I shall not spend,
For there are better deals to be had,
In this fair town, where I do dwell."

"Aye, fair traveler, let it be known,
That in this place, my hunger was shown
A chicken sandwich, not too bad, indeed,
And fried pickles, that my taste did heed.
The batter, just right, the warmth, divine,
I'd return, just for that tasty vine.
The price, fair, for an airport meal,
And free wi-fi, to make my heart reveal.
Charlotte Airport, not so bad,
This eatery, worth a visit, I am glad."

"Fare fit for a king, yet served in disarray,
With clamor and din that doth assault mine ears,
No place to rest mine eyes, for tables lay unclean,
And half the cost of PF Chang's, but dearth of cheer."
"In-n-Out. Been there, done that. Used to love 'em back in Cali, but now? Meh. It's just a fast food burger. Decent, sure, but not worth the hype."

"Arrived with a hangover for my 11 PM reservation. Mistake. Cramped seating, but kitchen view made up for it. Good food, but pricey. Make reservations early. Someone offered me $500 for mine the night before. Popular spot."

"This hotel's got a great breakfast spread, made to order just how you like it. Eggs, French toast, pancakes, whatever you want. And they give you a ticket to take down to the dining room, so you can pick your poison. Plus, they got all sorts of cereals, oatmeal, bread, muffins, fruit, juice, milk, and coffee. Can't go wrong there. Location's top-notch too, right across from the mall and some restaurants, easy on and off the interstate. Room's big, like a little studio, with a full fridge, stove, microwave, and it's clean as a whistle. But, couple things that ain't so hot. First, the room feels stuffy when you walk in, like someone's been cooking up a storm. Kick up the AC, but then it's too cold. Can't seem to find that sweet spot. Second, pillows are flat, like sleeping on a pancake. Two pillows don't help much neither. Third, stairs are steep, no elevator in sight. If you got trouble with stairs or got a lot of bags, might wanna ask for a first-floor room. All in all, it's a good joint to crash for a night, not too pricey, not too fancy, just right."

"This joint claimed to be the biggest restaurant in Arizona. Didn't look like much from the outside or the dining area, but my buddy was working his last shift as a server, so I figured I'd give it a shot. Not a big fan of steakhouses, but the atmosphere was sorta cool - like something outta the '70s. Dark inside, retro vibe, like a Arizona mobster might be chowin' down on a steak next to you. Heard there was a lot of history in the building, so I respected the decor. 

Ordered a killer shrimp salad, topped with the biggest, juiciest shrimp I'd seen in a while. Crunchy as hell, too. My roommate got a sirloin, but had to send it back twice to get it cooked right. Our waiter said that wasn't the first time that night, either. But the bread basket was top-notch - light, buttery, and with a nice rosemary kick. 

Best part of the night? Checkin' in on Foursquare and score a beer for half a cent at the bar. Our waiter hooked us up at the table, but damn, never seen a deal that sweet on Foursquare before."

"Liked: Reasonably priced grub at Mandalay Bay. Less than 10 min wait for our group of 10. Available seats post Rock and Roll 1/2 marathon. Burgers were solid, but after 13 miles, anything would've hit the spot. \n\nDidn't like: Sweet potato fries were MIA. Service was slow despite not being busy. Orders were botched. Onions were included when they shouldn't have been. Salad arrived late. Some dishes were served 5-8 min before the rest. Just an OK experience."

"A taro milk tea with almonds didst I order, and 'twas quite good, I must confess. But lo, the popcorn chicken didst not resemble the usual fare I hadst expected. Verily, I received a plethora of breaded morsels instead."

"Methinks 'twas my first time at Smash Em Up Burger,
And thus, the staff didst greet me with cheer.
Their words of warning, re the wait, didst ring true,
And so, I waited patiently, as one doth do.

A classic smash 1/3 pounder, mine order didst make,
Yet, alack! 'Twas not quite cooked, as I didst partake.
No query, re my preference, didst they ask,
For ten dollars, methought it a curious task.

Hot and tasty, the victuals didst prove to be,
But, alas! In appearance, not quite the spree.
For lesser coin, to Culvers, I wouldst go,
Their fare, more pleasing, doth my senses show.

Minimalist, the decor, doth seem,
Corporate, it doth feel, in sooth, a dream.
My friend, who suggested this place, didst say,
"Do they grill their burgers?" And thus, we didst play.
Eighty-twenty ground beef, their secret, doth reveal,
A bit surprising, and the grease, didst conceal.

I shall return, but, alack! 'Tis true,
Such places, numerous, doth my mind renew.
This one, not in my top five, doth rank,
For burgers, better, elsewhere, doth bank."
"Chicken good. Service bad. Cashiers snooty. Drive-thru messy. Girl gross."

Sunday afternoon, football and grub on the mind. Got a seat at the bar, quick and painless. Portions, big. Classics and specials, interesting. Food, just okay. Did the job, but not worth coming for. Service, terrible. Our server, Randi, nice but confused. Bill issues, long wait. Manager, MIA. Finally comped, thanks to gambling. Good for sports, bad for food.

"Methinks some sorts of pizza do possess a flavor most divine,
Yet none doth reach the heights of true gastronomic splendor.
This place, in days of yore, didst shine with cleanliness bright,
But now, alas! 'Tis clear that management hath changed,
And service doth decline, with speed most swift and dire.
Yet still, I find the cinnamon rolls to be most sweet,
And so, I return, to sate my craving, time and again."

"'Tis a tiny, cramped space, full of folk,
Serving dishes cheap, yet mediocre, at best.
A place of little note, save for the throngs
That gather there, their pennies to expend.

But, alas! The praise it doth receive,
Doth far exceed its worth, in my opinion.
For though the fare be fair, 'tis naught but grease,
And the atmosphere, most uninviting.

So, if thou seekest sustenance of quality,
Best look elsewhere, lest thou be sorely vexed.
For this place, though full of life and bustle,
Doth fall short of true culinary delight."

"Summer nights got you down? Head to a Hounds game. Cheap prices, good people, and a chill vibe. Lacrosse may not be the most exciting sport to watch, but the Hounds play hard. Bring a friend, grab a drink, and enjoy the summer evening. Props to the Hounds for using Memorial Stadium too. Keeping the old girl alive and kicking."
"Jaleo, 3.5 stars. Good grub, good service. Tapas? Ridiculous. Cheese tapas? Robbery. Paellas? Top-notch."

"This joint's not half bad. Name's a bit corny, but the grub's decent. Bar's nothing special, menu's meh. \n\nIt's a local spot, always some familiar faces around. Some of 'em can get pretty sloppy, but they're not too bad."
"Pizza prices too steep. Twenty-six bucks for a large? Ridiculous. Athens pizza, down the road, better and cheaper. Tastes better too."

"Methinks 'tis wise to partake of Chinese fare,
After a few buffets, doth my belly declare.
Came I here for luncheon, with naught but coin,
Food, though pricey, didst my senses entwine.
But fear not, fair reader, for I didst dine
Upon comp, and thus, my purse didst not decline.

The salmon cold noodle, a dish most divine,
Didst stand out amongst all else, methinks 'twas fine.
Apart from this, all else didst seem but average,
Yet still, my hunger didst it doth assuage."
"A solid British pub's what we all need. Barkeeps are straight shooters, no fuss, just pourin' drinks and servin' up decent grub. Ideal spot for catchin' a game or grabbin' a pint after work."

"Methinks the raves for this eatery did pour forth like a river in springtime. Service, it did excel, and with our meal, a medley of veggies didst accompany. Fried dumplings, we didst begin with, and though delectable, the filling, I didst wish for more. Bibimbap, a sizzling stone pot didst bring, with beef, alas, in scant supply. Rice, the dish didst mostly compose, leaving the beef and veggies in scarcity. A change, I do suggest, to augment the beef and veggies, and reduce the rice, that all may partake in a feast most bounteous."
"Beans and cheese, decent. Cheese, cold and unmelted. Oil instead of lard, a plus. Green salsa, good. Chips, a small side, would be nice. Hard tacos, good. Lettuce, too much, filled half the shell."

"3 Stars. Big joint, nice decor. Cold outside, but upstairs balcony looked sweet. Two rooms, two DJs - one hip hop, one top 40. Main room DJ, terrible. Beat matching? Forget it. New Year's Day in Vegas, expected better. Staff, nice though. Cover charge, steep - $40 weekends, $20 ladies. Bouncer, cool. Let girl in free, I paid $40. Normal Vegas club pricing, I guess. Wouldn't go back, too many other clubs to try."

"Ate at this joint, took out. Had the pad tai and pho. Place was bright, new, and cute. Service was friendly and prompt. Pad tai was great, everything I expected. Tried my friend's beef, also good. Went there for the pho, since we don't got none on the NW side and I was feeling sick. Needed that pho, you know? But man, was I let down! Read all them reviews, got excited. Opened up the container, didn't smell right. Tasted sweet and thick, not good. Dark brown too, even though I asked for chicken pho. Gave it another shot, added noodles and spices and chicken how I like. Couldn't take the smell and taste, though. Drained the juice and just ate the noodles. Woulda given 'em five stars if it weren't for that bad pho. Maybe it was a bad day, who knows?"

"Happy hour drinks, cheap and strong. Tiny bar, real characters. Smoky, loud, locals' hangout. Entertainment hit or miss, but the crowd's always worth it. Had some good grub too. Free popcorn inside. Dartboard's crap, bring your own darts. Friendly staff, no problems."

"Hark! What eatery doth reign supreme?
In this fair land of T-Bird and 59th Ave,
A question doth arise, and thus it seems,
Why doth Del-Taco trouble itself to be?

Chipotle, a name of quality and renown,
Doth serve the masses with its tasty fare,
Bean or veggie burritos, a choice most sound,
Yet, alas! They doth upcharge with such glee,
For chips and salsa, a price most steep,
Eight dollars, a sum most dear, doth be,
For a meal most simple, coke, chips, and salsa,
A cost most high, a price most rude, doth be.

This place, a tidy keep, a duty doth impose,
To keep the dining space, in order, doth dispose."

"Went to Daisho sushi twice. First time it opened, second time tonight. Nigiri was fresh, green tea ice cream was good. Service was alright. Rolls lacked flavor. Maybe we ordered wrong. Live across the street, thought I'd give it a shot. Still prefer my regular sushi spot for the same price."

"Fam and I love this joint. Drive-thru's our jam. Food's always fresh, hot, and delish. But lately, this older broad with the thick eyebrows at the window's been actin' sour. Like, anything we say or order's a huge pain in the ass. Condescending, too. Like she hates her gig. Good thing there's a new Mexican spot down Greenway. Better service, same great grub. Three stars, Rivas! Attitude adjustment, por favor!"
"Good spot by the pool. Grub was decent. Pricey, sure, but not outrageous for M.Bay."

"Vegas, no fancy meals here. Quick service, hunger satisfaction, that's it. Prosciutto sandwich, crusty baguette, prosciutto di parma, mozzarella, arugula, balsamic. Simple, fast, on the go. Cheese pizza, soggy under crust, needed more oven time."

"Went in with a mate earlier this month. Tuesday night, place was dead. That was alright, we could chat without shoutin'. Heidi, great gal, friendly service. Had the Oggie, mushy peas, chips. Food was alright, not amazin'. Pasty was a bit dry, wine gravy took gettin' used to. Beef was lean, but not the tenderness I've had. Can't say I'd recommend it for the grub, but the Strongbow and Hoegaarden were decent. Stuck around to play some cricket on the dartboard, which wouldn't usually be avail. Good spot for drinks with mates, and a livelier crowd on a busier night."

"Vegas, baby. Friend and I, we heard good things, so we checked it out. Cheesy, yeah. Guys, some couldn't dance worth a damn. Ahead or behind, didn't matter. Looked like they threw the routines together. For what it was, it was alright. Some of 'em were cute, others, not so much. Long-haired dude, he got a little too into it. Host, he was funny as hell. Made the show better. Ladies, bachelorette party, this'll do the trick. Trust me."

"Marry, good sir, thou dost speak the truth. Forsooth, this sandwich, though fair in form and flavor, doth lack the proper bread, a flaw most grievous, indeed. Methinks, were it not for this defect, 'twould be a feast fit for the gods. Pray, good sir, rectify this error, that we may partake of a truly wondrous sandwich."
"Needed grub before MJ show. Bar seemed quicker. Bartender took her time, but service was good once she showed. Had kobe beef fries with chili and cheese. Satisfying. Decent spot for sports too."

"Hark! What store is this? A veritable treasure trove of beauty supplies, it doth seem. Twice the size of others, with products galore, it doth astound. 

Upon my recent visit, after work, three employees didst attend to customers' needs. One didst greet me, though her mien didst not bespeak great enthusiasm, she didst show courtesy. 

My purpose, swift and simple, to procure nail polish, using the $5 coupon gained from joining their club, didst not require aid. The cashier, kind and cheerful, didst tally my purchase, and I shall return anon."

"Gilley's. Cheap Jameson, decent grub, fun patio. Been there a few times now. First with Dana S - you know, Some Hot Bitch. We laughed at karaoke, drank cheap whiskey. Went back for more drinks and food recently. Nachos were alright, like Taco John's. Chicken strips were frozen and fried, but the vinegary sauce was good. Had some jalapeno grits too, they were the best part. Not a bad spot, but not the best either. The Strip has better options, but in a pinch, Gilley's isn't terrible."

"This joint wasn't half bad, but for the famous folks that stopped by. Not much of a dance floor, but the tunes were alright. More of a chill spot. Ladies got in free and champagne flowed like water on Valentine's weekend. We were fixin' to bounce at midnight, but then LMFAO showed up and we stuck around 'til the bitter end. Damn good time. My buddies went last year and said they spotted Far East Movement. So, choose your nights wisely."

"A fair and pleasant place, where one may find solace in a steaming bowl of corn chowder, 'tis true, the service doth lag, yet the fare doth make amends. A varied menu, with choices most fair, and staff, who doth strive to please. Their breads and muffins, too, are worth the try. For breakfas', lunch, or e'en dinner, 'tis a goodly spot, I do declare."

"Went to Enso for lunch with a buddy. Ginger salad, standard fare. Sushi, pretty but unremarkable. Spider roll, damn good. Atmosphere, too dark, trying too hard to be upscale. Run by Yanks, zero authenticity. Spent a hundred bucks, no booze. Good, but not worth it. Hit up New Zealand Cafe for better sushi at half the price."

"I dig their sandwiches, man. Turkey, ranch, and bacon - that's my jam. But, you know what sucks? Those new Coke machines they got. Every time, it's like lime juice in my drink. No bueno. Can't even let it run for a bit, still tastes nasty. That's a bummer, 'cause the sandwiches and staff are top-notch. Guess I'll have to stick to takeout."

"We hit up this joint hoping to score some prime rooftop real estate, but they told us we could only order takeout and sit up there if we cleaned up after ourselves. What a bummer. The service was alright, our waitress was nice but a bit scatterbrained. She brought us two beers when we only ordered one. The grub was meh, not terrible but nothing special. Had the pork queso dip, which was solid, but not as spicy as I like. I'd order it again, though. I went for the Cuban, but the lettuce and tomato killed the flavor of the BBQ. Once I ditched the veggies, the BBQ was decent. Hubby got the straight BBQ sandwich and liked the meat, but it wasn't anything to rave about. This place isn't worth regular visits, but I won't complain if someone else suggests it."

"My crew and I hit up this WH spot after a night of ragin'. It's not much to write home about, just your typical greasy spoon fare. But the service is top-notch and it's got this vibe that makes my hangover feel a little better."

"Methinks, fair traveler, thou hast chanced upon a place most wondrous and unique. Forsooth, the rocks that rise from the earth do resemble those of the red planet, Mars itself. But alas, good sir, 'tis a pity that this place doth lie within the borders of Arizona. Fie upon it, say I!"

"Methinks 'tis hard to render judgment on this place,
For though our server was most excellent and bright,
And we didst enjoy the victuals and drink, alack,
Two of our number didst fall ill, in truth quite wight.

A plague upon the mussels, say I, forsooth,
That dish didst bring us naught but woe and blight.
We hadst crab cakes, short ribs, arancinis too,
Gnocchi with lobster, and potato, all in view.

In sooth, I didst enjoy each dish, save the arancinis,
Which didst taste of port wine, a bit too keen.
The drinks we hadst, from Braddock's smash to moscow mule,
Were pleasant, and the manhattan, make thine own, a rule.

This hotel restaurant, within The Renaissance,
Didst boast an eclectic, upscale ambiance, in sooth.
But, alas, the food poisoning doth mar the score,
And thus, this review doth merit but three stars, no more."

"Tucked away on Howe Street, a humble abode,
The Standard bar, a gem, yet unassuming,
Popular with locals, both New Town and Stockbridge,
Surprisingly spacious, once inside, it's sumptuous.

The interior, smart and plush, a comfortable den,
Sip on a beer, or Sauvignon, and let the hours glide,
The atmosphere, jovial, inviting, and free,
A place to linger, and indulge, wild and carefree.

The menu, decent, and inexpensive, a treat,
For hearty pub grub, a burger, chips, and a seat,
Or a full breakfast, to cure the morning after,
The Standard, a haven, for all, a true laughter.

Though I must confess, my bias, sports do bore,
But for those who revel, in matches, and roar,
The Standard, a haven, with screens, a delight,
Busy, especially, during rugby's might."

"Chili's, a place I visit with family and friends, about twice a month. Bell and 7th St., or 27th Ave and 101, are the spots we hit up. Food's decent, chips and salsa, a good deal. Green chile and enchilada soups, top-notch. But, service at North Valley Parkway, a kink. Orders messed up, waitresses friendly, but clueless about the menu. Food takes forever, no apologies. Try again, a few months later, same issues. Wait time for food, ridiculous. Drink refills, a pipe dream. Last Saturday, nice waitress, friendly greeters, food as expected. 90 minutes for soup and salad, water to drink. Four times, same problem, not a coincidence. Chili's on 7th St., great service, normal wait time. Hope it changes, a decent spot."

"Pied Au Corchon booked solid? Try this joint instead. Fresh grub, manageable servings, and a swanky rustic vibe make it a sweet spot for visitors or small gatherings. Service can drag, and it gets loud, but the food's worth it. Had the veal tartare - fresh and flavorful, but missing a je ne sais quoi. Came with killer fries and a decent salad. Split the apple tarte for dessert - nice presentation, vinegary apples, and a tiny scoop of sorbet. Not mind-blowing, but a solid choice. Worth the cost, and a good alternative to the fancier spots in Le Plateau."

"Coffee at Morning Squeeze was piss poor. Tasted like dishwater. Couldn't even tell if it was freshly brewed. Disappointing, especially for a joint that calls itself a breakfast spot. Should be serving up top-notch joe, not swill. Maybe they'll step up their game, but until then, stick to the basics. Atmosphere's decent, though."

This joint's got real potential. TVs are set up nice, even in the can. I'd give it five stars easy if they stepped up the grub and had a better selection of brews and hard stuff. I've asked for Crown Royal Cask 16, Jack Daniel's Honey, Kraken, Captain Morgan Private Stock, Jack Daniel's Single Barrel, but they don't have any of 'em. Half Moon, hello! Not everyone's looking for bottom-shelf swill. Fix these two problems, and I'll give it another look. Five stars, easy.
"Settled in, ordered a Caesar. Snack between meals, nice dressing but a bit too much seasoning. Casual spot."

"Korean food in Champaign? Not bad. Went for a quick lunch, ended up at the first place that opened at 11 AM. Easy to order, they got a nice laminated menu. Would be better with pictures though. I got the combo platter, bulgogi for 9.99. Waited about 25 minutes, not bad. Got a lot of rice, two ban chae, and a bean soup. Could've gotten the beef bulgogi for less, but less variety. Meat was cut small, but flavorful. Prices gone up since my wife was in college. Above average, but need to try others."

"Grub's a crapshoot. Afternoons, it's a miss - salty fries, flavorless meat. But nighttime, it's a hit - sandwiches are solid. Ribs, when they got 'em, are a joke. Don't drink, so can't speak to the bar. Just the grill."

"I was on a solo trip to Arizona. I wanted to taste the local flavors, specifically Native American cuisine. The Fry Bread House was my first stop. Their fry bread is made to order and has a nice kick to it. It's definitely worth trying."

"This Bruegger's joint, it's top-notch. Better than the one down the street, that's for sure. Friendly staff, quick service, and a damn fine cup of coffee. They got all the usual suspects on the menu - bagels, sandwiches, soup, you name it. And some nice booths by the window, perfect for watching the world go by."

"Methinks the air is full of cheer,
And prices, fair and not too dear.
Wine-a-ritas, diverse and tasty,
Yet, alack, not quite up to par.
Local vintages, light and crisp,
But, prithee, not my cup of tea.
I do confess, I hold CA wines
In higher esteem, and thus,
Their price doth seem a mite steep.
Aye, the pinot grigio, a gem,
Yet, at $25, a trifle dear.
I shall return, and next time,
The flight, for $6, I shall espie."
"Wings great. Sadly, closed. Slow service killed 'em."
"A fair pizza, with wings that didst lack moisture, alas, yet shall I not be deterred in my quest for a New York-style slice within this fair city."
"Food, great as always. New digs, nice. Chairs, uncomfortable as hell. Music, too damn loud. Can't hear a thing. Get some decent seats and turn down the noise, or I'm taking my grub to go."

"Tis a pleasure to find a luncheon spot that doth prioritize health,
Without relying on outdated menus or unhealthy wealth.
This place doth impress, with its dedication to wholesome fare,
And the variety of options doth make it a worthy lair.

But alas, there be a catch, a flaw in the plan,
The price of breakfast doth seem quite out of hand.
A sandwich, with egg and wrap, doth cost a pretty penny,
And the quality doth not match the sum paid, methinks, 'tis a pity.

Yet fear not, fair reader, for the noonday meal doth make amends,
With a satisfying bang for thy hard-earned pence, it doth transcend.
Fresh, healthy, and delicious, the flavors doth abound,
And thy hunger doth depart, with a full belly all around.

So for breakfast, two stars doth this place receive,
But for lunch, four stars doth it most certainly deserve.
Thus, an overall rating of three doth it earn,
A commendable score, without a single qualm or concern."

In fair Sally's, where night owls do convene,
Late eats are served, when others do close at e'en.
Their decor doth please, with motors, knick-knacks,
And guitars of old, a rockabilly attack.

A gathering spot, it is, where friends do meet,
To fortify themselves, with bites most sweet.
The servers, friendly, booths, big and soft,
Ice, oh ice, so fine, like snow cones aloft.

All in all, Sally's, a place of merriment,
Though naught to write home of, a decent haunt.
If smoking were allowed, five stars would be mine,
But 'tis not for them to decide, so I do design.

"Hark! This place doth please me well, my friends,
A medley of tunes they do play,
From oldies to hip hop, rap and rock,
A varied mix, indeed, doth make my day.

Upon a Friday eve, we didst venture forth,
And found the crowd, in sooth, a bit uncouth,
Yet still, the dance floor, small though it be,
Didst bring us joy, in spite of all we see.

Forsooth, they didst give away gifts, my friends,
To those who waited patiently in line,
Clothes, they gave, but, alas, in limited supply,
Fifteen, in total, didst they distribute, by and by.

One garment per person, they didst bestow,
A token of their love, for local ladies, know,
This place, a haven, for those who seek delight,
In music, dance and mirth, through the long, cold night."

"I ain't some young buck who hangs out in Old Town. Been livin' in Phx for over 30 years, seen most fancy restaurants 'round town. Went with pals for Restaurant Week. Won't be goin' back too soon. Service was good, attentive. Ambiance's been hyped up, tables packed tight, noise level's high. Not exactly romantic. Food was decent, but no homerun. Venison I had was raw inside, not even medium rare. Sent it back, cooked it wrong. Dessert, foie gras and donuts, was strange. None of us liked it. Cocktails looked nice, but we ain't big drinkers. Regular menu's pricey for small servings, but worth tryin' once."

"Methinks we dined at Vogue but late, my dear,
And found the victuals to be of great cheer.
I had the meatloaf, juicy and sweet,
My spouse, the lasagna, rich and neat.
We shared the calamari, alas, a woeful sight,
Fried tempura, drowned in grease, a sorry plight.
The ginger'mongst the carrots, a delight,
But little calamari, a sorrow to behold,
Our waiter, courteous, yet his manner cold.
We felt unwelcome, as if to say,
'Depart, good sirs, and tarry not, I pray.'
But nay, the entrees, worth each penny,
A verity, a truth, a certainty."

"After one visit, I must confess,  
The ambiance was quite pleasant, I must profess.  
The decor was lovely, but the lighting, alas,  
Was dark, and made it hard to see, I do surmise.  

The service, oh how it did excel,  
With Pin Kaow, I must give them a bell.  
Their table touches, though, did border on the extreme,  
Five people checked on us within five minutes, it did seem.  

The food, it was a mixed bag, I do declare,  
The chicken satay, grilled perfectly, beyond compare.  
The peanut sauce, authentic, yet lacked a certain flair,  
A flat taste, that left me not entirely aware.  

Tom Ka Koong, a rich and sour broth,  
With coconut milk, lemongrass, mushrooms, and shrimp, in truth.  
A delicate balance, that not all may enjoy,  
For some, it may be too sour, and thus destroy.  

Roasted rice beef, a new concept, indeed,  
With cabbage, Thai basil, and spices, it did proceed.  
Crushed rice, roasted, and scattered on the beef,  
An interesting texture, a unique experience, in belief.  

Chicken yellow curry, delicious, I must say,  
A dish that pleased my palate, in a major way.  

Overall, a B+, I must aver,  
Hoping to return, and try more dishes, I do endeavor."

"O, how vexing it is when a local place doth fall short! Monroe Hardware, though decent, doth not compare to yonder general store of old, like Mast Drug or Renfrow in fair Matthews. Nor doth it rival the grand chains, Home Depot or Lowe's, in scale or scope. 'Tis a curious thing, indeed, for in betwixt these two extremes doth Monroe Hardware lie, like a ship lost at sea, betwixt and between.

In Mint Hill, there doth stand a location, once a Winn Dixie, now a spacious abode for hardware and wares. Alas, the vastness of the space doth make it hard to fill, leaving staff to roam and customers to their own devices. Alack, the convenience of its proximity to mine own domicile doth make it tempting still, yet for projects grand, Home Depot or Lowe's shall be my will. Forsooth, their stores, like castles strong, doth hold the keys to all my hardware needs, and thus, my heart doth sing."

"Hark! This Dillard's doth now serve but one purpose,
A place where last season's finery doth find its haven.
The lower floor, once bustling with life and cheer,
Now lies dormant, empty, and devoid of light.

Upstairs, the racks doth brim with garb of renown,
Designers' names doth grace each hanger and gown.
Fourty percent, the least of discounts doth show,
Fifty and seventy-five, the larger sums doth flow.

By size, the clothes doth hang, a sight to see,
In Michael Kors, a top of quality doth be.
Eighteen, the price doth drop, from fifty's height,
A steal, indeed, a bargain of great might.

Bedding, accessories, and shoes doth fill the space,
But alas, the footwear doth leave much to trace.
For those with small or large feet, choices doth lack,
Or gaudy styles, which doth not appeal to all, alack."

"Alack, I soon didst prove myself no Vegas lass,
With heels, I didst not grace the dance floor's grass.
A pinched nerve in my back, a bouncer quite strict,
Didst almost bar my entry, save for my wit.

The view, a disappointment, a mere glimpse,
Of bright lights, a crowded floor, a pricey sip.
To avoid the throng, a table, one must pay,
Or suffer strangers' touch, nightlong, each day.

So, ere thou goest, a word of advice,
Buy liquor at the CVS, a wise pretense.
And thus, with a good buzz, thy wallet spare,
Shalt thou enjoy thyself, without a single care."

"Bravo's got reliable chains. Decent salads, no fuss. Reservations help skip the line, 45 minutes ain't worth it. Their Romano crusted chicken, balsamic chicken salads hit the spot. Parmesan dressing, damn good. Entrées? Too much salt for me, but hey, grabbing a salad while shopping or catching a flick works. Plenty of parking, that's key."

"Taco of black beans, priced at two dollars,
Better than burritos in Manhattan, I do avow,
But not as delectable as some hotspots in this town,
Where the patio's charm is amplified by night's gown.

Before First Fridays, we did dine upon this fare,
And our server, in converse, did share her cheer,
Speaking of Shark Week, a most wondrous sight,
Goodness, what a pleasant evening, full of delight!"

"Jamie C. and I agree. Gotta come back for my final decision. Server was top-notch, wish I'd gotten his name. Sangria was good, two glasses worth. Michael wasn't sold on his mojito, switched to Stella. Shared calamari and blue corn chicken enchilada, both tasty. Sauces were great, ate it all. Enchiladas were good too. Want to try more shared plates, will be back."

"Bouchon, we'd heard. Elegant dining hall, proper. Brunch, good but not mind-blowing. Salmon Baguette, a bagel with salmon and cream cheese, pricey at $15. French Toast, not really. More like bread pudding. Too sweet for brunch."
"Cute gift shop. Quirky ideas. Pricey, though. Still, good spot for unique presents. Staff's friendly. Found a great card for my friend's grad."

"Verily, my friend and I didst partake of sustenance at a place called Buldogis. Our meals, the Gold Standard and the Longhorn, didst come with scant toppings, yet their cost didst rival that of a fine steed. Fear not, good sir, for these dogs didst satiate our hunger and were quite tasty, though I wouldst not venture to say they were the finest in all the land. The staff didst treat us with kindness and respect, and though the prices didst seem steep, 'twas naught but a trifle compared to the riches of the realm. In conclusion, if thou art a devotee of hot dogs, then by all means, give Buldogis a try. But if thou art not, then mayhap look elsewhere for thy culinary delights."

"Parent co. Frias fixed my problem. Researched, found cab and driver using credit card info. Did full investigation. Don't know if driver got reprimanded, but they were diligent in follow-up. Might take Ace Cab again, but double-check next time. 

Initial post below. Parent co. contacted me next day and looked into it. Appreciate their effort. Will update if anything happens.

Original post: Driver was rude and a thief! Left iPad in car. Called lost and found, no response. Guy who bought iPad from driver called us. Sounds like a scam, but driver didn't turn it in. Company never got back to me. Ace is one of many cab cos. run by parent co. Avoid them all if this is how they do business. At least follow up. Hard to monitor all drivers, but pretend to care."

"Hark! Traveler, take heed of this advice,
For thou dost seek to navigate the skies,
At McCarran Airport, beware the woe,
Of Wi-Fi, free yet unreliable, doth flow.

Fly Southwest, my friend, 'tis best,
Their gates, two areas, dost possess,
But alas, the layout, doth cause distress,
A long journey, to reach the other side, doth press.

Rental cars, a shuttle, doth require,
A waste of time, thy patience doth conspire,
And Fox, a company, doth stand apart,
Avoid them, lest thou lose thy heart.

In Las Vegas, rentals, cheap doth lie,
So choose wisely, lest thou suffer loss,
And thus, my friend, thy journey doth make,
With caution, wisdom, and a careful take."

"Hark! A fortnight past, we dined within these walls,
Upon the rave of reviews that did enthrall.
Our feast didst consist of duck, steak, and salmon,
The first, a tender morsel, most divine.
The second, fair at best, yet lacking zest,
And third, a fish most wondrous, fresh and blessed.
A cheese plate, too, did grace our table's side,
With flavors rich and varied, a delight.
The service, prompt and courteous, did abide.
We shall return, ere judging this place finally,
To savor more of its culinary artistry."

"Food's alright, but pricey. Duck appetizer? Disappointing. Dry meat, no crisp to the skin. Sweet and sour pork, good. Coconut rice, great. Worth $30? Nah. Will be back for coconut rice and satay. Update later."

"Hark! A tale of woe and disarray,
At a restaurant, where I did dine,
I ordered brisket, with fries of nacho,
And an outlaw burger, a feast most fine.

My cousin, he ordered ere I did,
Yet his meal came forth, ere mine did.
A stranger, too, didst receive his fare,
Before mine own, oh how unfair!

I asked the waiter, why the delay?
He said, "Fear not, 'tis coming straightway."
But ten minutes passed, and naught arrived,
My hunger grew, my patience died.

At last, my fries didst appear,
But where, oh where, was my burger dear?
The waiter said, "It comes anon,"
But ten more minutes passed, and still no sign.

At length, my meal didst arrive,
But oh, the frustration didst thrive.
The fries were crispy, the burger juicy,
But the service, alas, was quite unglue-y.

I would return, despite the woe,
For the food, it was quite good, you know.
But four stars, I cannot give,
For the mess, and the waiter's shift.

So, let this be a lesson,
To all who serve, or wish to impress,
Take heed of orders, and deliver swift,
Lest your customers do suffer and rift."

"Davio's dinner didst leave me unimpressed,
Service, a vital part of any feast,
Didst falter, like a play with too much repetition,
Leaving me to feel as though at Eat 'N Park I didst dine.
Fare, just passable, yet not of high quality,
Akin to others of its ilk, in taste and presentation lacking.
Server, unskilled and ignorant of menu's contents,
A poor substitute for one who knows his duties and can present.
Time, a precious commodity, best spent elsewhere,
At Arlecchino or Alla Familia, a better choice, I do declare."

"Upon my travels, I chanced upon this place,
In search of sustenance, a different taste.
'Tis new, I think, and located near a gas station,
At Southern and Higley's northeast corner, a convenient station.

I ordered Gyro and Fries, a simple feast,
And took it to go, at 12:15, a quiet guest.
The flavors were good, but not the best I've had,
And the portion, three meat slices, left me somewhat sad.

The menu held interest, with dishes unique,
Worth trying later, a culinary seek.
A decent option, not worth a long journey,
But if in the area, I'd return for a Gyro in a hurry.

I'll visit again, in a month or so,
To see if they're thriving, or if they shall go.
A difficult spot, with visibility low,
But perhaps their food will make their fame grow."

In fair Paris, I didst tarry three nights,
And asked for a chamber with kingly bed,
But they didst give me a room with twain queens instead,
Which brought me discomfort, and my rest didst mar.

The next day, they didst move me to a room with a king,
Whose bed was not so bad, and I didst find solace within.
The rooms were clean, and the bathrooms, too,
With showers closed, and a tub, wherein I couldst renew.

The TV hadst some good channels, and the sound was clear,
But alas, the elevators didst work with great speed,
My view was of the airport, not so grand, I fear,
But the location of the hotel was most excellent, indeed.

I didst use their spa services, and wrote a review apart,
And found the restaurants in Paris to be a work of art.
I recommend climbing the Eiffel Tower high,
For the view from the top is most wondrous to the eye.

The monorail metro is nearby, a convenience, indeed,
But my only sorrow was that they wouldst not let me use the spa on the day I didst depart, which didst cause me great need.
Yet, in conclusion, 'tis a good place to stay,
In the heart of Paris, where one can find delight in every way.

"Methinks I came to this place once more, a scant few days since my first visit. Alas, the fair visage of the establishment didst soon prove to be deceiving. The pours of ale and wine, though modern and pleasing to mine eyes, didst contain but a paltry amount of liquid. Verily, I didst feel mine host had played a cruel trick upon me.

"Forsooth, we ordered two dishes, the Louisiana Chicken pasta and the Bibimbap. The former, alack, didst taste wondrous indeed, but its richness didst border on the obscene. Aye, 'twas a vast bowl of heavy cream and melted cheese, with some pasta tossed in for good measure. Methoughts the waitress shouldst have donned a vest with flair pins and exclaimed, "Welcome to Applebees!" 'Twas not what I didst expect from a place such as Miga.

"The latter, alas, didst disappoint. Though it looked most comely, its flavor didst leave much to be desired. Missing, it didst, the essential component of that dish - the dolsot, or hot stone bowl. In sooth, 'twas naught but a cold salad, and no true Bibimbap at all.

"Mayhap I shall return anon, but I shall give the menu time to rectify its shortcomings ere I do."

"Fair fare, indeed! Yet, mark my words, good sir,
That payment by card doth not suffice,
Nor doth the coffee flow, without a fee,
And thus, I fear, this place I shall not see,
As oft as I wouldst, for these reasons, three."

"Aunt Chilada's, been there a few times. Arizona days, ya know? One time, me and a buddy, we decided to get all fancy, comb our hair with plastic forks. Hell, I don't know why, just seemed like a good idea at the time. Maybe we were trying to impress the ladies, or maybe we just wanted to look like a couple of damn fools. Either way, we ended up looking pretty ridiculous. But hey, that's not the point. The food, it's alright. Not great, not terrible. It's like, 'Eh, I won't complain if you let me sit on the patio and drink margaritas.' So, it's a'meh' experience, but not gross. And hey, if you're in the area, it's probably your best bet for Mexican food. So, I'm giving it an extra star for that."

Methinks we sampled many dishes upon the menu,
The pork sliders, verily, didst please my palate,
And lo, the mushroom burger, cooked to perfection,
Was devoured with gusto, and no hesitation.
The fries, they were quite good, with crunch so fine,
But alack, the mashed potatoes, they didst decline,
For they didst taste of naught but aged earth,
And left us feeling rather lackluster and of little worth.
But oh, the buttermilk fried chicken, how it didst fail,
For though it was crispy, and fried to perfection's bail,
It had no flavor, none at all, I do declare,
As if celebrity chef Aaron Sanchez didst forget the flair.
Perhaps the staff didst omit the salt, in their haste,
Or mayhap 'twas an oversight, of the worst taste.

"Methinks 'tis hard to render judgment on this place,
For oft I've come hither, and in days of yore,
'Twas grand, but latey, e'er since, methinks,
The quality doth suffer, and doth leave me sore.

All strive to play the host, in manner Italian,
Yet, alack, they be not from that land,
But rather, from the East, where tongues do stammer,
And thus, their speech doth grate upon mine ear.

I've tried most dishes, and found one to my liking,
The veal, ohso bucco, doth please mine taste,
But all the rest, methinks, doth pale in comparison,
To chain restaurants, which doth bring me shame.

Yet, if thou art fortunate, and dost secure
A table on the veranda, with view so fair,
Thou mayst forget the food, and revel in the atmosphere.

I still would recommend this place, with caveat,
That if thou hast good Italian food nearby,
Thou wilt not be impressed, nor think it a treat.

Not the best in Vegas, but worth a single visit,
To see if it doth suit thy taste, and whether
Thou wilt return, or choose to flee, in disgust."

"Bouchon for brunch, eh? Our friends had the itch, so we gave it a go. Sourdough waffles, fresh strawberries, vanilla bean butter - not bad, like a fried waffle. Vanilla bean yogurt, granola - rich, but the granola helped. Cobb salad? Meh. Limp lettuce, scarce chicken, small portion for $17. Good for carb-loading before hitting the clubs, though. Service was top-notch, water always full. Pricey for a mediocre meal at The Venetian. Grand Luxe next time, their menu's better. Not the place for health nuts - everything tasted rich and heavy."

"TGI Fridays I have visited twice, good sir. Firstly, I didst order their filled potato skin appetizer, a dish most grand. Alas, 'twas dry as dust, lacking sauce or any moisture, leaving much to be desired. 

The second time, I didst opt for their Caribbean chicken sandwich, with "Caribbean" sauce, no less. Fie upon it! 'Twas a vile concoction, tasting of Christmas and pumpkin pie. Cinnamon and cloves, I didst detect, on a chicken avocado sandwich, oh what a woeful sight! My husband and mother-in-law, they didst agree, 'twas not fit for consumption, I do declare. 

So, I didst send it back, and ordered the turkey burger instead. Not bad, it didst taste, but alas, I couldst not enjoy it, for everyone else had finished their repast, and I didst feel quite stressed, I do confess. 

But, the service, I must say, was most excellent. Friendly and professional, they didst attend to my needs, without hesitation or delay. And, they didst not charge me for the first dish, a kindness, indeed."

"A merry place, indeed, to dine with friends,
Bar-B-Barn, where ribs and fowl are served with ease.
If thou dost seek true Southern barbecue,
Best look elsewhere, for this place doth not pursue.

But should thou wish for tasty, cheap delight,
Come hither, friend, and take a seat tonight.
We came upon this spot, with hopes to view
The hockey game, yet found no telly in sight, alas!
Yet still, the cozy atmosphere did make
Our evening merry, despite the lack of sport.

The ribs, they were quite tender, and the sauce,
Sweet and sticky, left us all in a trance.
I had the small portion, with three ribs and fries,
And that sufficed to fill my hunger's cries.
So if thou art in search of cheerful fare,
And camaraderie, come to Bar-B-Barn, and share."

"Took the missus here for a tapas date before catching a late show at the Manor. Strong cocktails, good ginger cooler. Shared some small plates, spring rolls, taro puffs. Veggie options limited, but that's a blessing. Elegant atmosphere, romantic lighting, attentive staff. Held hands, played footsie, left satisfied. Prices steep, but worth it for the experience."
"Cool joint, good happy hour deals. Rooms are spacious and tidy. But they'll try to gouge you. And then they got the nerve to ask for a tip? What's their angle?"
"Server was polite, but not too attentive. Selection was limited and prices were steep. Might give it another shot."

"Methinks my wife and I didst hear much talk of Freddy's, and thus we didst decide to give it a go. Upon our arrival, the dining room didst bustle with activity, which didst add to mine own anticipation.

I didst order the number one, which didst consist of Freddy's original double burger, with cheese, of course. And when it didst arrive, I must confess, I was somewhat dismayed by the portion. Wherefore, the beef? Forsooth, the patties were of a size most similar to cold cuts, and the bun didst overshadow the burger, by far.

Despite this, Freddy's doth remain a good choice, and I wouldst return, anon, should I find myself in the vicinity. Howbeit, I wouldst not venture forth out of my way, forsooth, for the portion didst leave me somewhat disappointed."

"Noodles and dumplings, main menu. Prices, reasonable. Fast service. Packed house, lunch and dinner. Pork feet noodle soup, had it on a cold night. Hit the spot. Portion size, just right. Service, accommodating. Busy servers, still hustling. Good work."

"Methinks I am surprised that thine reviews of this place be so high. Forsooth, I do confess that I am particular when it comes to mirth and laughter, yet I found this establishment to be but mediocre. The seats, alack, be old-fashioned and uncomfortable, in the style of days of yore. The show, alas, be interactive, which brought forth both merriment and woe. (Verily, I knew not of such things as World of Warcraft, which the crowd did suggest with great fervor.)\n\nI must confess that I didst find myself bored more oft than not, for the skits didst drag on overlong. I fear that I shall not trouble thee with my presence again. Yet, I do acknowledge that thy venue be most welcoming to children, a trait that doth speak well of thee."
"Fare victuals, fair ambiance. A trifle dear, perchance, for midday repast, yet satisfactory. Servants, attentive and brisk. Shall revisit, anon!"

"Hopped in a hackney coach and made haste to Del Frisco's, whereupon arrival, found the establishment to possess a certain je ne sais quoi, a certain... how shall I say? A certain air of informality, akin to a humble tavern, rather than a refined Chicago steakhouse. Yet, the martini, well-mixed and generously poured, did please mine taste buds. 

Verily, I do confess, aesthetics play a significant role in mine culinary experiences. And thus, I must admit, the diminutive size of the salad fork didst strike a discordant note. Forsooth! A hearty, manly utensil doth complement a $50 steak, in mine humble opinion.

Moving onward, the crab appetizer, alas! Didst not quite meet mine expectations. A copious amount of Old Bay, coupled with a generous portion of crab, didst not quite tantalize mine taste buds. Nay, nay! Give me crab served upon a bed of golden straw, and I shall be content! Alas, this dish didst fall short of mine lofty standards.

The Wedge salad, dressed with blue cheese, a dish which, when prepared aright, doth delight, didst suffer from an excess of moisture, rendering the lettuce limp and the dressing somewhat bland.

But fear not, dear friends! For the steak, verily, didst shine resplendent! With mine miniature fork, I didst partake of a most tender, flavorful steak, accompanied by a trio of delectable sides - corn, spinach, and mashed potatoes. (Aye, I didst order three sides, forsooth!)

In conclusion, gentle readers, should thou find thyself in the vicinity of Del Frisco's, do give the steak a try. 'Tis worth the price of admission, I doth assure thee!"

"Walkin' the Strip, thinkin' which club to hit up. Bank rep outside Bellagio's handin' out "free" wristbands, so I gave it a shot. Turns out it ain't free, still gotta pay $20 (reduced price, I was told), but you get a free drink. Line wasn't too long, so I was in within five minutes. Used coat-check, but they charged $5 (better pay than losin' it). Went straight to the bar, presented my free-drink coupon, bartender told me my options, I picked one. It was an okay drink. Enjoyed it while watchin' the gogo dancers and other girls dancin' and partyin'. GoGo dancers were okay, beautiful, but they barely showed some good moves. Friendly, though, and people were gettin' pics with 'em. Girls in the club were beautiful. Didn't get a chance to dance, but enjoyed the music - mix dance music, speakers were just loud enough. Dance floor looked decent-sized. They got a VIP area for private parties, too. Might repeat."

"Alas, fair traveler, I have witnessed woe,
In terminals one and two, such misery doth flow.

The first, for domestic flights, doth boast
Of covered parking, a convenience, no doubt.
But alack, the coin-meter parking, gone, alas!
Yet, payment by card, a small reprieve, 'twill pass.

Cleanliness, a virtue, lacking, I do fear,
In terminal one, a tidy state, not always near.
The information desk, with friendly folk, doth abound,
And signs, clear as day, on LCD screens, are found.

Ah, but alas, fair reader, avoid, I pray,
Scheduling flights on Fridays, weekends, nay!
For crowds, aplenty, doth fill the space,
A chaotic scene, most vexing, in this place.

And thus, we come to terminal two,
For international flights, and those to Hawaii, anew.
Signs, easy to miss, a problem, I do declare,
A larger sign, a solution, they should prepare.

Parking, uncovered, rates the same, I find,
A pity, for travelers, with luggage, in mind.
Cleanliness, a word, not often heard,
In terminal two, a state, unpleasant, I have feared.

Four carousels, for luggage, a sight to see,
Easy to find, your belongings, a relief, for thee.
But watch, dear traveler, thy goods, with care,
For in this terminal, a sense of unease, doth linger there."

"A feast most genuine and fresh didst lie before mine eyes, yet more onions than my taste doth crave. Alas, no substitutions were allowed, and thus I made do with the dish as 'twas writ. Forsooth, I hold that when I spend mine own hard-earned coins, the meal should be as I desire. The chef, Romeo, doth believe his creations perfect, and any change would mar the flavor. Mayhap, but the menu didst not meet mine expectations, and thus I fear I shall not return for another repast. Save for the sweets, which didst delight mine taste buds. Verily, an wondrous array of confections."

"Alas, I had hoped to find delight in this spectacle,
But alas, it did not quite meet my expectations.
There were moments that did stir my soul,
But overall, it did not leave me in a state of elation.

The first part of the show, all I saw was Holly's back,
A sight that left me feeling somewhat lacking.
But fear not, dear friends, for her bosom did make an appearance,
A sight that brought a smile to my face, I must confess.

The green pole dancer, she was a wondrous sight,
Her movements fluid and graceful, a true delight.
And the chosen gentleman, oh so awkward and cute,
He brought a chuckle to my lips, I must admit.

But alas, the rest of the girls, their breasts were not so fake,
A surprise, indeed, for in my life, I've never seen such a sight.
So, my advice, dear friends, wait for discounted tickets,
For on the night of the show, or before, they may be found.

We watched it on Christmas weekend, and the row in front,
Was empty, a shame, for it was a sight to behold."

"Kung Fu Tea, a swell spot for boba in Vegas. But the tea, not so much. Three stars for the drinks, five for the tea quality, and five for the service. That's three and a half stars overall. 

Had the milk black and milk oolong. Seventy percent sugar, not sweet enough. Flavors got lost in the dilution. Stick with regular sugar, that's my advice. 

High-quality tea leaves, maybe too much for us. Oolong's woodsy, smoky, an acquired taste. Black tea's got bergamot oil, floral notes. I dug it, but my friend and boyfriend thought it was soapy. He took it back, they offered to make him something else. Class act, that's why I'll be back."

"Hark! A place most wondrous, where thou may find solace and cheer,
In the still of day, when energy doth wane and flag.
A haven of delight, with treats both sweet and savory,
To revive thy spirits, and banish all flagging.

Their banana Nutella, a dish most divine,
Doth strike the perfect balance, betwixt sweet and fine.
And should thou seek a drink, of fruit and worth,
Their smoothies, priced the same, shall quench thy thirst and earth.

So, gentle reader, heed my words of praise,
And seek out this haven,'midst the busy days.
For there, thy senses shall be regaled and cheered,
By the wondrous fare, that doth await thee, unfeared."

"Been hankerin' for a Mongolian stir fry in the QC for a spell. Got some fond memories of visitin' a similar joint when I was a youngin'. So, it wasn't no surprise that I was tickled pink when I heard 'bout Genghis Grill in Charlotte. 

Good stuff: 
You make yer own meal here, that's fer sure. Lotsa toppings to choose from - protein, starch, veggies, sauces, spices, and whatnot. Staff's instructions are spot on, helpin' ya navigate the bowl bar like a pro. Liked my bowl just fine, loaded up on dragon sauce, jalapeno, and red pepper. My mouth was on fire, boy! Prices ain't bad neither, $8.99 fer lunch and $9.99 fer dinner. Kids'll love this place. 

Meh: 
It's a chain, so it's got that cookie-cutter feel. Service was good, but I didn't wanna hang around longer than necessary. Protein quality was lackin', shrimp were tiny, and my steak had some gristle. 

Go back to Genghis Grill? You betcha. Healthy, quick, and affordable meal. That's A-okay in my book."

"Hark! To Phat Phranks we didst venture forth,
For Mexican victuals of the earth.
A 3.5 star establishment, by my reckoning,
With fare that didst leave me somewhat shaken.

The huevos rancheros, a dish most fair,
Didst come with sauce of red or green, I didst declare.
Green, with pork, didst I choose, in sooth,
But found the dish in grease to be o'er-suthed.

Beans, eggs, and fried chips, all didst swim
In a sea of grease, most unbecoming.
A traditional huevos rancheros, 'twas not,
But the fried potatoes, delicious, they were got.

Flautas, crispy and fresh, with guacamole so bright,
Didst please mine taste buds, with delight.
Good service, we didst receive, in truth,
But tap water, charged, a strange sight, in sooth.

A 3.5 star rating, I didst give,
For the greasy meal, and the water, I didst live.
A Vegas thing, perchance, but strange, indeed,
To pay for water, when all else doth succeed."

"Upon this fair course, we didst play,  
On twenty-sixth of November, in the year of five.  
The greens, they were slow, yet the views, they were fair,  
Some amazing, some not, but still a sight to see there.  
A good course for the ladies, with tees of four thousand,  
Four hundred, a number that doth make their game more gentle.  
A value of one hundred, a price most fair and true,  
Not quite as testing as Wildfire, but still, a challenge anew."
"No reservation? Tough luck getting served. Bar's packed, you gotta be quick to snag a seat. But hey, those Swedish meatballs? Top-notch."

"A humble tavern, fit for any purse,
With victuals savory, and a pleasant course.
Chang's fiery fowl, a dish divine,
Yet, broth of sour and hot, a touch too fine.
Dim lights within, a fitting scene,
To feast and revel in this culinary dream.
Kind servers, swift in their employ,
And drinks galore, to make merry and enjoy.
PF Chang's, a place to visit, now and then,
For a meal most satisfying, and a night with friends."

I stepped into the joint, a plain place with a too-familiar feel. Ordered a drip coffee, tuna sandwich. Both good, but the sandwich's price tag made me wince. Eight bucks? Damn steep for a slice of fish on bread. Service was snappy, no complaints there. But that ambiance? Underwhelming. Like a Starbucks knockoff. Not terrible, not great. That's how I'd sum it up.

"Hark, good sir! Let us begin with five bright stars,
For such was my initial impression, 'twas quite fair.
But then, alack! The service did falter,
For though there was but one other patron, 'twas a bother.

The time it took for my repast to arrive,
Was fifteen minutes, a wait most unwise.
And lo! A car did pull up, and the pair within,
Didst enter, and thus, another star didst spin.

Ah, but the food, how couldst it be so?
Heavy on salt, a fault most grievous, I do declare.
Yet, praise be to the man who took my order,
For he was kind, and ensured all was in order.

This place, a dive, alack! Yet, fame didst it gain,
From Food Network's show, a worthy acclaim.
My Pastrami Burger, delicious, beyond compare,
And the garlic fries, oh! How they didst fare!
Thin, yet moist, and full of flavor, a true delight,
I shall return, to partake of their splendor, anon, this night.

Alas, the price, a bit steep, I must confess,
Yet, the portion, generous, and thus, 'twill suffice.
So, to the Decatur St location, I shall make haste,
To savor once more, their culinary grace."
"Restaurant was cold as hell. AC blasting like it was mid-summer. Pico and guac, damn good. Fish tacos, solid. Ceviche, not what I expected. Wouldn't go out of my way, but I'd come back."

"Methinks, fair Vegas, thou art a place most dear to my heart,
Where gambling and revelry do ne'er depart.
I've visited many a casino in NorCal, 'tis true,
But none have offered me a massage, save this one, anon.

At a pai gow table, full of players, I did sit,
When a worker approached, with a offer most fit.
A massage, he proposed, and the player beside me,
Did accept, and thus, a giant cushion did he see.

The masseuse, with skillful hands, did work her magic spell,
And the player, in relaxation, did revel in his seat.
For ten minutes, she worked, and then, did ask for pay,
