A score of twenty dollars, a fair price, come what may.

Alas, the cocktail waitresses, did not often come by,
With drinks, to quench our thirst, and thus, we did sigh.
But still, I would return, for the pleasure of the game,
To this casino, with three stars, and naught but fame."

"Hark! What discord doth mine ears perceive?
A tumult of loud noise, a cacophony most dire.
'Tis naught but cash that doth the patrons crave,
And boobs, alack, do they so eagerly engage.
Prepare thyself to stand for hours on end,
For music, good or great, doth never cease to blend.
Girls dance upon the bar, with grace so fine,
While bartenders, full of mirth and wit divine.
Alas, a place of merriment, yet I, a maid so fair,
Didst feel most ill at ease amidst the rough and wild array."
"Cowboy Ciao for the heavy eaters. Service good, hostess friendly. Food? Meh. FNB better."

In this place of chance and sport,
The staff doth wear a friendly countenance,
And welcome guests with open arms,
To partake of games of hazard and delight.

The floor of play doth shine so bright,
With shops and eats to please the sight,
A theme of old New York doth reign,
And all doth seem so well maintained.

But alas, the rooms above,
Doth show their age, and need of love,
For time hath left them somewhat behind,
And modern touches they do lack, in sooth.

"Rude lady at the counter. Never been so upset. Ordered 7 orders of dumplings to-go, got shorted 20. They thought we wouldn't count 'em. Not only that, they were rude about it. Leaked all over the bag, asked for another, and she gave us a dirty look. What the hell? Disappointed in the service, but the food's damn good. Enjoyed it a lot, wish we got what we ordered, but still good. Nice waitress though, young one, real sweet, gave us extra sauce."

"A fair and lovely inn, with rooms so fine,
But, alas, the eateries, too dear for mine.
Their plays, a delight, 'Yellow Brick Road' doth shine,
And 'Steel Panther', a band of merriment divine.
The pool, a haven, where one may lounge and play,
But, lo, last Saturday, they didst us away,
At four o'clock, to make room for a wedding feast,
And with such haste, our stay didst come to an end, ere we couldst finish our repast."

"Methinks I fell prey to o'er-hyped patties,
Good, yet not quite mind-blowing, didst they seem.
Quality of meat, indeed, was of high grade,
But flavor, alack, didst lack that certain gleam.
A pinch of salt, I added, to give it zest,
Lest it be deemed plain, and thus, unworthiest.

The side salad, small, yet fresh and fair,
With dressing, most excellent, didst pair.
My companion's grilled chicken, good,
But seasoning, alas, didst lack, as it would.

Tessaro's, give it a try, I do advise,
Yet, heed this warning, lest thou be misguided.
Keep thy hopes low, lest disappointment doth arise."
"Dinner was decent. Not bad. Won't harm you none. Might not stick in your memory, but the ambiance and service were on point."

"In days of yore, when Quebec's streets did teem
With shoppers eager to partake of dreams,
A place of commerce did arise, 'twas called
Dupuis and Frères, a store of great renown.
Its wares did draw the masses far and wide,
And with each passing year, its fame did grow.
The family who owned it, Canadians of old,
Didst make it thrive, their efforts never cold.
But now, alas! the times have changed,
And with it, the purpose of this place arranged.
A center commercial now doth stand,
With shops and eateries at hand.
Yet still, within its walls, a sense doth linger
Of that which once did make it such a tinger.
For those who seek the past, a visit doth reveal
A tale of success, of dreams that did conceal.
And though the present may not be so grand,
Still, 'tis a place where memories doth expand."
"Chocolate concrete, shared with the missus. Toasted coconut, extra. Filling, but worth it."

"Chinese grub, that's my jam. Always on the lookout for a new spot to try. This joint, decent happy hour deal. Rare find in these parts. Pricewise, a steal. Food, not the best I've had. One of my buddies, dubious about the meat. But hey, you get what you pay for. Filling, cheap, can't complain."

"Methinks I do adore the Italian cuisine,
And thus, when near a Best Western didst stray,
I searched on Yelp for a nearby place to dine,
And chanced upon Foccaccio, a humble wayside inn.

The food, though tasty, lacked a certain flair,
For Parmesan, freshly grated, I do declare,
Is what I seek in an Italian meal,
Not some bottled impostor, vile and mean.

The portions, too, were somewhat small,
Yet still, I would return, for all in all,
Foccaccio's fare, though not the best I've had,
Did please my taste buds, and made me feel glad."

"This joint's got potential. Good staff, stage, games - all the makings of a swell spot to kick back. Roach coach serves up decent grub too. Worth checking out, especially with that Living Social deal."
"Went for brunch on a weekday. Wynn picked up half the tab. Nothing special, but nothing bad either. If you're sweet-toothed, Wicked Spoon's got better options."

"Wine list? Meh. Not bad, but not what I'd expect from a Wine Spectator award winner. And Jesus, the prices! They're raping you, brother. Fish menu's mostly sustainable, but I asked the waitress about the Chilean sea bass and she didn't know the difference between farmed and wild caught. Wait staff needs a crash course in sustainability. Dinner's good, though. Risotto's flavorless, but everything else is solid. View's nice, but not worth a C-note per head. You feel me?"

"Four years they've been open. Empty room, two women chat. No wait, in and out in ten. Quick questions, sanitize, get to work. All business, roll, grab, pull. Surprised, jumped. Not painless this time. Looked stuck in surprise. Two brows, distinct shape. Light brush, clip at end. Good work, precise. Be more vocal next time. Standard price, ten bucks."

"Hark, good sirs and madams, listen well,
For I have tales to tell of coffee's spell,
A brew most average, yet the staff, so bright,
Doth make my mornings merry and light.

Their service, swift and friendly, doth prepare
My soul for interactions with the fair,
Or perchance 'tis the caffeine, which doth stir
My spirit, making me most eager to share.

So, here's a tip, my friends, for thee,
To seek out their expertise, you'll see,
In flavors, they do excel, I do confess,
And thus, my quest for knowledge, doth begin.

Post your suggestions, prithee, let them be,
For I do crave the best, as doth my soul,
And with each sip, my heart doth sing,
Of joys, that only coffee can bring."

"Hark! In fair Las Vegas, I didst partake
Of a most wondrous feast, a veritable smorgasbord
At Caesar's, a place of renown, they say
But alas, my expectations were not quite met
For though the spread was vast and fair
The meats, oh how they didst disappoint
Dry and lackluster, a sorry sight
Prime rib and roast beef, a poor showing
And some of the sides, oh how they didst lack
In flavor and inspiration, a true letdown
But lo, the desserts, they didst make amends
Creme Brulee, a heavenly delight
Pastries and crepes, a sweet reprieve
But alas, a pricey meal, it should be noted
The main course, a letdown, a true shame
The service too, left much to be desired
Alack, my waitress, nowhere to be found
Dirty dishes piled high, a sorry plight
Attention, hard to come by, a true disgrace
Yet still, compared to others on the Strip
This buffet, not the worst, a faint praise."

"In sooth, fair friends, I must confess,
I ne'er would purchase aught from Digger's nest.
No malice do I bear, nor have I cause,
'Tis but a matter of my own heart's pause.

Their wares, though bright and colorful,
Do not entice me with their charmful lure.
Their quaint decorations, handmade with care,
And eye-catching trinkets, doth not ensnare.

Alas, their appeal doth lie with mothers dear,
And daughters too, who hold them in affection sincere.
Forsooth, they call it 'twee', a word of endearment,
A term of fondness, and a token of their gentle sentiment."

"A pox upon the steakhouse! Their meat doth lack,
In flavor, texture, and in price, a woeful pack.
My wife, she ordered rare, yet they didst bring,
A steak so red, it seemed to sing.
And I, who asked for medium, didst receive,
A cut so done, 'twas hard to chew, and didst leave,
A taste most foul, like that of old shoe leather.
They claimed they cooked it right, but I didst know,
That better steaks are found at Outback, Longhorn,
Where tender meat doth dance upon the tongue,
And fill the senses with delight, not wrong."

"In Vegas, this joint was my spot for nutrition gear. Prices were the best I'd found, anywhere. Even online. They had a decent selection, from protein bars to vitamins. If you needed it, they had it or something close. Service wasn't great, but I didn't care. Prices made up for it."

"Hark! My third fave steakhouse doth lie,
With blooming onions, green veggies in the sky.
Broccoli, strings beans, asparagus they do bear,
And Texas Roadhouse, their steaks do declare.
Outback, with mushrooms, doth take the cake,
But Delfrisco's, pricy, the Wygul doth make.
The entrance, strange, doth give me pause,
Yet still, my two cents, I herewith cause."

"Upon this fair day, the twenty-first of January, two thousand twelve, I didst visit this establishment, Bombay Grille, with a most wondrous coupon, a Groupon, if thou must know. The ambiance, dark and elegant, didst please mine eyes, with naught but recessed lighting to illuminate the space. The service, prompt and attentive, didst ensure that mine glass of water was ever full, a true blessing, indeed. Forsooth, half of their menu didst cater to those who doth eschew meat, a most excellent sight. A complimentary plate of flatbread and chutneys didst greet mine arrival, a most generous gesture. The veg sampler, a diverse array of delights, didst tantalize mine taste buds, with paneer pakoras and cauliflower pakoras reigning supreme. Malai kafta, mine main course, didst satisfy mine hunger. Garlic naan and paneer bread, both most delectable. Alas, Bombay Grille, though pleasant, doth not surpass the culinary excellence of Woodlands, a place that hath captured mine heart, forevermore."

"Sandwiches taste great, but there's an issue. Why do only cops and firefighters get discounts in Vegas? I'm in private EMS, and even in uniform, I'm told there's nothing for us. We're all part of the same team - public safety guardians. Fix this."

"We were en route to Noodles of Asia for a 6:00 pm lunch before our 11:30 dinner reservations at Raku, but we stumbled upon Pinot Brasserie instead. The menu looked harmless, so we gave it a shot. For $9.00, the French onion soup was decent, and the $15.00 mussels and fries were a steal. The white wine, butter, and garlic sauce were sublime, especially when dipped with the fries. The French onion soup was one of the best I've had, with a rich onion broth that wasn't overpowered by salt. For dessert, we tried the roasted strawberry with vanilla and mint ice cream, which was surprisingly good despite my aversion to roasted fruit. However, the service was abysmal. Our server was unfriendly and unhelpful, barely acknowledging us except to push dessert. Even the busboy/girl provided better service. A smile and some attentiveness would have doubled their tips."
"Skip MGM. It's not worth it. They screwed up my reservation, tried to downgrade me to a shoebox. Rooms, casino, pool, service - all subpar. Don't waste your cash."

"A three-star tavern, by my reckoning, suiting well my taste in alehouses and merriment. 'Tis a true public house, with a playful Australian motif, postcards of comely lasses and swains adorning the walls, a cheeky sign pointing to an empty space, inviting patrons to partake in mirth. The atmosphere doth recall a students' guild, albeit somewhat better appointed. The clientele are convivial, the barkeepers friendly, though strict in their domain. A portion of the bar doth bear a sign, "NO SERVICE," warning those who dare approach, lest they incur disfavor. Yet, twain pool tables beckon, a true delight, provided one doth heed the custom of inscribing one's name upon the chalkboard, thereby securing a turn at play. The patrons, congenial and eager to engage in chat, shall make thy acquaintance. Common drinks, lacking fancy mixology, yet adequate for a public house. A cozy venue, thronged by Australians on their national day, but hardly shabby."
"Place is fun. Drinks, neat and pricey. Went last night, two entrees, two drinks. Coupon, twenty bucks off, still sixty bucks. Been there before, fun spot in Vegas. Food, delicious. Staff, friendly."

"A plethora of tea, a feast for mine eyes!
And my raspberry hibiscus iced tea, oh how fine!
Brewed to perfection, a taste divine.
I would frequent this place, 'twere it not so far,
In the midst of Tempe Marketplace, alas!

Four stars, not five, for they had none of my desire,
And the lad at the till, he didst speak in ire.
Against Starbucks, his words didst flow,
Unaware that I, a Starbucks manager, didst know.

Keep thy opinions, but hold them tight,
For thou ne'er knowest who may hear thee in the night."

"Workin' late, I do. They stay open past closin' time, don't mind if you show up five minutes early. Food's better than your average Chinese joint. Ask 'em for a suggestion, they'll give it to ya. Chicken fried rice, that's my go-to."

"A foul stench doth fill the dining hall, alack!  A pox upon the scent, that doth my meal besmirch!  Oh, how I wish to dine alfresco, in yonder patio, where flowers bloom and birds do sing!  'Tis a fair place, indeed, for diverse folk to gather, with victuals for all, from savory gyros and shwarmas, to a medley platter, fit for vegetarians, with hummus, baba, tsaziki, tabouleh, and falafel, in abundance.  Generous portions, prithee!  Lentils and rice, a feast for the eyes, as large as the main course, itself!  Swiftly, the food doth arrive, and at a fair price, no less!  No wonder, then, that this establishment doth teem with patrons, night and day!"
"Walked north, hungry for something new. Found a joint near the onramp to 279. Lunch special, cheap. Ordered Kung Pao Chicken, tasty. Ate inside, few tables, clean enough."

"Casanova, a quaint Italian eatery in the Venetian, seats only a handful of patrons. I made a reservation for thirteen, but they sat us outside - smack in the middle of the Grand Canal Shoppes walkway. Loud, yes, especially with a nearby bar and food court nearby. For a small group, no more than four, it's ideal. Inside, it's charmingly decorated. Their prices? Reasonable, for an Italian joint at The Venetian. I ordered the Timballo - penne, creamy pesto, parmesan cheese, baked to perfection. Flavorful, indeed. Couldn't finish my plate. Their bread? Delightful, roasted, warm. If you crave good Italian cuisine at a fair price, give Casanova a try."

The store’s a flurry of activity. Lines can stretch long, but they move quick. Some deals are damn good, 99 cents or two for 99 cents! It ain’t the biggest 99 cent store around, but it’s close.

Still, there’s some things I won’t touch. Don’t know where it comes from or how it’s been handled. And the place can get messy.

I usually go in looking for one thing, but end up dropping 5-10 bucks on stuff I suddenly need.

"Methought, fair readers, I would give a try
To Beijing, a place most convenient nigh,
In stead of Ho Ho Cherry House, my heart's desire,
Whose fare I oft have savored with great delight.

A sesame chicken dish, extra crispy, didst order I,
With fried rice, egg roll, and soup, a feast most fair and nigh,
And broccoli, a vegetable most green and bright,
Didst complete this meal, a veritable sight.

Ten minutes, a mere moment, didst pass ere my food didst arrive,
Freshly cooked, a feast fit for a king, didst I perceive.
The egg rolls, a delight, didst surpass Ho Ho's, I must confess,
For in them, cabbage was not the only guest.

The rice, a treat, didst please my taste, I must avow,
And the soup, a delicacy, didst warm my heart, I vow.
Even the young ones, whom I didst babysit, didst enjoy,
The won-ton soup, a treat, didst make their eyes employ.

But alas, dear friends, the crispiness, a shame,
Didst lack the punch, a fault, didst bring me shame.
I fear, didst I not ask for extra crispy, a mistake,
The chicken, a disappointment, didst my senses forsake.

And thus, my friends, a try, I shall give once more,
With emphasis on crispiness, a must, I implore.
For though the sauce, a letdown, didst seem,
The price, the location, a dream, a scheme."

"Good eatery. Had the slider trio, jalapeno coleslaw, and hot link. Slaw was meh, pork roast, not my fave. Hot link? Spicy! Cobbler? No bueno. Not sweet enough. Place was packed, liked the murals. Will return for smoked meatloaf."

"My buddy's got a thing for gift shops. Spends hours in 'em, especially the official ones. This one's legit, but it's got some tacky stuff too. Still, there's some nice, classy gifts in here. Better quality than the crap on the Royal Mile, and no loud music or bright lights. Just depends on your budget and how much you wanna hunt around. Lady at the counter's real friendly, doesn't mind my friend takin' his time. Not like that other cheap joint that followed us around like a hawk. If you paid to get into the castle, might as well take a stroll."

"Last week, I dined with a friend at this establishment. Parking nearby is possible, but limited, and there are no dedicated parking spots for the restaurant. Upon entering, I was greeted by the delightful aroma of spices. The atmosphere within was cozy, yet intimate, with tables arranged closely together. As a larger person, I found the seating to be somewhat cramped, but not overly so. The staff were friendly and attentive, and the food was fresh, tasty, and served promptly. The menu offered a variety of dishes, some with a hint of Indian flavor, though I cannot truly judge its authenticity, never having been to India. My friend's dish and the desserts were particularly enjoyable, the latter being a house-made almond and cashew ice cream, flavored with cardamom, which was truly exceptional. Unfortunately, I cannot comment on the restrooms, as I did not use them. Payment by card is possible, but I am unsure if they accept all types of cards."

"This joint's got some style, that's what drew me in. Nice fish tank, classy decor. Everyone's decked out in white, like they're trying to make a statement. I ordered the beef and noodles, but it was just alright. Lacked some serious flavor. For the price, I expected more. My tab came out to around $35, including a cold one. Not the best value in Vegas, that's for sure."

"Methinks the ambiance here doth seem familiar, yet strange,
A feeling hard to describe, like a dream half-remembered.

We tried the luncheon special, a dish most fair,
An open-faced green chili meatloaf sandwich, with care
Piled high upon the plate, a feast for mine eyes,
With mashed potatoes o'er the bread, and a slaw most prize.

Alas, the potatoes, they were o'er-mixed, I fear,
And thus, their texture, gummy, and not so dear.
But still, the meatloaf, tasty, and the slaw, a delight,
Did make the dish worth trying, in my sight.

The grilled salmon salad, a dish most fine,
With chive risotto cake, a flavor divine.
Yet, mayhap 'twas the citrus dressing, that did clash,
And made the risotto cake, a taste not so dash.

The service, good, and naught to complain,
A pleasant experience, save the gummy grain.
I would return, but not with haste,
For other ventures call, and time doth waste."

"Forty minutes to spare, the crowd did swell,
And thus, my worry of slow service did dwell.
But lo, a table free, I quickly didst sit,
And in five minutes' time, a drink didst fit.

Buffalo wings, twenty minutes didst take,
But in ten, they didst upon my plate make.
The service, in truth, didst excel,
But alas, the wings, too vinegary didst tell.
Two gentlemen, with fish and chips didst dine,
And deemed them good, their taste didst align.

A fair price, the menu didst hold,
But nine dollars, for a Stella, bold?
Yikes, indeed, such price doth make me shudder."

"Though grub didst not impress, the server's grace Did make amends. A man of skill and pace, He catered well to our each whim. My name, alas! Mr. Tofu, didst conjure thoughts Of veggie dishes, but alas! Not so. A solitary soup, cold and plain, With three ingredients didst make its claim. Noodles, tofu broth, and ice didst play Their parts, but flavor didst not stay. Tasting of tofu, bland and weak, I added kimchee to make it speak. Side dishes, good, didst add their zest, But still, I shall not visit, save my quest For meat, once more to savor and delight."

"What's with the fuss over these? Comfort? Style? Not in my book. They look stiff, like they'd rather be sitting in a museum than on your feet. And that style? Outdated, if you ask me. Not for the young bloods. But hey, if you're into that sorta thing, you're in luck. Half the store was 50% off last week. Just saying."

"Five stars for the idea, bringing a cupcake joint to Scottsdale. Bright, airy store. Not a fan of sweet myself, so take my rating for what it's worth. Had cupcakes at Magnolia in NY, loved 'em all. Sprinkles, not so much. Too damn sweet. Shared a red velvet, the top came off. What the hell?"

"Lobster in various forms. Sandwiches, salads, fried dishes, and even ice cream. Prices were a bit high, $23 for a six-inch lobster roll, but the lobster salad was decent for the cost. Standard bisque. Lobster-n-chips, beer-battered and fried, was quite good. And the lobster ice cream? Vanilla ice cream with tiny bits of lobster. Not bad, but worth a sample before purchase. *wink*."

"In fair Tuscany Casino, where we did abide,
A conventioneers' haven, as we did reside.
Our group of ten did gather, with much delight,
To dine within its halls, on a most pleasant night.

The seating, plentiful, did accommodate our throng,
And our server, patient, did attend to us long.
With coupon in hand, two for one, we did implore,
And he, unruffled, did honor our request, and more.

The victuals, decent, did please our taste,
And prices, fair, did not burden our purse.
The portions, ample, did satiate our hunger's haste."
"Good eatery. Not fancy, but solid grub for lunch or dinner. Meet up with pals here."

"A review for eyebrow waxing, I do pen,
On a Saturday afternoon, I did stroll in,
No waiting, straight to the back, 'twas quick,
My usual place, a half-hour journey, doth take.

This place, close by, doth save me time,
But waxing, not plucking, doth be their crime,
My brows, thin, unexpected, doth seem,
Yet, not a hair in sight, a week hath passed,

Pricing, fair, a tenner, doth be the cost,
If in a bind, again I wouldst resort,
They cards accept, but cash, for tip, doth seek."

On a Sunday, I didst venture in,
For the first time, my curiosity didst spin.
Till midnight, they do stay open wide,
A convenience, indeed, for those who doth reside
In this fair city, where the night doth reign,
And hunger pangs do strike, with naught but pain.

The sushi, alas, didst fail to impress,
A mediocre feast, at best, I must confess.
Three stars, I gave, for their edamame,
Not organic, nor their soy sauce, the same.
I ask thee, dear friends, what doth it mean,
To feed upon genetically modified dream?

A non-GMO verified soy, I doth desire,
But alas, the masses, they doth not acquire
Knowledge of GMOs, a sad, sad plight,
Leaves me to ponder, in the dark of night.
Will we, one day, doth care, and doth demand,
A change, forsooth, in this unnatural land?
Until that day, I fear, we doth remain,
In this world of modified, unnatural grain.

"Hark! A tale of Mesa Grill, a place I didst choose,
After hearing Delmonico's praise, didst lose its sheen.
A table of six, we didst have, and awkward was the seat,
In the midst of others, ours didst seem most discreet.

The food, it was great, all didst agree,
Duck, ribeye, pork, and sides, a feast for thee.
But wait, the service, not so grand,
Forgets the sides, and slow, her hand.

Desserts, just fair, the creme brulee, a delight,
But profiteroles, with ice cream, a sorry sight.
And so, Mesa Grill, a visit worth,
Despite some flaws, a place of mirth."

"Hark! What news is this? The Target doth transform,
Into a Super Store, they do declare.
A change most wondrous, and most strange,
To those who dwell within this city's range.

The folk who shop there, full of cheer,
Do welcome renovations, quite sincere.
But some, like I, do harbor fear,
That all we seek, may disappear.

For when I venture forth to buy,
My groceries, I pray, let them be nigh.
Chicken breasts, olive oil, and wine,
These are the items that I do design.

But lo! The Target now doth lack,
These very things, that I do seek.
And when I ask, with hopeful heart,
When they shall restock, they do depart.

Alas! Their answers, brief and cold,
Do leave me in a state of woe, so bold.
I pray, dear Target, heed my plea,
And bring back all that's missing, ere long, ere long!"

"Hark! I didst order noodles, a humble dish,
To sate mine hunger and quench mine thirst.
But lo! The instructions, they were unclear,
Or perhaps mine interpretation, it didst err.

In Phoenix's heat, I didst toil and sweat,
And thus, I craved naught but rest and ease.
I reached mine home, and saw the sauce,
Lava-red, it didst seem, in its intensity.

I ate a third, and wished I hadst not,
For mine lip didst swell, and face didst sweat.
A Coca Cola bottle, I didst drain,
To quench the fire that raged within.

Good sirs, do check the pepper's might,
In those take-home orders, ere ye send them forth.
I shall give thee another chance, anon,
And pray, do heed mine words, lest this mishap befall another.
This experience, I shall not soon forget,
Nor shall I let it mar mine appetite."

"Methinks I wanted to love this place, but alas, 'twas not meant to be. A humble burger joint with a fine selection of ale, yet something didst not sit well with mine eyes.

As I entered, I stood there, lost in thought, forsooth. No sign didst indicate that I should seat myself, and thus, I didst wait in vain. At last, I found a table bare of menus, and thus, I didst assume 'twas not a place of much import. But lo, the other tables didst have menus, and I didst feel a fool.

I didst order bruschetta and a pesto burger, verily, 'twas delicious, but alack, the portion was small, scarce five ounces for seven gold coins and fifty-nine silver pence. Nay, 'twas not worth the cost, though 'twas tasty, I do confess. And if thou dost desire a side of fries, prepare to pay a pretty penny, for 'tis ten gold coins, indeed.

My companion didst order mac and cheese with a bacon burger, and though the parts were delicious, the burger itself didst lack moisture. Mayhap a cheese sauce wouldst have helped?

The beer menu doth boast a grand array of brews, but alas, the rest of the establishment doth leave much to be desired."

Hark, good sir or madam, listen well to my tale,
Of a shoppe where I do frequent, with naught but praise,
The staff, they be friendly, and helpful too,
But alas, the bathroom, foul and stinking, doth ruin all anew.

A pox upon the loo, that doth sully the name,
Of this otherwise fine establishment, with shame,
For who would wish to tarry, in such a place,
Where filth doth reign supreme, and doth leave a foul trace?

And yet, despite this woe, I still do come,
For the wares they sell, beckon me, like a siren's hum,
But oh, the bathroom, how it doth make me frown,
And question whether I should stay, or turn tail and run.

A fair sports bar, 'cross from the book of sports,
In MGM, a place to grab a brew and bites.
On Saturdays and Sundays, when the football's on,
The crowd doth swell, and tables scarce become.
But fear not, for the bar doth offer seats,
If thou art early, and thy luck doth beat.

The victuals, basic fare, yet satisfying still,
Wings and burgers, worth thy while to try.
Deals on game days, shots and brews, a merry mix,
And beers on tap, a diverse lot, doth please.
No fancy frills, yet pleasant, nonetheless,
To linger, watch the games, and revel in the mess.

"Aye, Green river soda pop doth flow,
Fried mushrooms, a feast for mine eyes,
And all the Chicago favorites, so bright,
Red Hots, hot dogs of various delight.

I, myself, do lean towards fried fare,
At places such as these, 'tis my desire,
But alas, the service here did slow,
And in my heart, a pang of woe did grow.

For in this very spot, a pizza place,
Did once reside, a taste of grace,
Now gone, alack, and in its stead,
This new establishment, a different creed."

"Hark! This Dunkin' Donuts doth be one of the first,
In Madison's land, to open its doors.
'Tis situated on a corner most fair,
Where highways Q and 19 do meet and share.
A gas station doth it call its home,
A place to fill thy tank, and thus doth roam.

The staff, so friendly and full of cheer,
Didst greet us with smiles, and banish fear.
The donuts, decent indeed they were,
Worth a visit, should thou have a crave to spare.
So, if thou find thyself in this fair town,
And dost desire a sweet, tasty crown,
Give these good people a chance, I pray,
And may their donuts bring thee joy, ere the day doth fade away."

"A merry place, with victuals fair and bright,
Not wholly true to roots, yet still a sight,
A worthy meal, or twain, doth make it right.
The service, too, was good, in truth, not tight,
But laid-back, easy, like a summer's night.
The tortilla soup, a joy beyond compare,
Didst make my heart sing, and banish all despair.
So, come not here expecting grand display,
For 'tis a humble place, where one may play.
Yet, for a casual visit, 'twill do, I say."

"Pros: Prime spot, close to the action but without the hefty price tag. Westin Heavenly Bed and Shower, perfect for a peaceful night's sleep. Ample parking, no need to worry about finding a spot.

Cons: Small pool, modest spa facilities. No iHomes in the rooms, a minor letdown.

Service could use some improvement. Bellhop MIA, left us waiting with our bags. Concierge and check-in staff twiddling their thumbs, no one bothered to assist. A simple acknowledgement would've gone a long way. Disappointing experience."

"Motel 6, clean and cheap. Friendly staff, too. Slept like a baby, even missed my wake-up call. Pool's nice, plenty of parking. Theme park nearby, no big deal. Can hear it, can't see it. Not much around, but that's okay. Breakfast's a short drive away."

"Cake batter, vanilla, chocolate - all good. Decent toppings too. Don't forget to ask for mochi. Interesting folks inside. One Indian mom even asked how much I charged per hour (I was wearing a'rent by the hour' shirt). Still feels awkward."

"Methinks 'tis strange that I, who dwellest here, ne'er set foot within these hallowed halls. Yet, thus I ventured forth, to partake of their culinary delights. 

Ah, the view! 'Tis a sight most fair and bright, a true delight for mine eyes. But, alack! The other scribes have penned their praise, and so I shall move on. 

The eatery itself, a space most elegant and cozy, didst provide a sense of privacy, that rare and precious gem. The staff, kind and attentive, didst keep my cup full and ensured all was well. 

But, alas! The victuals, methought, were naught but middling fare. The bread, afore the meal, a disappointment, lacking that certain je ne sais quoi. And yet, the pesto dish, though pleasant, didst not surpass the ordinary. My comrade's pasta, spicy and savory, didst find favor in his eyes, and the sweet tiramisu, a satisfying conclusion. 

In conclusion, Ventano's, a place of worth, yet not of exceeding excellence. I shall return, perchance, when the whim doth strike me."

"Kabob House, that's what it's called. Clean joint, too. Attached to a beverage store, but that's neither here nor there. Order the ground meat kabob, that's my advice. You'll get a ton of meat, wrapped around a long skewer. Don't forget to add some rice and bread, makes it all the better. Service is friendly, but don't expect a quick in and out. They ain't got the best English skills either."

"Christmas week, premium price on buffet, around $30 per head. Regular line packed, but we had a line pass. Been here before, quality's gone down. Standard fare - shrimp, prime rib, chicken. King crab legs, but I don't like 'em. Food's a bit dry, need lots of sauce. Dessert's the best - creme brulee, creampuffs, ice cream, brownies, banana fosters, cookies. Creme brulee and cookies are good. Pop and juice included. Not worth $30 for lunch, but ok for $20."

"Went to the joint with a buncha folks. Portions were big, real big. Some dug the grub, others not so much. Jerk pork and chicken, meh. Pork BBQ, now that was good eatin'. Sweet taters and rice, too."

"A fortnight past, with colleagues numerous,
I dined at an establishment of repute,
Where upon my lips did grace a burger,
Kobe beef, with cheddar white as snow,
And fries of sweet potato, crispy delight,
Together did they dance upon my tongue,
A culinary symphony, most fair and bright.
The burger, cooked to perfection, did impress,
And fries, oh fries, how wondrous thy taste!
Yet, alas, not the finest burger I've known,
But mirth and merriment did that eve unfold."
"Sushi, alright. Few good rolls for five bucks. Quick pick-up lunch during work week. No seating, takeout only."

"Hark! What light through yonder deli breaks? A place wherein I find some solace in the form of sustenance most fair and rare. Forsooth, they boast a bounty of broths most savory, fit to warm the cockles of mine heart. And sandwiches, too, of decent sort, with flavors diverse and bold. But, alas, their ice cream doth steal the show, a sweet delight that doth my senses stir. Yet, though I may not seek it out, I shall not shun it neither, should fate or friendship lead me thither."
"Food's good, but pricey. Chicken Marsala's my pick. Kid working there, looks like Jonah Hill's long-lost brother. Service is meh, but the kid makes up for it."

"This place, fair sir, couldst be five stars, an it change but a few things. The menu, verily, doth please mine taste, and the ambiance, by th' gods, doth delight. The indoor-outdoor setup, 'tis a marvel, and the patio, where thou mayst bring thy cur, doth make for a pleasant evening. Alas, the bartenders, full of pride, do seem to scorn their patrons. Alack, the owner, wouldst he send them to Ve Bene, in Ahwatukee, to learn the ways of a true bartender? Forsooth, they offer no drink specials at night, and the prices, they do mount. Mayhap, 'tis why the place doth stay so slow, save for the occasional customer. Methinks, they do seek to keep out the rabble."

"Methinks my first visit to this place didst yield a shredded beef burrito, priced at six twenty-nine. Verily, I found it to be but mediocre, alack! Yet, their warm chips, nine pence, and guacamole, two six nine, didst please mine taste buds exceedingly. 

Thus, I have returned to this establishment on multiple occasions, merely to partake in an order of chips and guacamole. Methinks my mouth doth water at the mere thought of those lightly salted chips and tangy guacamole. 

In sooth, while I do prefer Qdoba's chips, for burritos, Baja Fresh doth hold sway. And, indeed, Qdoba doth resemble Chipotle, as if they were but twins. 'Tis strange, forsooth, that they should choose to situate themselves across the street from one another, in such close proximity."

"Twas good, not great, yet not so bad,
I ordered omelet, my love had strat.
With potatoes baked and fruit so fresh,
The meal was good, but not quite a quest.

At home, I could have made the same,
But still, I'd return and try their fame.
Their menu's vast, with veggies galore,
And lean meats, fitting my desire.

My love, a burger man, was pleased,
With Wisconsin pride, his heart appeased.
We celebrated his birth with cheer,
A cupcake sweet, but I was too full, my dear.

He savored each bite, with gleeful grace,
Carrot cake, cream cheese frosting in its place.
A walnut topping, a tasty delight,
He finished it swiftly, with joy in sight.

Perhaps, another time, we'll dine once more,
And sample their lunch, as we did before.
Until then, this review stands tall,
A decent spot, worth a visit, after all."

"Tis but a humble abode, yet priced so low,
During the mining convention, I didst stay,
And found the staff to be scarce, in truth,
Yet still, the chamber was clean, the water hot,
Adequate, but naught more, I do declare,
'Tis but an ordinary inn, no more, no less."

The joint was bigger than I expected, with a long bar against the back wall. Drink lines got long, and the prices were steep for a plain draft. But the staff were friendly, and there were plenty of folks keeping the place tidy and watching over the crowd. 

The cans were huge, with more than enough stalls to avoid a long wait between sets. Acoustics were good, but the GA floor had weird iron rails dividing it up. I guess they didn't want a wild mosh pit, but it was a strange way to set things up.

"We'd had great meals at Kai, so we were stoked to hear their ex-chef was joining forces with Mod. The grub was inventive, and some dishes, like the "shroom" plate, were top-notch. The venison lollipops were a bit raw for my taste, but my husband dug 'em. He also enjoyed the pescado loco tartare. I went for the duck big plate, but it was a letdown - the duck was solid, but the sides were nothing special. The okra was even too salty. A confused server brought us a mystery dish, and when we asked what it was, he shrugged. Not exactly sure what was up with that. The service was friendly, though, and the vibe was lively, despite the loud tunes. Might be worth it for apps and drinks, but not dinner, given all the other options in the Valley."

"Hark, a local and former Detroiter, I didst venture forth to Valet, a place of rest and refreshment. Alas, 'twas only open to guests of the hotel, and the parking garage, a woeful sight indeed. Seven floors, they didst reserve for valet, and then, the garage, it didst end abruptly, with nary a path to exit. I didst seek the famed American Coney Island, and though the fare was passable, the chili, a scant amount, didst leave me wanting. A draught of Vernors, that most refreshing elixir, wouldst have made the experience complete. Alas, the casino, with its dancing table girls and overloud music, didst strike me as tawdry and poorly executed."
"Give Bei a 3.5, maybe. Not like Shin Bay, not even close. More like Ra or Kona Grill. Fellow Yelpers, let's be real. Passable sushi in Scottsdale, that's all."

"Things are looking up, my friend. My experience has been different with each airline. Qatar Airways, now that's a story. Fastest check-in of my life, no joke. Thirty minutes, that's all it took. I felt like a VIP. Now, Air Canada, that's a different tale. Two years ago, it was a mess. One hour and twenty minutes for check-in, ten minutes for customs. But they've improved, you see. They've got this new system, a reader that checks your passport and declaration. Good idea, but the one I had didn't work so well. Took too much time. If you've got everything in order, great. If not, well, you'll be waiting. That's how it goes."

"Fare thee well, good sir! Verily, the victuals here be grand. A grilled salmon burrito, by my troth, doth please mine taste. The service, too, doth shine with kindness and exceeding diligence. Alas, the men's privy, foul and ill-kept, doth mar mine experience, like a stinking wagon halt."

"Hark! The victuals were but passable, I say,  
The flesh was naught but mediocre, fries the same,  
Yet, verily, a merry time was had, I pray.  
For those who weigh o'er three hundred fifty,  
Eat freely, 'tis a wondrous sight to see,  
But mark, good sir, they take no credit,  
Cash only, that's their decree, thou must comply.  
A gown and bracelet, too, thou must don,  
Lest thou be turned away, ere the night be gone.  
Alas, I would not return, forsooth,  
The fare, though pleasant, was naught but common,  
Yet, anon, the experience, I dare avow,  
Was merry, and shall stay with me, 'twill be shown."

"In fair Sichuan, land of beauty's reign,
A maiden fair, with wit and charm, doth hold the key.
To win her heart, thou must possess the whole,
A pretty face, a sharp mind, and passion's fire.

Oh, how the Yelp reviews do criticize and scorn,
The decor, the service, and the ambiance forlorn.
But who are these young souls that praise the fare?
(Alas, I do, with fondness and a twinkle there.)

Their spicy crispy chicken, oh how grand,
My taste buds dance with joy, my love for it so bland.
But alas, the Kung Pao chicken, a disappointment true,
The sauce too sweet, the heat not fiery enough, anew.

And thus, fair reader, we come to know,
What kind of maiden doth Ichiban's charms bestow?
A brainy beauty, independent, free,
Who cares not for thy thoughts, nor doth she thee.

Yet, methinks, a wish within my heart doth lie,
That she, perchance, mightst notice me, and sigh."

"Hark! If thou art in search of sustenance,
'Tis here thou shalt find delectable fare,
A humble abode, yet full of cheer,
With sandwiches and gyros to tempt thee there.

And shouldst thou chance upon a night
When music doth fill the air,
Do stay and revel in the delight,
For 'tis a place of joy beyond compare.

As student, I didst frequent this spot,
And still, whene'er I visit, do drop in,
For though 'tis plain, 'tis home to warmth and cheer,
Right on the campus, near the quad, my dear."

"Hark, my friends, I tell thee now a tale,
Of a place we visited twice in one eve,
For hunger pangs did strike our bellies fair,
And cheapness did our purses much relieve.

Their nachos, oh how grand they were,
Big enough to feed a multitude, I swear,
At $16, a bargain, beyond compare,
The cheese, though not quite melted, did please.

And if thou art in need of stronger drink,
Scrounge up some coins, or beg, or think,
A $1 margarita, strong and sweet, it doth provide,
To keep thy buzz alive, and merry make thy mind."

"We told them we were on the guestlist, but they didn't seem to care,
And so we paid $20, including the fairer sex, without a single soul aware.
But little did we know, if we had stayed at the Venetian,
We could have entered free, and avoided such a sin.

Inside the club, it was quite crowded, I must confess,
The booty-shaking girls, they were quite impressive, I must profess.
The Buddhas all around, they gave me quite a fright,
But others seemed to mind not, in the heat of the night.

They made us climb the stairs, to where Tao Beach lay,
A lovely spot, but for the plastic, that marred the view, alas.
We sat on couches, but they wouldn't let us rest,
For they were bottle service, and we were but guests.

Different rooms played different tunes, it seemed to me,
And in the main room, foam rained down from above, you see.
I walked around with a drink, when suddenly, a girl bumped into me,
My straw went up my nose, and my blood began to flow, you'll see.
I coughed it up, and thank the heavens, I am alive,
So don't you worry, my friends, I'm well, and I do thrive."

"Verily, this eatery doth boast a most excellent quality of meat,
A variety of cuts and choices that doth far surpass the rest.
The establishment itself doth shine with cleanliness, a true delight.

But alas, the service doth leave much to be desired, I do confess.
For those who speak not Korean, 'tis a trial indeed,
To receive the attention and care that one doth expect and need.

Yet, methinks the price doth justify the quality of the fare,
And so, I wouldst recommend this place, despite the service's snare.
For those who crave a savory feast, and can forgive the flaw,
This restaurant doth stand apart, and worth a visit, I do avow."

"This joint's got some character, but it's also kinda corny. Fake rustic decor and staff dressed in burlap shirts. More like a cowshed than a potting shed, if you ask me. Not my usual haunt, but it's in a good location and the grub looks decent."

"San Felipe's, you lucky devil. Right next to the stage at Tempe Marketplace, you say?

Arrived at 7 on a Saturday, just missed happy hour. Place wasn't exactly bustling.

Short line at the door, ID checks, and a bracelet for the 21+ crowd. "Wait to be seated", they say. So we wait, and wait some more. Two girls lazily wiping down menus, not a word. Finally, they take our name, and we're seated at the bar. Drinks ordered, and bam! The patio table we wanted is free. Score! 

We sit, and wait. And wait. And wait. Server! Oh, it's the same girl from last time. 

Lots of waiting at this joint. Sigh. Quesadilla takes forever, $4.95 for a small, add $2 for chicken or steak, $3 for shrimp. Decent, but pricey. They didn't skimp on the chicken, at least. 

Heaters kick in, gets a bit warm. Temp drops, perfect. Heaters off, and stay off. Hmm...

No dude holding the men's room door open this time. Relieved, I tell ya. 

Three stars, you ask? Free chips, killer salsa. Chunky, spicy, black-eyed peas, corn. Want it for my house, please!"

"Methinks I've dined at this establishment ere now, and found it to my liking, I must confess. But alas, this visit proved a sorry tale, indeed. For though the service was slow, and we didst wait some thirty minutes for our meals, the burgers, when they finally arrived, were lacking in size, I do declare. Nay, they were nigh on the same dimensions as those peddled by that wretched Mickey Dee's. And for a sum of nine dollars, I didst receive but a mere three-dollar burger. Fie upon it! I fear I shall have to reconsider my patronage of this place, forsooth. For though the folk be pleasant, the victuals, on this occasion, didst leave much to be desired."
"Food was great. Got there around nine on a long weekend Sunday. Kitchen closed while we were there. Not a fancy joint, more of a family spot or good option for couples on a weeknight."

"Upon mine eyes, a vision didst appear,
A cinema house, with flaws so clear.
In Stockton's town, it doth resemble,
A humble abode, with modest feature.
The seats, alas, didst lack comfort's grace,
And upward gaze, the screen didst embrace.
A relic, old and outdated, doth seem,
Even the privy, with age, didst gleam.
If naught else calls, and movie's thy quest,
Then here, thy steps, shouldst thou address."

"Upon my first visit to yon Church Brew Works, I must confess, fair friends, 'twas a disappointment. My taste buds didst crave the sweetest brews, but alas! The Oktoberfest and IPA didst fall short of greatness. And though the schnitzel didst please mine eyes, 'twas but a mediocre feast. Yet still, the atmosphere didst impress me mightily, a true marvel!"

"Hark! My rating doth be three and a half stars, good sirs,
Rounded down, 'tis true, yet still quite fair.
Thanks to Yelp, my thoughts now shared,
My gut doth guide me, ne'er to err.

Service, five stars, I do declare,
Friendly staff, our time they did share.
Food, alas, doth falter, I do fear,
Two and a half stars, my taste did clear.
Burger, flat grilled, hand pattied, 'twas thin,
Cooked medium rare, flavor did lack within.
Fries, unsalted, a dire need they did possess,
Coleslaw, a small portion, woeful, alack!

Building, clean, open, well-lit, a pleasant sight,
Three stars, methinks, a fair plight.
Breakfast, I shall return, 'tis my intent,
To savor morn's delight, my heart doth invent."

"A quaint and cozy brunchery, with victuals all locally sourced,
The service, warm and welcoming, like a genial host.
Though ambiance was wanting, somewhat plain and bare,
I shall return anon, for more of their fare."

"Build your own burger, not a new concept, but they got some interesting toppings and buns. Went for a 1/3 lb. brie and ham burger. Juicy, tasty. But expensive. My burger, just shy of $10. Bacon, ham, fried onions, mushrooms, extra $1. Second cheese, extra $1. Lettuce, tomato, onions, pickles, four free toppings, anything more, extra 50 cents. Fries, $3. Shakes, delicious, but $5. Good food, not worth the extra expense."

"Ten minutes passed, and still no service came,
At the bar, I sat, my thirst not yet quenched.
Another bartender, with the ladies played,
While I, ignored, my drink did await.

The other bartender would not lend a hand,
"Not my section," he said, with a shrug.
So we took a table, the hostess told,
To get a beer, and an appetizer, bold.

The manager walked by, with a glance,
But kept on walking, without a chance.
He spoke to others, but not to us,
It seemed we were ignored, alas.

This place has potential, great indeed,
But falls flat, with poor service, speed.
They brew their own beer, a selection vast,
But the server knew not, what to say at last.

My husband tried it, and found it good,
But the server, knew not, as he should.
The food was decent, but slow to come,
A disappointment, our evening became.

Alas, we shall not return again,
To this place, with service, so inane."

"Hark! A show most wondrous, yet most vile,
A spectacle that doth beguile,
With stars, both one and five, I do declare,
And thus, my friends, a tale most rare.

'Tis called The Sirens of TI, a sight to behold,
Akin to an ill-fashioned sweater, old,
Yet in its ugliness, a beauty doth lie,
A theme of mirth and revelry, doth it provide.

Go forth, dear friends, with minds untainted,
Expect not grandeur, lest ye be disappointed,
But rather, embrace the bad, the awful,
And in its wake, find joy unbridled.

Early shows, before the club doth open wide,
Are best, my friends, take heed of this advice,
In Christian Audigier's patio, a seat doth wait,
And with a drink, thy spirits shall be light.

So sit, and laugh, and let the badness fade,
For in its place, a merry time shall be made."

"Place ain't too busy. That's what I like about it. Got all I need for my tools and appliances. Even got the part for my fridge so I can change the water filter myself. Feels good to be handy. Customer service is solid, no pressure."

"Methinks 'tis a pleasant place indeed,
Wherein I've tarried oft, in days past.
The chambers, comfortable, meet my need,
Yet, truth be told, the casino's placement doth aggrieve.
A trifling matter, since 'tis nigh the Strip,
And wings, a quarter coin, do please my lip.
I take delight in games of chance,
But, alas! The staff, with scant civility, did dance.
Their gruff demeanor did my patience try,
And, in a rage, I did depart, ere long, to fly."

"Pray, good sir, take seat downstairs, for there doth lie  
The finest ambiance, by my reckoning, a hundredfold.  
And should thou chance to sit on the leftmost side,  
Thy gaze shall fall upon the fair Pittsburgh skyline,  
A sight most wondrous and worth thy careful eye.  
The service, too, was of the highest quality,  
I must confess, the swordfish did please me well,  
And though the shrimp appetizer lacked some zest,  
The food, in general, did prove somewhat dull."

"Hark! Ahead, I called to order pasta,
Two dishes didst I try, with sauces quite tasty,
But salt, oh so plentiful, didst make my mouth pucker,
And yet, I do adore the savory mineral, 'tis true.

The staff, so friendly, owner and cook,
Didst make me feel most welcome, in their book,
But, alas, the atmosphere, didst not agree,
With my fine watch, sharp dress, and imported car, you see.
Awkward, I didst feel, like an unexpected guest,
In this strip mall, not quite the coziest of nest.

The food, good overall, save for the salt,
Flavorful, it was, and not at all dull,
I shall return, and try the pizza, forsooth,
For though it was salty, 'twas not without its charm."

"Upon our visit to this place, the victuals didst please mine taste,
Yet, the cost didst seem a mite too much, in sooth.
A dish of hummus, priced at ten, didst leave me aghast,
For though 'twas delectable, the price didst seem quite vast.

The lamb shanks, which my wife didst order, didst cost
Twenty-three silver pieces, and though they didst taste
Most wondrous, the price didst seem a mite too high,
For what we didst receive, in truth, didst not seem quite nigh.

A draught of apple martini, priced at ten, didst flow,
And a Stella Artois, on tap, didst also show
Itself to be of worth, yet the music, loud and clear,
Didst grate upon mine ears, and didst bring a fear
That I didst shout, o'er the din, to make myself heard.

The service, however, didst prove to be most fair,
And the food, in truth, didst taste most savory and rare.
So, if thou art in search of something new and fine,
This place mayhap shall be worth thine consideration divine."

"Not bad, breakfast from 8 to noon, never experienced! Costs: all 4.90 euros with a drink, a euro cheaper. (Although the most expensive coffee of my life, 3.90 euros for a large cup of normal coffee) Breakfast was good, but every extra wish costs extra (no exchange of butter and marmalade for Nutella possible). Service very attentive, friendly, and quick."

"Aged theater, verily, 'tis true,
Parking, vexation doth it bring anew.
In renovation, mayhap, they do strive,
But service slow, and kiosks, scarce alive.
Seats, not comfort's finest, screens, middling fair,
Yet, near my home, convenience doth bear.
Independent flicks, a gem, doth shine,
Village Square, revival, doth entwine.
Hark! A tip, avoid the line,
Kiosk, confusion, doth entwine."

"Upon our return from YMCA's half-marathon, my spouse and I didst espy a novel establishment, The Nile Cafe. 'Twas nigh impossible to discern its openness, so raw and unadorned didst it appear. Yet, we didst venture forth and sample their Cilantro-Jalapeno hummus, a dish most wondrous and bold! Verily, 'tis my favourite, and I shall endeavour to pair it with various victuals, though it doth belong not on them. Alas, the pita bread, a paltry store-bought affair, didst detract from the overall experience. Still, I shall rally my comrades and revisit this venue, eager to partake of their schwarma, falafel, hasushi, tabouli, and chicken curry soup. Hark! I shall update thee on my subsequent visit. For now, heed my counsel and indulge in their delectable hummus."

"Had Jason's before at catered gigs, enjoyed it. But never ate in. Salad bar, a five. Well-stocked, everything you need. Ordered the Med Wrap, not great. Tortilla too thick, filling skimpy. Wouldn't order it again. Disappointed."

"Hark! If thou dost seek Chinese fare of the East Coast persuasion, this establishment shall serve thee well. We didst order from the menu, eschewing the buffet, forsooth, we do not partake in such. The victuals didst meet our expectations, with generous portions, piping hot, and fresh as the morning dew. Alas, the waitstaff, their English skills were lacking, and their service, poor, yet the atmosphere didst bustle with activity, the cooks and servers shouting betwixt the buffet and kitchen in Chinese. The dining area, alack, didst appear dated and unkempt. For takeout, we shall employ them, anon."

"Thursday eve, two AYCE dinners, 15 bucks a pop. Boarding pass, y'all. 

- Sign up fresh, get two fer one buffet, ya hear me? Don't tell 'em I sent ya. Wink-wink, nudge-nudge. 
- Cash only, no exceptions. Don't be that guy, got it? 
- Thirty-five minute wait at eight o'clock. Hunger pangs, yo. 
- Four bucks to access your own dough. What a gyp! 
- Nigiri sushi, bust. Come early, or it's a bust. 
- Chinese fried chicken, small wings, better than the rest. Word. 
- Tofu stir fry, yum. Hot and sour soup, too. Chicken noodle, yeah. 
- Tacos, always. Not as soggy as Sunset Station. 
- BBQ ribs, bonus! Summer special, you feel me? 
- Chopped sweet potatoes, Sunset gives you the whole shebang."

"Fare thee well, fair sir! How doth thy taste buds fare? Doth thou find delight in fried seafood, prepared with skill and care? Verily, 'tis good, yet somewhat dear. Methinks, at Long John Silvers, thou mayst find a similar feast, at a lower cost, and perchance, with greater haste. In sooth, 'twas naught but mediocre, not worth a verse or prose."
"Decent spread. Seen better, but not bad. Pharmacy folks, friendly and eager to assist. I'll be back for more."
"Comfort grub, no frills, just the basics done right. Good for those who don't want fussy food. Kiddos welcome, prime rib on point, coffee's a bust."
"Good eatery. Biscuit, top-notch. Lunch, decent. Soup, amazing. Catfish, thin. Fried okra, good. Returning."

"Food was decent, ambiance lacking. Employees seemed taken aback by our presence. Paper menus, no music or TV. Felt like we were intruding. Booth had an awkward outdoor sign. Strange seating layout. Food was good, though. Might order delivery, but won't be back for more."

"Saturday nights, Noches Caliente brings the heat. Live band, lively crowd, locals and visitors alike, all eager to dance. Cover's $10, includes a drink, but don't get too fancy. Seating's on three sides of the dance floor, good views of the stage and the dancers. Wear shoes with some grip, that wooden floor's slicker than you think."
"Hole-in-the-wall joints, I dig 'em. Service, though? This place, slow and scattered. Garlic bread, standard issue, still good. Bolognese, solid, but nothin' special. Just another average eatery."

"O, how I do adore Amsterdam, that wondrous city of delight! In days of yore, I didst visit this fair place, and verily, 'twas a night to remember! For on Tuesdays, the martinis didst flow like nectar, and the manicures didst shine like the sun! And, by my troth, the entertainment didst rival the gods themselves! 'Tis a place where mirth doth reign supreme, and joy doth fill the air! So, pack thy bags, my friend, and haste thee well to Amsterdam, forsooth!"

"Ah, Kohl's, thou art a wily store indeed,
Where savings doth await, but only for the keen.
Thou must shop sales and use coupons with great heed,
Lest thou pay too much, and thy budget doth bleed.

But fear not, dear shopper, for I have found
That toys, books, and decor, at Kohl's are profound.
Their selection doth change, like the wind doth blow,
So thou art sure to find the latest, don't ye know.

Kitchen tools, bathroom decor, and frames,
Doth Kohl's possess, in abundance, it claims.
But wait for sales, and use those coupons wise,
For adult clothing, alas, doth come at a prize.

Children's garb, though pricey, doth go on sale,
So bide thy time, and wait for the tale.
Use coupons, stack them high, and watch the cost,
For at Kohl's, savings doth come at any cost."

"Gave 'em a 3, service was lackin', bread crumbs everywhere. First impressions, girls up front were snotty, talked shit about our group. Restaurant's nice, but sat downstairs 'cause some joker rented the top spot. Waiter passed us off to an Asian dude, weird. Food was good, filets, ribeye, sebass, expected. Sides, though, disappointin'. Creamed spinach, mac and cheese, panko all over, gross. Mashed potatoes, no panko, thankful. Boxin' up leftovers, specify, 'cause they only gave us ribeye and one filet, lots left on plates."

"By Jove, fair readers, hear my tale of woe,
Of hunger pangs and forgotten food, didst flow.
To CSN, a savior, didst I make my way,
With haste, to find sustenance, come what may.

A Chipotle, nearby, didst I espy,
And in, didst venture, with hopeful eye.
But lo, the service, slow and cold,
Didst leave me waiting, as time didst unfold.

A fat burrito, didst I procure,
And off, didst hasten, to Building Kilo, sure.
The microwave, didst heat, with speed and grace,
My Smartpop, didst burst, with flavor, in its place.

But, alas, the food, didst lack,
Freshness, of Doug E. Fresh, in the past, didst lack.
The carnitas burrito, with brown rice, pinto, pico, lechuga,
Was but a mere, alright, didst not impress, didst not astound.

Yet, with hunger, didst I consume,
Every morsel, with relish, didst assume.
In conclusion, fair friends, heed my advice,
Visit during lunch, when bustling, does entice."

"Hark, my lord! A call didst thou receive,
From Pep Boys' manager, full of apology.
Thy words, they didst touch mine heart,
And thus, I doth update this review, with stars anew.
Forsooth, 'tis a sign of good management,
To right a wrong, and make amends, with all due haste.
So here's to thee, kind sir,
May thy day be bright, and fortune smile upon thee!"

"Good Thai grub, but pricey for the Third World digs. Been here a few times, and the food's always on point, but the portions are a bit small. Place smells like a mixture of pine and Lysol, gives me a headache. Sketchy location, in a rundown strip mall with some shady businesses. Saw a guy getting a blowjob from an Oriental woman outside once. Not exactly the kind of place you want to bring out-of-town visitors. Friendly male servers, but the women at the front desk can be a bit testy."
"Pack cash, small bills. Change machine dispenses coins. Gift shop exchanges, but skip the fuss."

"Two chambers booked I did procure,
For mother dear and aunt most sure,
The rooms themselves were fair and bright,
But staff, alas, did leave much to plight.
A problem great did we encounter,
With reservation, causing discontent,
Yet call recorded, did save the day,
And sixty-seven dollars went away.
Alas, I cannot speak too fond,
Of hotel, needing upgrade beyond,
Buffet, promised, did not appear,
And pool, in filth, did leave us queer.
RIO pool, far better, doth seem,
Luxor, in need of work, doth gleam."

"This joint's one of the few in Vegas that doesn't try to screw you over. Best time to hit it up's lunchtime. They got great deals for $5.99. I went for grilled chicken with mashed taters and veggies, my buddy got the mushroom penne pasta. My chicken was better than her dish, even though it was a bit dry. But hey, dip it in them taters and suddenly it's alright. 

Thing that sucks is some lady comes by and asks if you wanna take a pic for a souvenir card. Sounds nice, but she's just trying to sell you your own damn picture. Politely decline, that's my advice. Don't know why they do that. 

Oh, and the seats outside the john are uncomfortable as hell. Plastic chairs, man. Restaurant seats are way comfier, so sit inside."

"O, how the service did crawl at snail's pace!
The waitresses and hostesses, young and unprofessional in their attire, didst blend in with the diners, making it hard to distinguish who didst serve and who didst dine. But lo, the sweet potato tots, oh how divine! They didst stir within me a craving that didst linger for weeks. And the burger, verily, it was quite good. I shall return, forsooth, to partake of the PBJ & Bacon Burger, of which all speak so highly. Yet, methinks the slow service doth need some hastening."

"Lotus of Siam didn't quite live up to the hype. Maybe we ordered wrong, or maybe it's just overrated. The exterior's a bit rough, but I've learned that the best spots are often hidden gems. We tried the chicken wings, papaya salad, tom yum noodle soup, and something else I can't recall. It was alright, but nothing special. 

I give it two stars for the grub and an extra for squeezing us in on a busy Friday night. The hostess said it was fully booked and we'd have to wait an hour for a table of four, but she managed to find us a spot after a five-minute wait. 

If you're new to Thai cuisine, this might be a decent starting point."
"Thursdays, we got trivia. Stick around, fights break out at the bar. Cheap Great Lakes draft, too."

"Feelin' like a punk today. But hey, could ya put down yer drink? I need mine served, pronto. You know, after all that nonsense you spouted 'bout orderin'. Beans ain't bad, but service? Shoddy, kiddo. Shoddy everywhere."

"A fair location, yet too vast, alas,
All seemed a bit lost, in such a space.
A shame, indeed, that at a certain hour,
The club and its folk did change their power.
But elsewise, 'twas a place most fine."

"Pure's alright. It's a bit old-school, but still fun. Nice Grecian vibe with all the flowing curtains. Last time I was there, the bartender was preggers. That was something. My favorite spot's the rooftop bar upstairs. Nice view of the Strip."

"I hit up Metro SB outta convenience, not 'cause I love the joint. It's a weird spot, full a weirdos. Never been there at night, but I reckon it gets real wild. Place is havin' an identity crisis, can't tell if it's a dive, club, restaurant, or pool hall. Don't matter though, I'll still swing by. Just remember, they only take cash, so bring your benjamins or use the ATM - but watch out for them service fees, they'll rip you off."

"A-OK, that's what I'd call it. Not ready to commit to full-on fandom yet, but it's a solid start. For me, being a fan means being willing to make the trek downtown during rush hour, no questions asked. And let me tell you, it's worth it. The metal door slams shut with a satisfying thud, adding to the charm of the place. Dinner's not an option, they close at 4, so you better be ready for some serious lunch vibes. I followed Robert M.'s orders and went for the green chile burrito, enchilada style, with a side of beans. The beans were a little runny, but perfect for dipping my burrito bits. The enchilada sauce had a nice kick, too. All in all, I was pleased. A-OK, indeed. I'll be back, just maybe not during rush hour."

"Alack, I didst receive but biscotti from yon biscotti place,
The flavors, fair and good, yet consistency didst lack grace.
I know not what doth trouble mine experience with PIT,
But surely, Italian cuisine shouldst surpass this pitiful plight.

Alas, 'twas overly crumbly, didst fall apart like dust,
Perhaps, 'twas humidity that didst play the villain's role.
Oh, woe is me, for biscotti, once a favorite treat,
Now doth disappoint, and leaves mine taste buds to retreat."

"I met a friend at TT Roadhouse. She said it had a cool jukebox. It was punk rock, but I found some Jawbreaker tracks. Drinks were decent, and the crowd wasn't the usual Old Scottsdale bunch. Nothing special, but worth a visit if you're nearby."

"Methinks the service here is quite divine,
With staff most courteous and kind.
The victuals, though not of highest quality,
Are still a sight to behold, I find.

Chicken makhani, a dish most fair,
We order oft, with joy we share.
Tikka masala, a taste not so fine,
Leaves us unsatisfied, I do confine.

Naan and paratha, both breads most sweet,
Do please our palates, can't be beat."

"Airline's not bad. Like a bus in the sky, you know? Like the seats-wherever deal. But they take their time with the bags. Forever, man. But hey, at least they don't lose 'em like in Burbank or Sacramento."

"A humble bakery, beloved by mine own heart,  
Their pastries and breads, a culinary work of art.  
If only they didst expand their spice and sauce selection,  
And offered more traditional dishes, oh what a perfection!  
But alas, the shelves do oft lie barren and bare,  
So go not at the last moment, lest thou leave with naught but air.  
Yet, claim thou a slice of apple strudel, 'twill be worth thy while,  
For 'tis a sweet delight, that doth make my heart smile."

"Food at Wynn's place, top-notch as expected. Lobsters, perfectly roasted. Filet, cooked just right. Facility, wonderful. Service though, that's where they dropped the ball. Host staff, friendly, welcoming. Showed us to the bar, then to our table. Personal touch, using names instead of shouting them out. Table service started strong too. Rolled out the lobster cart, ordered right away. Good energy, sense of humor. Then, things went south. Waiter and table staff, not so great. No follow-up on food quality. Had to flag them down for drink refills, multiple times. Price point, Vegas reasonable. Menus online, plan ahead. Service issues, that's what'll keep me from bringing guests back."

"Hark! How fortunate I am to come at a time when all are busy,  
So my thoughts on crowds, I cannot truly divine.  
But one of the check-in staff, a rude knave indeed,  
Doth never greet me, nor doth he show any good cheer.  
He doth ignore my requests, and doth make me ask thrice,  
For a towel, a humble thing, yet he doth not comply.  
And though the rest of the staff, do make me feel welcome,  
This grumpy soul, doth mar my stay, with his scowl and ill temper.  
But still, I find this place, to be clean and swift,  
And folk here, do not pester, nor do they persist."

"Methinks I am most pleased with larger menu choices now.  Two employees, I didst ask, when this change didst occur, and neither knew the answer.  A guess, I do make, 'twas very recent.  My burger, verily, was quite good.  Next time, I shall order it medium rare, for 'twas too well done, to mine own taste.  Hot fries, I didst request, and they were brought forth.  My daughter, alack, didst find the pretzels and beer cheese to be lacking.  A tale, we didst tell, to the waitperson, of the faulty cheese.  Beer cheese, by rights, should be orange and creamy.  Alas, 'twas naught but pretzel bites, with a whitish, watery cheese, that didst taste of naught but salad dressing.  Ranch, it didst resemble, sans the garlic.  My daughter, she didst declare, 'twas awful.  And, upon tasting it, I knew somethings amiss.  Flavorless and watery, it didst lack all taste of cheese or beer.  The waitress, she didst not believe, nor didst she offer to replace it.  Strange, methought, for such a thing, she shouldst have done.  My daughter, she didst order appetizers, instead of a meal, and thus, I didst feel a pang of guilt.  Glad, I am, to see appetizers and other sandwiches, now on the menu.  Goldies, I hadst always thought, didst serve but burgers, wings, and pizzas.  I shall return, and try a sandwich, anon."

I came here for a full-body rubdown. It was alright. But the place could use some improvements. One big room, and all the noise from other folks gets distracting. Wish they had some privacy screens or somethin'. Didn't feel too relaxed, but I guess that's what you get for the price.

The gal who worked me over was nice enough. Started out gentle, but man, she really dug into my shoulders. They're still sore the next day.

And then there's this weird thing at the end. You gotta pay up front, and your masseuse just stands there, waiting for a tip. Feels like they won't let you leave 'til you cough up.

It was an experience, but I probaby won't be back.

"Thou asketh why three stars didst I give, and not five?
'Tis due to ambiance, dear friend, which didst falter. A winery visit shouldst be a pleasing sight, yet naught but dim silence didst greet mine eyes. No music didst fill the air, nor crowds to enliven the space. The servers, too, didst dress in humble garb, a stark contrast to the finery I hadst hoped to behold. 
But fear not, for the food didst make amends, in part. Bruschetta, alas, didst disappoint, being naught but plain toast, small and lacking in flavor. Yet, mushroom risotto, twisted burger, and mac and cheese didst delight, each dish a culinary triumph. Thy taste buds shall be pleased, I do confess. 
The service, too, didst impress, with swift and friendly attendance. 
In conclusion, my dear spouse and I didst enjoy our repast, yet the evening's memories mayst fade, shouldst we ponder future dates."

"I heard Sephora started carrying Korres, so I checked out their new store in Fairview, Pointe Claire. Turns out, Sephora Quebec doesn't carry it due to packaging regulations. What a joke. Consumers will always find a way to get what they want, even if it means shopping online and paying $5 shipping from the US. Sephora had a good selection of brands, not all girly, but staff were pushy about the $150 creams. I'd recommend researching brands beforehand, some were just there because of compliant packaging. Prices were similar to elsewhere, but some products had a premium attached due to limited availability. Sucks that Canadian Sephora orders over $150 have free shipping, while US orders over $50 do. Check out SkinStore.com instead."

"Methinks 'tis a fair outdoor mall, more suited for those of advanced years, my dear. On a day of warmth, 'tis a pleasant place to stroll, with mist sprays all about, and eateries aplenty to sate thy hunger."

"Hark! A tale of haste and prudence I shall tell,
Of a journey to Vegas, on the Fourth of July,
A last-minute trip, with naught but fate to guide,
We flew in swiftly, and with speed did arrive.

A cab we hailed, and in ten minutes' time,
Didst reach our destination, with nary a dime.
The fare was fair, and with a gratuity,
We paid the sum, and with ease didst enter in.

Six of us, in a suite of two bedrooms, didst abide,
With kitchen full, our needs didst satisfy.
Away from glamour and glitz, we didst choose,
This humble hotel, with shuttle service, didst cruise.

MGM, Mandalay, and airport, didst they take,
And though 'twas not the best, our stay didst make.
An OK rating, we didst give, I pray,
For other hotels, along the strip, didst sway.

A word of wisdom, let this be a sign,
To heed the call, when thy cab doth arrive.
Be prompt, my friends, and tarry not,
Lest thou be left, with naught but regret.

So heed this counsel, and with haste,
Make thy way, to thy appointed place.
For in this city, where lights doth gleam,
Punctuality, doth reign supreme."

"Eastern's got some decent bakeries, but Freed's ain't what it used to be. My family's been gettin' birthday cakes there for years, but the quality's taken a hit. 

I came back from Korea, and Freed's was the first place I went. Their strawberry shortcake, black forest, and fruit tarts were top-notch. But after a few visits, I noticed the cakes were too sweet and a bit dry. Maybe my taste buds changed, or maybe their prices just went up for no good reason. 

People say the service is lackin', but it's more like it's hit or miss. Sometimes they're on top of things, offerin' samples and chattin' with customers. Other times, it's like they don't care."

"Took the fam here after getting a coupon. Liked the joint's vibe, seemed clean too. But no kiddie menu? That stunk. Staff said we could order plain, so we did. Paid six bucks for a burger for our six-year-old. Same with the dogs. Get a Chicago dog, hold the good stuff. Fries were separate, but the large was enough for us all. Ordered waters, got tiny plastic cups. They make bank on drinks, but c'mon, it's Arizona! We need water. 

Food was decent though. Burgers were small, but tasty. Wonder how American cheese made it onto the all-natural menu. 

Might come back, but won't go out of our way."

"We holed up here for our Vegas trip. I'd have preferred a burlap sack. Renovations take time, sure, but this joint's got some work to do. Four buildings, and my buddy's in the old one. Two beds, a TV, and that's it. Front desk service? Non-existent. Bellhop looks pissed. My room was decent, but why not all like that? World Fare Buffet? Disgusting. Food court's got nothing good. This place needs a serious upgrade to compete."
"DH and I hit Upper Crust for happy hour. Pizza and wings, both on special. Pizza, Grimaldi's style, good. Wings, one star. Dark ambiance, needs color. Plenty TVs for sports."

"Methought I was in quite a pickle, torn twixt three and four stars, good sir!  

The potions, crafted with care, yet lacked a certain je ne sais quoi, a spark, a flourish, a flair, if thou wilt.  

The hall, though bare, didst possess a certain charm, alack, 'twas empty, save for us, upon a Sunday eve, at eight, when most do seek their pleasure.  

The service, middling, a single servant, yet sufficed for our small band, and he, though not effusive, didst speak the truth, all drinks, he said, were good, and that was that.  

And thus, we chose, Agnatha and Anni, August 21st, 1959, two draughts, the former, crisp, tart, strong, yet, ice, small, didst mar its beauty, and the latter, smoky, not to mine taste, yet, if such be thy desire, 'tis a good choice, forsooth.  

And thus, I say, I shall return, for convenience's sake, close by, solid drinks, and no worry of a table, a goodly spot, in sooth."
"Sushi, great. Spicy tuna, must-try. Steak, fillet mignon, decent. Chicken, dry, but saved by teriyaki sauce. Impressed, overall. Back in town, will return."

"Hark! The victuals here be passable, yet naught doth stir within my breast a fire of delight. No dish doth stand apart, ne'er to impress, nor doth it e'er offend. I have partaken of their fare a pair of times, and though the attendance be courteous, the viands themselves seem dull and lacking zest, as if they came to table straight from freezer or packet."

"Hark! A gathering at the Ritz doth lead us to Bistro 24's bar and restaurant, where we find solace in a delectable spread. On a Friday eve, no less! A feast for the senses, indeed. 

A buffet of appetizers, fit for a king, doth include Blue Point oysters, lobster bites, seared tuna with wasabi cream, filet mignon bites, shrimp, duck, and cheese delights. 

And then, a sushi stand, a veritable treat. 

Outdoors, the grill doth beckon, with filet mignon, lamb chops, organic salmon, grilled shrimp, and mashed potatoes, all vying for attention. Grilled greens, a delightful accompaniment. 

Lastly, the dessert stand, a haven of indulgence. 

And let us not forget the wine list, a fine collection, indeed."

"Methinks some of the finest dining experiences doth occur when thou dost almost pass by the establishment. Verily, 'tis a humble abode, yet the culinary delights within do make one grateful for the unassuming location.

The exterior, alas, doth leave much to be desired, and the environs are not the most salubrious. But fear not, dear gourmand, for this petite eatery doth boast a warm and welcoming ambiance, spotless tables, and a menu that doth delight.

My comrade and I didst chance upon Las Glorias, our curiosity piqued by a token of appreciation. And, by the stars, what a find! The tortilla chips, crispy and fresh, didst complement the delectable bean and salsa dips. The rice, cooked to perfection, didst accompany the generous portions of our meals. My companion, a connoisseur of chile rellenos, didst declare this rendition among the best she had ever savored, the batter light and fluffy, the cheese abundant.

We shall, without doubt, return to this culinary gem, coupon or no coupon, for 'tis a veritable treasure trove of gastronomic joy."

"Ere I purchased the Groupon, I perused each review,
So well prepared, I knew what lay in store.
A master of delay, I waited till the last,
And fortunate was I, for they found a way to accommodate me.

Jennifer and Kelly, a pair of skilled lasses,
Tended to my nails, their touch, a gentle caress.
Their work, a hour and a half, did take,
Friendly, they were, and their skill, did make.

Two gripes, I had, a minor quibble,
Awkward, the chair, for my pedi, did feel.
Couches, they had, for the ladies, fair,
More comfortable, it did seem, I did declare.

Nude shades, my preference, they lacked,
Explained, they did, their policy, quite attacked.
One more visit, discounted, I shall have,
Then full price, a pretty penny, I shall crave."
"Food and service, top-notch. Creepy guy with dog, unnecessary. Health code violation, likely."

"Reserved a table for me and a mate during Restaurant Week. Atmosphere was decent, if a bit lackin' in character, but the drinks were strong and good. Started with the pickle plate, had a variety of veggies. For the main course, had the pan-seared trout with barley risotto. Nice job on the cookin', real tasty. Dessert was key lime pie, couldn't resist. Overall, a good time, lookin' forward to comin' back and tryin' the regular menu."
"Sat outside by the fire on V-Day. Classy joint, great sangria. Local singer, Sarah, performs most Saturdays. Perfect spot for a romantic evening or laid-back gathering with pals."

"Hark, good sir! In fair Las Vegas, where we lay our scene,
There's a Chinese buffet, most wondrous to be seen.
'Tis our go-to place, where we doth often dine,
For freshness and variety, it doth shine.

Their sushi bar, with stickers of freshness, doth abound,
And Mongolian barbecue, a feast for the ground.
Pick thy own dishes, and they shall be cooked with speed,
A veritable feast, fit for a king's need.

The hall is spacious, with many a table and chair,
Yet rarely doth one find a wait, for the crowd doth thin.
