The food, in heaps, doth flow, like a bountiful stream,
Fresh and hot, a true delight, a dream.

Crawfish, both hot and cold, doth please the taste,
Soups and Chinese dishes, of every kind, in haste.
From fried rice to wanton soup, and pizza for the young,
This buffet doth offer, a true culinary throng.

So, gentle reader, take heed of this review,
And hasten thee well, to this Chinese buffet anew.
For thou shalt not regret, the price thou doth pay,
'Tis a feast, most wondrous, in every way."

"Hark! A Bricktop's update doth come anon,
And with it, news of their most excellent brunch.
Forsooth, my friend did sing a sweet melody
Of Bricktop's feast, and thus, we did converge
Upon this SouthPark haven, with haste and glee.

Their brunch menu, diverse and grand,
Doth rival their lunch and dinner fare,
In style, New American eclectic, 'tis true.
A bloody mary bar, thou mayst create thy own,
Or choose from special drinks, like blood orange mimosas,
Bellinis by the carafe, a wondrous sight, indeed.

My taste buds, they did dance with joy,
At the French Toast, a dish most divine,
Brioche slices, big and fluffy, with caramelized bananas,
Warm maple syrup, fresh whipped cream, and crispy bacon,
A feast fit for a king, or queen, for that matter,
All for the sum of eleven silver pieces.

If thou art feeling quite indulgent, fair sir,
Do try the bite-sized homemade doughnut starter,
Thirteen sugary doughnuts, with dipping sauces three,
Raspberry, chocolate, and vanilla cream, a delightful treat.

The brunch bill, it may rise high and steep,
But fear not, for 'tis worth each penny, mark my word.
So, give Bricktop's a visit, and revel in their cheer,
For their brunch, it doth rival any other, I do aver."

"Hark! Cantina doth rock indeed,
A place of gustatory wonders, 'tis decreed.
Though exterior doth not suggest such delight,
Within its walls, a feast doth take flight.

On weekends, young and loud doth throng,
But fear not, 'tis no fraternity strong.
Reserve a table, wait thou shalt,
Yet, trust me, 'tis worth it all.

Cantina boasts all that's good and fine,
Margaritas top-shelf, a taste divine.
Kiwi/Strawberry Special, try thou must,
A refreshing twist, a flavor just.

Good Mexican brews, on tap they flow,
Drink up, my friend, for all do so.
Food, oh food, how to describe,
Chopped tostada salad, a dream come alive.
Refried beans, pulled chicken, all doth please,
But Kobe beef fajitas, my heart doth seize.

Back I shall go, but plan not I,
A big night, for full and tired doth lie.
Scene is fun, loud, yet a gentle warning,
Eat, drink, enjoy, but pace thyself, my morning."
"Food's great here. Gets packed at lunch, though. Best come early or late if you wanna grab a seat."

Ale of low price, victuals of worth,
In this place, ye shall find what ye sought.
Loud it may be, but 'tis to be borne,
For in a dive bar of blue collar sort,
Such clamor is to be expected, no doubt.

In fair Montreal, we chanced upon a tavern old,
With prices reasonable, our spirits bold.
The open air did grant us fine views of folk,
And staff, most kind, did our hearts beset.
But lo, dear friends, the victuals they did lack,
Save grilled cheese, hot plate-cooked, a sorry snack.

"Hark! Borealis, a restaurant most fair,
In Cambridge, doth my heart ensnare.
Their slogan, think globally, act locally, they do bear,
With food and drink, all sourced nearby, with care.

Their menu, diverse and changing, doth delight,
With flavors, fresh and locally in sight.
Ontario beers and wines, their list doth boast,
To quench thy thirst, with joy and toast.

The service, though not always grand,
Doth serve with purpose, hand in hand.
A converted period building, old and gray,
Doth house this eatery, with charm in play.

A patio, large and concrete, doth grace,
The front, with seats, in sun or shade's embrace.
Check specials, dear, for drink deals galore,
And savor, thus, this place, forevermore."

"Verily, 'tis a wondrous shoppe, where treasures lie hid,
A chance discovery, fortune's whim, doth provide.
For though the wares be varied, and fortune's hand doth play,
I've found, each time I entered, riches beyond compare.

BabyGap jeans, a prize most fair and bright,
Janie and Jack, The Children's Place, in abundance doth shine.
My heart doth sing with joy, for this shoppe doth hold,
A trove of gems, fit for a queen, or so it doth seem.

And now, with child once more, the maternity sect,
Doth call to me, with promise of comfort and ease.
So shall I venture forth, and see what wonders lie,
In this, my favorite shoppe, where bargains doth abound."
"Wine snob? Don't let the name fool ya. Plenty to sip on here. Lunched there, impressed by the staff's hustle and grub's quality."

"Hark, where sauce doth reign supreme, and toast doth hold its own! Canes' chicken, alas, doth lack a certain je ne sais quoi, and fries, they do not stir the soul. But, by the stars, their sauce doth make up for all else! 'Tis so divine, I must request four extra servings, that my chicken and fries may bath in its glory. Alas, poor slaw, forsooth, doth pale in comparison, so I do substitute more toast, in its stead."

"O, how my heart doth sing with joy and mirth,
For this place, it doth be my utmost dearth!
Both locations, they do please mine eyes,
But the west side, it doth take the prize.

A score of vegetarian dishes, they do proffer,
And I, a creature of habit, do devour them with great zest.
The Bruschette Salad, it doth delight,
And the Athens Fries, they doth make my senses take flight.

Verily, I say, this place doth hold a special place,
In mine heart, it doth find its dwelling space.
For those who seek good food and cheer,
Come hither, friends, and cast away fear!"

"Driving through Henderson, searching for a decent spot to grab some grub. Strip malls everywhere, chains galore. Almost gave in to Taco Bell when I spotted a gem - Trader Joe's! Newly opened, it shined like a beacon in the desert. Clean, spacious aisles, stocked with all sorts of goodies. Best part? Not mobbed like the city locations. 

Hit up their pre-made sandwiches, few veggie choices, but scored a PB&J lunch bag for $3.49. First time seeing such a treat, and it hit the spot. Half a PB&J, crisp apple slices, 100 calorie cookies, string cheese, mini water bottle. Bread was a bit dry, PB&J filling a tad stiff, but the rest kept me satisfied. 

Solid deal for under four bucks. Hoping to find it again when I return to SF."

"In this locality, there be few eateries to choose from, thus Squid Ink doth quench mine appetite for sushi. More oft than not, I do opt for takeaway o'er dining within its walls, and service hath been prompt with victuals of passable quality. Their happy hour, methinks, doth offer fair value, provided thou art content with simpler rolls. Worthy of mention, 'tis a tad dear in price for its worth."
"Airports, people review 'em? Like they got choices? Like they pick cities based on the airport? Crazy, but true. Eight hundred plus reviews, that's just nuts."

In fair Tryst, where once the crowds did throng,
And Marquee, XS, did reign supreme,
Now dwindled to a quieter song,
Yet still, a lovely sight to see.

The sister club, with waterfall so bright,
And lights that dance, in shimmering delight,
A place where maidens can let loose their might,
And men, with phones, do capture their sight.

The music played, a joyous melody,
The bars, they bustled, full of energy,
But we, a group of four, did not tarry,
For we sought more, than just a drink to carry.

We went, at one, when night's dark veil did fall,
After a show, KA, which did not enthrall,
And gaming tables, where we did partake,
Did give us courage, and a buzz to make.

I put my name, upon a list, to gain,
Entrance, at one, without a strain,
The door folk, kind, did let us pass,
Without a fuss, or any task tolass.

Thus, Tryst, though not as crowded as before,
Still holds a charm, and magic in store,
For those who seek, a night of fun and bliss,
Shall find it here, in this fair Tryst's kiss.

"Methinks 'tis a bit steep, the cost of these wondrous sandwiches,
For two or three of them doth it take to sate my hunger's pangs.
But still, the taste, oh how it doth delight!
A place to visit with friends, and savor each bite.
The line, alas, doth stretch on, a wee bit long,
But patience, dear friend, shall be thy guide,
For when thou dost partake of this culinary joy,
Thou shalt find that 'twas worth the wait, I do avow."

"Twas our tenth year of matrimony, and thus,
We didst venture forth to dine,
At yonder restaurant, known far and wide,
For its fondue, most divine.

Afore, we hadst been, and knew full well,
What wondrous delights didst lie in store,
But now, the menu boasted greater choice,
To tailor to each guest's desire.

With Groupon in hand, we didst present,
Ourself unto the waiter, who didst attend,
With courtesy and grace, our every need,
And made our evening most pleasant indeed.

The Swiss cheese fondue, alas, didst not,
Entice my taste buds, as I had thought,
But my dear husband, he didst find it fair,
And thus, 'twas likely just my own fault.

The other courses, they didst delight,
And served in portions, reasonable and right,
So that we both didst feel sated,
And the single dessert, we shared with joy.

The service, mayhap, a mite slow,
But then, this place, it doth not cater,
To those who seek a hasty meal,
So we didst not mind, nor didst we fret.

In truth, I do enjoy a leisurely feast,
And thus, 'twas a most pleasant evening, indeed,
For which, I do give thanks, and praise,
Unto the chef, and all the staff, who didst provide."

"Went to Caffe Boa after seeing Payton slaughter a pig at Devoured. Had to check it out. Ordered fries in a big paper cone as an appetizer. Damn good. Sauces were great too. Calzone was decent, but not what I expected. Flatbread was strange, but the fillings were good. Service was fine, patio was nice, but the strip mall vibe wasn't my thing. Hope the rent is worth it."

"Hark! If thou hast perused my ramblings, thou wouldst know
That franchise eateries hold little sway with me.
But lo! Texas Roadhouse, an exception doth make,
A place where service, steak, and value do abound.
I've visited eight of their establishments wide,
In five states diverse, and found naught to deride.
This location, too, doth meet my lofty standards,
Our server, skilled; the victuals, savory and neat;
The call ahead seating, a minute's brief delay,
A trifling inconvenience, soon forgot, I ween."

"Smooth, rich, flavorful...vegan?  I didst harbor doubts about attempting soy gelato, but after sampling the spicy chocolate, I was ensnared.  A medley of chocolate soy and regular mixed berry didst grace my palate, and though both were delectable, the mixed berry was somewhat icy in texture, lacking the velvety smoothness of its counterpart.  The spicy chocolate didst boast a wealth of rich, spicy flavor, with nary a hint of soy's tangible essence.  Verily, a most excellent establishment for indulging one's sweet tooth!"
"Haven't been here in years. Saw 'Takin over the Asylum' today. Great show. Theatre's a real beauty, classic style, big chandelier. Students get \u00a35 tix on Wednesdays."

"Alexander Michael's, a spot on the 4th ward, serves up solid grub, good drinks, and top-notch company. If you're in the neighborhood, it's a place you'll return to often for a no-frills meal and quality brews. I had the chicken pita, and it hit the spot - juicy bird, flavorful seasoning, and a sturdy pita. Beans on the side satisfied my protein craving without the usual fries temptation. The joint's got character, too - a beam in the ladies' room that's a popular target for unsuspecting visitors, and a menu that shares the house's history. My only gripes are the TV in the dining area (can't folks eat without the tube?) and the low ceilings (cozy, sure, but not ideal for soaking up sunlight). Still, Alexander Michael's is worth a visit."

"Verily, this place doth please mine eyes,
I do beseech thee, give it a try.
Upon entrance, gaze downward, friend,
For thou dost stand upon a fishy fiend.
The decor, most trendy, doth impress,
And atmosphere, most chill, doth bless.
A drink we did imbibe at bar,
Upon a Wednesday eve, most fair.
Then forth we went, to patio's embrace,
Where dinner did await, with nary a trace.
Sushi, most delectable, doth delight,
Freshness, in every morsel, doth take flight.
Alas, one quibble, I must confess,
The bathroom sink, a wondrous mess.
Faucets, they do not work, I do declare,
Unless with force, the handle thou dost slam,
And then, the water doth spray, most queer,
In errant bursts, a sight most strange, I fear.
Yet, all else, most excellent, doth be,
This place, a gem, doth shine, for thee to see."

"Furr's Restaurant, a blast from the past. Grand and Sun City, just off the 101 Highway. Been around since the 50s, but still looking sharp. Had a swell time with some Yelp buddies - Rand, Mike, and Scott. Cafeteria-style, but you can go back for more, all for the same price. No digging through leftovers, just straight up service. Classic American grub, try a bit of everything. Tasty and fresh, can't wait to go back."

"Culver's, been there plenty. Son loves it, cheese curds top-notch. Pricey? Sure, but worth it. Five Guys, tried it, no comparison. Butter Burger, any day. Culver's, best in Surprise, hands down. Better than Five Guys, half the cost. No complaints on prices. Shakes, good. Burgers, fries, good. Cheese curds, win."

"Friday night, my wife and I hit up this joint. Nice weather, so we sat outside. Place was packed, but we didn't mind. They got an English menu, thank God, 'cause my French is rusty. \n\nThey got a ton of pizza options, too many if you ask me. Took us a bit to decide. But we did, and that pizza was damn good. Crust was spot on. So many toppings, we needed utensils. Service could've been better, though. Had to flag the waiter down multiple times for more water. Still, I'd go back."

"For twenty-five years, I've brought folk to this fair place,
To celebrate occasions most joyous and bright,
With sons' teachers, too, when they retired,
And visitors from afar, to dine on Sundays right.
The view, by day or night, cannot be beat,
A true delight, that doth please the senses sweet."

"Fair priced, delicious plant-based dishes, served with grace and care. Tunes play softly in the background, as I sip my tea and ponder life's mysteries. Though the menu be small, 'tis more than made up for by the sweet, sweet pies that lay within. A cozy space, where one can work and dine, free from distractions and worldly cares."

"O, how I adore Grand Lux Cafe, a place most fair and bright!
Though not as grand as the Venetian site, 'tis still a wondrous sight.
The servers, friendly and attentive, make our dining experience delightful.
The atmosphere, spacious and clean, doth please mine eyes and senses.
Aye, verily, a joy 'tis to partake of victuals herein.

Methinks, dear friends, thou shouldst try the Molten Chocolate Cake,
A sweet indulgence that doth live up to its name, by the lake!
So, order it forthwith, lest ye wait overlong,
For 'tis prepared with care, and taketh some twenty minutes to arrive, ere ye can savor its rich, chocolatey delight."

"Amidst the throngs of travelers, I did find
A haven in this hotel, clean and fair.
The chamber, spacious, modern, and divine,
Did boast a bed most comfortable, with pillows rare.

The shower, too, did please mine eyes,
With shelf and lighting, pressure that doth rise.
A mirror, lit and swiveling, did allow
Me, shaving in the shower, a gentle repose.

The halls were quiet, ventilation fine,
A testament to comfort, all divine.
The staff, though pleasant, cooperative,
Did falter somewhat, with room service unpredictive.

Yet still, the site, most fortunate,
Not on the Strip, a blessing, most elate."

"O, how I love this place! 'Twas through the Phoenix LocalDines website that I first didst stumble upon it, and since then, 'tis been the go-to date night restaurant for mine wife and me. We've only e'er ordered from the dinner menu, so I cannot speak to the quality of aught but the items they offer in the evening. Yet, ne'er have we been disappointed, and the variety doth keep us returning to try new dishes. \n\nDo try the Blue Corn Enchiladas and Chimi with sour cream green chile sauce. And, in sooth, do order the Guacammus and Waffle Fries for appetizers... thou shalt not be disappointed!"

"Methinks 'twas a most pleasant sojourn we had at this place, my friends! Arriving betimes on a Thursday eve, we didst partake of their libations, and lo! The bartender didst inform us that all well drinks were gratis for the first hour. A most fortuitous circumstance, indeed! Alas, poor wight, the one amongst us who didst order a drink of higher price didst pay dearly for his folly. The ambiance was most tranquil, with seats aplenty and music that didst stir our spirits. Mark me, good sirs, this place doth merit a visit, despite its location from the Strip. 'Tis worth the small fee for a hackney coach, arrive betimes, and take advantage of their generosity in offering well drinks without cost."

"Methinks this place doth get a bad reputation, my dear. Forsooth, 'tis true it may not boast the quaint charm of Wrigley Field, yet the seats are soft and cushioned, the weather doth never mar the game, and real grass doth cover the field. Moreover, the layout doth seem most cleverly designed, far better than any ancient ballpark. Why, one need not journey far for a piping hot dog or a privy, I do declare! \n\nAnd let us not forget the Suns, good sir. In the past decade, the Diamondbacks have been the local major sports team most likely to win a championship in any given year, anon."

"Mystery Castle, a strange and wondrous place,
Where cheap materials found new grace.
The builder, a man of curious mind,
Didst use recycled goods, so fine.
Burned bricks, a sight to behold,
Didst fascinate me, young and old.
The tour, a joy, a delight,
With guides, so kind and bright.
Cash only, the price we paid,
Worth it, I didst not hesitate.
But the creator, a man of ill repute,
Didst abandon his daughter, so cruel.
A castle, for his kin, he didst build,
But his actions, didst leave a stain.
His wife and child, he left behind,
And though he gave them wealth, unkind.
Mary Lou, a woman of intrigue,
I wished to meet, alas, she didst not arrive.
A unique experience, indeed,
But the father's tale, didst leave a seed.
Of sadness, of regret, of pain,
A lesson, to ponder and maintain."

"Verily, fair friends, the service here doth please,
But lo, the prices now do cause dismay.
Forsooth, the cost of dining here hath grown,
And withal, the victuals' taste doth wane.
Thus, I do say, my visits now are fewer,
For 'tis a pity to pay more for less, anon."

"Aye, fair Parc Jean Drapeau, thou bring'st back fond memories of days past, when first I courted my love, my heart's desire. Each eve, we'd stroll an hour long, amidst thy verdant paths and shaded nooks, our spirits lifted by thy beauty and grace. Thy winding trails, thy tranquil spaces, and all the merry festivals that bloom within thy borders, make thee a jewel of Montreal, a treasure to behold. When seek'st a pleasant day beneath the sun, and wish not to depart the isle, then hie thee hence, and revel in thy charms."

"Taco joint gave us too much grub for our buck. Not complaining, but damn, lotta food. Carnitas, best I've had in ages. Crispy, flavorful, perfect texture. Tortilla, hot and fresh. Service, friendly and quick. Open 24/7. My only gripe, taco shell too hard, overcooked. Everything else, perfect."

"This joint's got a ton of stuff, and I mean a ton. Big selection, too. Would've picked up some nice pieces if I hadn't already spent a pretty penny at the outlets. Women's section's huge, way bigger than what they got in San Francisco. Place is packed, loud as hell, too. Didn't appreciate the cashier only taking plastic, made everyone else wait longer. They got these pull-baskets instead of real carts, like in SF. Poor sap who's gotta clean this mess at the end of the day, my heart goes out to 'em."

"Methinks I've supped here oft, and ne'er didst fail  
To savor well the victuals they didst proffer.  
A family-owned establishment, 'tis clear,  
For diversity of dishes, staff, and cheer.  
Their bill of fare doth boast an Italian bent,  
With prime rib, pork, seafood, and Caesar's mint.  
Yet, I, a fool, do stick to pasta's embrace,  
For fear of change, and habit's steady pace.  
But linguiu with king crab, and leeks so fine,  
In lemon butter sauce, doth make my heart entwine.  
My spouse, a traditionalist, doth swear by spaghetti,  
And Kobe meatballs, that doth make his eyes light up so brightly.  
The service here doth rival the gods above,  
And decor, a feast for mine own eyes to love.  
A wine list vast, and cocktails of every hue,  
Do make this place a den of seduction, anew."

"Hark! A culinary find, my dearest friend,
In KJ kitchen, where doth Yelp doth wend.
A first-time visit, and oh, what joy didst bring,
For food most wondrous, doth our taste buds sing!

Pork belly, oxtail, red wine, pork chop too,
Cantonese style, all dishes didst shine anew.
Complimentary soup and dessert, a sweet delight,
Our hunger sated, with nary a single bite.

The crowd, it swelled, as evening drew near,
We waited patiently, without a speck of fear.
Yet, verily, the wait, it was worth the while,
For flavors such as these, doth make us smile.

Aye, we shall return, at an earlier hour,
To savor more, of KJ kitchen's power.
Great victuals, that didst not disappoint,
A gem found, in this culinary quest."

In this place, the folk were kind and true,
Especially the RN, who helped me through,
In the cardiac unit, his cheer and grace,
Did ease my fears and lighten up the space.

Four stars, I gave, despite the wear,
For things that can be fixed, should be made clear,
The creaky hinges and the shaking faucet,
Cried out for mending, with a quick dispatch.

A maintenance man, with less than half an hour,
Could fix these issues, and make it our power,
To trust John C. Lincoln, for our health's sake,
And know they'll care for us, without a mistake.

"Good folks to work with. Prices are fair. Plenty of stock to pick from. Maybe too much, but that's a good problem to have. Did our downstairs with wood laminate and new baseboards. Looked real nice. Honest people. We'll use 'em again for our upstairs work."
"Las Vegas Ramen, first try, liked it. Spicy tonkotsu bowl, good stuff. Fried rice, gyoza, not bad. Prices, cheaper than Bay Area. Will be back, try Tonkotsu-Shoyu next."

"Methinks Mesa didst surpass mine expectations,
All dishes were full of flavour, no disappointment found.
The ribeye, jalapeno cornbread, both doth please,
A feast fit for a king, or group of friends, at ease.
We chanced upon this place during Restaurant Week,
A fortuitous encounter, their fixed price, a steal.
For sixty-six dollars, a three-course meal we didst partake,
A veritable bargain, our bellies didst shake with delight."

"Been here since a kid. Thai grub's top-notch. Only gripe's the extra rice fee - two-fifty for four or more. Otherwise, best Thai food in Vegas. Recommend it to anyone lookin' for somethin' new or good Thai eatery."

"Methinks 'twas passing fair, with choices many to select.
In a prime site, 'twas simple to detect.
Yet, alack, my mind didst not receive a wondrous impact,
For all that 'twas, didst seem but commonplace, I reckon."

"O, what a wondrous bartender, skilled in his craft!
And entrees, they do please mine taste, so fine and fair.
But lo, the sashimi, priced so high, doth vex me sore,
For half the quality, twice the cost, I do declare.
Alack, the finest fish, I did not find, alas!
Yet, lamb belly, oh so tender, doth make my heart sing.
I didst have the rabbit dish, but, alack, not first,
For naught can compare to lamb, so sweet and fair."

Monday, a day most dire, didst I dine forth with mine own brood,  
For kids, they do eat free, and 'twas a bargain, I didst conclude.  
The hostesses, fair maidens both, didst loiter and converse,  
And I, in fear of poor service, didst ready myself for the worst.  
But swiftly seated, our waitress didst attend to our needs,  
With haste, she took our order, and with speed, our drinks she didst proceed.  
Her care, it was most excellent, for she didst not pester us,  
Nor didst she neglect her duties, but watched o'er us with gentle fuss.  
A man, in plain attire, didst approach, and enquired of our state,  
We answered, all was well, and he, in stealth, didst take my cup,  
And asked, if my waitress had fetched me another ale,  
I told him, nay, and thus, his purpose, I didst infer.  
A manager, perchance, he was, yet a name, or badge, he didst lack,  
And so, I knew not who he was, nor what his aim didst attack.  
But overall, good food, and service, we didst receive that day,  
And happy hour, long and generous, doth stretch from dawn till night's decay.

"Aye, 'tis true, fair friends, that I couldst see
How one might loathe this place, with its long queue
That doth wrap round the building, like a snake
In wait for entrance, with patience most meek.

But fear not, dear companions, for I hadst
A Fast Pass, thanks to some kind connections,
Which allowed us swift passage, past the throng
And into the heart of the revelry strong.

For once within, the devil in me didst stir,
And bade me cast aside my cares and fears,
To join the throngs in their wild abandon,
Dancing with joy, and banishing all tears.

The music, which doth oft my senses vex,
Didst seem, in this place, to be a perfect fit,
And I, who ne'er didst care for house and its ilk,
Didst find myself moved by its rhythmic beat and lilt.

The space, so vast and grand, didst hold within
A multitude of merrymakers, lost in sin,
Their laughter and shouts didst ring out through the night,
As we danced on, till the morning light didst break.

And thus, my friends, our evening didst end,
With feet sore, but hearts full of mirth and zest,
XS, thou hast been good to me, and I do swear,
Thy charms shall draw me back, again and anon, my dear."

"Hark! What wondrous praise doth flow from mine own lips,
For at the Mac Shack, such bounty doth abound.
Their pasta, of high quality, doth please mine eyes,
And fresh, the veggies that do crown the dish.
A friendly staff, with smiles so bright and wide,
Do serve the fare, and make my heart feel light.

This time, I didst choose to take away,
And lo, the flavors didst not fade away.
E'en when I reached mine home, the taste didst linger,
A testament to their most excellent cooking.

Oh, and for those who do prefer meat not,
Fear not, for they have options most fair and bright.
So, to the Mac Shack, give thou a visit,
For there, thy taste buds shall be most delighted."

"Methinks 'tis FroYo place most fair,
Which doth my heart's desire ensnare.
In truth, 'tis nigh to CenPho's bounds,
Where "Twitter Tuesday" doth abound.
Their flavors, consistent, ne'er do fade,
Nor toppings, which my taste doth sway.
A creature of habit, I do confess,
Cookie Monster, my choice, doth impress.
Tiny PB cups, so small, yet sweet,
Do make my frozen treat complete.
Alas, the price, a tad higher, doth seem,
Than other shops, where frozen dreams do gleam.
But Twitter, I do follow, 'tis true,
And Tuesdays, there, my visits do accrue.
A "secret" word, whispered with glee,
Doth grant half-off, a bargain, 'tis to see.
Two frogurt treats, for me and mine own,
For five dollars, a price most unknown."

"Methinks 'tis a fair establishment, where one may partake of a delectable sandwich at a most reasonable cost, especially given its proximity to the city center. I didst sample their All-American offering, which, alack, didst contain cranberries, a fruit that doth not oft please mine taste. My love, however, didst enjoy his Cannonball, a dish that didst earn his hearty approval."

"Matt Goss, Palms hotel and casino. Saw him perform, same power, same passion. Caesar's Palace, next stop. Phenomenal show, guaranteed. Strong stage presence, svelte voice, dancing, loves the audience. Great band, sexy dancers. Singing, moving, grooving. Next chance, Caesar's Palace, definitely. Sexy show, pure sex."

In sooth, I knew not what to make of this place,
Being within the Plaza hotel's embrace.
But lo, the victuals didst please mine eyes,
A poke bowl, my belly didst surprise.
My spouse, she didst try the seared ahi dish,
And found it to be most wondrous and delish.
Yet, if thou art in search of poke,
Poke Express, up Craig road, doth brook.

"In Crystal's mall, next to Aria's grand sight,
Beso lies, a restaurant of delight.
With service swift and attentive, we did find
Our seats and wine list quickly, without mind.

Their prices range from twenty to fifty,
With drinks and sides, seventy-five, you'll be in it.
We tried the oyster shooters, non-alcoholic,
And found them good, the tomato gazpacho, most specific.

Tuna and salmon, both we had,
Prepared well, and portions, not bad.
Sides, separate, but large, we found,
The wild mushrooms, eleven, and too profound.

Dessert, we saw, and couldn't resist,
Churros, amazing, caramel, and cream, we insisted.
Six, we ate, and wondered, how we did,
In the nightclub, upstairs, the bathroom's hid.

Outside patio, and dining room, cozy,
Our table, fountain view, quite breezy.
Empire State, fake, but still, a sight,
Zylo Steakhouse, W's, in mind, took flight."

"Methinks 'tis a grand fete, where joy doth reign supreme! Huzzah!

Verily, if thou dost cherish the radiant sun and merry folk, then hast thou found thy haven.

Aye, the entrance fee may seem a mite steep, yet for a full day's mirth and merriment, 'tis a fair price to pay. I do recommend this festal gathering, with all its delightful trappings."

"Hark! My friend, a local of this fair city,
Didst introduce me to this place, so pretty.
She bade me ride the shuttle, free of charge,
From the strip, where driving is most large.

Sam's Town, the name of this wondrous site,
With interior grand, a western delight.
Two floors of gaming, and a cinema vast,
A buffet, with food most tasteful and vast.

Prime Rib, the theme of the day, so fine,
I did not know of the bowling alley divine.
I shall return, to gamble once more,
For luck didst smile upon me, evermore.

The cocktail waitresses, with drinks so fine,
Came round oft, to make my heart sing.
A great experience, indeed, it was,
I shall take the shuttle, to Sam's Town, anon."

"Methinks I've been a member of Massage Heights for nigh on nine months now, and verily, I fear I shall not renew it again. Forsooth, I do enjoy their establishment, but alas, my workplace, a resort upon the strip, doth offer additional perks which make the experience all the more pleasant. Trow, 'tis the small touches that doth make the difference, such as water and healthy victuals before and after the massage. Yea, though my work doth not provide a membership, I do believe 'tis worth the coin now and again. Thus, I shall fulfill my one-year contract with Massage Heights, but shall not renew it, forsooth, for I believe I may find better service elsewhere."

"Thai places make me wary. Love massaman, but it's hit or miss. Had some bad ones - too salty, undercooked, flavorless. Gave this joint a shot. Their massaman? Damn good. Potatoes cooked right, shrimp still had their tails, but they were decent. Sauce was tasty, like tomato bisque. Enjoyed it. Decor was nice - wooden, not too cramped. Floor could've used a sweep, though (sorry, Pin Kaow). Tried the rice and coconut ice cream for dessert. Rice was gummy. Sticking to the massaman. Will be back."

"Hark! This place doth please mine taste, I say,
In group of many, diverse dishes did play.
Foie gras, spicy crab, and tuna tartare,
For appetites, did make their entrance fair.

And for main course, 'twas surf and turf, they call,
With fois, a huge chunk, and butterfish, standing tall.
On bed of shredded sprouts, black truffle sauce did flow,
Decadence, indeed, doth this dish bestow.

Other dishes, too, didst taste, with glee,
Creamed spinach, gnocchi, lobster au curry, for thee.
Spinach, oh so fine, didst make my heart sing,
Amidst these flavors, my senses did take wing.

Desserts, a trio, didst delight mine eyes,
Chocolate souffle, mix candy bar, and chocolate surprise.
Pistachio ice cream, a worthy mate, didst accompany,
Souffle, the best, a sweet symphony."

This place, my heart doth sing its praise,
A favorite, 'bove all else it raises.
Their Gyros, oh how divine they be,
Lamb meat, so tender, falls apart easily.
Z sauce, a perfect complement, no doubt,
Together, a flavorful harmony, without.
Eight dollars, a fair price to pay,
For such a meal, that doth satisfy.
A combo, with fries and drink, doth come,
For just two dollars, more to succumb.
Give this place a chance, do not hesitate,
It may seem small, but worth the debate.

"Hark, what cheerful spot doth lie before mine eyes!
A place where friends may gather, laugh and love,
And partake in sweet libations, savory bites.
The atmosphere, it doth delight,
As doth the drinks, with prices most fair and bright.
Sushi, nigiri, martinis of diverse kind,
All served with mirth and joy, to make our minds inclined.
And should we sit at yonder sushi bar,
We may behold the chefs, their skills to show,
Preparing our repast, with speed and care,
A feast for eyes and belly, beyond compare."

"Hark! If thou seeketh a burger most fair,
In Las Vegas, this place doth hold a rare gem.
Crisp fries, both sweet and savory, doth abound,
And burgers, oh so juicy, doth astound.

Bahn Mi and Kalbi, twain favorites of mine,
With flavors rich, and spices most divine.
Yet, wagyu and foie gras, a burger most grand,
I have not tried, but heard of its land.

Alas! The ambiance doth leave much to be desired,
A strip mall feel, with naught but concrete tired.
And, alack! The meat, not of the finest breed,
Tasteth of frozen, or CAFO-fed.

But fear not, dear gourmand, for they doth make up,
With dressings and toppings, a veritable feast.
And, hark! A fine selection of ale and beer,
In Las Vegas, where choices be few and far between.

So, if thou art nearby, and hast a mind to roam,
Do seek out this place, and taste its culinary boon."

"Hark! A traveler I, from distant lands,
Didst venture forth to this place, with eager hands.
The crowd, a mix of folk, didst gather here,
Upon a Friday eve, with laughter and cheer.

The service, swift and sure, didst please me well,
And though the privies were not pristine, tell,
I've seen far worse, and so, my heart doth sing,
For this place, I shall return, with joy doth bring.

The draughts, they flowed from tiny pitchers,
And mirth didst fill the air, with each tipsy finger.
Alas, my clumsiness, didst cause a sight,
With drink spilled on myself, and floor, in plain sight.

Yet, shall I not be deterred, forsooth,
For this place, it shall be mine, to revisit, anon.
Aye, 'twas a merry night, with friends and cheer,
And thus, my heart, doth sing, with joy, and love, dear."

"Maggiano's, a place most wondrous,
Where food doth please and service doth astound.
The chicken Alfredo, a dish most delectable,
Doth reign supreme, my heart doth bound.

I have partaken of their other fare,
The chicken francese and potatoes, a delight.
But Alfredo, oh how it doth compare,
A true delight, that doth shine so bright.

The maitre'd, Loray, with haste did seat us,
And our server, a gem, most courteous and kind.
Their service, a true marvel, doth exceed,
In this, Maggiano's doth truly shine."

"A hearty feast, with flavors bold and bright,  
We savored pho, spring rolls, and chicken, oh so right.  
A first-time taste, for me, of Vietnamese delight,  
My senses pleased, my hunger satisfied, day or night.  

The owner, a man of wit and charm, did guide,  
Our choices made, his recommendations, we did bide.  
With ease, we took his lead, our taste buds did cheer,  
For his advice, we found, was quite sincere.  

The crowd, it swelled, the tables full, did tell,  
No room, alas, for large groups, a tale to dwell.  
But fear not, friends, for those who dare,  
To dine at seven, on a Friday, do declare."

"This joint's a crapshoot, friend. Been here a few times, and it's either great or mediocre. Salad bar's always top-notch, though. Even grabbed one to go once. Only open for dinner, so it can get crowded early on. Staff's friendly, so it's worth a shot."

"George Street, a place of wonder, doth host
My dearest shops, where I do oft browse and boast.
Cath Kidston, Penhaligons, Coast and Karen Millen,
A trio of treasures, worth a king's ransom, I reckon.
And Paperchase, a haven for stationery delight,
Where pens and papers do dance in sight.

But alas, not all these shops be for buying,
Some be for show, and mere window-shopping lying.
Yet still, the street doth hold a charm,
With bars and eateries, a culinary balm.

On summer days, a stroll along this way,
Doth bring me joy, and chases all dismay.
The buildings, grand and old, do stand tall,
A testament to history, and a story to enthrall."

"Vegan food ain't my thing, but I gave it a shot. Nighttime, weekday visit. Place had a bohemian vibe, staff was friendly. Ordered the jerk tofu salad to go. Dressing was good, flavorful. Cardboard packaging instead of styrofoam, wooden fork, but still in a plastic bag. Odd, but a good change of pace."

"Hark! Bask in ambiance, plenty of seats doth abound. At the bar, I didst sit, 'twas my desire. Sports on TV, a pleasant sight, while rolls were being prepared, a wondrous delight. Happy hour, on weekends, a time of joy, all-you-can-eat, a feast for a king, a veritable employ. Honey Roll, Honey Roll, a sweet delight, 99 cents, a bargain, a steal, a prize. Crab legs, a half-pound, with dinner, all-you-can-eat, for 9.99, a sumptuous treat. Rolls, fast and fresh, not too much rice, a fan of Rainbow roll, I do confess. Service, slow at first, but later, made up, and then some, a worthy reprieve. On this side of town, in future, Sushi, I shall seek, at lunch, a worthy quest. Kobe burgers, on the menu, a hearty meal, a food coma, it doth seem, a culinary dream. Names and ingredients, clever and bright, a true delight."

Hark! What news is this? A place called Chandler doth abound,
With wings so fine, they do astound.
A champion eater, I do confess,
Yet these wings, they do impress.

The sauces, oh how grand,
Above average, they do stand.
I judged them by the hot,
And found it quite tasty, whatnot.

ATL rub, a flavor so rare,
I didst try it, without a care.
Sweet cool aid, a drink so fine,
Although I do not partake, 'tis divine.

A regular, I shall become,
And try all 18 flavors, ere long.
Chandler, thou art a wondrous place,
Where wings and sauces do entice.
"Lunchtime. Buffet. Many stations. Variety. Some good, some not. Family poll: shrimp, slaw, cornbread, Italian stew, bok choy, carne asada, flan, chocolate cake. That's it."

"Hark! Alack, why doth this place not boast of five stars? 'Tis true, fair friends, for though their victuals be most wondrous, fresh and novel, yet doth the ordering process prove a mite perplexing. And, alas! Their tables, last we visited, didst remain uncleared. But fear not, dear patron, for in time, I do perceive, they shall iron out these wrinkles, and thus, 'twill be a most excellent venue to partake of a swift and delectable pizza."

"This ampitheater, it's a real gem. Easy to get to, easy to park, easy to find your seat. Saw Dave Matthews there in July, had a blast. They let you bring in your own grub, no problem. Nissan Pavilion, that place can eat my dust."

"O, how the reviews didst speak the truth,
Of slow service, a woeful plight.
But when the steak and eggs didst arrive,
'Twas worth the wait, a culinary delight.

Yet, alas, the delay didst stretch on,
For twenty minutes or more, anon.
But still, the taste didst make amends,
For all the time that didst expire."

"Methought, fair sir, when pondering where to dine,
The Greentree Inn didst spring to mind, a place divine.
In all my years, so near yet never had I been,
I thanked the stars that led me thither, 'twas a wondrous scene.

The victuals, oh how delectable they were,
A feast fit for a king, or so it seemed to me.
And as I sat, entranced by atmosphere so rare,
I knew that this, my choice, was truly meant to be."

"Verily, 'tis a pleasure to behold a chain that doth strive for excellence in all they do. In fair California, there doth lie a Habit restaurant, which we didst visit on a whim, and found to be most satisfying. My wife and I, we didst order the same dish, to test the consistency, and lo, it was consistent indeed, and most delectable, I must confess. If thou find thyself in Chandler, with a craving for a savory burger, do not hesitate to partake in the Habit's offerings. Four stars, I wouldst give, for the fare, though somewhat costly, yet worth every penny, forsooth."

"Hark, what greasy delight doth mine eyes perceive? A pizza so divine, it doth leave me in awe. The crust, it doth crackle beneath mine teeth, and the sauce, it doth dance upon mine taste buds with a merry zest. The pepperonis, they doth blanket the piece, a veritable feast for mine hunger. And the cheese, it doth melt within mine mouth, a river of richness that doth never cease. Methinks 'tis a treasure, this New York Pizza of which I speak. A gem hidden amongst the throngs of chain eateries, a place where one may find solace in the form of a savory slice.

But alas, the interior, it doth lack a certain je ne sais quoi. A few tables and chairs, booths and televisions, nothing more, nothing less. Yet, who needs grandeur when the food doth shine so bright? Forsooth, I shall return anon, to partake in their delectable wings, fries, and subs. Aye, for this humble abode doth hold a special place within mine heart, a haven of gastronomic joy."

"Hark, what news is this? A place most fair and bright,
Where one can dine within, or out in the light.
A booth with TV, for those who wish to see,
Or on the patio, with thy mut, so free.

The aju sliders, oh how they delight,
With flavors rich, and savory bite.
So come, my friends, and taste for thyself,
For this place truly doth rock, and doth excel."

"Verily, 'tis a rare delight to find a place where service doth excel,
Amidst the city's glitz and glam, where kindness doth abound,
In this fair restaurant, all are pleasant and bright,
E'en the staff, with smiles so warm and welcoming, doth ignite.

One star, a quick assembly line, yet friendly faces doth greet,
A fine beginning, indeed, for a meal most meet,
Two stars, the owner doth introduce himself, and doth ensure,
Our pleasure, with meats to sample, and a word of cheer.

Three stars, the Kalua pig, a flavor so divine,
Doth burst forth in thy mouth, a culinary shrine,
No fast food staple, this, but a feast fit for a king,
A true delight, and worthy of thy praise, I do sing.

Four stars, the coconut bark, a treat beyond compare,
A sweet indulgence, worth each penny, beyond compare,
A shame to share, so get thine own, a wise decision,
For this delicious treat, doth merit thy attention.

Alas, the fifth star, doth lack, for tacos and burritos,
Did fall apart, a mishap, in wrapping and filling, no doubt,
Yet still, a place of wonder, for Hawaiian fare,
With chipotle spice, and flavors beyond compare.

The coconut bark, a memory, doth linger near,
A craving, a desire, doth persist, year after year."

"A swift journey down didst I make from Mesa's heights,
Despite the rabble that didst board the train with me.
Forsooth, 'twas public transport, and I didst bear it well,
Though my legs didst ache from the hard seats, I must confess.
A woeful burden, indeed, for one with Restless Legs Syndrome,
That plagued me still, days after, with pain most grievous.
Yet, for the sake of thrift, I wouldst take the train anon,
Didst save the gas, and hadst naught to do but praise the route.
Alack, my first time, and a costly mistake didst I make,
For my poor car didst get towed, and a $200 fine didst partake.
So, heed my words, good sirs, and mind thee well where thou dost park,
Lest thou suffer the same fate as didst I, in sorrow and in dark."

"Hark, what news is this? A wedding in the sky,
With choppers hovering, doth it fly high.
A package deal, with pilot by our side,
And views so grand, it doth our spirits pride.

Option there was, to add a photog too,
And capture all the moments, new and true.
We chose to do so, and glad we art,
For memories kept, in photos smart.

But video, alas, we did not choose,
For one man's task, it doth not excuse.
The mic, it failed, and my voice did fade,
But still, our vows, in love's embrace we made.

So here's my tip, for those who seek,
To wed in Vegas, in a chopper sleek.
Check well thy mic, ere thou dost take,
Off into the wild blue yonder, forsooth, and make."

"Ahem, my dearest friend, let us speak of dining delights,
In Charlotte, there lies a place, called Fig Tree, a sight most fair and bright.
I chanced upon this eatery, with my love, on a winter's eve,
Their decorations, festive, did our spirits lift and leave.

My heart, it did desire, their grouper, in butter sauce,
With lobster meat, a-top, a feast, most wondrous and grand, I did avow.
And though the cheese plate, good, did seem a bit steep,
At seventeen coins, a price, that did our purses weep.

My love, she chose, a pork chop, alas, a shame,
For it was fatty, and not, to her taste, a worthy name.
But still, I tried, a bite or two, and though not lean,
I savored each morsel, with relish, like a true gourmand, I mean.

The service, kind and prompt, our server, a delight,
Did make our visit, pleasant, and filled with warmth and light.
So though our meal, not perfect, was our night,
For Fig Tree, a spot, most charming, shall we revisit, anon, with delight."

"Dunkin' Donuts, that's my jam. Specifically, the Toasted Coconut and Chocolate Frosted cake. Can't get enough of that combo. Used to go there too often, but they know me now. They know I want the good stuff. No chocolate glazed or frosted glazed, just the real deal. Friendly staff, too. Get the coffee punch card if you're a regular like me."
"Yesterday, my man had lunch with a colleague. They relished it. Keep at it."

"Methinks the tapas selection doth please mine eyes,
My love and I didst partake of diverse dishes,
A couple from each sect, to sample their delight.
The deep-fried artichoke, a favorite of mine, doth shine,
As doth the foie gras, most rich and delectable.
And let us not forget the bunuelos, so sweet,
In deep-frying, they didst attain a wondrous treat."

"A mighty fine establishment, this quaint shop doth be. With outdoor seating and an interior most fair, 'Tis a place where one can tarry and enjoy a cup of coffee, or perchance, partake of delectable pastries. The staff, they doth possess a pleasing demeanor, and their brew, it doth please mine own taste. Verily, I do not oft employ such language, but in this case, 'tis most apropos."

"Upon this eve, my love and I didst dine,
At this establishment, with much design.
The ambiance, pleasant, didst set the tone,
For a most enjoyable evening, all alone.

The service, prompt and courteous, didst abound,
Our server, friendly, with a smile profound.
The victuals, fresh and delectable, didst delight,
Chow Mein, the best, in many a night.

Alas, the sushi roll, Golden Cali, we didst try,
Didst not meet mine expectations, I do confess.
My love, however, didst find it to his liking,
A difference of taste, our palates not aligning."

"Methought I didst not feel most welcome there,
Yet still, the roast beef sandwich with blue cheese didst please me well,
'Twas truly one of the best sandwiches e'er I didst taste,
A culinary delight that doth my senses amaze."

"O, how I love the taro yogurt and mochi balls,
The sweetest treats that e'er did grace these halls!
But, alas, the lack of seats doth cause me woe,
And those collegiate youths, they do swarm, you know.
This place, it doth get loud, and full of strife,
I'll take my yogurt to go, and savor life."

"Hark! A tale of wonder doth unfold,
Of stay at Golden Nugget, stories told.
First time, we ventured forth to roam,
In Downtown Vegas, our hearts did moan.

A suite in Rush Tower, nicer than before,
In Palazzo, luxury we did ignore.
Despite the heat, and lost riches too,
Our spirits high, our joy did break through.

The staff, attentive and kind, did strive,
To make our stay, a pleasant jive.
Clientele, not flashy, nor trashy,
A perfect blend, of class and brashy.

Table limits, food and drink, all fair,
Our poolside fun, without compare.
My wife, a spa day, did quickly book,
A good value, her relaxation took.

With friends, she's keen, to return once more,
But player's card, a mystery to explore.
Downtown Vegas, don't be afraid,
Ziplining, concerts, a joyous parade.

Eagerly, we'll return, our hearts do sing,
Golden Nugget, a treasure to cling."

"I chanced upon this salon nearby and decided to give it a try. Verily, I must say that Kay, the lady who tended to my locks, was quite skilled in her craft. She worked with haste, yet her touch was gentle as a dove's wing. A rare find indeed, for oftentimes speed and skill do not dwell together in harmony. The salon itself was a sight to behold, adorned with vessels of beauty and seats of comfort. The price was fair, and the service, top-notch. A plethora of gel hues lay before me, and the atmosphere did stir within me a sense of tranquility. I give this place a hearty thumbs up, and shall return anon to partake in Kay's expert ministrations."

Hark! For two years, I've come to this place,
Their shrimp fried rice doth please my taste.
'Tis convenient, too, next to my work,
And service, fast and friendly, they do render.
Their lunch menu, a bargain, doth delight,
A feast for little coins, a wondrous sight.

"Hark! I didst order yonder yellow curry,
With chicken, a dish most wondrous and fairy.
'Twas delicious, I must confess,
But alas, the egg rolls, they didst disappoint.
Greasy and flavorless, they didst seem,
A pity, forsooth, for such a noble dish.
Five stars, I wouldst have given, ere now,
But these rolls, they didst mar the whole somehow."

Hark, fair friends! I must confess,
In days of yore, I didst have some strife
With Cox, the cable company of might.
But lo, I didst stick with them in spite,
And in my latest visits, all was right.
Their staff didst work with me, in truth,
To lower my bill, and their service was swift and youth.
So here's a shout-out to Cox, I say,
For their kindness and their helpful way.

"Hark, fair friends! My words do sing the praise Of AZ Humane Society, where compassion doth reign supreme. Their Campus for Compassion, a marvel to behold, Doth house the canine kind with care and tender mold. But lo, my visits thrice didst yield a curious sight, For dogs, alas! were wanting in their kennels bright. Methinks 'tis chance or swift adoptions doth play a part, Yet still, a puzzle doth remain within my heart.

A plea, I make, for more dogs to find their way From county shelters to this haven of the day. For once within, their care doth rival royal throne, With classical music, air conditioned, all alone.

Their design, a stroke of genius, doth provide A low wall, separating kennels, doth abide. Stress doth lower, dogs doth stare not at their peers, And passage doth become a trivial matter, free from fears.

In sooth, this shelter doth excel, a gem beyond compare, A place where dogs doth find solace, love, and gentle care."

"I couldn't wait to get back to a Smashburger after having my first one in Vegas. I got the Sincity burger there and they don't offer anything like it here. Bummer. So, I settled for the Arizona burger. It was okay, but it didn't satisfy my craving for the Sincity burger. Now I'm still waiting for that crave to be fulfilled."

"O, how the memory of thy savory delight doth linger in my mind, Lo Lo's! Thy fried chicken, a dish most divine, hath captured my taste buds and left me in a state of pure bliss. And the waffles, oh how they complement thy chicken so well, a match made in culinary heaven! I do confess, I have not yet ventured to try other menu items, for the #8, the Betty Boop, hath stolen my heart. The Kool Aid, a refreshing delight, doth quench my thirst most satisfactorily. And the macaroni and cheese, a dish most comforting, doth satisfy my cravings for cheesy goodness. Thank thee, Lo Lo's, for another delectable feast! And, fair maidens, take note, for this establishment doth provide a most satisfying repast, fit for royalty."

"Walked in, got a pedi. Staff was friendly, especially the two ladies. Cozy joint, but it was hot as hell. Must be spring. They got a ton of polish options, though. Those chairs with the back massage? Nice touch. Twenty bucks for a basic pedicure. Not bad. Some of the staff spoke Mandarin. Even better. I'll be back."

"In Charlotte, there be a tavern dark and dim,
Where light doth scarce illume the floor within.
No need to clean, the shadows hide the grime,
And patrons revel in the gloom, their sins unseen.

An Irish pub, with twin bars on two floors,
And outdoor seats, for summer storms' assurance.
Corn hole, a game of skill and chance, doth please,
And bartenders, friendly, make the mood most ease.

The peak hours, full of life and noise, doth swell,
But off-hours, quiet, for old friends to tell.
So, if thou seeketh merriment and cheer,
This place, thy heart and soul, shall comfort near."
"Thursday nights, this joint's got a real hometown vibe. Came for the open mic, stayed for the cheap drinks and good times. Can't wait to come back."

"Kabob Grill, not cheap but worth it for the tasty Mediterranean eats. Tabbouleh, potato harra, shawerma, lamb kabobs - all good. Pickled condiments, excellent. Hommos, smooth, could use more lemon. Meat pies and grape leaves, fair. Nice selection of wine and beer, including heavy Ukranian brews. Check Ballantyne mags for coupons."

"O, what a quaint and charming spot to dine!
A bridal shower brunch, I did attend, and 'twas divine.
The victuals, they did please my taste,
Creamy corn porridge, sausage glazed with maple haste.
And apples roasted with cinnamon sugar, oh so sweet!
I chanced upon it, not knowing what to expect,
But glad I was, when it arrived, a culinary inspect.
Five stars, this place could be, but for the staff,
Lax and inattentive, leaving much to be desired.
We, eight ladies, new to this place, didst not know,
Drinks were self-serve, water, coffee, juice to flow.
No mimosa or other drink, we were asked to partake,
Leaving us to figure it out, a puzzle to unmake.
Yet, I do look forward to returning once again,
To savor the flavors, and the charm of this inn."

"Apartment complex felt nice. Spacious rooms with couches, dining table, sink, and large bathroom. Cheap too, got mine for 25 bucks a night. Downsides? Rooms looked a bit dated, stale, and not much to see with a small TV. But hey, it's a few blocks from the strip, can't knock it for that."
"Chocolate bar, milk, peanut butter filling. Smooth. Like Snickers, but no nuts. Clerk, nice, professional."

"Hark! A new eatery doth grace the ground floor of yonder warehouse old,
With high ceilings doubly tall, and mezzanine level, bold.
A warm greeting we didst receive, and swiftly seated were we,
Near windows grand, with arches curved, in candlelight's glee.

The interior, clean and simple, with red glass candles aglow,
Didst give the space a peaceful air, like zen's gentle flow.
All staff, true Spaniards, genuine and reassuring to see,
For tapas lovers, this place doth deliver, as bright as can be.

The menu, in three parts divided, 'Orchard', 'Sea', and 'Farm',
We ordered six tapas betwixt us, and wondered if 'twould suffice.
But fear not, dear friends, for the dishes, though small, were rich and fine,
Pork and mushroom cream sauce, and monkfish, prawn, and squid in tomato's shine.

First time I've savored squid, not rubbery, but melting in the mouth,
A delight! This restaurant, fair and new, doth merit thy south."

"In fair Scottsdale, where chain restaurants doth abound,
We chanced upon a place that did our taste astound.
The reviews on Yelp didst speak of its delight,
And so we ventured forth, with hope in sight.

Upon the back patio, dark yet romantic,
We sat and savored each delicious morsel and draught.
The fare was excellent, as was the sweet dessert,
Our servers, friendly, made our evening's sport.

In brief, a capital experience didst we have,
And wouldst recommend it to all who do crave
A meal most satisfying, in a setting fair,
In Scottsdale's midst, this place doth stand out rare."

"Chips and salsa, best in town. Want 'em all to myself. Fiesta platters for my home gatherings. Good eats all around. Four stars for the occasional shortage, like that time they ran out of Pollo fundido. Still, a solid spot with quick service and a tidy atmosphere."

"A haven of artistry, with atmosphere most cool,
My spouse and I did dine there, seeking lunch most fair.
And lo, the flavors did delight, in sandwiches so fine,
Mango, Cajun fowl, and avocado, a taste divine.

Oh, how the contrast did please, a culinary joy,
The mango sweet, the chicken spicy, and avocado's creamy employ.
A feast most satisfying, a meal most true,
At this artsy place, our hunger did anew."

"Hark! This place doth hold a special place within my heart,
For many friends of mine do toil within the kitchen's art.
Their wares, I must confess, are quite beyond compare,
And oft I come to sample their delicious fare.

The Reuben, oh how grand! The Cajun, a spicy delight!
And let us not forget the Royal, a true gastronomic sight.
But alas, my friends, these treats do come at a cost,
For they are not the healthiest of choices, I fear the most.

Yet still, I say, 'twere wise to share a pastry with a friend,
That way, two flavors thou mayst taste, and thus thy journey's end.
And should thou seek a drink to pair with thy repast,
Fear not, for here they have a fine selection of ale at last."

"Methinks 'twas but a fortnight past,
When to Scottsdale's fair domain,
I chanced to stray with friends in tow,
In search of sushi most divine.

Aye, upon Yelp didst we espy
This eatery, and forthwith didst decide,
To partake of their culinary delight,
And verily, our spirits didst take flight.

The owner, Greg, and Miki, sushi's king,
Didst greet us warmly, and with grace didst bring
Our feast, a veritable cornucopia,
Of freshest fish, and flavors most ambrosial.

Their hospitality, likewise, didst impress,
And in their care, our evening didst pass,
With joy and mirth, and laughter free,
In this, their humble, cozy tavern, we didst be.

So, gentle friends, heed my advice,
And seek this place, where sushi doth entice,
For truly, 'tis a gem, beyond compare,
And worth thy while, thou shalt declare."
"Patio, great. Group of friends, came. Pork plate, yummy. Little Johnny cakes, good. Wasabi mashed potatoes, excellent."

"A feast most wondrous, fit for royalty,
My Mahi Mahi, a dish divine,
And my fair wife, her Salmon did relish,
Both, a culinary delight, a true treasure.
The service, swift and with a smile so bright,
Did make our evening, a pure delight.
To dine again, and try new dishes,
Is my desire, my heart's fond wish."

"By fortune's hand, I pen this review on 4-20 eve,
A day of merriment, when minds are free.
And where, pray tell, doth one seek refuge,
When inebriated, and in need of sustenance?
Cheba Hut, my friends, doth fit the bill,
With toasted subs, that doth fulfill.
So gather round, and heed my words,
For Cheba Hut shall be thy haven,
On this, the day of 4-20,
When thou dost seek a culinary heaven."

"A haven of repose, a spot to dine and imbibe,
In Phoenix's heart, this place doth thrive.
The staff, with smiles and grace, doth serve,
And choices plenty, for all to preserve."

"Verily, a most excellent cut of beef,
A feast fit for a king, or so it seemed.
The service, though, did leave a bit to seek,
But then, I am a Yank, and speed is my creed.
I'd still return, forsooth, whene'er I roam,
For that steak, oh, it doth make my heart sing home."

"Quick-service sushi joint. Order at the counter, pay, and they bring it over. Fill your own drinks. Sushi's decent, nothin' special, but prices are good and service is fast. If I lived nearby, I'd go often."

"This joint? Next day after a hangover, it's my jam. Specifically, their Pho game is on point. Cheap, too. Can't go wrong with a good bowl of noodles. Their Banh Mi? Not huge, but still solid. Everything else? Better than most. Except spring rolls. They're alright. Boba drinks? Got 'em. Just don't expect them to always get your order right. They nod, smile, and still mess it up. Cilantro? Forget about it. But hey, little things, you know?"

"Thou art receiving an additional star, my dear, for two reasons most fair. 
The first, the remodel is complete, and the store doth shine with beauty rare. 
And second, this Iggle doth serve the finest sushi, with quality most true, 
Of all the Iggles in the land, none can compare, I do declare to thee. 
I have consumed many a rainbow roll, from diverse locations near and far, 
But none have matched the excellence of this Iggle's sushi, so divine and rare. 
'Tis a bold statement, indeed, but one that doth hold much weight, I swear. 
For I do love sushi, and desire it oft, with convenience and speed, 
And this Iggle doth provide all three, with quality that doth exceed."

"Diner. Service, hit-or-miss. Atmosphere, nothing special. Menu, pretty good. Tips: share a malt or shake, huge and delicious. Stick with what you like, some exceptions (Meatless Meatloaf). Vegetarian options, fantastic. Three stars."

"Pepperoni rolls, six for $6.49. Worth it? Hell yeah. Woodchuck hard cider, on tap. Deep dish pizza, decent. Sausage chunks too big, needs smaller pieces. Haven't tried thin crust or other menu items. Friendly service, knowledgeable about dipping sauce and drinks."

"Verily, the victuals, attendance, and atmosphere didst impress. Alas, a woeful minstrel didst sully the evening's delight with his wretched crooning of Beatles ditties, causing the departed Fab Four (God rest their souls!) to turn in their graves. Happily, he didst cease his caterwauling ere long. And so, we moved on to the feast...

The calamari, by Jove! 'Twas a delectable sight, with tender, juicy squid, shallots, Asian noodles, carrots, scallions, cashews, and red chiles bathed in a savory sauce. 

Halibut cheeks benedict, with lobster and Hollandaise, didst delight. The biscuits, aye, they were fit for a Southern queen, and the Hollandaise, not too stiff nor too rich, didst complement the eggs to perfection. The accompanying salad, alas, didst pale in comparison. 

Lobster bisque, a hearty thank thee! Not overly creamy, with a generous helping of lobster flavor, and a pleasing texture, it didst warm the cockles of mine heart. 

Asparagus, with Hollandaise, didst shine like the morning sun. Fresh, tender baby spears, they didst make mine mouth to water. 

Corn, oh corn! So fresh and full of life, it didst beguile mine taste buds. I couldst not get enough of its sweet, succulent goodness. 

Bananas Foster butter cakes, a mite too sweet for mine liking, yet others didst find them delectable. The butter pecan ice cream, by the gods, didst steal the show! 

Godiva chocolate cake, with vanilla bean ice cream, didst tempt me sore. Methinks 'twould be a sin to lick the plate clean, but oh, the temptation didst assail mine soul! 

Whitehaven Sauvignon Blanc, a fine vintage indeed! Its light, fresh bouquet didst evoke memories of Kim Crawford's finest. 

From the moment we didst step inside, the service didst impress. Swift, efficient, and professional, in every aspect, 'twas a grand evening, fit for a king!"

In fair Las Vegas, where pleasure doth reign,
A wondrous sight doth grace Fremont Street each day.
A show, with lights and sounds, doth take its place,
And all the town doth gather to behold the play.

The hotels, easy to access, doth invite,
And downtown's seediness doth add to the delight.
The neon lights, they doth shut down,
And all the people, they doth stop and stare, entranced.

The spectacle, it doth captivate,
As strangers gather, lost in the moment's embrace.
The street, it doth come alive,
As the lights flicker back, and all doth resume their pace.

'Tis not just the show, but the people,
That doth make this phenomenon most intriguing.
For in the crowds, we find our entertainment,
And thus, our time in Las Vegas, doth bring us joy and content.

"In fair Ohio, I didst reside,
But now, in this place, I do abide.
A massage therapist, I didst seek,
And Jill's name, didst my eyes meet.

On Yelp, her praises didst I read,
And thus, didst decide, to give her heed.
Her touch, so gentle, like a breeze,
Didst ease my tension, and my sore knees.

She knew her craft, with skill and art,
Stretching muscles, a daily part.
Forty seconds, a hold, didst seem long,
But with each breath, my body didst throng.

Now, every three weeks, I do attend,
To Jill's parlour, my body doth wend.
For a massage, most excellent and fine,
I do recommend, Jill, divine."

"Hark, what news is this? Steve Wynn doth strive
To have the finest buffet in all of Vegas,
And lo, his wish doth come to pass, forsooth.
The Wynn buffet, by the gods, doth take the cake,
In quality of ingredients and cooking, 'tis a step above the rest.
Thin-crust pizza, brick-oven baked, doth please,
And crab legs, meaty and huge, doth satisfy.
A rack of lamb, from New Zealand's green hills,
Doth make my mouth to water and my senses to thrill.
And mark, good sir, the Asian noodle soup bar,
Fresh longans, not canned, and Asian pears in salad,
Do add a touch of exotica, rare and fair.
But, alack, the line, it doth stretch far and wide,
A wait of 1.5 hours, and some did wait longer,
A fainting spell, a nosebleed, oh, how dire!
My lord, Steve Wynn, consider this, I pray,
A FastPass system, to ease the waiting fray."
"Tucked away, behind a row of shops. I went there for pho, always. It's the closest thing to the noodles I had back home in China."

Methinks I do adore Arrowhead Mall, 'tis one of mine favorites, good sir! Its layout doth please mine eyes, for from either end, I may behold other shops with ease, and all are within reach. By Jove, it doth possess an Apple Store, a place most dear to mine heart! My fondness doth lie with American Eagle and Footlocker, yet for my wife, they have all else... verily, she doth enjoy a merry time, browsing through their wares. When wearied of our perambulations, diverse eateries doth await, ready to sate our hunger. In sooth, this mall doth contain all we need, and being nigh unto our domicile, we need not journey far to AZ Mills or Fashion Square Mall, save when ennui doth strike, and then, the journey shall be worthwhile.

"Methinks my hopes have not yet fully matured,
Since entering the VA system, I have endured
Two doctor's appointments, two visits to the lab,
And today, a meeting with a nutritionist, I had.

And lo, I must confess, I am quite pleased,
For waiting, there was none, and needles, they did not seize
Their chance to pain me. Volunteers, so kind and true,
Didst make my journey through the halls anew.

It took some time, indeed, to gain entry,
But now, I must admit, their care doth shine so brightly.
This VA, it doth serve a multitude,
And patient needs, they do take heed, most rightly.

So here's a thank you, to the staff, so fine,
For tending to my health, with such design."

"Hark, good sir or madam, let us begin anon,
The service at the register, most friendly was shown.
Aye, 'twas a sight to behold, a true delight,
The staff, with smiles so bright, did make our day take flight.

And lo, the theaters, they were but passable,
With Turbo, a film most wondrous and able.
But alack, the bathrooms, a sight most foul,
Did leave much to be desired, I do avow.

Yet still, the service, with thanks so genuine,
Did earn four stars, a rating most divine."

"Hark, my dear son! I have a word for thee,
A dish most wondrous, fit for royalty.
'Tis porkbellies, grilled to perfection,
With sides of rice, eggplant, macaroni, and cucumber,
A feast most satisfying, crunchy, and sweet.
Indeed, it doth not get much better than this,
A meal most excellent, fit for a king or queen."

"Methinks 'tis a place most wondrous fair,
With melodies that do delight mine ear,
And potions strong, that do stir mine spirits high,
Upon that roof, where one may gaze upon the sky.

Yet, alack, 'tis true, the crowd doth swell,
And four stars, not five, my rating doth tell.
For entry, naught didst we pay, nor didst we wait,
And through an escalator, Playboy Club, we didst straight pass.

A marvel, indeed, that such a place doth be,
Connected thus, in elegance and luxury."

"Fair sir, the victuals here be good, the attendance most kind,
Yet doth the bill of fare seem somewhat scant, and lacking in design.
In sooth, the viands be clean, wholesome, and true,
But wherefore doth the crowd not gather, as I do reckon they should?
Alas, 'twas but a weekday, and nigh upon the hour of one,
And lo, the tavern lay empty, devoid of mirth and fun.
Pray tell, what causeth this dearth of patrons, pray?"

"Hark, my dear friend! While I may not be the greatest aficionado of Mexican cuisine in our fair village, I must confess that dining here hath always been a pleasure. 'Tis a curious blend of Grecian and Mexican flavors, a true gastronomic union! But, alas, what doth capture my heart are the delectable chips and salsa. Verily, their Veggie Burro doth reign supreme, a culinary delight indeed!"

"Hark! What luck didst thou bring us, fair Pub and Grill?
A night before, at Gordon Ramsey's, we did dine,
But this, my friends, didst far surpass the bill.
We arrived at eleven, to avoid the throng,
And found the place bustling, with folk galore,
Ten parties waited, their patience to test,
But we, dear friends, didst not have to endure the woe.

Our server, kind and fair, didst guide us through,
The menu vast, with choices manifold,
She shared her wisdom, her suggestions made,
And we, dear friends, didst take her counsel to our heart.

The burgers, oh! How juicy and divine!
No fault couldst we find, in taste or form so fine.
Sweet potato fries, a mountain high and steep,
We struggled to finish, but 'twas a happy sleep.

The price, so fair and reasonable, a delight,
For thirteen to fifteen coins, a feast most bright.
Alas, the shakes, we didst not get to try,
But shall, anon, forsooth, ere we say goodbye.

A great place, indeed, with service true,
We shall return, and that, anon, we'll do."
"Hef's is our go-to spot. Intimate but lively, with a mixed crowd. Their fried tomatoes, divine. Drinks, stiff."

"Hark, what news is this? A car wash, they say?

Whoa, whoa, whoa, whoa, let us sing its praise!

'Tis Danny's Family, with locations many,
Their business thrives, as the crowds demonstrate.

Oh, how I love to wait, until the need is great,
To feel the joy of a clean car, oh so elate!

Danny's does the deed, with speed and care,
A job well done, beyond compare.

And lo, on Tuesdays, a discount doth await,
For ladies, a perk, a benefit so great!

Then note it well, and heed my words,
On Tuesdays, to Danny's, thy car convey!"

"In sooth, this creperie doth lie within a strip mall, and dimly lit it be. Yet, cozy and casual it doth feel, and comforting doth the food prove to be. For groups of four or more, al fresco dining shall be thy fate, at the front of the establishment thou shalt sit. A small counter doth provide a space to watch the crepes being made, as thou dost enjoy thy repast. A Frisco crepe, with fresh blueberries in lemon curd, powdered sugar, and whipped cream, didst I order. Perfect with my morning coffee, it was, yet a tad more lemon curd, I didst desire. For those who wish to venture forth from their usual breakfast fare, 'tis a place most excellent. FUNtastic, indeed!"

"Freshest ingredients, Italian dishes most true, Decor authentic, as if from Tuscany anew. Fast delivery, a marvel, I must confess. Garlic bread, a middling dish at best, But numerous other wonders, my tastebuds did bless. Fettuccine Alfredo, a rich delight, Sicilian pizza, a masterpiece, so bright. Mattarocca, oh how sweet thy flavor doth lie."

"Hark! What hotel is this? A place most fair,
With location on the Royal Mile so rare.
A climb, indeed, from train station steep,
Yet worth it, for the view of Arthur's Seat doth keep.

Older architecture, crypt-like bar doth hold,
Nespresso machine in room, a Radisson gold.
Bed, enormous, super comfy, a delight,
But alas, poor TV reception, a sorry sight.

Reception service, excellent in every way,
Helped with restaurant choice, for quiet day.
Reserved a table, with book in hand,
A peaceful meal, without a single stand."

"Methinks 'twas much improved, this second stay,
Compared to when we first did come this way,
When Aladdin's magic didst fade away,
And Planet Hollywood took its place, by day.

I am glad, fair friends, that I didst give
This hotel chain another chance to live,
For now we have a room most fair and bright,
With two queens, non-smoking, and a plasma in sight.

A bottle of Skyy Vodka, free of charge,
Didst come with our room, a gift so large,
And forty dollars in casino play,
To boot, my dears, what more could one say?

The bathroom, spacious and clean, didst boast
A tub, a shower, and two sinks at the cost,
Of but a single room, a steal, methinks,
For us four ladies, and our many blinks.

But, alas, dear friends, there was a flaw,
In the form of lighting, dim and raw,
The room, though large, didst lack in lights,
And left us groping in the darkest nights.

And, verily, the bathroom didst grow hot,
From too much light, a fault, I do not,
But, all in all, we didst enjoy our stay,
Despite a bed with stains, which didst fade away."

"Hark! A culinary delight doth lie within this eatery's walls, my friends! Forsooth, I didst partake of their savory beef arepa, a dish most wondrous and divine. Yet, alas! The chicken salad, a dish of mediocrity, didst not impress mine taste buds as much. But lo! Their grilled chicken, served with rice and beans, didst make mine mouth to water and mine belly to sing with joy! 'Tis a feast fit for a king, I say! And, by the stars, I shall return anon to sample their delectable empanadas, for they didst appear most appetizing, indeed!"

"Alack, good sirs and madams, how I do detest
This bar that doth proffer naught but woeful cheer,
Their adult milkshakes, verily, be the only boon,
That doth redeem this place from utter disdain,
For all else, 'tis but common, lackluster fare,
With speakers galore, that doth assault mine ears,
In sooth, 'tis naught but mediocrity that doth reign,
In this, the tavern of the saddlebag trail, alas!"

"Hark, what news is this? Jim and Tabitha, twain of skill,
Do serve the finest drinks with wit and will.
On Wednesdays, laughter doth fill the air,
As comedians take stage, their craft to share.
And lo, the victuals, priced just right,
Do please the palate, a wondrous sight.
So gather round, friends, and make merry,
For here, mirth and cheer do reign supreme."

"Hark, what changes have occurred since my last visit! The fair but uncomfortable chairs, once a sight to behold, Have been replaced with cushioned seats, though somewhat too wide for the tables, alack! 

We began our feast with Summer Rolls, large and delectable, beyond my expectations, indeed! The beef within had a charcoal flavor, quite delightful, and fresh veggies wrapped in rice paper, a refreshing treat, served with a light fish sauce, a perfect complement. 

My Spicy Stir-Fry, not as fiery as I had hoped, yet still possessed a pleasant kick, I must confess. The chicken, cooked to perfection, a medley of fresh crunchy veggies, all cloaked in a well-balanced sauce, a veritable feast for the senses! 'Twas a dish most excellent, and worth every penny of its meager price, $7.25, a true bargain, by my reckoning. 

Verily, I say unto thee, my dear friend, that thus far, naught but satisfaction hath I known at this establishment. They offer divers options, rare and unique, a true delight, and the victuals, most solid, a culinary joy, anon!"

"Fuego Bistro, generous portions, prices scared me off, loved my Cuban sandwich, top notch mojito, delicious sliders, Groupon, huge dinner portions, easily share an entree, dozen shrimp, mounds of pork, wonderful sides, don't let dinner prices scare you off, delicious food, money's worth."

In fair Las Vegas, where we chanced to roam,
We celebrated our first year of wedlock's home.
At Margaritaville, within Flamingo's walls,
We savored tacos, and sipped flavored margaritas that enthralled.
The atmosphere was lively, full of cheer,
With live music that did banish all fear.
A place most suitable for families, I do declare,
Margaritaville, a haven of delight, beyond compare.

"Las Vegas' finest Vietnamese grub, in my humble opinion. Packed to the gills, especially on weekends. Authentic flavors, generous portions, and my kinfolk can't get enough. Service? Not their strong suit. Indifferent servers, too busy with less pressing matters. But who cares? Their victuals are that delectable."

"A store of wonders, filled with drinks galore,
For adults who seek to indulge and explore.
Rows upon rows of wine, beer, and spirits,
A sight most marvelous, and a delightful treat.

The staff, so friendly and eager to help,
Makes one feel welcome, and the experience quite swell.
I found a beer, Alien Stout, oh so fine,
And Nut Brown Ale, a taste divine.

Wells Banana Bread beer, a surprise,
Beyond belief, a true delight.
The wine selection, vast and grand,
Intimidating, yet, a treasure to behold.

Glassware and snacks, aplenty to choose,
To complement your drink, and make it quite loose.
Boarhead meats and cheeses, a delicious find,
And chips and mixes, for a tasty mind.

In conclusion, this store is a gem,
A place to find all your alcoholic whims.
Lee's, take note, this place stands supreme,
A true delight, for all to esteem."

"O, wondrous coaches, skilled in their art,
Do teach the young ones with a zealous heart.
But, alas, the place where parents do congregate,
Is woefully inadequate, a sorry state.

A seat, ye cannot find, so dense the crowd,
And standing, long, thy feet doth wear a cloud.
When two hours pass, and classes doth begin,
Thy patience doth wear thin, in discomfort's pinch."

"Twice in recent months, I've visited Root,
A place of gastronomic delight, no doubt.
The first time, 'twas a truly wondrous night,
Our server, a friendly soul, made our evening bright.
We talked of beer and food, and shared our tales,
And the ambiance, it was quite divine, I daresay.
The food, oh how it did impress,
Especially the Brussels sprouts, a tasty mess.

But alas, the second time, 'twas not so grand,
Our server, seemingly stoned, did not take a stand.
He came, he went, he brought our check,
And left us wondering, what the heck?
The food, it was decent, I must confess,
But the service, oh how it did disappoint, I must profess.
So, Root, a place of wonder, indeed,
But hit or miss, it seems, is how they proceed."

"Hark! What news is this? The parking system now doth function well,  
A vast improvement, indeed, doth tell.  
Good morrow, gentlemen! Your diligence doth earn my praise,  
For working hard, despite the rain's wild gaze.  
The track, once soggy, now doth lie dry and flat,  
A testament to thy dedication, stout and pat.  
Well done, good sirs! Thy efforts doth deserve a cheer,  
For making sure the race didst start without a fear."

"Verily, this pizza doth stand alone,
In Pittsburgh's culinary scene, 'tis shown.
Eleven other pies have I essayed,
But none compare to this, my heart's arrayed.
When homesickness doth strike, and I do yearn
For a taste of New York, then IVP doth burn
Brightest, like a beacon in the night,
Guiding me home, with flavors so tight."
