Boyfriend had the same, he liked it too. Service was good, fast."

"Hark! What news is this? A Mood Lounge, new and bright,
In yonder forest, where the trees do take flight.
'Tis a wondrous sight, with Kiefern trees so tall,
And a clearing, where one may hear the birds' call.

The interior, stylish and chic, doth please the eye,
And one may sit, in comfort, and never say die.
But alas, my friends, the service there,
Did leave much to be desired, I do declare.

For when I went, the crowd did throng and press,
And yet, the waiter, with a heavy heart, did confess,
A mistake had been made, and thus, a delay,
Did cause me to wait, in utter dismay.

But then, a Tequila Sunrise, did appear,
In a long glass, with ice, and liquid cheer.
The mix, it seemed, was correct, but oh,
The barkeep, he did not understand, I know,
The ways of English, and thus, didst fail,
To add the Grenadine, with grace and flair.

So, in the glass, did float, some ice,
In a uniform orange mixture, not nice.
Alas, my friends, the service, poor,
And the cocktail, only worthy of a roar.

Thus, I must say, the location, five stars,
But service and drink, a single star, alas!"

"This Phoenix gem, transformed, doth boast an air most welcoming, cozy, and chic, without a hint of pretension. The small bar, snug 'twixt kitchen and windows, doth afford a view most pleasant, of the patio outside. A fine vantage, indeed, for savoring a draught of craft beer, such as the seasonal Great Divide Wild Raspberry Ale, with its amber hue and genuine raspberry essence. As one who doth delight in dairy, the griddled cheese sandwich didst seem most alluring - a choice recommended by several servants, and one that didst live up to its reputation among the foodie crowd. Paired with the soup of the day (a cheesy chicken enchilada), it was a true delight for mine taste buds."
"Toured the joint, packed with kiddos, summer swarm. Workers kept it tight, impressive. Shelled out ten bucks for chocolate pizza, worth every penny. The chocolate, top-notch. Selection, plentiful."

"Verily, I have graced these hallowed halls with mine own feline friend, a fierce tiger in a tiny form. The staff, kind and gentle souls, hath ministered unto us with great care and compassion. Dr. Brown, a wise and learned scholar, hath explained all manner of things, from pneumonia to asthma, with great eloquence and insight. I didst not feel hurried, nor didst I sense any urgency, for the staff didst truly care for mine and my cat's well-being. They didst proffer samples, too, to aid in my cat's medicinal intake. Huzzah! Piper Glen Animal Hospital, thy name doth ring with praise and gratitude!"

"Twas a Tuesday when we dined here, and the crowd was not too great. Service was slow, I reckon, for they had many orders to fulfill. Yet, this place is the best for sushi in Madison, mark my words. A great spot for a date, and the wait time may vary, but 'tis worth the while. The salmon with mango, a most excellent roll, and all the food was cooked to perfection."

"Fast Asian fare, most excellent,
Crowded at noon, the place doth swell.
Fresh and full of flavor, doth my belly cheer,
Combos, a bargain, with potstickers so bright."

"Hark! Mert's doth serve most excellent soul food,
My comrade and I didst partake of their fare,
The cornbread, though tardy, didst prove most sweet,
With butter, 'twas a culinary delight.

Our server didst suggest the ribs, and thus,
I didst order them, with fowl, mac and cheese,
And greens, all of which didst please mine eyes,
The ribs didst fall from the bone, most tenderly,
The fowl, a delight, the mac and cheese, sublime,
The greens, a taste of heaven, so divine.

But alas, the peach cobbler, not so grand,
A pity, for I didst crave something sweet,
Perhaps a chocolate dessert, to end my meal,
But nay, 'twas not to be, at Mert's, I didst feel.

Yet still, I wouldst return, for the fare is fair,
And the service, friendly, with a smile so rare,
At Mert's, thou shalt find solace for thy soul,
In the food, and the warmth that doth make thee whole."

In fair Verona, where we lay our scene,
A cafe doth stand, most charming and serene.
Within the Paris Hotel, its beauty doth shine,
A haven for sweet treats, and pastries divine.

Their desserts, oh so fine and delicate,
Are crafted with love, a true work of art.
Coffee and sandwiches, a simple delight,
To satisfy hunger, without breaking the heart.

An Americano, a drink of choice,
With a proscuitto sandwich, a tasty voice.
On a baguette, a meal most fair and bright,
For just eleven dollars, a true delight.

And in the back, a shop doth lie,
Where merchandise doth wait, for thine eyes to try.
Cups, cookbooks, aprons, and more,
Some with a Paris theme, to make thee adore.

So, gentle traveler, if thou art in need,
Of a sweet respite, and a place to feed,
This cafe, most charming, doth await,
In fair Verona, where love doth create.

"Hark! We snatched up tickets at the eleventh hour,
For Zarkana's opening night, a wondrous sight.
A spectacle true to Cirque du Soleil's name,
With garb that would shame any Halloween game.

Their cast, a group of sprightly youths, didst perform
Feats of agility that left us in awe and wonder.
And though the tale they told, we pretended to discern,
In truth, 'twas but a riddle, a puzzle to uncover.

Yet still, the show didst provide a merry reprieve,
From the clanging slots and tables that do steal our coins.
A respite brief, but sweet, from the gambling den's thrall."

In sooth, fair friends, Eggspectations doth boast  
A varied menu, fit for any roast.  
Benedict, omelette, Sugar Shack, and more,  
Doth grace the list, to satisfy thy gore.  
And though 'tis not a singular find,  
'Tis priced fair, with atmosphere divine.  
My latest visit saw me choose with care  
The Eggs Florentine, a dish beyond compare.  
See for thyself, good sir, the menu here:  
http://www.eggspectation.com/wp-content/uploads/2012/05/Menu_MTL_EN.pdf
"Charlotte, last night of my trip. Food, good. Service, friendly. Vibe, nice. Plenty TVs for sports. Pulled pork plate, huge portions. Mac & Cheese, Fried Okra, yummy. Booths, plenty."

"A modern tavern, yet cozy and bright,
With elevated British grub, a wondrous sight.
The bar, a marvel, with taps of finest brew,
And a backdrop, like iconic British booths, anew.

With friends, I visited this merry place,
And savored each dish, with joy and grace.
Deviled eggs, soup, shepherd's pie, sausages galore,
Fish and chips, burgers, squash soup, and more.

All dishes, delicious, cooked to perfection,
Leaving us in awe, with no room for correction.
Fish and chips, shepherd's pie, standouts indeed,
But all dishes, superb, our taste buds did heed.

Affordable, too, with the Caesar's card,
Our waitress, kind, and her service, not hard.
We'll return, without a doubt, to this jolly place,
For another round of culinary delight, with haste."
Arizona Donut Co., Tempe. Friendly ladies, mediocre donuts. Old-fashioned glaze and glaze twist, half uneaten. Oil evident in taste and sight. Unlikely return for donuts, possible try at boba drinks.

"Hark! What news is this? A sushi place most fair,
Where one may dine on endless delights, without compare.
I, a loyal patron, come hither oft,
For their seared tuna dish, a true culinary thought.
A local's secret, too, they hold within their walls,
A stamp card, granting freebies, for those who enthrall.
Nine purchases made, a tenth dish shall be thine,
A gift from the gods, a treasure truly divine."

"With mine own parents, I didst visit this eve,
And found them in a state of indecision, quite bereft.
We wandered forth, in search of sustenance and cheer,
And chanced upon a place called Vida, my dear.
The victuals there, didst please mine parents mightily,
And we didst dine, in merriment and glee, most rightly."

"Pizza joints come in two varieties: those that serve the real deal, like Brooklyn V's, and those that peddle a pale imitation, à la Pizza Hut or Domino's. After sampling their garlic knots, which were top-notch, I ordered the 14-inch white pizza with pepperoni, onion, and garlic. The crust was light and crispy, a definite plus, but the pie itself was a bit soggy. Still, it was enjoyable, and the portion size was generous, leaving us with leftovers. Pricing-wise, Brooklyn V's falls somewhere in between the genuine article and the pretenders, so it's up to personal preference and priorities."

"Hark! A kindly receptionist didst greet me with a smile,
And gave me a chamber on the first floor, in style.
But lo, I wished to be on higher ground,
On the second or third floor, with a better sound.
The receptionist didst tell me, with a gentle grace,
That naught but tomorrow couldst grant me that place.
Good service, indeed, didst they provide,
And so, I shall observe and update, as I reside."

"Sandy Bells, a joint where folk music reigns supreme. No regard for capacity, just cram 'em in, like sardines in a tin. Impromptu ceilidh, always on the cards. Edinburgh institution, through and through. Acts, incredible. Keep an eye out for folkies at the Liquid Rooms, after party's here, no doubt. \n\nBut, alas, the smoking ban's taken its toll. Thick fog of smoke, gone. Sweaty stench, dominant. My advice? Down a few pints, ale, too. Your sniffer'll thank you."

"Methinks 'tis a wondrous place for swift repast,
Where first I came upon a Groupon's quest.
A year hath passed, yet ne'er didst I return,
For reasons such as these, my heart doth yearn.

A bargain-hunter, I, with zeal and cheer,
Do seek out deals, discounts, and sales so dear.
But alas, at Zaba's, none couldst be found,
And thus, my visits there were few and far between, profound.

Their prices, verily, do seem quite steep,
For fast food fare, a truth most people keep.
Seventeen crowns, I spent on salad and burrito vast,
Yet portion sizes, generous, our hunger did surpass.

The shrimp, freshly cooked, our taste buds did delight,
Whilst chicken, somewhat old and dry, did not excite.
But lo, the rest, a cornucopia of health and glee,
Sweet potatoes, beans, fajita mix, and rice, we did enjoy with glee.

In conclusion, full and content, I did depart,
Wishing only, that some coupons they would impart.
Fresh Mex, feel-good, a meal most satisfying,
Leaving thee, dear reader, with naught but joy and gladness."

"O, what a wondrous brunch place doth this be!
Always full, yet seats are found in ten,
And food doth come in twenty, by my reckoning.

Scones, oh how delicious they doth taste!
Savory ones, my heart doth sing with joy!
Quiches too, they doth please mine appetite.

Pastries, if thou desirest them, doth wait,
But walk a short ways down, and find thee
The pastry shop, where sweet treats doth abound.

Pigs in a blanket, oh how novel an idea!
Sausage in pancakes, who hath not tried it?
Mac and cheese pancakes, with andouille sausage,
A dish most wondrous, and worth mine usage.

Speedy eggwich, for those who crave simplicity,
A humble dish, yet full of flavor, I do declare.
Grits with sausage patties, my newfound delight,
Leaves me fulfilled, with leftovers to boot, in faith!"

"Outside Inn, it's a joint I dig. Beer selection's decent, grub's not too shabby either. Pretzel chicken sandwich, sliders, they're my jams. Bar food, but a cut above. Wine-o Wednesdays, not a bad deal. My wife and I, we hit it up after work, grab a bite, couple brews. Air's clean, don't notice the smoke much 'less it's right on top of me."

"Hark! In days of yore, 'twas Lucky's, then Albertson's,
This Greenland Supermarket, where I didst roam.
But now, alas! 'Tis changed, like all around,
On Spring Mountain, betwixt Rainbow and Decatur, profound.
Chinatown doth flourish, a wondrous sight,
A food court within, doth pique my appetite.

A Hawaiian stall, with sweet spam musubi,
Sushi, too, doth tempt, with nigiri so cheap.
Korean fare, I tried, with kim-chee and meat,
But found the aftertaste, a curious treat.

A coffee shop, with Boba, doth quench my thirst,
Though out of stock, a pity, I didst not desist.
In conclusion, a fair experience, indeed,
I shall return, though variety doth decrease.
A Vietnamese booth, or more, wouldst be grand,
To make this food court, a true Shangri-la land."

"Sesame Inn, again. Time to kill before the Richard Thompson show, so I went for Chinese. Egg rolls, shrimp with pea pods, good stuff. But Jesus, they give you way too much. Lunch portions would be nice for dinner. Stashed the leftovers in my office fridge for later."

"A humble abode, this eatery doth seem,
With fare that doth delight, and prices so keen.
Their hummus, though not to my taste, doth flow,
For they must cater to the masses, I do know.
But oh, their babajanoush, how rich and divine,
Made with love and care, a true work of art, fine.
The pita, warm and soft, doth fill the belly,
And tabulli, a mix of flavors, doth dance merrily.
In balance, all doth seem, a feast for the eyes,
A pleasant repast, at this cozy surprise."

"Thrive/Fresche's got great bowls, but their joint's got a funny smell. Like bleach or somethin', but it ain't clean. Seats are stained, look dirty. Can't blame 'em for customers makin' a mess, but they should take pride in cleanin' up quick and replace broken stuff. Sit outside? No way, smells like trash. Prob'ly got a dumpster nearby, outta their control. Get your bowl to go, call ahead to skip the wait. Enjoy."

Yesterday, went in with a buddy. Service was alright, server checked on us only when necessary. Ordered beef tips, enjoyed 'em, but needed a to-go box. Packed up leftovers, left 'em on the table, and headed to the ladies' room with my friend. Came out, and our table was cleared, including my to-go box. Found the waiter, who apologized and offered a new, smaller portion. Didn't have time to wait, so passed. Annoyed they didn't wait a sec to ensure we were gone before tossing my stuff. Appreciated the quick resolution, though.

"Hark! Good sirs and madams, gather 'round,
And heed my words of wisdom, proffered with haste.
A place of wonder, a cinema of renown,
Where films are shown, and tales are told with grace.

The prices, fair and reasonable, doth please,
$10 for adults, on Friday and Saturday eves.
For matinees, the cost doth drop, to $8,
A bargain, indeed, for those who do arrive early.

But wait, there's more! A special deal, for thee,
Who doth desire to save a few coins, with glee.
Combo deals, at the concession stand, doth abound,
And discounts, for students and seniors, are found.

So, sign up now, for the Cinemark email,
And receive coupons, of which thou shalt not fail.
And, lo! On Mondays to Fridays, before the sun doth set,
Seniors, doth pay but $4, a sum most frugal, I reckon.

Thus, hasten thee well, to this theatre of delight,
Where movies doth play, and fun doth take flight."

"A wondrous abode, with space enough to spare,
The staff, kind-hearted, did our needs prepare.
We chose the North tower, as wise men do,
For updates fresh, our stay to make anew.
A minor blemish, paint peeled from the bath,
But elsewise, joy did our hearts engage.
Our time there, pleasant, we would not part,
And thither, again, our steps would move with haste."

"Hark! To rate Stoney's N40 aright,
Two sides must thou consider in sight,
The saloon, where food doth reign supreme,
And club, where dance and music do gleam.
A smoke-free place, a virtue indeed,
That sets it apart, a crown to proceed.
I've dined at many a place, my friend,
Famous Dave's, Mesquite BBQ, Dickie's, Lucile's,
But Stoney's, with its service so fine,
Doth rival them all, a gem divine.
Their food, a feast for the taste buds,
Substitutions, no problem, they'll budge.
Weekly, we dine there, a treat for us,
For those who don't enjoy, alas, what fuss!
But, alack! The club, a different tale,
Lacks the luster, the charm that doth prevail.
Revolver, nearby, doth steal the show,
With Stoney's, a mix of genres, they do know.
Country hats, flat bills, young and old,
A diverse crowd, but not as bold.
Gaming machines, a solution, perchance,
To draw in more, a better chance.
Then, mayhap, they shall turn anew,
Back to their roots, a country bar, anew."

"A place with too much variety on the menu raises suspicions. Can they truly excel at everything? Doubts lingered as we ordered alfredo pasta, burgers, carne asada burritos, and cheesecake.

Burgers, cooked to order, impressed. Rare to well-done, they nailed it. Medium-rare for me, medium for my companion. Frozen beef patty, perhaps, but flavorful toppings made up for it. Fried egg and sautéed mushrooms elevated the burger.

Crisp veggies, soft bun, and salty fries pleased. Ketchup complemented them nicely. Dill pickle, a delightful surprise. Fruit punch, however, lacked oomph. Watered down, it seemed. Recommendation: drinks without ice, add when ready.

Iced coffee, standard, yet satisfying. Quick delivery, a plus.

In conclusion, extensive menu, average burger and fries. Delivery, fairly priced and prompt."

"Tasty grub and a swell joint. Got a table in the bar, no fuss, no muss. No gluten-free options, but they whipped up something nice. Looking forward to seeing what's new on the menu next time. Highly recommend, but call ahead or get there early."

"A feast most wondrous, with dishes galore,  
Didst please my palate, and left me wanting more.  
The cost, alas, didst climb to lofty heights,  
Yet, for such victuals, 'twas a fair price to pay.  
I shall return, with hunger pangs anew,  
To savor more of this most delectable brew."
"Aria's got a fresh joint, real swell grub, and atmosphere to boot. Been there a few times, always a stylish crowd, top-notch service. John Venegas, he's my man, go say hi."

"Hark! A cheese pizza didst I have today,
And verily, 'twas a feast for mine eyes.
The victuals and service, both were of high degree,
A place most worthy of thine culinary cravings, an it please thee.
The salads, too, didst delight mine taste buds,
And swiftly came the server, with nary a pause or fuss.
Aye, 'tis a place to dine, when thou dost seek
A meal of merit, and a pleasant time to speak."

"Verily, 'twas a merry night, indeed! This place, Kazba, doth beckon with its lively atmosphere and warm reception. Methinks, the folk here be friendly and welcoming, eager to share their revelry with strangers. I chanced upon this place, seeking diversion on a Friday eve, and found myself swept up in the mirth.

"The interior, though compact, did teem with people, making it quite warm within. Yet, the heat did not deter my enjoyment, for I found solace at the bar, whereupon I requested a surprise concoction from the bartender. He, in his haste, did present me with a refreshing elixir, Electric Lemonade by name, most delectable!

"As I waited, engaged in sprightly banter with those nearby, I noticed not the delay, for the bartender did attend to his duties with diligence. And lo, upon my invitation, I did join a group of merrymakers on the balcony, reserved for a private gathering, partaking in the finest spirits, Grey Goose and Red Bull, plentiful and free.

"Huzzah! To Kazba, and all who dwell within, for providing a most excellent experience, replete with conviviality, fine music, and potent potables. May this night be remembered, and may future visits be forthcoming!"

"Marry, what a wondrous sight doth lie before mine eyes!
The players, with their skills so fine and fair,
Do conjure up a show most magical and bright.
I could not follow every twist and turn of tale,
But grasped the gist of it, in general, well enough.
The plot, alack, doth not the reason make,
For one to witness this most wondrous play.
In conclusion, 'twas an evening most delightful,
And one I shall not soon forget, by my troth."

"A hidden gem, this place, on north side of town,
Gives Swingers' vibe, with drinks of island renown.
Mix of cocktails, with names so bright,
And games of chance, for those who dare to fight.
Funky jukebox plays tunes of old,
But don't expect free drinks, unless you're bold.
Seats in back or at bar, are best, I say,
For tables in center, are not the way.
Bartenders friendly, service quick,
I look forward to my next trick."

"Fare: marvelous, a feast most fair and fine,  
With bone-in rib eye, a cut divine.  
Price: alack, 'tis true, yet still I say,  
In Vegas, worth the cost, come what may.  
Ambiance: pleasant, not too much ado,  
Service: waiters, staff, most courteous, too.  
Overall: mark my words, a steak most prime,  
If premium fare be thy desire, 'tis thine."

"A hidden gem, this sushi place, away from prying eyes,
All-you-can-eat, for a fixed price, a veritable surprise.
I, a man of discerning taste, with an appetite quite vast,
Do justice to the menu, and leave not a single morsel past.

The catch of the day, be it salmon or tuna,
Fresh as the morning dew, and just as succulent,
Tempura, a delicacy, fried to a golden hue,
Satisfies my craving, and leaves me feeling anew.

Uni and amaebi, a treat for the refined,
One dish per person, a rule to keep in mind.
Toro, a rare delight, when in season,
A flavor so exquisite, worth every single reason.

Verily, a place to return, when in this fair town,
For the sushi, a feast, and the service, a crown."

"Methinks we had a most enjoyable time at yonder Summerlin place,
The staff were pleasant, and the surroundings didst grace,
A right merry eve we didst have, save for one small thing,
The barbecued shrimp, alas! didst not please our king.

Four medium shrimp, overcooked and hard as stone,
Didst lie upon the plate, a sorry sight alone,
The rice, too, didst lack the flavor that doth bring,
A proper sauce, to make the dish worth a king's ring.

Oh, how I wish they had used large shrimp, in shell,
And rethought the sauce, to make it more swell,
For garlic, that most noble of herbs, doth make,
A dish most fine, and worthy of a king's partake."
"This joint's alright. It's near my digs and they got decent brews. But the service? It's a crapshoot. Sometimes it's good, sometimes it's meh."

"Hark, what fortune brings me to this place?
A hunger pang, a craving for some grace.
Eight months with child, I waited patiently,
Fifty minutes passed, yet still no sign of tea.
But lo, the California club did please,
A worthy dish, with flavors rich and sweet.
And then, the goo ball, oh how it teased,
A treat so fine, it left me speechless, neat.
I ate it slow, savoring each delight,
My six-year-old, curious, asked for a bite.
But nay, my dear, this treat is mine alone,
For in its sweetness, I found my heart's home.
The restaurant, unseen, yet still divine,
For food so good, it makes me wish for more, a sign.
I'll return, yes, when my belly's not so round,
To taste again that wondrous goo ball profound."

Methinks I do enjoy Lai Lai's fare,
But my fair lady doth not share my cheer.
She saith the spice doth lack, e'en with red oil,
And finds it tame, alack, and void of zest.

I, myself, do not desire fiery food,
And thus, their sweet sauce doth please mine taste.
Their noodles be the best I've had, in truth,
In all the Mongolian places of the land.

The worker lady, kind and fair, doth seem
To know me well, and her warmth doth beam.
Yet, pineapple, huge and hard to find,
Doth make my meal less pleasant, I do mind.

Moreover, prices be a bit steep,
And leftovers, they doth not allow to keep.
To-go orders, by weight, they doth charge,
A policy strange, and worth a sigh or two.

"Classy joint, top-notch grub and digs. But they'll bleed you dry, no doubt. Standard rooms, a hair better than average Vegas fare, but not worth the extra scratch if you're lookin' to cram a bunch of folks in. Suites at a lesser hotel, that's the way to go. Nice place, though. If you've got money to burn, you'll find plenty of ways to light it up."

"A real good spot for dumplings. Small place, fits a group of five, tops. Staff's friendly, service is quick. My girl and I stopped by while checkin' out Chinatown. Place was packed when we got there, had to wait a bit. Family run joint, decor's alright, not too fancy. Menu's simple, dumplings cost five to nine bucks, salads are a buck fifty. Had the wasabi salad, damn good. Then tried the beef and onion dumplings, shrimp, pork, and coriander ones too. Best I've had, no doubt. Wait wasn't long, just five to ten minutes. Real good place, I'll be back, no question."

"Fascinated by this exhibit. Bodies on display, different body systems. Educational, even for a science-hater like me. Arteries and veins, visible and clear. Helps to understand the whole thing. Recommend it to anyone. MGM Resorts has a deal, three attractions for $54. Includes this one and the CSI Experience at MGM Grand. Nice savings."

In fair Orleans Hotel, where value doth abound,
Amidst the glittering lights of Las Vegas' ground,
It stands, a beacon, praised by all who've found,
A haven, fit for kings, with luxury unbound.

The rooms, spacious and comfortable, invite,
To rest and relax, after a long night's delight,
The pool, a haven, with sun and shade in sight,
A place to cool, and let the world glide by.

Good bars and eateries, within its walls,
Do serve the finest fare, to please all palls,
And new, a TGI Fridays, doth draw the crowd,
A popular spot, where laughter doth resound.

Bowling and cinema, on the upper floors,
Do offer entertainment, and endless roars,
Of fun and joy, to pass the time away,
As night doth fall, and dawn doth break the day.

A slot tournament, yearly, doth draw me near,
With rooms and entry, for a mere three hundred cheer,
Though yet, alas! My luck doth fail,
Yet still, I dream, and hope doth never pale.

A drawback, some may say, its location doth,
Off-strip, on Tropicana Avenue, a path not trod,
Yet, Seamless Gentlemen's club, doth lie across the way,
A haven, for those who seek a different play.

So, if thou seeks a place, of value and delight,
In Orleans Hotel, thy search doth end in sight,
For though it be not on the famed Strip's side,
'Tis still a place, where memories doth reside.

"Methinks my dearest wife doth love this place,
For she doth send me hither on a regular basis.
In June, she visited twain within a fortnight,
And now, since we did move, I have been thither thrice.

She doth enjoy their burritos, enchilada-style,
With green sauce, rice, and beans, in a most wondrous guise.
Their containers, they do keep the food hot for hours,
A feat most marvelous, and worth many a praise.

Alas, their menu doth contain but few choices,
Yet, methinks 'tis worth the price, forsooth, their voices.
For though 'tis costly, still the people doth flock,
From far and wide, to partake of their culinary clock.

So, if thou dost desire authentic Mexican fare,
And art not afraid to venture into the "hood,"
Then, prithee, give this place a try, my friend,
For 'twill be the best eight dollars thou didst ever spend."
"Custard, amazing. Five stars. Icy, not my thing. Lemon, lime, cherry, chocolate chip, strawberry-mango, cucumber melon. Liked the last two. Make the right combo, great experience."

"Methinks I love this place, good sir! Forsooth, 'tis a fine establishment, with atmosphere most pleasant, and service most kind. But, alack! There be a few things that doth keep it from being a five-star affair, as thus: the calamari appetizer, small indeed, with naught but seven or eight rings; and, alas! They do not serve soda water, which doth vex mine soul. Yet, despite these shortcomings, 'tis still a grand value, with prices most fair and hibachi dinner most delectable. Verily, I say, 'twill be a pleasure to return anon."

"Sushi joint near my office. Been there a few times for lunch. Decent spot, quick and affordable. Conveyor belt serves up a variety of dishes, some of 'em comical - cream puffs, jello, canned fruit. Service could improve, but no issues with splitting checks or getting what I want. Haven't tried dinner, might be different. Photos of stacked plates are amusing."

"We stayed in a one-bedroom suite at a hotel off the strip. My boyfriend has a timeshare there. It was my first time in Vegas and I liked the quiet atmosphere. No casino, but I don't gamble. I wanted to experience the city without the noise and crowds. Our suite was cozy, with a living room, kitchen, and big bathroom. We had a great view of the city. If you're looking for a relaxed stay, I recommend this hotel."

"O, what a feast we had! A salad of baby spinach, warm with bacon's embrace, did please my taste buds most ardently. And lo, the filet, so tender and juicy, did rival the finest cuts of beef at Ruth's Chris, that famed steakhouse of old. My spouse, with manly appetite, did devour the ribeye, its marbling rich and savory. But alas, my heart doth belong to Ruth's Chris still, for none can match its culinary prowess."

"Methinks my first encounter with this establishment was most vexing,
But now, in sooth, they have made amends in a most generous fashion.
We were accorded treatment fit for kings, nay, verily, for VIPs,
And the victuals, by the gods, didst taste most wondrously divine.
I do confess, the cost, methinks, doth border on the exorbitant,
Yet, in this land of commerce, 'tis their prerogative to charge as they list."

"Hark! What news is this? The cupcake stock doth seem to dwindle,
Alack! 'Tis but half an hour till closing time, I reckon.
Fear not, fair maidens, for the sweetest of treats,
In ten varieties, doth await, though out of sight,
In yonder kitchen, where they doth reside,
To be adorned with frosting, at thy behest,
And thus, the cupcake crisis doth cease.

But lo! A bonus gift doth come my way,
For mentioning "sugar rush," in Twitter's fray.
A red velvet cupcake, fresh from the oven,
Doth grace my palate, with its sweetness,
From Sprinkles, the bakery of renown,
Whose website doth charm, and seasonal flavors crown.
This weekend, I shall return, for Key Lime delight,
And savor each morsel, with joy and delight."

"Hark! What wondrous feast did we devour,
My friends and I, in yonder bower?
A sandwich most divine, with flavors bright,
Did please our taste, and filled our sight.

But lo! The sweetest treat, that e'er did grace,
Our table, was the giant chocolate cake,
With layers deep, and moistness beyond compare,
It did astound, and left us all in awe.

The frosting, oh! It was a marvel, indeed,
Like fudge from Disney World, or Rocky's creed,
So rich, so smooth, so utterly divine,
It did surpass, all frostings that are mine.

And though, at times, I do suspect,
That such a meal, was but a dream,
I ask my wife, and she doth say,
'Twas real, and not just fantasy's play.

Then, by my honor, let this be known,
This place, doth serve, the finest fare,
In all the land, there is none better,
For culinary joy, it doth deliver."

"Hark! A local from Hawaii, I say,
This place, not bad, doth pass the day.
I tried the Kalua pork, a dish most fine,
With cabbage, a pairing quite divine.

A hamburger steak, a bit lacking, I fear,
In veggies, a sight most queer.
The Korean chicken, oh how grand,
Crunchy skin, spices at command.

But alas, the cash only rule, most vexing,
In a casino, a sight most perplexing.
A minor quibble, a small annoyance,
Yet still, a pleasant experience, in essence."

"Ah, fair Target, how fondly doth my heart remember thee! In days of yore, when youthful vigor filled my veins, thy hallowed halls didst play host to many a merry meeting with friends. 'Twas naught but joy to hop down to thy welcoming embrace, to partake in the latest wares and perhaps, perchance, quench our thirst with a cool Coca. And thus, no matter where fate may lead, thy familiar visage doth evoke memories of home, sweet home.

"Verily, this humble abode hath stood the test of time, its gleaming floors and shelves a testament to diligent upkeep. Though 'tis not a SuperTarget, boasting no Starbucks, its modest selection of victuals and chilled delights doth suffice. Aye, safety and cleanliness reign supreme within these walls, a beacon of hope in Silverado Ranch's bustling midst."

"Great meal. Good service, nice waitress. Filet, perfect medium rare. Greens, well-dressed. Hubby's beer-brined wings, delicious. Avocado sauce, tasty. Caesar salad, crunchy pig ears on top, awesome. Only letdown, my cauliflower side, cold and not as described. Funny bathroom decor. Dining room, pleasant. Warm towels post-meal, nice."

"Oh, how my taste buds doth sing with joy,
At this sushi house, where salmon doth employ,
In forms most wondrous, and most fair,
To tempt my palate, and leave me there.

The kama, crisp on the outside, doth reveal,
A velvety goodness, that doth steal,
My senses, and doth make me swoon,
With flavors, that doth conjure June.

The sashimi, oh, how it doth delight,
With its divine taste, that doth excite,
My taste buds, and doth leave me in a trance,
As if in love, with a sweet, sweet dance.

And the salmon rolls, oh, how they doth please,
With flavors, that doth tease,
My senses, and doth bring me cheer,
As if in spring, with flowers near.

But alas, their non-salmon sushi, doth lack,
The flavor, that doth make my spirit attack,
And the seaweed salad, doth seem a bit bland,
As if in winter, with no land.

Yet fear not, for they have fried delights,
That doth make up, for the lack of might,
Soft shell crab, tempura, and more,
To satisfy, and leave me in awe.

And lo, they have a deal most fair,
All you can eat, for just twenty there,
And happy hour, doth come most often,
To make my purse, feel not so brooding.

So to this sushi house, I shall return,
For more of that salmon, that doth burn,
My love for it, doth never fade,
As if in love, with a sweet, sweet shade."

"Verily, I didst espy a gentle soul's nether regions, exposed to the elements, no doubt due to a lack of unmentionables on laundry day. But fear not, dear friends, for 'twas all part of the grand adventure. 

I do confess, my dear, that driving in the city doth stir within me a great loathing, but this wondrous conveyance hath lifted that burden from mine shoulders, praise the heavens! The carts were spotless, and our wait was brief indeed. We encountered not a single obstacle, and the journey was smooth as silk, save for a few brief halts at the traffic lights. We disembarked and boarded anew thrice, and never once did we encounter a ticket-checker, even when the cart was filled to capacity. 

By my troth, I do eagerly anticipate the day when this marvelous contraption shall run till the wee hours of the morn, that we may explore further the delights of downtown and central Phoenix, with nary a care in the world."

"Methinks 'twas fortunate that I didst dine
Here once afore, and found it to my liking.
The rave reviews of yon chopped salad didst pique
My curiosity, and I didst give it a trying.
By Jove, 'twas the most delectable salad
That e'er didst grace mine eyes or lips, I swear!
Aye, the ambiance didst bespeak an inn of note,
With prices to match, yet I wouldst not demur.
Forsooth, I shall return, my friends, anon,
To savor that salad once more, ere I go."

"Methinks I do enjoy this place as much, or mayhap a trifle more than yon Los Feliz tavern. The tunes upon the jukebox didst please mine ear, and were a far cry better than the discordant sounds that echoed forth from the Beauty Bar next door. \n\nUpon a Friday and Saturday eve, the throng was merry and full of cheer, yet still I found a snug perch, alack! 'Twas situated nigh unto a pair who didst engage in amorous sport, their passionate embraces most unseemly and wanton. The young man's gestures, howbeit, didst afford me some mirth and diversion."

"Unprepared I was, my garb unsuited to the grandeur of the place, expecting rougher surroundings, but alas, the Wine Loft's modern structure gave no hint of the refined atmosphere within. Upon entry, I didst utter a 'woah,' so struck was I by the opulence. Dark, rich tones, with hints of masculinity, blended harmoniously with sleek, contemporary furniture, bathed in soft, dim lighting, creating an air of intimacy and romance, perfect for impressing a fair maiden or savoring a glass of fine wine, with naught but low-key, mature, and sensual vibes."

"By th' heavens, what a feast we had!
The Wagu beef sliders, oh so tasty!
And th' pork belly, it did please my palate,
As did th' mashed potatoes, oh so fluffy!
Th' ambiance, it was quite cool,
Th' music, it did make my spirit soar.
But alack, our server, he was divine,
Yet th' assistants, they did seem quite strange.
A minor quibble, forsooth,
For this place, it doth beckon thee,
In fair Las Vegas, it doth reign supreme."

"Hark! This eating house doth boast most delectable fare,
And sugary delights in abundance to share.
If thou art lodged at Paris Casino, 'tis a fine choice indeed,
For break of fast or midday meal, as thou dost need.

The sweet shop joined to the tavern, doth brim with tasty morsels,
A haven for those who crave such sugary quarrels.
And, if thou art enrolled in Harrah's loyalty band,
Thou mayst employ thy comp points in either land."

"A merry whim, a sudden fancy took me,
To dine at Pho Da Lat, a place most fair and bright.
With friend in tow, we entered in,
And found ourselves within, a space quite neat and tight.

The hour was two, the day a Saturday,
And few folk there, did make our stay most pleasant.
We sat, and menus we did receive,
And time to ponder, our choices to conceive.

Quails, a dish most fine, we did decide,
To start with, ere we made our main course choice.
And lo, the staff did bring us samples,
To taste and savor, ere we made our voice.

My friend, a question didst pose,
Concerning spicy dishes, and which to choose.
And I, a suggestion didst make,
Lemongrass chili chicken, forsooth, a dish most great.

Our food, it came, and alas,
Our appetizer, forgot, it was.
But still, the feast, most satisfying,
And spices, just right, our taste buds didst thrill.

Again, I shall return,
For more dishes, I wish to learn.
And wine, forty and more,
A challenge, I shall take, and see what's in store."

"Hark, what fortune doth bring me to this place,
So near my humble abode, a wondrous grace!
A garden of olives, where I may find solace,
And savor the flavors that doth please mine taste.

Afar, I didst stray, to a location not so fair,
Where service was poor, and my mood didst sour.
But here, oh here, my heart doth sing with cheer,
For all was well, and naught didst bring fear.

My seat, it was ready, and swiftly didst I sit,
My draught, it didst flow, with haste and great wit.
The soup, it was hot, and didst fill mine belly with delight,
And Chicken Marsala, oh how it didst ignite!

A dessert, I didst request, to take away,
And lo, my server, didst hear my dismay.
She offered it free, with a smile so bright,
And I, with gratitude, didst accept her kind sight.

This Olive Garden, it shall be mine haven,
Where I may find peace, and dine with heaven.
For here, they do know, how to serve with grace,
And make a weary soul, find a smile on his face."

"Hark, what news is this? A breakfast feast,
At three o'clock, a most curious hour indeed!
And yet, I found myself within those walls,
Enjoying every morsel, without a single qualm.

The orange juice, freshly squeezed, I must confess,
Was worth the trip alone, its flavor so pure and bright.
The French toast, original and nothing less,
Satisfied my hunger, with no need for excess.

But oh, the banana nut pancakes, how divine!
With prosciutto, seared to perfection, a perfect pairing of sweet and fine.
I savored each bite, and wished for more,
A culinary delight, beyond compare.

The soup of the day, chili, spicy and hot,
A fitting end to our repast, and left us not a drop.
The service, too, was worthy of praise,
Our server kind, and with a gentle grace.

One thing, fair friends, I must confess,
The portions large, so share with ease.
For though my hunger great, I could not finish all,
And left, content and full, with naught to gall."

"Good burgers, this joint's got a cool setup. Custom-built, you pick the meat, bun, cheese, toppings, sauce. Finally, a burger that tastes homemade without the gut bomb. But, it ain't cheap. Two burgers, a small fry, waters, that's over twenty bucks. A bit steep for burgers, but the ingredients are top-notch. You can mix and match to make some killer combos. Worth the price, I reckon. I'd go back, wish they had more places like this around the country."

"Oh, how I do adore the fare at Firebirds, 'tis a feast most fair and fine. Their burgers, oh so juicy and sweet, do please my taste buds well, and their house salad, a delightful treat. Verily, I say, the prices be steep, but worth each penny, for the quality doth shine. And on special days, they do offer deals most kind, a bargain for a king, or so it doth seem. But what doth make this place most charming, is the bar, where one may sit and sip, and bask in warmth of yonder fireplace, when winter's chill doth grip."

"Hark! What fortune doth mine eyes perceive? A place of rest and refreshment, where kind servitors do attend with haste and cheerfulness. The victuals, fresh and free from excess oil, did please my taste and leave me content. Verily, I shall return anon to partake of their offerings once more."

"A 4runner of yore, with flaws and defects galore,
Didst I purchase, with a price most reasonable,
Foreseeing the repairs, that it wouldst require,
Yet, with hope, that it mightst yet serve me well.

The exhaust, in partic'lar, didst pose a threat,
A rusted cat, that didst spew forth a treat,
Of fumes and smoke, that didst choke the air,
And made it hard, to breathe, with nary a care.

But fear not, dear friends, for I didst find,
A place, where they didst mend, this exhaust of mine,
Advance, the name, of this shop, so fine,
That didst fix, my ride, with skill divine.

They welded in, a new cat, with grace,
And didst the work, with haste, and in its place,
While I didst wait, with patience, so bright,
They didst complete, the task, with all their might.

Now, for all things exhaust, they are my guide,
My go-to, for any ride, that doth require,
Their expertise, so vast, and wide,
In this realm, they doth reign, with pride."

"Methinks I've passed by this place many a time,
And vowed to return with friends in tow,
But alas, 'twas not meant to be,
Until last week, when fate didst allow.

Their victuals, same as those at other sites,
Are served with haste and great delight,
But here, the crowd is not so great,
A tranquil spot, ideal for a peaceful night.

If thou dost seek the bustle of Central's air,
Thou shalt not find it here, my dear,
For 'tis more akin to Mesa's tone,
Albeit somewhat subdued, alone.

Go forth and dine, for service is prime,
And all the staff, in courtesy do shine,
So wait no more, and heed my words,
For thou shalt leave with full belly and light heart, anon."

"In sooth, fair Pittsburgh, thy victuals be
Above the rest, a veritable feast for me.
This pho, a dish of note, doth please my taste,
And in this town, where food doth often waste,
'Tis a delight to find a culinary prize.

In other realms, perchance, this pho were deemed
But decent, not awesome, yet in Pittsburgh's scheme,
'Tis the best of all, a true gastronomic gem.
I speak the truth, though faint praise it be,
For in this place, a craving's fierce demand,
Is met with satisfaction, a rare delight.

Two other pho places, alas, didst fail,
Their offerings poor, a bitter, sorry tale.
Yet here, a revelation, a shining light,
Doth make my day, and banishes the night.
All's relative, they say, and thus I find,
In Pittsburgh, this pho doth truly shine."

"Hark! A tale of woe, my friends, doth unfold,
Of buttons lost and fabric rent asunder.
But fear not, for I, a man of skill,
Can stitch them back with speed and great dexterity.
A small patch, ugly though it may be,
I can affix with ease, 'tis plain to see.
But alas, my friends, my talents end there,
For needlepoint, I must confess, I know not.
Yet still, I sought to mend these garments fair,
And found a shop with prices most reasonable,
Five coins for each repair, ten for the hem,
A bargain, indeed, and worth the gamble.
The work, my friends, was done with grace,
By two fair ladies, full of charm and pace."

"O, how I do adore Papa Murphys, a pizza most divine!
Their DeLite crust, it doth reheat with ease,
A choice most wise, for it doth please.

The toppings, they doth abound,
Fresh as the morning dew,
Sauce, it doth complement,
A flavor most true.

Coupons, seek thee online,
For they doth offer, a bargain most fine.
Call ahead, a few moments doth save,
A plan most wise, for a meal most brave.

Alas, a flaw, they doth possess,
A lacking, of certain ingredients, alack!
Bacon, it doth disappear,
A sorrow, most profound, I do declare.

Yet still, a pizza, most worthy,
For those who crave, a meal most hearty.
So, take heed, and doth give a try,
Papa Murphys, a pizza, most nigh."

"Saturday morning, woke up craving something new. Decided to check out Chez Boris, a spot in Mile End that's been on my radar all summer. They specialize in doughnuts, and for 75 cents each, you can get 'em fresh and made-to-order, coated in a variety of ways. I went for two sugared, one cinnamon, and one raspberry. Perfectly cooked, crisp outside, fluffy inside. Just what you want in a damn good doughnut. If you're looking for something different, give Chez Boris a shot. You won't regret it. And they use an SNES as a card holder? That's just icing on the cake. Cheers!"

"Methinks 'twas fortnight past, I chanced upon Logan's Roadhouse,
For luncheon, with a friend from Sky Harbor, in tow.
The hour was late, the crowd was sparse, our server keen,
Our thirst, with soda, did she promptly quench, I ween.

But those dinner rolls, oh how divine!
My comrade, ne'er had tasted such, did now entwine
His fingers, in their fluffy embrace, a true delight,
A culinary joy, that doth make all troubles take flight.

I, myself, didst savor the pork chop, with relish,
And sweet potato fries, with cinnamon's gentle kiss.
Broccoli, cooked just right, didst round out the feast,
A healthy choice, to counterbalance the rest.

And thus, our meal, with nary a flaw, didst end,
When my friend, with grace, the bill didst amend.
'Twas then, the dinner rolls, didst play their part,
A perfect finish, to a meal most smart."

"Upon a Tuesday eve, I chanced to find
Myself with time to kill, and so I did
Repair to Pewter Rose, a place of old renown,
Where once I'd savored many a tasty crown.

Their kitchen counter, open wide, did call
To me, and I, with hunger sharp and tall,
Did take my seat, and watched the chefs at play,
As they prepared the dishes of the day.

A feast for eyes and taste buds both, I swear,
For we were served the nutty fried chicken, dear,
With sweet potato mash and asparagus too,
A meal most satisfying, I do declare.

And oh, the rolls! So fluffy, soft, and light,
They stole my heart, and left me in delight.
For ere they served, a chef's approval they did seek,
A sign of quality, and worth the extra week.

In brief, a pleasant evening, full of cheer,
At Pewter Rose, a place I hold most dear.
I shall return, to sample more of their fare,
For their menu holds much promise, beyond compare."

"My husband and I didst dine upon this place,
With veggie spring rolls, sweet chili, and plum sauce,
A tasty treat, indeed. The restaurant's ambiance,
Dark and cozy, like a secret hideaway.
Our waitress, kind and fair, didst attend to us,
And brought our feast with hasty speed.
Chicken phad thai, we didst share,
Mild spice, but extra peanuts, beyond compare.
I craved more heat, but still, the dish didst please,
So we added red chilis, and spiced it with ease.
A noble meal, and one I shall not forget,
For I, a Seattle native, do know Thai cuisine well,
And this, my friend, didst rank among the best,
Though still, I search for greater phad thai, and rest."

"Came here with five friends for breakfast. Beat the crowd. Two of us had iced tea. Just okay, watered down and weak tea flavor. 

I had the Cowboy Omelette with cinnamun pancakes. Also tried carrot, red velvet, and wheat pancakes. Ranked from best to worst: cinnamun, carrot, red velvet, wheat. 

Cinnamun pancakes were flavorful, not too sweet. Recommend. Carrot pancake was good but couldn't taste the carrot. Like wheat but sweeter. Red velvet was dry, sugar overpowered it. 

Cowboy omelette was alright. Eggs were overcooked, veggies overcooked. Prefer watery eggs, less cooked veggies. Fried potatoes were fine. Not too salty, not burnt. 

Give this place 3.5 stars. Good for breakfast, come back again. Excellent portion sizes. Pancakes are great. Service was excellent. Next time, try french toast, another egg dish."

"Hark, good sir! This place doth merit twixt four and four and half stars, I reckon. 'Tis new and the service, impeccable indeed. The victuals, a fair price for thy purse, $45 per person, and the wine, a steal at $30, or even hundreds of crowns, should thou desire. A buffet, they do not call it, but in essence, 'tis similar. Thou shalt begin at a boundless salad bar, with mozzarella, parmigiano, prosciutto, salamis, smoked salmon, and soups galore. When ready, they shall bring forth the meats. Ask thou for filet mignon, a rare treat, and their succulent ribs, which doth melt in thy mouth. The lamb, a tad gamey, yet still a worthy choice. Chicken, a feeble selection, compared to the other delights. Take heed, my friend, and tarry awhile, for haste maketh waste, and the servers, overeager to slice thy meat, may cause thee discomfort. An enjoyable sojourn, indeed, and worth another visit."

"I've been meaning to try this joint for a while, so I took my buddy here for a celebratory dinner last week. Service was top-notch. They were out of the bottle we wanted, but the server suggested another one at the same price. Nice touch. The corn cakes with pulled pork were the highlight of the meal - damn good. The Arcadia Salad was solid too. The green chile Mac n Cheese was a bit of a letdown, being from New Mexico and all. The ribs were just okay, not falling off the bone like I'd hoped. 

I dig the vibe here - open, airy, and plenty of interesting artwork. But the music? Not feeling it. Paula Abdul doesn't exactly set the mood for a killer dinner. Maybe they were just having a cheesy moment, but some edgier tunes would do wonders for the atmosphere. 

All in all, I'm a fan. Good job."

"A slice of cheese pizza and some zeppole didst I partake,
Both dishes, I must confess, didst please my taste.
The service, though not fantastical, didst bear a smile,
And thus, my visit, didst prove most worthwhile."

"Hark, good sir! Burger Bar, a place most fair,
Concocted by Chef Hubert Keller, 'tis there.
Build thine own burger, choose from meats so fine,
Buffalo, lamb, angus, kobe, all dost shine.

Tons of toppings, temperatures to choose,
Customize thy burger, as thou dost muse.
Rossini, the largest, sixty dollars doth cost,
Kobe-style Wagyu beef, foie gras, truffles on a boast.

But fear not, good sir, for thou canst build
A burger similar, minus the truffles so grand.
Thirty dollars, the price doth descend,
And truly, the black truffles, their flavor doth blend.

Fries, oh so skinny, a delight to consume,
With a sampler of sauces, a veritable boon.
Spicy ketchup, truffle mayo, and more,
A feast for the taste buds, forevermore.

The best burger, a claim not so bold,
For Burger Bar, a culinary gold.
Expensive, yes, but worth every penny,
Give it a try, and thou shalt see, 'tis sunny."

"Thrice didst I come with friends, ere we could gain entry without tarrying an hour. The queue didst stretch forth from the door, and taxes didst convey visitors from the strip with great haste. \n\nThe victuals were of fair quality, I must confess. Yet, an hour's wait for a mere burger? The fare didst not astound me, but it was good. The frites, methought, didst surpass the burger in excellence, for they didst please mine appetite mightily."

"Hark, 'tis time to end this review, LOL.
On opening day, we came, and lo,
The wait, it was not so bad, praise be.
The hostess, with her iPad, did check us in,
And texted us, when our table was within.
The service, it was most welcoming,
Professional and friendly, no need to frown.
But let us speak of the food, ere we part,
For 'twas the highlight of this culinary art.
I ordered the Hells kitchen burger, full of zest,
With a spicy kick, that did my taste buds bless.
It was, indeed, my new favorite dish,
And I, who come to Vegas every fortnight, shall wish
To visit here again, when 'tis not so crowded,
And savor more of their delectable fare, that's promised."

"Steak and seafood, best I've had. Salmon, perfectly cooked. Hubby's steak, juicy and tender. Lobster mash, divine. Complimentary dish, can't recall the name, but delicious. Crowd, lively mix of young and old, stylish and sporty. Music, loud and fun. Prices, a tad steep, but worth it for the top-notch service and scrumptious grub."

"Methinks I do adore BWW, where $2 Stella doth flow on Thursdays, and wings that burn with fiery passion. Verily, 'tis worth the price! \n\nA grand vista of a TV doth greet mine eyes from any seat, and many a place doth provide a comfortable perch. I have brought clients hither for luncheon, and ne'er hath mine experience with servers been aught but pleasant. Though they may not always hasten, I have ne'er deemed them slow."

"Methinks 'tis wise to sample their sesame chicken,
Or perhaps the mix'd veggies with fried tofu,
Pray tell, good sir, to make it spicy hot,
Forsooth, the proprietors are quite pleasant, too."

"Verily, the victuals were most wondrous fair,
A feast fit for a king, with service rare.
But lo, the seasoning, a mite too salt,
I pray they'd use more herbs, forsooth, to halt
The overpowering flavor, which doth detract
From the enjoyment of the meal, I do suspect.

The presentation, a marvel to behold,
My filet, cooked to perfection, a sight to behold.
Yet, alas, the meat, didst contain some gristle,
A flaw, which doth mar the overall merit.

I wouldst venture to try another dish,
But pray, good sirs, that ye monitor the steak's quality, lest it doth suffer thus."

Yesterday, a coworker and I visited the Gold & Silver Pawn Shop around 4:30 pm. Luckily, there was no line to get in and it wasn't busy, so we could take our time and chat with the workers. We learned a lot about how the show is filmed and it was a shame we arrived so late, we could have been extras since they were filming that day. I was told the guys work there Monday to Friday from 9 am to 3 pm, but mostly stay in the back to avoid the crowds. If you want to be on TV, bring something worth showing and be charming, or get there early to be an extra if you're lucky. They had some touristy stuff, but I didn't care, I got a Pawn Stars t-shirt and I'm proud of it. They didn't have a big store, but I enjoyed the memorabilia and heard some stories about how they got them, just like watching the show at home. Great experience, recommended for any Pawn Stars fan.

"Hark! Good pizza doth abound in Arizona's land,
A steal of a deal, two slices and a drink at hand.
For just five dollars, tax included, thou shalt partake,
In Scottsdale's finest pies, a feast for thy senses to make.
So come one, come all, and taste the difference for thyself,
At Good Pizza, where a fine meal doth await thee, by the self."
"Tasty joint. Good fish. Better than the dump across the street. Friendly service too."

Alas, fair maiden, I didst venture forth to this place,
Forsooth, to partake of thy sweet, delectable Cinnabon grace.
A former servant of that esteemed establishment, I,
Didst crave the taste of those most wondrous rolls, so nigh.

But lo, alack, the rolls they served, how pale and wan,
Didst fail to meet my expectations, so high and grand.
For in my mind's eye, a true Cinnabon doth dance,
With flavors rich and depth, a veritable chance.

Oh, how I yearn for Schlotzsky's to hire with care,
Employees who shall tend the Cinnabon side with love so rare.
That I might savor each bite, with joy unconfined,
And thus, my heart and belly, both be truly aligned.

"Charlotte-bound, hubby and I sought vegan fare. Easy find, off the expressway. Cozy joint, all scratch-made. Gluten-free options abound. Fifteen-minute wait, worth it. Intimate setting, limited seats, but we scored a table post-lunch rush. No public loo."

"A fine hostelry, with victuals most delicious,
And servants, whose courtesy doth never slack.
Though age hath touched the walls, 'tis clean and bright,
A place of chance, where fortunes may be made or marred,
For those who seek the ancient way to wager."

"Hark! Why settle for a common sub shop when thou hast the Pita Pit at hand? They doth grill the meat fresh before thine eyes, and thou mayst choose thy toppings as thou wilt, even as at most sub shops. \n\nVerily, there be something about the bright green and orange hues that doth please mine eye when I enter this establishment. The atmosphere doth pulsate with life and energy, ensuring that I depart in high spirits."

"Aye, 'tis a joy to work with speed and grace,

For all my home projects, this place doth hold a special space.
The people here, so kind and full of cheer,
Hast made my tasks, a pure delight, my dear.
I have not used their services, for aught professional,
But stickers, postcards, and photos, they do print with great zeal.
So, if thou art in need, of such things, anon,
Do visit them, and thou shalt find, their service most wondrous, ere long."

"Verily, my heart didst sing with joy, when Ishi's walls didst hold a different tale. Forsooth, their former home was cozy, full of warmth and cheer, a place where one couldst find solace in the company of friends. Alas, they have since moved to a larger dwelling, and though the space be grand, 'tis true, they had to cut corners in some regards. Fear not, dear patron, for the sushi and hibachi doth remain of high quality, and the price, not too dear. And as for saki bombs, by the stars, they be a curious delight indeed!"

Thus, I did miss the Lobster and Steak Day,
Moved from Monday, now on Thursdays held sway.
'Tis a fair spot, indeed, to watch the game,
With staff most kind and food of highest claim.
But lo, the DJ would not play the tune,
"Freaks of the Industry," deemed too slow, no boon.
Yet, free parking, a bonus, did abound.

"Hark! This place I visit ere Pens games or plays,
Where drinks flow like nectar, and victuals delight.
But alas, fair maidens, 'tis not always easy,
To catch the eye of yon bartender, so flighty.
At times, thou must roam, and seek her out,
And pray she attend thee, with speed and devout.
Yet still, 'tis a place most wondrous, my friends,
To gather before or after events do end."

"Hark! What wondrous delights doth this establishment bring?  A feast for the taste buds, a treat for the soul.  Their kafta, a dish of the finest quality, doth please mine appetite.  But lo, their rice, a celestial delight, doth steal the show.  So delectable, I pray for an extra serving, lest I perish from want.  And their pita bread, fresh from the oven, doth warm mine heart.  'Tis a veritable feast, fit for a king.  The service, too, doth shine, with friendliness and grace."

"AZ88's got the vibe you want from a modern joint. Decor's tight, lighting's rad. Menu's not too shabby either, plenty to choose from. Prices are fair, you'd think it'd cost more given the ambiance. Food's solid, group agreed. Bathrooms? Top-notch. Just watch out for them mirrors, they'll play tricks on your mind."

"Last Saturday, my spouse and I did stop for tiffin,
In a place that was quite empty, save for us twain.
The server, a merry fellow, did attend to our needs,
With bread and dip that did our taste buds ardently seize.

We both did order the chicken bacon sandwich,
With tortellini salad, a dish most wondrous and fine.
The salad, a pleasant change from the usual fare,
Did complement the meal with its flavors so fair and rare.

The prices and portions of the meal did please,
Leaving us satisfied, yet not overly sated.
Alas, the outdoor space did lack in charm,
But still, the meal did earn a rating of four stars, no alarm."

In sooth, fair friends, we chanced upon this place,
Whose praises Guy, of Diners, Drive-Ins, and Dives, did sing.
The line, alas, did stretch some thirty deep,
Yet moved it swiftly, our patience to keep.
A pager they gave us, and within a quarter hour,
Fresh, homemade fare, didst our hunger devour.
Breakfast, indeed, didst we consume with glee,
Pancakes, huge as thy head, didst delight thee.
Home-made sausage, and crispy potato fries,
Didst accompany, to our great surprise.
And, oh, the lemonade, a refreshing treat,
Cheesecake, too, that didst our taste buds greet.
A worthy place, indeed, we shall return anon,
To savor more, of their delectable fare, ere long.

"It's a humble joint, that's for sure. Inside, it's a small Greek diner with some American twists on the menu. Like that buffalo chicken gyro, for instance. Now, if you're hankerin' for some stuffed cabbage, potato pierogies, or halushki, this is the place to be. And all for a steal, might I add. Our tab was a measly ten bucks. They've got the usual gyros too, but that buffalo chicken version caught my eye. I was too full from my meal to try the ice cream, but it's definitely on my list for next time."

A wedlock feast didst I attend at this place,
'Twas a grand venue for a merry gathering,
The premises were fair, the servants kind,
And victuals plentiful, to my heart's liking.

The space was apt, with ample room for tables,
And a dance floor, where guests didst twirl and sway,
Well-stocked bars didst quench our thirsty souls,
As mirth and joy didst fill the night's array.

The bridged and groom, in delight didst they beam,
And guests, in merriment, didst dance and gleam,
A night to remember, in this fair estate,
Didst leave us all, with joy and love elate.

A wondrous afternoon didst we spend, my dear,
At yonder Phoenix zoo, in sunshine bright.
The crowd, not overmuch, didst make it sweet,
And beasts, though sleeping, didst lie in sight.

Their slumber, perchance, didst they forget,
Or else, they didst not heed the call of fate.
But still, 'twas pleasant, in the open air,
To bask in autumn's mild and gentle glow.

Alas, the extras didst cost a pretty penny,
Yet still, 'twas worth it, for the joy we had.
For in that place, with nature all around,
Didst we find peace, and a merry heart.

"A most excellent evening, I must say,
At this fine eatery, they did display
Attentive service, on a Saturday night,
Their waitstaff, with grace and poise, did shine so bright.
My meal, beef burgundy, was truly divine,
My fiancée's steak, though undercooked, did still shine.
One star ding, for that small flaw, I must confess,
But overall, a solid choice for a special night, I do profess."

"Verily, in all my days, I ne'er didst lay mine eyes upon such a sight as this. 'Tis as if Gene Summons himself didst curate this collection, with M&M's aplenty to delight and amaze. Dolls, candy machines, bottles, toys, and of course, the tiny, flat chocolate wonders that we all hold dear, doth fill this space to bursting. A must-see for any traveler with a sweet tooth, for there be much to behold, not merely to purchase, but to marvel at and revel in the sheer delight. I didst have a most excellent time, partaking of numerous flat chocolate treats, and I doth implore thee, good reader, to do the same."

"R n R, a fair establishment, doth please mine eyes,
With architecture most wondrous, a feast before thou doth arise.
Two floors of seating, both inside and out,
Tons of servants, bartenders, and music, no doubt.

On Saturdays and Sundays, the afternoons be loud,
As the tunes doth fill the air, a joyous crowd.
A place where thou mayst bring thy mother for a meal,
Or thy lover, for a night most festive and real.

Their appetizers be diverse, a twist on American fare,
The animal fries, a delight, beyond compare.
Nachos and sliders, too, doth please my taste,
All the food, a joy, a culinary embrace.

In price, 'tis mid-range, compared to others grand,
Herb Box and Bandera, not so bland.
I've sat inside, and on both floors of the patio,
The decor, most lovely, a true delight to see, oh so.

This place, I do adore, and shall return anon,
For more of their delights, ere the day be gone."

"A feast most wondrous, a spread most fair,
With dishes countless, beyond compare.
In Vegas' heart, this buffet doth shine,
A culinary delight, most divine.

But alas, dear friends, a drawback there be,
A queue most long, a wait most weary.
And prices steep, a purse most light,
Doth make one pause, and ponder in the night.

Yet still, my friends, this buffet doth claim,
A visit worth, a taste most rare.
So pack thy patience, and wallet deep,
And venture forth, this feast to keep."
"A swell spot for grub in Vegas. Breakfast, specifically. They got a Yelp deal too, so that's neat. Good chow, good times. Weekends, though? Expect a queue."

"Hark! Good sir or madam, hast thou heard?
On Tuesdays, movies doth play for just a dollar!
And on other days, 'tis but a dollar and a half,
A paltry sum, yet still a wondrous sight.
The seats, alas, do not recline,
But who doth care, when price so fine?
Seeking a frugal date, with one to woo?
Bring them hither, and their heart shall be won anon."

"L'Appartement, I'll take the place tomorrow morning. Been there three times now and it's always a pleasure. Atmosphere's cozy without being too loud, windows let in warm light, and the service, once again impeccable and friendly. Menu's simple but well-executed and prices are attractive. Definitely adding it to my address book. Signing off."

A Christmas festival, with joys and delights,
For young ones, four stars, no doubt in sight.
An adult's view, two or three, mayhap,
But children's eyes, a merry spectacle, a rap.

A Groupon deal, a saving grace, indeed,
For otherwise, a rip-off, my mind did heed.
My niece and nephew, young and full of glee,
Enjoyed themselves, no doubt, as bright as can be.

Three hours passed, with games and fun,
We made our own, beneath the sun.
A hay ride, a train ride, too,
Through desert loops, with lights anew.

Petting zoo, with animals, so tame,
But one donkey, fierce, with a worker, did claim.
A warning given, to keep afar,
From the pig, large, and grumpy, by far.

Friendly folk, with help, at hand,
Made the day, a merry land.
Next year, Zoo Lights, we shall see,
A brighter Christmas, for thee and me.

"This joint's a gem. Good grub, cheap. Tonkatsu, pad thai, General Tsao - all the hits. Don't come for the decor, though. It's utilitarian, like me. But hey, who needs fancy when the food's this good? Take-out's popular too, so expect a wait during peak hours."

"Methinks 'twas a feast most fair,
But lo, the crab, a mite too rare,
And steak, o'er-salted, did offend,
Yet still, our party of eight did wend,
In pleasure, to the meal's sweet end."

"A wondrous place, indeed, for young and old,
With ample space and pleasant, helpful folk,
Cleanliness abounds, a joy to behold.
My granddaughter doth delight in each visit,
Though prices be steep, deals do come by and by.

But lo, the snack bar doth leave much to desire,
The yogurt bar, in particular, doth falter,
Sour and ill-made, with stale, unpleasant toppings,
Best to stick with water and pizza, lest ye suffer.

A pox upon the yogurt bar, I say,
For marring an otherwise pleasant day."

"Hark! Brunch Buffet doth please,
With victuals plentiful, a feast for all.
Though service be but spotty, food doth make amends,
Awesome, indeed, yet still a buffet, friends.
Compared to others of its kind, 'tis truly grand,
But to a sit-down feast, where dishes are freshly made,
It doth not compare, so temper thy expectations,
And gorge thou shalt, till thy belly be sated."

"In a quiet nook, far from the bustling throng,
We chanced upon a sweet bakery, so quaint and long.
Their wares, though few, were freshly baked that day,
And fluffy, light, and soft in every way.
Their roll cakes, too, did please our taste,
And Japanese castella, a delicious haste.
Puddings, as well, did grace their shelves,
A culinary delight, that doth ourselves."

"Verily, I say unto thee, my dearest friend,  
That St. Francis, a place of wonder, doth descend.  
Their service, with grace and poise, doth abound,  
And the architecture, a marvel of the ground.  
Ask for a tour, and they shall gladly share,  
The secrets of the place, with love and care.  
But beware, my friend, for 'tis not cheap,  
Yet, the experience, doth make it a bargain, so neat."

"A room we did procure, my wife and I,
For fifty pieces of silver, a night's lodging, nigh.
On Priceline, we did find this place,
With a pool, a glass door, and a comfortable space.
Our chamber, modern and neat,
Did boast a bed, soft and inviting, a treat.
And, lo, no fee for parking, a bonus, indeed,
Near Scottsdale Fashion, a location most speed.
I would return, anon, to this place,
For a getaway, with haste, and without a trace.
Though Valley Ho, my first choice doth be,
This inn, a worthy second, for thee and me."

"Airport most fair, with terminals linked by foot,
Easy to navigate, though much walking is sought.
Comfortable shoes, a must, and sturdy wheels,
For luggage, lest ye weary, and tiredness reveals.

Hub central, with eateries of choice,
Chili's, where Superbowl I didst rejoice.
Vegan options, for those who do adhere,
And shops, for those who seek to banish fear.

Not the best, but fair, with qualities in mind,
Cleanliness, food, and ease, for all mankind."

"Soft, plush seats, a sight to behold!
And nearby, pizza most divine,
From Five50 Pizza Bar, just a stone's throw.
A feast for the taste buds, and a treat for the soul."

"Menu had some good dishes, some were just alright. Drinks, now that's where they shined, especially the vodka and pomegranate. Kimchi fried, not bad, but Ichiza's version is cheaper and tastes similar. Salmon was decent, miso added a nice flavor, but the price tag was a bit steep."

"Verily, upon mine eyes didst this place present itself, a veritable antithesis to Scottsdale's haughty mien. Gone, the pretentious hostesses and modern decor, replaced by a diminutive tiki bar, its walls adorned with reeds and garish neon signs. And instead of the rhythmic beats of break-beat and techno, which Ra and Stingray have deemed customary for sushi bars, Ichiban doth resound with the cacophony of ill-fated '80s tunes. Ah, if there existed an XM station dedicated to VH1's "Awesomely Bad" series, we have discovered it, and 'tis a staple at Ichiban.

"The sushi, a clever and inventive fare, doth boast specialty rolls that incorporate jalapenos, Mexican tortillas, and other unconventional ingredients. My heart doth belong to the Chimichanga roll, a philly roll with avocado, flash-fried to perfection. Alas, the swiftest route to mine affections lies through mine arteries. Hark! A happy hour, from five to seven o'clock, doth offer $4 Cali rolls and sake at a most reasonable price. And should thou sit at the bar, thou shalt witness the owner, who doth prepare each specialty roll with his own hands, providing endless mirth.

"Alas, a caveat, good friends! Arrive not later than seven o'clock, lest thy bill doth suffer a most unfortunate fate. Yet, "We Built This City" doth threaten to bestow a fifth star, though barely."

Hark, fair friends! On Saturday last,
I didst dine here, and 'twas a feast most vast.
The Filipino cuisine, though not my specialty,
Didst please mine taste, and filled me with glee.

A humble abode, with scant seating, true,
Yet their carry-out trade doth flourish anew.
Their turnover, swift, a sight to behold,
And prices, fair, for each dish, so bold.

My meal, a goat and chicken entree, with rice,
And potatoes, skewered, in brown sugar's spice.
Squid, too, didst grace my plate, and other delights,
A veritable feast, that doth ignite.

If thou art near, do stop and partake,
For this eatery, a gem, doth truly make.

"Upon mine twenty-first year of life, I didst venture forth to celebrate this milestone with friends and family. And lo, didst fate smile upon me, for I was upgraded to a grand suite on the twenty-third floor, with windows that didst overlook the sparkling pools below. Two bathrooms didst grace this noble abode, each with its own entrance to a wondrous double shower, fit for royalty. A mighty tub, adorned with mirrors and closet space aplenty, didst complete this luxurious chamber. 'Twas a room most fair, and within walking distance of the finest inns. Verily, I didst have the time of mine life."

"A far shorter wait doth grace the front waiting room,
Compared to the main, where spines are oft' the boon.
In yonder medical complex, a corner doth hold
The surgical facility, where waits are not so bold.

The best aspect, indeed, doth lie in wait,
For those who seek a swift pre-op fate.
The time doth pass with haste, a welcome change,
And eases fears that often do range.

A place of healing, too, where procedures doth reign,
Common as they may be, yet still a worthy gain.
The nurses, skilled and true, doth watch with care,
And make sure all doth feel secure and fair.

To pass the time, a movie doth play,
So thou and thine mayst entertain the day."

"Cool joint downtown, CityScape. Not your pop's bowling alley, sweaty old men and stale beer. This place, built for lounging, not just bowling. Big screens, college football, local brews from Four Peaks. Service was meh, but new spot, give 'em time. Recommend checking it out, CityScape's gonna be hoppin' soon."

Since Culinary Dropout didst open its doors at the Yard,
I have been there at least once a month, sometimes more.
Their food doth please mine taste buds, so many dishes to devour,
Bistro steak, Korean style steak, salmon, meatloaf, and ribs, oh so sure.
A nice small menu, perfect for brunch, with beer and wine galore.

A year or so past, in fair Mandalay,
At Trattoria del Lupo, I did dine,
And savored their Ragu alla Bolognese,
A dish most rich and satisfying, I must confess.

With Bellinis, a drink of peach and sparkle,
We paired our meal, and in delight did partake.
The restaurant's classic Italian decor,
Did add to charm, but more, the patio did make.

Inside Mandalay's restaurant row, they do boast,
An open patio, where one may sit and roam.
On a Friday night, we spent some hours,
Watching clubbers, wobbly and full of power.

Although the price was somewhat steep,
The experience, for tastebuds, was worth the keep.

"Good Thai grub, close to ASU. Friendly servers, warm atmosphere. Spicy Pad Thai, on point. Fried tofu, sweet and spicy sauce, solid. Papaya salad, order it hot. Pad Prik King, green beans, carrots, lemon leaves, stir-fry. Pad Thai or Pad Woon Sen, glass noodles. Service, quick and kind."

"Methinks this place doth please mine eyes,
Wherein most maidens be of beauty's prize.
Their lap dances, too, do stir my soul,
For they be nude, and ye may touch, whole.
They lay thee down upon a bed,
And if thou couldst quaff a draught within,
This club would earn five stars, no doubt,
For lap dances be its crowning bout."

"In from outta town, found this joint in the desert. Like walkin' into the Batcave, it was. Dark, man. Felt my way 'round, squintin' through the racks. Grabbed some comics, headed for the light. Got my flashlight app, ready for next time."

"Penguins, monkeys, and a kapibara in Canada? Hell yeah, that's worth a visit to the Biodome. Stroll through the ecosystems for 90 minutes or two hours, doesn't matter. It's time well spent. Animals got freedom to roam, ain't no cages here. Spot some monkeys or admire them macaws, just don't try to own one, they'll outlive you. Avoid school holidays and weekends, don't want no rowdy kids ruining your vibe. Get a good spot to sit and watch them penguins swim, don't let no crowd block your view. Admission's steep, but it's worth it. Bundle it with the Botanical Garden, that's a better deal. Don't bother with the Olympic tower, Mont Royal chalet's got a better view and it's free. Just gotta hike up the hill."

Hark, good sir or madam, listen well,
For I have news of happy hour to tell,
A time when prices drop and cheer doth flow,
At this establishment, 'tis so, don't you know?

From five to eight, and twelve till close,
The deals are sweet, the savings, they do grow,
A steak and side, for half the price,
A bargain, indeed, a wondrous sight,

The atmosphere, within those walls,
Doth evoke the spirit of old Western halls,
A place where cowboys once did gather,
To drink and dine, and share their tales,

And mint julep, oh, how grand,
A drink most potent, fit for any hand,
One glass, and thou shalt feel its might,
So, heed my words, and make it thy sight,

But, gentle patron, take heed of this,
Make haste and reserve a table, ere thou miss,
The happy hour, and pay full price,
A fate most dire, a pennywise's device,

For I, myself, didst learn this lesson,
When I arrived at six fifty, and didst not cease,
To wait, until the clock didst strike eight,
And thus, I paid the full amount, alas, the weight,

So, heed my words, and plan ahead,
For happy hour, it doth await,
With steak and side, and drinks galore,
A time to revel, and a night to score.

"Hark, good sir! Thou seekest sustenance within these hallowed halls of art? Fear not, for thou shalt find a feast fit for a king, or so it doth seem. A restaurant of repute, with dishes most fair and fine, doth reside within these walls of culture and refinement. 'Tis a place of wonder, where flavors doth dance upon thy palate, and service doth abound with warmth and grace. Prices, too, doth please, for they doth not break the bank, nor doth they leave thee penniless and in dismay.

Aye, we didst stop for drinks and an appetizer betwixt exhibits, and lo, we were most agreeably surprised by food of quality, served with a smile and in a cozy atmosphere. We didst plan to return, our bellies full and ready to partake of more delights. Forsooth, the sandwiches didst appear most delectable, with ingredients of the finest sort. Crab cakes, too, didst catch our eye, with nary a filler in sight, save for the server's word. And coconut cake, oh how grand a portion! A feast for the gods, indeed!

And thus, dear sir, thou hast my words of praise for this most excellent eatery. Mayhap thou shalt find thyself within its walls, enjoying a meal most heartily."

Alas, my friends, I must confess,
I hold a certain fondness for Zipps,
A place wherein I oft did find solace,
During the madness of March's wild rips.

Their doors but newly opened wide,
And though some say the service be poor,
I say, give them a chance, let time abide,
For all new ventures suffer such a sore.

In truth, I've helped to open many a place,
And know full well the trials they face,
But fear not, dear friends, for with grace,
Zipps too shall flourish in its chosen space.

"Tuesday morning, 10:30. First time here. Heard it was busy, so figured we'd beat the crowd. Place was jumpin', but we got seated quick. Noisy, but the service was fast. Coffee, just right. Had the scrambled eggs, salami, hash browns, and wheat toast. Home fries, but got hash browns instead. No complaints. They were great. Strawberry jam, top-notch. Be back."

"Five years hath passed, my visits here each moon,
To seek the skilled hand of yonder tech, anon.
In faith, no other place shall e'er entice me,
For here, my heart doth find its peace and glee."

"O, fairest of bakeries, how my heart doth sing thy praise! Thy bacon-covered cinnamon rolls, a delicacy most rare, Do tempt my taste buds with their sweet and savory embrace. And should I ask, with politeness and a purse of gold, They shall add a fried egg, a crown upon the dish, making it most divine. Ah, what a genius I, to think of such a feast! A breakfast fit for kings, a meal most bold and blessed. But alas, good sirs, might thou consider a lower price? For though thy treats be worth it, my poor purse doth not agree."

"A bottle service, Kaskade, and nurses of the night,
Make me a happy camper, indeed, a delight.
This club, I shall return, 'tis my desire,
