This location, dear to me, doth hold a special place,
Where FnE and McDowell's Safeway cannot compare in grace.

One-stop shopping, indeed, it doth provide,
From US Bank to pharmacy, all necessities abide.
But alas, late night shoppers, take heed,
For slow checkout lines, a woeful deed.

Yet, fear not, for produce, fresh and fair,
Doth fill the shelves, a bounty beyond compare.
And certain products, always in stock,
A treasure trove, for which my heart doth knock."

"Upon our arrival at yon eatery, we were told 'twould be a brief wait ere our table was prepared. No bother, thought I, for my spouse and I did order potions at the bar, and waited patiently for our table to be readied. But lo, when our hostess did summon us to our table, she didst not proffer to convey our draughts thither. Alack, 'twas vexing indeed, for who doth wish to bear a martini glass, clad in heels and burdened with a purse, unto their seat? Yet, this aside, our repast did prove most delectable. The lobster bisque, which they did graciously partition for us, did taste divine, and we did share the rib eye, cooked to perfection, medium rare, and a side of risotto, lest we be o'erfilled. Our server and his minions did attend to us with care, and e'en hastened our victuals, that we might not miss our spectacle. Well done, good sirs!"

"Hark! If thou find thyself in Newhaven's bounds,
Take heed of Porto and Fi, a place most profound.
A deli and cafe, where thou mayst partake
Of sustenance and drink, and tarry awhile, forsooth.

When I did toil in Granton's environs near,
My comrade and I would oft repair hither, dear.
For lunch, we'd savor, and our spirits lift,
For 'twas a treat, indeed, a moment to enrich our rift.

Their victuals, fine! They strive to source them local,
And such endeavor doth make each dish most palatable.
Even a humble sandwich, delectable and neat,
Doth satisfy thy hunger, and doth make thy spirit meet.

Their cakes, oh! How they doth delight mine eyes,
Chocolate and beetroot, a curious surprise.
Yet, fear not, fair traveler, for this odd pair,
Doth complement each other, beyond compare.

Busy, it may be, for the townsfolk do embrace,
This haven of gastronomy, with open arms and grace.
But wait, good sir, for 'tis worth the while,
To partake of Porto and Fi's gentle smile."

"Aye, fair traveler, thou hast found a place most rare,
Off the beaten path of Mill St., a culinary lair.
The victuals, fresh as the morning dew, didst delight,
Pad thai, a dish most wondrous, a true gastronomic sight.
Beef salad and spring rolls, a duet of flavors bold,
Didst stir within me a craving, a hunger most untold.
Each dish, a masterpiece, didst leave me in awe,
Alas, a draught of ale or wine, I didst not draw."

"Hark, my dear, what luck! A cafe near the stadium,
With friendly servers, charm, and glee.
The dining room was full, alas,
So out to the patio we did stray.

We ordered at the counter with ease,
And waited not long for our drinks with cheer.
I savored the Melon Mojito, oh so sweet,
My boyfriend's pulled pork sandwich, a treat to eat.

Great service, delectable fare,
A cozy atmosphere, beyond compare.
This cafe, a gem, for brunch or lunch,
I highly recommend, with no hunch."

"Wi-fi gratis gana mi corazón cada vez. No hay muchos lugares de carga, pero hay muchas sillas de rocanrol. He estado aquí varias veces y siempre disfruto de mi breve estancia. Hay muchos Starbucks dispersos por todas partes, así que no tengas miedo, hay mucho café aquí."
"Tommy, the waiter, is top-notch. Gigi, always friendly. Good menu variety. Happy hour needs more options. The Lotus Roll, the best in town."

"Hark! What happy hours doth this establishment boast?
And service most excellent, if fortune doth smile
Upon thee, and grant thee Aaron's guiding hand,
A place to sit, and rest thy weary feet awhile.
Methinks 'tis thanks they doth deserve, for longevity
In trade, a testament to their great worthiness."

"Methinks these donuts be most wondrous fair,
A sweet delight that doth my senses cheer.
If thou art on a diet, have but one,
And when thy guilt doth rise, have another, prithee,
To remind thee why thy indulgence was worth the fee."

"Hark! What merriment we found within this place,
A feast fit for a king, with food of grace.
Though slow in coming, 'twas worth the wait,
For flavors that did dance upon our plate.
The lentils, oh how they did delight,
And plantains, verily, a wondrous sight.
The beef, alack, a mite dry, yet full of zest,
A true delight, and worth the quest.
An eclectic menu, diverse and grand,
I do confess, I shall return to this land.
The owner, a gentleman of great renown,
Our server, friendly, helpful, and crowned.
This place, a gem, for lunch or eve's repast,
A choice most excellent, and one to savor fast."

"Hark! What wondrous feast doth lie before mine eyes?
A chimi of carne asada, by the gods, how prize!
Combo number twenty, crispy and full of savour,
With guacamole aplenty, a true gastronomic favour.
The staff, they sang and laughed in merry cheer,
A place most pleasant, and I shall visit here."

"Hark! A tale of South Point Hotel, I pray thee, listen well. 'Tis a place of wonder, a bit off the beaten path, yet all-inclusive, so thou needst not venture forth. Bowling, bingo, movies, casino, and more, they have it all. And lo, a daily Texas Hold'em tourney doth take place, a mere $55 buy-in, and I, myself, have emerged victorious thrice. Newer it may be, but clean and well-kept, it doth remain.

A word of caution, fair traveler, for on one visit, maintenance did cause a power outage in the dead of night. But fear not, for I, a wearer of CPAP, didst not even stir. Rooms, most affordable, and shouldst thou join their email list and players club, invitations to return at lower rates, thou shalt receive.

In conclusion, South Point Hotel, a gem it be, and highly recommended, by mine own hand, doth it stand."

"Hark, fair friends! I do declare,
In search of coffee, far and near,
I've traveled wide, both near and far,
From Seattle's misty skies to Hawaii's sun-kissed shore,
And back again, in quest of that sweet spot,
Where coffee flows, and service doth not falter.

In Maui, Honolulu Coffee Co., a gem didst shine,
With brews so rich, they doth rival the divine.
Ann Arbor's Common Cup, a cozy nook,
Didst serve with grace, and coffee most took.
Ypsilanti's Ugly Mug, a quaint abode,
Doth pour with skill, and atmosphere doth owe.
Bellingham's Black Drop, Lettered Streets, and Firehouse too,
Tony's Coffee, all didst please, with flavors anew.
Seattle's Vivace Espresso, a place of renown,
Doth brew with art, and taste doth crown.

Now, in Phoenix, Lux Coffee Bar doth rise,
With vibe so smooth, and atmosphere so wise.
The service, outstanding, doth greet with cheer,
Bakery/deli products, a delight, so pure and clear.
Beans, hand-roasted, in 'Employee Lounge', doth make,
Caramel shots, poured with skill, a sight to partake.
Milk, so stretched, so creamy, doth complement with ease,
Baristas, talented, doth craft with finesse.

Lux, oh Lux, doth have it all,
A coffee shop, where one wouldst book a fall.
Trust me, dear friends, it doth deliver,
In ambiance, coffee, and service, it doth surrender."

"Methinks 'twas fortune that didst guide me hither, led by friends and colleagues of mine own. Ne'er had I set foot within these walls, yet found I hospitality most kind and fare most delectable. A draught they call the shanty, didst please mine taste buds most ardently. And mark my words, good sirs, the chicken mole doth merit highest praise indeed."

"In Pittsburgh, there's none better, I do declare,
For pizza, six stars, beyond compare.
The other dishes, naught but air,
But beer, four stars, beyond despair.
Prices, two stars, yet still I pay,
For owner, five stars, in every way.
Employees, two stars, alack,
But timeliness, five stars, no lack.
I rate by taste, and thus it's clear,
Graziano's earns five stars, year by year.
My friends, from far, do come to partake,
And praise it loud, with no mistake.
Avoid the singles, I implore,
For they are made with lesser lore.
Go for the large, plain or cheese,
And savor each bite, with joy and ease."

"My love, she doth reside but a short distance hence,
A mere stones throw, as 'twere, from this fair place.
We dine here oft, mayhap thrice or four times a moon,
And ever do we find the service most excellent,
The victuals, too, of highest quality, I swear.
If thou hast visited Zipps, then know that Goldie's came first,
In this, the original, thou shalt not be disappointed."

"Amidst the bustling streets of Sin City, where vice doth reign supreme,
There lies a restaurant, most memorable, indeed, a gem.
For there, my love, didst propose to me, upon our fifth year's eve,
As we sat by the window, watching the fountains dance and the sun dip.

Their sauteed pork chops and filet mignon, oh how they did delight,
So tender, so juicy, a feast fit for a king, or a knight.
I sipped on berry champagne, while my love didst taste a mojito,
And the waiter, so kind, didst help set up the proposal, a true amigo.

Tears streamed down my face, as the dessert didst arrive,
A sweet surprise, that didst leave me in awe, and my heart full of joy.
A stranger, from afar, didst see my love propose, and didst bring us cheer,
Two glasses of champagne, to celebrate, and banish all fear.

Oh, how lucky were we, on that night, in that place,
To have found such a gem, a memory to embrace.
I shall return, again and again, to this restaurant so fine,
For it holds a special place, in my heart, and in my mind."

"Hark, good sir or madam, to my words of praise,
For yonder cafe, where coffee, beer, and wine doth flow,
In aid of refugees, 'tis owned by Catholic Charities,
And local artisans' wares, dost thou behold?

The atmosphere, so cozy and inviting, doth make one feel at home,
With coffee, tea, and pastries, all roasted, brewed, and baked,
Fresh fare, with local ingredients, doth grace the menu,
Pulled pork, tuna, salsa, chips, and salads, all delectable, I do declare.

A private room, for meetings and gatherings, doth await,
And on the second and fourth Tuesdays, music doth fill the air,
A showcase of talent, local voices, and instruments, doth play,
An intimate setting, for all to enjoy, in this fair place.

So, gentle reader, heed my words, and pay a visit,
To this establishment, where community doth flourish and thrive,
For in supporting it, thou doth support the refugees,
And in doing so, thy heart shall swell with joy, and spirit, alive."

My maiden voyage to Select Auto didst prove most pleasant,
And I shall surely return, God willing and the creek don't rise.
The staff, in their courtesy and care, didst attend to my needs,
And their customer service, it didst leave naught to be desired.

A fortnight past, my carriage didst require repair,
And Select Auto, they didst complete the task with dispatch and flair.
They kept me informed, with regular updates,
And even dealt with mine insurer, to grant me further grace.

They transported me to my rented steed,
And when the work was done, they didst take it back with speed.
I must confess, I didst not expect such finery,
In a place where cars are mended, but 'twas a sight to see.
Clean, modern, and with a touch of hipster charm,
It didst make my heart sing, like a lark in springtime's form.

Great joy didst I find, in this, my first encounter,
With Select Auto, and I shall not soon forget their tender.

A grand arena, spacious and wide,
With seats for five to seven thousand inside.
A place of comfort, with lounges so fine,
And food to savor, a feast divine.

'Tis a sight to behold, a vision fair,
With concerts of renowned Christian prayer.
Their sports, a delight, a competition grand,
And the Monsoon/Havoc section, a loyal band.

"Hark, this pizza place doth reign supreme,
On the East Coast, a gem of note,
I've dined within its walls, and fetched,
Their pies, with haste, to savor at home.

The quality, each time, doth stay the same,
A consistency that doth earn renown,
For those who crave a pie of worth,
And seek not disappointment, nor frown.

So, if thou art in search of pizza fine,
And dost desire a culinary find,
Look no further, for this place doth shine,
And leave thee not in doubt, or design."

"Hark! This eatery doth lie near my workplace,
Where my colleague and I do oft dine,
Or order in, for they do deliver,
And thus we found this culinary shrine.

Their service doth match the quality of their fare,
Which doth please mine taste buds beyond compare,
At prices fair, with flavors most rare,
They doth offer a loyalty card, with nary a care.

Oh, sweet potato fries and tots, how divine!
Blackened mahi mahi, a dish most fine,
But the signature sliders, they doth steal the show,
For all their dishes, I do give a hearty "Yea!"

This place, my friends, doth be my go-to spot,
For lunch, a quick and tasty lot,
In under an hour, I doth come and go,
With a full belly and a happy heart, I doth say "So!"

"Hark, my dearest wife and I didst decide
To climb Camelback Mountain, a feat most grand.
The path was steep and winding, a true test of endurance,
But we didst persevere, hand in hand.

I wore my trusty Nike shoes, a wise choice, no doubt,
For the descent was slippery, and treacherous, to boot.
We rose ere dawn, to beat the heat,
And reached the summit, by seven thirty, neat.

The day was Monday, and the park didst open late,
But we didst wait, patiently, our turn to fate.
The sun didst rise, and we didst start our way,
Down the mountain, by nine, in a brisk array.

A good hike, up and down, I must confess,
I loved it, indeed, with all my heart's excess."

"Fare thee well, good victuals, service most fair!
What more couldst thou ask for, pray tell?
A shorter wait, perchance, were it not so rare.
Forsooth, 'tis love that doth cause the delay,
As all do flock to savor thy delight.
My heart doth sing of praise for BC's sandwich,
And my dear spouse, he doth swear by eggs benedict.
This place, our Sunday brunch, doth reign supreme."

"Hark, what place is this? A haven for the weary traveler,
With breakfast fare that doth my hunger devour.
The service, swift and friendly, doth my heart sing,
And portion sizes, generous, my belly doth fling.
A fair price, indeed, for such a feast doth lie,
I shall return, anon, to savor more of their delight."

"Methought I spied a review that didst liken Gadzooks to Chipotle, and lo, upon mine own visit, I couldst see the truth in this comparison, in so much as the preparation of mine meal didst parallel that of the latter.  Aye, the menu doth boast but a few options, yet the choices for fillings didst multiply like a veritable cornucopia.  I didst partake of a green chili pork enchilada and a bison enchilada, both of which didst delight mine taste buds.  Verily, the bison didst rival any other I hath had, and the house-smashed guacamole didst prove a delectable accompaniment.  Fearing the noontide throng, I didst arrive at 11:30, yet the establishment didst already bustle with activity.  I didst secure the final parking space and the penultimate table within, and thank the stars, for the tables didst turn with all due speed, and the queue didst move apace.  For those who must await a table, misters doth grace the patio, providing a refreshing respite from the heat.  I shall return anon, and bring with me friends, that we may partake of this culinary delight once more."

"Methinks my wife and I didst seek to relocate from fair San Francisco, and thus didst require the services of a most excellent real estate group in the land of Scottsdale. Upon perusing reviews of great renown and surveying the website of The Hill Group, I didst determine that their expertise wouldst be the key to our success in purchasing our first home.

I must confess, good sirs, that I was most favorably impressed by all whom I didst encounter within The Hill Group, particularly the esteemed Steven James, whose fervent dedication to his craft didst know no bounds. Our requirements, I do assure thee, were quite particular and exacting, yet Steven, with his unwavering professionalism and unrelenting drive, didst rise to the challenge and didst succeed in finding for us a dwelling that didst meet with our utmost approval.

In sooth, I do believe that Steven's primary aim was to ensure that we, his clients, didst find a habitation that didst bring us joy and contentment, and in this, he didst not disappoint. My dear sir, I do express my sincerest gratitude for thy assistance in this matter, and I do wish thee all the best in thy future endeavors."

"Methinks, fair readers, I didst chance upon this establishment on a most fortunate day. Forsooth, the brew they call coffee, didst please mine taste, and service, swift and attentive, didst make me feel most welcome. Their chili, a dish of spicy delight, didst warm mine belly, and the decor, a blend of elegance and whimsy, didst charm mine eyes. Being a former dweller of that fair city, New York, I have had mine share of crepes, and thus, the Caprese I didst order, didst strike me as most skillfully prepared, and verily, quite tasty. And thus, I shall bring mine clients hither, for 'tis a place of moderate price, and moderate grandeur, nigh unto the hospital for children. In conclusion, 'tis a spot most suitable for those who seek a tranquil, yet delectable repast."

"Methinks 'twas wondrous care that we didst receive,
In ward A 3, where teams of excellence didst dwell.
From cleansers to attendants, nurses to servitors,
All were most kind, with hearts of gold, and gentle spirits.
Their smiles were contagious, their care, most tender,
Amidst the night, when darkness didst descend,
E'en then, their vigilance didst never slack,
For which, our gratitude doth know no end."

"Hark! What's this? A place to dine, and open wide,
Twenty-four hours a day, no need to hide.
Cheap too, compared to other feasts,
In Vegas, where excess is the least.

Oh, how the lines may stretch and grow,
But fear not, for they move apace, you know.
A must-visit spot, for hunger's pang,
Or drunken cravings, that won't let go.

So heed my words, fair traveler,
And make haste to this wondrous place,
For it shall soothe thy rumbling belly,
And ease thy wallet's heavy load, by grace."

"Ay, 'twas a joy to work with Eric and his men,
Their diligence and skill did make our garden glen,
A place of beauty, where we do take delight,
In the sweet flowers and trees that doth ignite.

Their plan, so clever, didst please us well,
And their execution, flawless, we must tell,
Save for a tiny glitch, a light that didst not glow,
But swiftly fixed, our worries didst they know.

We cannot praise them enough, so fine,
Their work, a true reflection of their design,
Thus, we do recommend this crew with cheer,
For gardens fair, they shall make it appear."

"Hark, what news is this? A grand opening deal most fair,
On tires, that doth make my heart sing with joy!
Big Rob, a man of great renown, didst serve me well,
With customer service that doth rival the skies.
And lo, they didst offer me water and coffee,
A generous gesture, that doth show their grace.
This place, methinks, is truly blessed,
For it doth possess a spirit of excellence."

"Verily, all the praise thou dost sing, 'tis true, my friend. This wondrous place doth serve the finest victuals, fit for a king! The guacamole-based green salsa, oh how grand, doth steal the show, I do declare. In Austin, Texas, we didst partake of this delectable delight, and by the names "green salsa" or "Salsa Dona" it was known. 'Tis a spicy treat, but fear not, for 'tis worth the trial. Hie thee hence, my friend, and partake of this culinary joy! Alas, the only drawback, a larger venue, to accommodate all, I do pray."

"Medusa, a hairdressing chain of renown,
In Edinburgh's city centre doth have its crown,
Two salons there be, and a third in Musselburgh,
Where beauty services and nails doth take their turn.

The Teviot salon, full of life and cheer,
Doth bustle with activity, and loud doth hear,
Seven hairdressing stations, all with clients filled,
A popular place indeed, my heart doth build.

An appointment quickly gained, my thanks doth give,
A thorough consultation, my stylist doth live,
She listens well, and understands my desire,
Her friendly chat, my nerves doth soon retire.

Shampooed and seated, a hot drink doth arrive,
Real coffee, not instant, my heart doth revive,
A biscuit too, my pleasure doth now increase,
I leave the salon, feeling grand, my soul doth release.

This place, I cannot fault, modern and trendy,
Yet friendly and professional, my praise doth send,
Medusa, a hairdressing chain of great renown,
In Edinburgh's city centre, doth wear its crown."

"Hark, what wondrous feast doth lie before mine eyes! A veritable cornucopia of delights, fit for a king or queen. The spread, so lavish and grand, doth rival those of highest esteem. Each dish, a masterwork of culinary art, doth tantalize mine taste buds and leave me in awe. The presentation, a symphony of colors and arrangement, doth delight mine senses and fill mine heart with joy. I have not found a single item to displease mine palate, nay, each bite doth bring me closer to the heavens. Methinks I shall return anon, to partake in this gastronomic splendor once more."

In fair September, we didst order a cake,
For our son's wedlock, a joyous undertaking.
William, a man of great skill and art,
Didst fashion a confection, a true work of heart.

The cake, a vision to behold,
Was devoured by all, young and old.
Its sweetness and moisture, a delight,
left us in awe, with naught but delight.

And thus, we didst order once more,
For our husband's fiftieth year, in store.
A cake, a symbol of love and cheer,
To celebrate a life, now full and clear.

And lo, the cake didst please once more,
With its raspberry mousse, a flavor galore.
A hit, a true success, a wonder to see,
A cake, fit for a king, or so it seemed to me.

"Hark, what place is this? A temple, nay, a shrine,
Where beasts are slain, and I, a devout worshiper, doth dine.
A cathedral of meat, where I do count my blessings,
And revel in the joy that I, a carnivore, do possess.

Oh, the salad bar, 'tis true, doth boast the finest greens,
But here, my friends, the focus lies upon the meats.
Hot, smoking, marinated flesh, all tantalizing,
Doth tempt my taste buds, and doth leave me quite amazed.

The steak, oh how it doth delight, so juicy, so tender,
With flavors that doth dance upon my palate, and linger.
The burnt, salty end, and pink, medium rare within,
Doth make each bite a joy, and leaves me wanting more, my friend.

But alas, the steak, it doth lose its charm,
As it doth cool upon my plate, and loses its warmth.
But fear not, dear friends, for Texas de Brazil,
Doth have a secret weapon, a scientific approach,
That keeps the meat hot, and the flavors at their peak,
A feast fit for a king, or queen, a true culinary freak.

So if thou art a meat lover, like myself,
Then hasten thee well, and doth give this place a try.
For in this cathedral of meat, thou shalt find thy haven,
And thy taste buds, they shall be in a state of pure delight, my friend."

"Our offspring, two in number, didst inherit
The iPhones of yore, with batteries weak and faint.
These men, their vigor and expertise on display,
Didst replace the batteries in haste, ere break of day.

The cost, a fraction of what Apple doth demand,
A paltry sum, scarce worth a second thought.
Their speed, a marvel, like lightning in the land.
Friendly and courteous, their demeanor, a gem.

I do proclaim, in verse or prose,
This service, top-notch, at a reasonable cost.
For those in need, I say, without a flaw,
Seek out these men, and give them thy trust."

"Hark! A tale of wondrous change, my friends,
Of surgeries elective, by Transformations' skilled hands.
The staff, so kind and fair, didst work with me,
Though I didst dwell in NYC, and they in Wisconsin's land.
The cost, a third of what it wouldst be in the city,
Didst make my journey worthwhile, and my heart full of glee.
The results, my friends, didst bring me joy beyond compare,
And thus, I do recommend this place, without a single care."

"Verily, a most excellent eatery doth reside within yon college halls,
Whose outdoor seats on State Street do provide a merry ambiance,
And victuals, savory and sweet, doth please mine taste buds well.
African cuisine, a new delight, doth tempt me to partake,
And thus, I shall return anon, to sample more of their fare."

"Heinz Field, a place most wondrous and fair,
Where football's finest battles are fought with great flair.
The site lines, a marvel, a joy to behold,
And the history within, a tale to be told.

The Great Hall, a chamber of fame,
Where trophies of old, and heroes' names,
Are displayed with pride, and rightly so,
For this is a place where legends grow.

And, oh! The food, a culinary delight,
Primanti Bros., a taste, a true delight.
Tailgating, a ritual, a time to share,
A tradition, that's, beyond compare.

So, come one, come all, to this hallowed ground,
To witness the splendor, to hear the sound,
Of cheering crowds, and gridiron clash,
At Heinz Field, where football's passion is rash."

"Oh, what a feast for mine eyes doth lay before me!
A draught of Kool-Aid, cold as winter's snow,
And chicken, fried to perfection, doth arouse
My hunger, like a rooster doth crow.
Golden waffles, crispy and hot, doth tempt me so,
I cannot wait, my dear, to dine once more,
In this place, where food doth reign supreme, you know."

"Hark, what news is this? My 21st year hath come,
And with it, a celebration most grand.
A hotel, conveniently located, doth beckon,
With clubs and revelry at hand.

Venetian, the name of this fine place,
Doth boast of TAO, a club of great renown,
And Palazzo, its sister, doth embrace,
Lavo, another spot, where one may dance and prance.

The rooms, spacious and comfortable, doth hold,
Six to eight people, with ease, I am told.
Two queen beds, full size, and a couch, doth make,
A restful night, for all, a certain take.

The bathroom, large, with double doors, doth allow,
All the girls, to prepare, without a flaw.
Mirrors, plenty, doth adorn the walls,
Aiding in the process, of making oneself fair.

In conclusion, Venetian, a place of delight,
For clubbing, eating, shopping, and gambling, in sight.
Five stars, I give, for the rain of money, so bright,
A memorable night, indeed, with my dear friends, in sight."

"Ere we arrived, just ere the closing hour,
And I didst fear, that quality might suffer.
But oh, how wrong my doubts didst prove!
The salad, cold and fresh as morning dew,
The garlic knots, a culinary delight,
Didst bring me another round, I didst beseech!
And pizza, excellence itself didst manifest.
From henceforth, here shall be our pizza haven."

"In urgent need of lodging, we didst call upon each inn and hostelry, yet all were full, their halls and chambers occupied till morn. Our plight didst seem most dire, our hopes didst dwindle, till fortune didst smile upon us at this humble abode. They didst proffer us a chamber ere noon, a boon most welcome, and bade us partake of breakfast, a meager feast, yet one most grateful. And as we waited, they didst allow us liberty to roam their grounds, a pleasant oasis, and didst provide a shuttle, conveyance most convenient, to bear us to the Strip, that famed and vaunted thoroughfare. The rooms, though modest, were clean and well-appointed, with couches that didst convert to beds, a clever device. And all this, dear friends, at a price most reasonable, a sum most fair and just. So if thou seekest rest and peace, a respite from the din and tumult of the city, then seek thee out this haven, a place of solace and of comfort."

"Thou canst comprehend, my friend,  
If thou hast trod the path,  
The finest victuals of the East,  
A feast fit for a king's repast.  
The hospitality doth make thee feel,  
As if thou wert a prince of great wealth,  
The surroundings, prospect, and folk,  
All doth conspire to give thee mirth."

"By my troth, I didst once avow
Buffalo Wild Wings, ne'er knew
Another wingery could compare
Until my love, she didst declare

Wing Stop, a place of wonder
With wings so divine, they plunder
All other eateries of their fame
And leave them with naught but shame

Their flavors, though fewer in number
Do not detract from their great slumber
For in their wings, there lies a charm
That doth surpass all other arms

I have attempted, since my heart
Didst turn to Wing Stop, to part
With BWW, but alas, their wings
Do not compare, they bring

Naught but woe and disappointment
For they cannot match the content
Of Wing Stop, that sweetest place
Where wings do reign in grace."

"Hark, the hype doth swell, my friends, 'Tis a most wondrous sight, this curb so fine. My wife and I, we didst park thereof, And found it to be most divine. I, on the street side, didst take my place, While my wife, on the curb side, didst grace. She didst love it, by the stars above, And I, in agreement, didst nod and glove. For why doth one mess with perfection, sayeth I? Each to their own, I do surmise, And thus, Aaron's doth earn two whiskers high."

"In fair Las Vegas, where revelry doth reign,
A visit to Marcy's brows, a wondrous gain.
For just ten coins, she doth shape and form,
Bringing forth beauty, with nary a storm.

Her touch, so gentle, leaves naught to fear,
And her skills, they do make thy brows appear,
Like a masterpiece, crafted with care,
Fit for a queen, or a maiden fair.

But Marcy's gifts, they do not cease,
For she doth offer more, to increase,
Thy glamour, for Vegas' nights so bright,
With services, that doth make thee shine so light.

Oh, fortunate souls, who doth reside,
In this fair city, where pleasure doth abide,
Visit Marcy oft, and let her work,
Transform thy brows, like a masterful quirk.

The ambiance, clean, comfortable, and bright,
Doth make thee feel, in a home so delight,
The energy, it doth radiate, with cheer,
A place, where thou doth feel, so welcome, my dear."

"Ay, 'tis a place of old, a cantina of yore,
Where Mexican dishes be served, and hearts be bore.
Cramped, it may be, but atmosphere doth abound,
And the victuals, they doth please, beyond compare, profound.

The hot sauce, it doth burn, with flavor so bold,
Chips, they doth flow, like a river, so cold.
Fundito, the gringo, doth delight,
A dish, so fine, it doth ignite, the appetite.

So, heed my words, and hasten thee well,
To this place, where culinary joys doth dwell.
Forsooth, 'twill be crowded, in short order, I reckon,
So, tarry not, and make haste, ere the day be gone."

"Verily, this eatery doth serve the finest sushi in all of Vegas! The Kanji roll, a marvel of culinary skill, doth please mine taste buds beyond compare. Yung, the sushi master, doth prepare each dish with artistry and grace, leaving naught but envy in his wake. Ji, the proprietor, doth ensure each guest doth have a most excellent time, with a keen eye for detail and warm hospitality. The Kanji clan, in sum, doth make one feel most welcome and well tended. In sooth, a superior dining experience, in every aspect!"

"Hark! What woeful souls begrudge these men their due?
Their autos old, their purses thin, they rail and rant.
But I, dear friends, have found their service true,
Their hearts kind, their pricing fair, their skill profound.

My BMW M6, now gone, didst once receive
Their tender care, and at a price most reasonable.
Their brakes, though loud, didst pass inspection, free,
And for their toil, a mere $50 didst I pay.

My Mustang, too, didst benefit from their art,
A mere $330, tax included, didst it cost.
A ride, besides, didst they provide, gratis,
Their kindness, tipped, doth merit praise, no doubt.

So let us laud these men, their work most excellent,
Their customer service, beyond compare, a gem.
For those in need, their aid doth never falter,
German Motors, praise be, a true friend to thee."

"Hark! How fortunate I am to dwell but a stone's throw away from this most excellent eatery, a true gem of Central Phoenix. 'Tis a place most wondrous, where guests from afar may partake in a genuine Phoenix experience, far removed from the mundane fare of chain restaurants. Verily, I have never tasted anything there that did not exceed my expectations. Be it a special occasion, a gathering of friends, or merely a casual repast, any hour of the day doth bring forth delectable victuals. The sweet potato fries, a marvel! And my heart doth sing with joy at the mere mention of the lobster quesadillas - yummm! In sooth, I cannot praise this local treasure enough."

"O, how I love this place! Taro with boba, oh how grand,
Their glazes, a feast for the taste buds, so choose at thy command.
Some snohs, too sweet, a warning, lest thou desire,
To pair them with toppings, less sweet, to quench thy fire.
I've had their boba but once, yet still I do declare,
'Twas fantastic, beyond compare, a true delight, beyond compare.
A group of friends, unfamiliar with the menu, didst say,
"We'll stick with fruit snoh, chocolate toppings, come what may."
Yet still, they loved it, and found it to be grand,
A testament to the quality of this wondrous land.
The workers, friendly and kind, offer samples with glee,
And the atmosphere, artsy and nerdy, doth please me.
Jenga and games, a pleasant pastime, doth abound,
Making this place, a haven, where one can be found."

"Hark, what hospitality doth lie within this place! Our host, Marty, didst extend to us a warm embrace, and with his skilled hand, didst prepare for us a feast most wondrous. The fare, so fine and delicate, didst delight our taste buds, and the ambiance, quaint and charming, didst make our visit all the more enjoyable. Verily, the meatballs, they didst steal the show, their savory flavor and tender texture, a true marvel. We shall return, forsooth, to partake in this culinary splendor once again."

"Thirteen years have we dwelt in this fair valley of the southwest, and for as long have we sought a mechanic, just and true.  At last, our search hath ended, for we have found Phil, a man of wit and wisdom, who doth run his business with a steady hand.  Our carriage, with its faulty brakes, didst shake and rattle with each step, a perilous thing indeed.  But fear not, dear friends, for Phil and his able crew didst complete the task with all due speed and within the bounds of reason.  Aye, there is something to be said for dealing with a humble, family-owned shop, where honesty and fair play are the rule, rather than the exception."

In fair South End, there doth lie a place,
Lark & Key, where art doth take its space.
A second location, new and bright,
Where paintings, jewels, and pottery doth delight.

Duy Huynh and Sandy Snead, the owners true,
Do showcase their works, both old and new.
Acrylic paintings, a sight to behold,
And jewelry, that doth shine like gold.

The staff, friendly and full of cheer,
Do make one feel most welcome, my dear.
I do confess, I do enjoy to stop,
And dream of purchases, beyond my cop.

For though the prices may seem steep,
The quality, a true treasure doth keep.
So fear not, dear reader, to part with thy pence,
For 'tis a investment, worth every penny, in sense.

"A humble abode of commerce, neat and tidy,
Their work, a testament to their industry.
The staff, a beacon of kindness, ensure contentment,
And fortune smiled upon me, for they were not busy.
But lest thou wish to tarry, make haste to call,
For 'tis a small domain, and appointments befall.
I chanced upon this treasure, perusing Yelp,
And grateful am I, that I didst stop and help."

"Verily, this eating house doth please me well. My hunger for a steaming bowl of ramen didst lead me to seek out a place of repute, and fortunate was I to find this cozy nook. The broth, rich with savory flavors, didst delight my taste buds, and the price, most reasonable indeed. I didst partake of the miso ramen, a veritable feast for my senses, with noodles plentiful and long. My spouse, with eager relish, didst devour the pork belly bowl, its flavors true and delectable. A dish of fried rice we didst also share, though middling fair it was. Yet, in conclusion, good cheer and victuals this place doth offer, despite its modest size."

"A hearty breakfast, fit for a king,
With generous portions, and a cook most kind.
Nikki, the chef, doth serve with grace,
And doth ensure each guest doth find their place.
The patrons, friendly, doth converse with ease,
So thou shalt not dine alone, nor feel disease.
The cooking, homely, doth please the taste,
Hot, and fresh, doth make thy hunger haste.
In this compact space, doth all feel dear,
And shouldst thou need, a neighbor doth draw near."

"Morn, my dearest DH and I didst take the chance  
To partake of donuts, at a shop most fair and bright.  
And though we be not connoisseurs of such sweet fare,  
The freshness and taste didst leave us in delight.  
A Bavarian Cream, Snickers, chocolate and raspberry filled,  
We didst sample them all, and found them most fulfilling.  
The staff, so friendly and welcoming, didst make our day,  
And thus, I do recommend this place, shouldst thou seek a sweet way."

"Hark, good sirs and madams, listen well,
For I have tale to tell of service swell.
In need of cards, we sought with haste,
But Fedex's stock was flimsy, not of taste.

So I did call, and Franklin didst say,
They'd deliver by morn, come what may.
Their staff, so kind, so professional,
Didst take the time to hear my quip.

Kerry, Michele, Mike, all were so bright,
Their work, a joy, a wondrous sight.
They charged a fee, but worth the cost,
For they didst deliver, as they had boast.

And lo, the cards, they didst arrive,
In time, in mint, a wondrous jive.
So here's to Franklin, and their crew,
A job well done, a service true."

"Methinks 'twas a wondrous night indeed,
With ale aplenty and victuals most fine.
Their burgers, oh how they doth excel,
A feast for mine eyes and lips so divine.
Fresh as the morning dew, the buns did seem,
And toppings, they did complement the meat most finely.
I shall return anon, forsooth, my friends,
For this tavern, it doth hold a special place within mine heart."

"Aye, working with Rosemary doth bring ease indeed,
With a humble budget of two hundred crowns,
She doth provide flowers of beauty and grace,
For bridal bouquets, maidens, and boutonnieres in their place.
A true professional, I do highly recommend her,
And praise the late hours that doth cater to our needs,
For those who toil in Scottsdale and reside downtown,
'Tis a blessing indeed, and I shall return with pictures profound.
Thanks, good sirs!"

"O, wouldst thou learn the secret of my heart's desire? 'Tis Schwartz, the institution where I'd gladly confine myself, day after day, didst they but allow it! What words can I employ to praise this wondrous place, that hath not already been sung by the multitudes who've tasted its delight? In Montreal, nay, all the eastern realm, there's none that doth compare to Schwartz's smoked meat, so delectable and fine!

The lines, they doth stretch far and wide, come summer and holidays, when folk doth flock to partake in the feast. A word of wisdom, dear friend: go forth in twos or threes, that thou may'st avoid the queue and gain swift entry to the hall of gastronomic joy!

Fatty meat, oh how it doth delight, when ordered thus, it doth unlock the fullest flavor, and with a side of slaw, pickles, and a cherry drink, thy senses shall be transported to a realm of pure bliss! And when within, do not forget to greet thy fellow diners, seated close by, in this cozy, bustling hall.

And ere thou dost depart, do stop next door, to purchase a pound or two, to savor later, at thy leisure, for 'tis a sin to leave without a morsel to enjoy anon! This place, it doth command a visit from each traveler to Montreal, for nowhere else doth smoke meat, as doth Schwartz, in all its splendor!"

"Food trucks doth roam the campus grounds,
But ne'er didst I partake in their fare.
A skeptic, I, of such mobile feasts,
Yet now, do I repent my former care.

A friend and I, betwixt classes, didst stray,
To sample their wares, and pass the day.
The register-man, a kindly soul, didst say,
"Order thus, and thou shalt have no sorrow."

I asked for Greenwich, in salad form,
And waffle fries, with spices to transform.
The avocado dressing, oh how grand,
Didst make the salad, with onions caramelized,
Swiss cheese melted, tomatoes sliced so fine,
And toasted bread, a perfect complement divine.

The fries, with cajun seasoning, a delight,
Didst leave me wanting more, with all my might.
My plan, to save some for another time,
Didst fail, alas, for the food was sublime.
Ten dollars, a fair price, I didst pay,
For a meal most satisfying, come what may.

I shall return, to partake once more,
In their delicious fare, forevermore."

"O, how I do adore this place, where I may feast and revel in delight! 

The hotel, so neat and tidy, doth beckon me to tarry awhile, 
And in its midst, a charming bakery doth sell sweet cupcakes, 
Whiles nearby, Hash House A Go Go doth serve up savory treats. 
Verily, I say, 'twill be a joy to lodge herein, anon."

"Hark! This lodging, with its luxurious appointments and excellent service, hath won my heart and that of my kin. Not a single grievance did we have, so great was our satisfaction. Verily, we shall return anon."

"Verily, my dear friends, thou seekest knowledge of cars and shops?  Look no further, for I, a man of wisdom and experience, shall share my thoughts with thee.  Twice hath my trusty steed been to this place, and both times, the alignment hath been done with great skill and care.  The folk who work there, kind and honest, doth ensure all is well.  I, a man of modest means, doth not possess an alignment machine, and thus, must rely on those who doth.  Fear not, fair reader, for these good people shall not deceive thee, nor take advantage of thy ignorance.  They doth strive to do what is just and right, both for thee and thine automobile."

"Hark, what news is this? A place most wondrous,  
Where coffee flows, and all are amazed.  
A bit steep, the price may seem,  
Yet still, we flock, like birds to the beam.  

My friends, they drank of Carmel's brew,  
And one, of iced coffee, pure and true.  
I, myself, did taste the chocolate's might,  
In triple form, a joyous sight.  

All three, a delight to behold,  
But Carmel's, the favorite, to be told.  
So here, on the west side, we shall stay,  
And make this place, our own, each day."

"Hark! If thou dost enjoy a hearty bruschetta, thou shalt adore this place! 'Tis true, the roasted red pepper doth please mine taste, and the prosciutto, it doth satisfy. In days of yore, this was the gathering spot for mine friends and I, on Wine Wednesdays, for happy hour did we partake. The outdoor seating area, 'twas a merry place, when sun did not beat down too fiercely, and music, live, did they play! Fond memories, I do hold, of this place, so dear!"

"Verily, this eatery doth boast of fare most wondrous and an atmosphere most fair. The proscuitto pizza, a dish divine, didst stir within me a desire most fierce. And the Limoncello, oh how sweet, didst quench my thirst with grace most meet. A place most trendy, indeed, in Phoenix's heart doth lie."

"Verily, a most excellent eatery, this pizzeria doth be! With atmosphere so pleasant, and service so fine, 'Tis a place where one can dine with great joy and glee. The prices, fair and reasonable, do make it a spot For families and friends to gather and partake Of their delectable victuals, both cold and hot. Their pizzas, a true delight, with toppings so fresh And crust, so crispy and flavorful, doth leave One in awe of the chef's skill and art. In conclusion, this pizzeria doth earn an A+ From this humble bard, for its fare and its charm Do make it a place worth visiting, again and again."

"Fuego Bistro, a place most wondrous,
Where food doth please and drinks do flow.
Twice have I visited this fair spot,
And both times, my taste buds did sing and shout.

A mojito, with Pernil Asado, do try,
For it doth pair most excellently, I do swear.
The staff, so friendly, doth greet thee with a smile,
And know their patrons well, by name they do style.

The restaurant, though small, doth hold much charm,
And atmosphere, most cozy and warm.
So, if thou art in search of a meal most fine,
Fuego Bistro, do give it a go, 'twill be divine."

"Hark! Good sir, in search of air filters thou art?
'Tis Joe Filter, a website of ease and grace,
Wherewith thou mayst purchase them online, in haste.
Anon, their site doth lie at Joefilter dot com,
A place of wonder, where thy search doth end.
'Twas simple, inexpensive, a joy to behold,
My filters, they didst arrive, in good time, so bold.
I do beseech thee, give their wares a try,
For thou shalt not be disappointed, ere long, say I."

"By th' stars, good sirs, take heed of this place,
Where Tex-Mex omelets doth reign supreme,
With salsa, guac, chorizo, and sour cream,
'Tis a feast fit for a king, or so it would seem.
Their bread, like thick Texas toast, doth delight,
And potatoes, oh so fluffy and bright.
The price, a steal, a true bargain indeed,
For such a meal, so fresh and of good seed.

The service, swift and friendly, doth abound,
Our server, a gem, with a smile so profound.
The food, it doth arrive with haste,
A true delight, for those who hunger and waste.

A small place, cash only, doth it be,
But worth it, for the culinary spree.
So, gentle folk, take heed of this tale,
And seek out this eatery, without fail."

"Hark, good sir! I prithee, tell me, how doth one reach the city centre from the airport with great haste? Aye, 'tis a secret well-known to the locals, that for a mere \u00a33, thou shalt be whisked away to the heart of the city in naught but 20 minutes, or less, I do declare! 'Tis a marvel, indeed, that this wondrous service doth run every 10 minutes, dropping thee off at the Caledonian and the Sheraton Grand hotel, or, if thou desirest, at the Waverly station. And, lo! It doth also journey to the Zoo, in but 8 minutes' time, a feat most wondrous and grand! In sooth, 'tis an excellent, timely service, with friendly, efficient folk, all for the low, low price of \u00a33, each way, I do avow! Huzzah!"

"A treasure trove of sushi, hidden from view,
In a strip mall, where Dysart and McDowell do meet.
A gem, indeed, that doth shine so bright,
With sushi, that doth rival all in sight.

Their sashimi, fresh as morning dew,
And drinks, that doth flow like a river anew.
Their rolls, a multitude, to choose from,
Like the ninja jalapeno, a dish most succulent.

Double Double, Cactus, and more,
All dishes, that doth make our taste buds explore.
This place, a secret, no longer,
For all who seek, the best sushi, to savor."

"Verily, 'tis a wondrous place indeed,
Where one may find such culinary delight,
That doth surpass all else in its stead.

Oh, how I doth extol its virtues fair,
And praise the cooks who doth prepare
Such feasts that doth astound and amaze!

But alas, 'tis only open brief,
A few short hours each passing week,
So heed my words, dear friend, and seek
To align thy schedule with their own,
That thou mayst partake of their delights,
And savor each morsel with joy and relish."

"Hark! What fortune doth bestow upon mine eyes!
A place of wonder, where cleanliness doth reign.
No waiting did I endure, a rarity indeed,
For in I walked, and straightaway was attended.
The maiden who did tend to mine feet,
A perfectionist, her skills didst gleam.
I shall return, to have mine hands adorned,
For this establishment, doth earn my cream."

Hark! What news is this? A new Indian eatery,
Marigold Maison, doth please mine eyes and taste.
In Phoenix, 'tis a gem most rare and fair,
A culinary delight beyond compare.

Their seared eggplant, oh so tender and sweet,
Didst dance upon mine tongue with flavors meet.
Spicy naan, a marvel of a bread,
Didst complement the shrimp, so fresh and red.

Tandoori Shrimp, a dish most wondrous and grand,
With prawns of size most generous and bland.
A curry dish, a symphony of spice and flair,
Didst leave me in awe and wonder there.

A bottle of white Bordeaux, a wine most fine,
Didst pair with dinner, a match divine.
I shall return, and soon, to savor more,
For Marigold Maison, my heart doth adore.

"By Jove, fair readers, hear my tale of woe,
A humble tavern, where my love did grow.
The neighborhood, unremarkable, I confess,
Yet, in this place, my heart found happiness.

The decor, not grand, nor sumptuous, I swear,
But 'twas there, my love, I first did hear.
The crowd, a motley mix, I must avow,
Yet, in their company, my heart did glow.

The drinks, affordable, bartenders kind,
A haven, where my love, did take its mind.
You may smoke within, a rarity, I find,
And, lo, the jukebox, doth play its part, in time.

A Spy On Vegas event, did bring us hither,
Where, fate, didst play its gentle, guiding hand, in yonder.
My husband, met, in this, our humble nest,
Our love, did bloom, in this, our quiet, little band.

So, gentle friends, if seek thou, a low-key place,
To sip, relax, and let thy cares, fade away, in space,
Come, join us, in this, our modest, little dive,
For, in its walls, dost lie, a love, most true, and rife."

"Methinks 'tis a wondrous place to dwell,
Wherein I did move in April of fourteen,
And since then, 'tis a pleasure to tell,
That all is well, and naught but neat.
The night security doth keep the peace,
And not a scrap of trash doth lie in sight,
The dog-friendly folk and diverse throng,
Do make this place a joyous, quiet delight.
The pool, too, doth shine with sparkling light,
In this fair home, wherein I do take flight."

"Verily, 'tis a truth most certain, this doughnut shoppe in Las Vegas, the finest of its kind, doth reign supreme. The people have spoken, and their voices do proclaim it thus. And, in sooth, I must concur, for the doughnuts they do serve, are indeed most delectable and divine.

At dawn's early hour, I chanced upon this sweet emporium, and lo, the selection was sparse, yet still, the treats they had, did please mine eyes and taste. A apple-filled roll, similar to a Cannelloni, didst I partake, and oh, the joy it did bring! The crunchy, sugary crust, didst complement the cinnamon-flavored apple filling, in such a wondrous way, that I didst declare, this doughnut, a true marvel.

And, alack, my camera, didst fail me, ere I couldst capture the splendor of these glazed raisin doughnuts, yet, fear not, dear reader, for thou needst not mine images, to be convinced of this shoppe's excellence. 'Tis a truth, most certain, this doughnut shoppe, doth stand alone, in all of Las Vegas, a true gem, a treasure trove, of sweet delights."

"Hark, good sir! I say to thee, this place doth serve
Excellent fare, fit for a king, or so it seemeth to me.
Twice have I graced its halls with my presence, and twice
Have I been pleased with the victuals and the service, by my troth.
If thou art one who canst set aside thy dietary constraints,
Then do thou partake in the feast, and revel in its delight.
Forsooth, 'tis a veritable haven for gastronomic indulgence,
And thou shalt not be disappointed, an it please thee to dine."

"Thou, Thomas, with thy wondrous device, didst cleanse our carpets with a finesse none other hath been able to match. Thou didst take the time to enter our abode, shift furniture, and ensure all was restored to its proper place. Thy demeanor, professional; thy fees, most reasonable. We doth heartily endorse thee."

"O Cornish Pasty Co, how dearly I do wish
To partake of thy savory delights each day!
Thy classic pasties, steeped in tradition's ways,
Do please my palate with their hearty grace.
And, oh, the Royale with cheese doth tempt me sore,
With its rich flavors and textures that do explore
My taste buds' every nook and cranny. Nor doth
The Chicken Tikka Masala one fail to allure,
Its spices and herbs a true delight doth bring.
In sooth, I say, thy pasties be a wondrous thing!"

"O, wondrous staff! Swift and prompt, they be,
No waiting, nor rudeness doth thou see.
In Tempe, a chill Mesa location, 'tis found,
A haven for good food, and night most profound.

Go, seekers of culinary delight,
And revel in the peaceful, clean sight."

"Hark! A ride most swift and sure didst thou provide,
From airport's gate to destination's side.
A tight schedule didst I have to keep,
Yet thou didst deliver me in timely sleep.

Thy chariot, clean and new, didst take me in,
And with a gentle touch, didst ease my fear within.
The driver, skilled and courteous, didst attend,
To every need, and made my journey wend.

On time, we didst arrive, no moment lost,
And for this service, my heart doth boast.
Highly do I recommend thee, good sir,
For thy ride, a true delight, and worth the hire."

"Verily, this eatery doth please mine taste buds! Many visits have I made hither, and each time, all dishes do delight. Pad Thai, a feast fit for a king, doth reign supreme. Beef pho, with garlic's sweet embrace, doth dance upon mine tongue. Panang chicken, a midday meal most fine, doth satisfy my hunger's call. Spicy, thou art? Fear not, good sirs, for they do heed thy request. A three, I say, doth suffice. A treasure trove, this place, though somewhat far, doth merit the journey."

"Joel Franco, a man of wit and worth,
Whose creative mind doth know no earthly bounds,
A true rainmaker, with a vision most clear,
He doth bring calm to stress and anxious fears.

With him, collaboration is a joyous thing,
A unity of spirit, where all may sing,
A safe space for creativity to flourish and grow,
Where risks are taken, and great art doth flow.

I do confess, I eagerly await,
To work on projects with this man of fate,
For he doth possess a special gift from above,
And his success, I do most confidently love.

In short, my praise for Joel Franco doth know no end,
For he doth stand among the best of men,
A shining star, that doth forever ascend,
A true creative force, that doth never descend."

"Hark! What wondrous delights doth lie within this place,
A feast for taste buds, and a sight most fair.
The fabled smoke meat, so tender and so sweet,
At prices that doth make thy purse sing with delight.
And service, oh! So swift and full of grace,
That thou shalt feel like royalty in this place.
In Montreal, my friend, this be the spot,
To savor flavors that doth rival the gods' own pot.
So heed my words, and make haste to dine,
At Schwartz's, where culinary dreams doth combine."

"Verily, this place doth offer luxury most true,
With drinks creative and servers attentive too.
Amidst the desert's chill, thou sitt'st in comfort's embrace,
In plush couches and chairs, with naught but space.
A table, far from others, doth provide privacy,
And thus, thy night in Vegas doth become most merry.
The waterfall, in splendor doth spout forth,
Every thirty minutes, a show doth bring mirth."

"Hark! For six long years, I've been a patron of this place,
Where honesty and sincerity doth grace each face.
No matter the sum, be it a hundred or ten thousand,
Their service doth remain constant, never waning.
And, by the way, they do pay well for gold,
A true delight for those who doth possess it, I am told."

In days of yore, when hotels were new,
This one did stand out, fair and true.
My love and I, we booked a suite,
At price most reasonable, we did greet.
And thus, our stay did prove to be,
Most wondrous, filled with glee.

"Hark, good sir! Forsooth, this feast doth please,
A veritable cornucopia, if thou wilt.
In Vegas, 'tis the best, by far, they say,
For weekend dinner, a mere $35 doth pay.

Snow crab and king crab, both pre-cracked,
Doth grace the table, with nary a lack.
Red meat, aplenty, doth make its mark,
Kalbi-marinated ostrich, prime rib, quail, pork loin, in the dark.

And save some room, fair sir, for sweet delight,
Mini-sized desserts, a joyous, sugary sight.
Arrive betwixt five and six, ere the queue doth grow,
And enjoy this spread, fit for a king, I do avow."

"Verily, I say unto thee, this shop doth boast the finest customer service I have e'er laid eyes upon! In this field, I have toiled for many a year, and thus, I do comprehend the virtues of hospitality and people skills. But lo, these gentlefolk, they possess it in abundance, as if 'twere innate! They treat each guest with such warmth and familiarity, as if they were kin. Forsooth, their honesty and forthrightness doth shine like the sun! They conduct their business with utmost care and precision, teaching me much about the wondrous creatures that doth inhabit the reef tanks. My queries, they didst answer with patience and grace, ne'er once making me feel a nuisance. And when I sought a particular fish or coral, they didst spare no effort to obtain it for me, at a most reasonable price, I might add! In truth, I cannot praise them enough; they doth deserve even more stars than I can give! I shall return anon, for further purchases, and I doth implore thee, good reader, to do the same!"

"Hark, fair maiden, how my heart doth yearn
For thee, O Chinese food of finest sort.
In Maricopa, alas, such cuisine is scant,
And so, I journey forth, my hunger to assuage.

This humble abode, though plain in sight,
Doth boast a culinary delight.
Fresh, fragrant dishes, made with skill and care,
Do satisfy my craving, beyond compare.

Oh, wouldst thou, kind proprietor, consider
Opening a new branch in Maricopa's center?
For there, thy delicious fare wouldst find
A grateful audience, and a profitable bind."

"Our twins, they doth delight in visits to Dr. LePore,
Whose kindness and care doth make their hearts sing.
He doth possess a special gift, a charm,
That doth put our sons at ease, and doth dispel their alarm.
Even my eldest, who doth shy away from strangers,
Doth find solace in the doctor's gentle manner.
And when in need of prescriptions, he doth aid,
A true friend indeed, in times of medical dismay.
Dr. LePore, thou art a marvel, a true gem,
A shining star that doth light the path to health and serenity."

"A chamber most fair, with service of the finest sort! A bed, so soft and inviting, that sleep did come to me with ease. Their shampoo, a potion of delight, Shanghai Tang, doth fill my senses with sweetness. In this haven, I found peace from the madness of the Strip, a tranquil respite, indeed. I shall return, forsooth, to this place of rest."

"Hubbard, we dote upon thee! Our eldest son, a lad of seven winters, hath attended thy hallowed halls since he was but two summers old. And our younger brood, a pair of cherubs aged five and two-and-a-half, hath likewise graced thy doors since they were but six moons old. Thy tutors, ever warm and welcoming, have guided them with skill and care. Their rates and rules, most fair and reasonable, have eased our minds and lightened our purses. But most of all, their gentle handling of our son with Autism hath won our hearts. Our kin, in gratitude, doth thank thee, Hubbard, for teaching our young ones the ways of the watery deep."

"Fair fare and fine service didst greet mine eyes,
Mushroom bisque, scallops, panna cotta, a feast divine.
Three paragraphs more, I pray thee, let them be naught,
For my belly's full, and my taste buds have been caught."

"If thou art to visit but a single antiquarian bookshop in all of Edinburgh, let it be Old Town Bookshop, my friend. 'Tis a charming, wee storehouse of wonders, nestled upon one of the fairest streets of the city. There, thou shalt find a dazzling array of tomes, spanning the years from 1850 henceforth. Scottish history, architecture, and topography, alongside rare editions of the classics, such as Shakespeare, Dickens, and Burns, doth fill the shelves. And, as the proprietor is a painter, thou mayst also discover lovely prints, lithographs, etchings, paintings, and maps of Edinburgh and the surrounding lands, priced betwixt \u00a330 and \u00a3300, depending on the age, quality, and rarity of the piece."

"Hark! The proprietor didst greet us with a smile so bright,
And bid us sit and dine with all due haste.
Our orders placed, she didst invite my daughter fair
To play with hers, when done with her repast.

Our victuals came apace, and oh! So fresh and sweet,
I didst request more jalapenos, but she didst present
Chopped Thai chilis, homegrown and of finest quality,
A substitution most wondrous and fair, indeed!
Forsooth, most establishments fail to provide
The fiery zest that doth my taste require,
But this place, verily, doth excel and satisfy.
I shall return, forsooth, anon."

"A Groupon didst I purchase, forsooth,
This place doth lie not far from mine own roof.
With husband and two-year-old in tow,
Didst venture in for a meal most fine, I didst vow.

Their hospitality didst know no bounds,
For they didst cater to my youngest with glee.
Kiddie cups, crayons, and coloring books galore,
Didst make our visit a joyous one, indeed, and more.

The staff didst treat my little lad with grace,
In a sports bar/grill, a rare sight, I didst find.
My husband didst enjoy the prime rib wrap,
He thought it was amazing, a feast for his lips to snap.

I didst have the Spaghetti Amatriciana,
A dish most delectable, a true culinary gem.
More food than I couldst eat, 'twas a wondrous sight,
Leaving me full and content, with naught but delight.

And lo, a kid's menu didst they have,
For my little one, a feast most fair and brave.
Chicken strips and fries didst he devour with glee,
A happy child, a joy to behold, forsooth, didst see.

We shall return, anon, I do declare,
For this place hath won our hearts, beyond compare."

"Hark, good sir or madam, dost thou seek  
A skiing trip, with ease and convenience?  
Look no further than the Alpine Ski Club,  
In Phoenix, where thy troubles shall dissolve.  
They package all, from transport to lifts,  
And hotels too, at a most reasonable rate.  
With rental discounts and a helpful guide,  
Thy trip shall be a most enjoyable jaunt.  
Their mission, plain, is fun and affordability,  
For families, couples, singles, all humanity.  
The staff, well-versed, doth run the show,  
With trips each season, for all to know.  
From Sunrise, quick, to Durango, far,  
They cater to all tastes, near and afar.  
At times, themed, for added merriment,  
So, give them a chance, and thy wallet's content.  
For solo travel, or with friends, 'tis true,  
The Alpine Ski Club shall make it anew."

"Afternoon delight, Tonto's charm doth lie,
In prickly pear margaritas, twain,
With Three Sisters Salsa, guacamole by thy side,
Dessert, a treat, doth change with each passing tide.

Youngest of all, we doth frequent this place,
Friday eves, or nights, our time doth grace,
Burgers, sweet potato tots, my heart doth cheer,
Margaritas strong, not weak, my spirit doth clear.

Two margaritas, my joy doth reach its peak,
Birthday blessings, chocolates, handmade, unique,
Follow Tonto on Facebook, new dishes doth appear,
Plans changed, based on photos, our hearts doth cheer."

"Hark, what news is this? Our high school reunion,
In Vegas, didst take place, and on the final eve,
We chanced upon an izakaya, run by one
From Okinawa, our native land. My role,
The designated driver, kept me from imbibing,
But as a group, we feasted, drank, and made merry,
The bill, a mere $20 per head, a sum quite fair.
We lingered long, past closing time, and still,
The proprietor, with kindness, offered us
A large bottle of Orion, a beverage most fine.
Tis love, indeed, that binds us all in unity."

"Methinks 'twas a feast most wondrous and fair,
With meats, cheeses, olives, and sausage so rare,
And pizza, hot from the oven, did delight,
With gelattos, homemade, a sweet, sweet sight.

The wine list, a marvel, with vintages so fine,
The staff, knowledgeable, and helpfull, divine,
The patio, a place to behold, with performers so bright,
A place to sit, and drink, and revel in delight.

Verily, we did enjoy, this place so fair,
And shall return, to doth savor, its delights once more there."

"Indeed, 'tis true, my friend, thou dost receive  
What thou dost pay for, and here, 'tis quite a sum.  
A suite, with three TVs, a mini bar, and space  
To stretch and relax, cleanliness, and a smile  
From friendly staff, doth make thy stay most pleasant.  
But, alas, the pool, that sparkling gem, doth lack  
The warmth of sunshine, and thus, doth leave me cold."

"Verily, the finest cinema in all of Las Vegas doth lie within this hallowed hall. Prices for victuals and drinks doth be as expected, yet the humble popcorn doth shine with a most wondrous butter topping. The screens doth loom large, and seats doth stretch forth in grandiose comfort, reclining near fully, a true marvel of engineering. Alas, the cost of admission doth be somewhat steep, yet for a film most dear, 'tis worth the splurge."

"Hark, what news is this? A sweet delight,
A creamy treat that doth excite.
In my own neighborhood, a shop doth rise,
With frozen treats that doth surprise.

Their ice cream, oh so smooth and fine,
Doth rival any of its kind.
And lo, they have a cronut too,
A double treat for me and you.

Methinks 'tis a family owned place,
With love and care in every trace.
Their joy doth shine in every scoop,
And in their service, a gentle loop.

So let us raise a cone, and cheer,
For this new shop, so pure and clear.
May it bring joy to all who doth visit,
And happiness, like a sweet mist."

"A marvelous spectacle, full of delight,
With actors most skilled and a tale so bright.
Their price, most fair, doth make it a treat,
In comparison to other shows so neat.
Thou shalt not repent, nor feel mislaid,
For this play shall bring joy, mirth and aid."

"Hark! A new CFA doth grace the Arcadia scene,
With cramped confines, yet cleverly designed,
The entrance, solely on 44th street doth lie,
To ease the flow of patrons, passing by.

Their fare, a delectable spread, doth please,
Chicken, saucy, savory, doth delight,
And service, with a smile, doth never cease,
A true delight, for all to revel in."

"A haven for imbibers, this tavern doth boast  
Some one hundred fifty brews of finest sort,  
Together with quizzes of wit and wisdom,  
For those who delight in knowledge and sport.  
A motley crew, indeed, doth congregate here,  
From ale aficionados to rowdy youth,  
Yet all do find a welcome, and cheer,  
In this, a true drinker's paradise, of truth.  
The staff, well-versed in draughts and dram,  
Doth guide patrons through their liquid quest,  
And happy hours, diverse, doth grace each eve,  
Save Tuesday, when trivia doth reign supreme.  
This place, my friends, doth merit highest praise,  
For those who seek a refuge from the fray,  
Of sports fans, that is, and their loud displays,  
Seek ye instead, this haven of peace, my way."

"Methinks 'tis my most cherished round of golf within the vale,
No frills, nor costly, yet the play doth please me well,
The vistas fair, the staff most kind, a men's club of renown,
Yet fear doth grip my heart, for ASU doth seek to take hold,
And thus, the tee times shall be scarce, alack,
I do beseech thee, ASU, to let Karsten be,
And suffer not this course to fall beneath thy sway."

"Hark, my friend, what news is this? A place called BlueMoon, where we may find solace in the culinary arts? Pray, let us hasten to this venue, and partake in the feast that doth await us.

Upon our arrival, our eyes didst behold a sight most wondrous. The establishment, though small, didst radiate an air of cleanliness and warmth. The staff, with smiles upon their faces, didst greet us with a friendly demeanor.

My heart, it didst yearn for spring rolls, and thus, I didst order two. One filled with shrimp and pork, the other, BBQ pork. Oh, how delightful they didst taste! Fresh, and full of flavor, they didst leave me in a state of gastronomic bliss.

And then, the main course, a noodle soup, didst arrive. Rare steak, flank, brisket, tendon, and tripe, all combined in a savory broth, didst fill my belly with joy.

Verily, there be many other dishes on the menu, which doth tempt me to return again and again. The service, it didst excel, and the price, it didst remain within the realm of modesty.

In conclusion, my dear friend, BlueMoon, it doth shine bright, a beacon of hope for those who seek a culinary experience most divine."

"Hark, what wondrous delight doth mine eyes perceive?
A feast most fair, a curry of golden hue,
That doth arouse my taste buds with joy anew.
I pray, kind sir, how doth thy kitchen brew
Such savory delights that doth evoke the West?
For in fair Los Angeles, I didst quest
Forthright, in search of sustenance most fine,
And lo, upon mine first attempt, I find
This haven of gastronomic bliss divine.
Thy Thai cuisine, a true delight, doth shine."

"Ay, what a wondrous feast did mine eyes behold,
In this fair restaurant, where I did dine so bold.
The waiters, swift and kind, did tend to mine needs,
With grace and wit, they did my hunger feed.

The food, though costly, did my taste buds delight,
My Grilled Shrimp Salad, a culinary sight.
But lo, the dessert, a Coconut Cake so fine,
Did steal the show, and left me in awe divine.

Dense, moist, and sweet, the cake did please my soul,
The frosting, rich and creamy, did my senses control.
A perfect meal, indeed, did I partake,
And thus, I say, this place, a true gem doth make.

So, gentle friends, take heed of mine advice,
And come, enjoy this eatery, full of nice.
With time to spare, visit the museum near,
And make of it a day, most bright and clear."

"Hark, what news is this? A carpet cleaner, Patrick by name, hath graced our humble abode with his presence and skill. He, with careful hand and watchful eye, didst place protective guards in every nook and cranny, lest any harm befall our belongings. And lo, the once-stained and matted carpet, now doth shine like the sun on a clear day! His work, swift and thorough, left us in awe, and our allergies, they didst not stir. Aye, 'tis a blessing indeed to have found such a skilled and eco-friendly cleaner, one we shall recommend to all we hold dear."

"Hark, what news is this? A pizza place of renown,
Where lunch doth come at a most reasonable cost.
The victuals, they do taste of sweet delight,
And service, it doth match the finest of hosts.

Verily, I say, this pizza place doth reign,
A gem within the city's culinary domain.
So, gather round, good friends, and heed my word,
For here, thy taste buds shall be well-rewarded."

"In fair Las Vegas, where dining options abound,
The Burger Bar doth stand out from the crowd.
Amidst the city's glitz and glamour, 'tis a gem,
Serving up burgers of highest quality, a true delight.

My spouse, a connoisseur of all things green,
Didst savor the veggie burger, deemed it most serene.
Whilst I, a lover of seafood, didst indulge
In the salmon burger, paired with a rich veal-shallot sauce, most sumptuous.

The staff, friendly and knowledgeable, doth aid
In choosing from the vast menu, a true bonanza.
So ask their counsel, and heed their every word,
For they know the secrets of the kitchen, and will not be misunderstood.

With prices fair and options galore,
'Tis a sin to leave unsatisfied, a true bore.
So eat at the Burger Bar, and revel in its delight,
For 'tis a culinary experience, worth thy while, a true sight."

"Most excellent service, I do declare! The staff, so friendly and kind, didst strive to make us feel at ease. My husband, in particular, didst enjoy the massage so much that we didst return the next day for yet another 90 minutes of blissful indulgence. Verily, he is now quite spoiled!"

"Marry, what a feast doth lay before mine eyes!
Catfish, boudin balls, shrimp \u00e9touff\u00e9e, all delectable.
Never have I savored Cajun cuisine, I must confess,
But now, I swear, I shall return, to partake of this delightful mess."

"O, what a wondrous sight doth meet mine eyes,
A feast most sumptuous, fit for kings and queens.
The caterer, Lena's Flowers and Catering, doth excel,
In providing victuals that doth please and tantalize.

A tasting, we didst partake, and oh, what joy,
To sample all the dishes, savory and sweet.
The prime rib, pork tenderloin, they doth delight,
And mashed potatoes, sun-dried tomato, garlic, oh so fine.

The flowers, too, doth impress, in form and hue,
A bouquet, most fair, for me and mine attendants, too.
They doth listen well, to mine ideas, and doth suggest,
Flowers most fitting, for the occasion, in their splendor.

A pleasure, it was, to work with such a vendor,
Again, in future, I wouldst not hesitate, to call upon them."

"Upon mine eyes, a new sight didst appear,
A tavern small, yet warm and full of cheer.
With darts and screens, both high and low,
And seats at bar, where one may freely flow.
In center's heart, 'twas hidden from view,
But found we did, with patience and pursue.

Their ale, a plenty, didst they have in store,
Twenty taps, and bottles, more and more.
A feast for taste, their selection grand,
We savored each, with joyous hand.

Pretzels hot, salsa smoky and spicy,
Chicken Thai, and muffuletta, oh so nice-y.
The crowd, it swelled, upon a Thursday eve,
Yet service swift, our wants didst retrieve."

"Hark! What wondrous feast hath mine eyes beheld?
A Pig, Pork, Cow burger, most delectable and fine.
'Twas Ivan, that jovial host, who did prepare
This culinary delight, with skill and care.
And, oh! The Bloody Mary he didst mix,
With flavors bold and subtle, a true fix.
Methinks 'twas a meal most fantastic, indeed,
And Ivan, a man of great hospitality and speed."

"Michele V, my stylist, didst work her magic on my tresses,
And turned them from dull and lackluster to full of life and vigor.
She cut my locks with skill and speed,
And left me looking grand, indeed.
I highly recommend her services,
For she doth possess the touch of a true artist."

"A compressor of old, a Chrysler of yore,
On my air conditioner, did fail once more.
Mark came in eventide, with haste he did repair,
And found the part deceased, beyond all hope or care.
He tested well, each wire, cap and ground,
Whilst others merely glanced, with nary a sound.
He gave a quote, most fair and reasonable,
For his labors, in writing, most legible.
In the end, another's services I did employ,
Due to a bond of trust, though costing more, alas, the joy.
But Mark, I would hire, and recommend to all,
For his skill and diligence, standing tall."

"By my troth, how doth this place not boast a full five stars? Methinks 'tis due to mine own fondness for humble taverns and fine ale, which others may not share. 

Upon a second visit, with my dearest companion, we didst enjoy a most excellent eve. Though we didst not partake of victuals, all dishes didst appear most delectable. The selection of beers didst rival any other, and prices were most reasonable. Moreover, the jukebox didst play a fine tune, and many televisions didst broadcast various sports, to our great delight. The ambiance didst strike a perfect balance, betwixt lively and tranquil, and the staff didst attend to us with diligence, yet not oppressively so. 

Verily, I shall return oft to this most agreeable establishment!"

"Oh, how I do adore this salad most fair,
With shrimp and dressing that doth please my taste.
I'll cross the town, a journey quite long,
Just to partake of this delicious feast.

Their Shrimp Caesar Salad, a dish divine,
Hath captured my heart, and doth make me swoon.
The cilantro dressing, a sauce most fine,
Doth complement the shrimp, a spicy boon.

And though the noodles be crispy and light,
They doth complete this culinary delight.
My daughter, she doth love their pizza too,
A treat most fair, and affordable as well.

The decor, a bit kitschy, mayhap so,
But I do not mind, for my focus doth go
To the salad, oh so fresh and green,
A true delight, fit for a queen.

They doth ask me if I wish my tea,
To be packed up, for my journey home to be.
A small gesture, yet it doth show their care,
For their customers, they doth truly spare.

So here I shall return, again and again,
For this salad, it doth my heart maintain."

"A year hath passed, my friends, since first we did employ
JNS Final Touch, and by the stars, they doth not disappoint.
Their service, consistent still, doth please us well,
Nor have we e'er encountered any issue great or small.
Their owner, a man of worth, doth communicate with grace,
And honesty doth shine within his every word and deed.
In our home, they doth possess a special place,
For trust and professionalism doth they abundantly yield.
Thus, highly do I recommend this company, my friends,
For they doth merit praise and shall forever be our guide."

"Hark! This place doth please mine eyes and taste,
A true gem found on Yelp, a wondrous feast!
My love and I didst enter, and at first,
Didst feel a bit uneasy, being the only guests.
But fear not, for the fare didst soon dispel
All doubts, with dishes most delicious and swell!
Yellow tail nigiri, gyoza, shrimp tempura roll,
Salmon and tuna in rice paper, California roll,
With fresh tuna on top, a treat for the tongue,
And cucumber salad, a gift from the kitchen, young!
The gyoza, eight in number, a generous share,
And nigiri, fresh and tasty, beyond compare.
The rolls, oh how they delighted,
With fish so fresh, and portions so just right!
We ordered too much, but could not resist,
The mochi ice cream, a sweet and pleasant surprise.
The service, excellent, with warmth and grace,
A true welcome, in this place of culinary embrace.
Harumi Sushi, a name to remember,
For a dining experience, most endearing and tender."

"A pizza, hot from the oven, doth please me well,
With melted cheese and toppings of mine own choice.
The quality doth never falter, nor doth the taste,
And e'en the sweetest of pizzas doth bring me joy.
Marry, 'tis a treat most wondrous and fair,
This pizza of which I do speak so fondly.
Forsooth, I shall enjoy it till my dying day,
And ne'er tire of its savory delight."

"Verily, a wondrous time didst I have upon yon patio!  Excellent serviceth didst Garrick provide, a true connoisseur of fine ale and its pairing.  Delicious victuals didst we devour, amidst an atmosphere most convivial.  And, by the stars, what wondrous brews didst they serve!  'Tis now my favored haunt for merrymaking and good cheer!"

In fair Montreal, there lies a place,
Most wondrous, full of charm and grace.
Atmosphere, non-chalant, chic and bright,
Even late on Thursday night.

The staff, most courteous, kind and wise,
With menu and wine list, a delightful surprise.
Planche de charcuteries, pave de saumon,
Bonbons de foie gras, cassolette de champignons,
A feast for senses, a true delight.

A culture gem, this place doth shine,
Alexandre Gosselin, chef, doth compete divine.
Gold Medal Plates, his skills doth show,
Good luck, dear chef, may fortune be thy guide, I pray.

"Hark! What joy doth fill mine heart, my dearest spouse and I,
In this place we didst find most wondrous things,
Furniture for our twain boys, Marshall and Mathew,
The salesfolk, kind and knowledgeable, didst bring us wings.

We do adore the small merchant, and their wares so fine,
And thus, our patronage doth here incline,
For service personal, and with care, they doth attend,
To all who seek, like us, to make amends.

So, gentle friends, take heed of this our tale,
And seek this shop, where thou shalt not fail,
For in their care, thy needs shall be met,
As ours were, with most happy result."

"Four Peaks, a place I seldom visit, yet one that holds such delight. Their brews, oh how renowned they be! But, alas, their victuals, too, are worthy of praise. Last eve, I partook of their delectable apps, and each one was a feast for mine taste buds. The spinach artichoke, in sooth, was the most excellent I have ever had. 'Twas chunky, yet creamy, a true marvel of culinary skill. And the baked pretzel, oh, how I do adore it!
